EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were closed near Sanger due to high water.
I-27 was flooded and subsequently closed due to a rapid rise of water.
Water was over Northwest Highway at Hillcrest and Northwest Highway and Denton.
Water was over Highway 75 at Parkview.
Flooding resulted in high water rescues and major damage to one street in Harker Heights.
A bridge on County Road 720 was submerged near Little Elm.
A bridge on County Road 720 was submerged near Little Elm.
Street flooding was reported north of Farm Market 1709.
Flooding from the remnants of T.S. Allison.  Damage included in previous report.
Flooding from the remnants of T.S. Allison.  Damage included in previous report.

The northern portion of the county received between five and ten inches of rain in several hours.  Portions of Farm-to-Market Road 596 and several other secondary roads were flooded.  The engine of a center pivot irrigation system remained underwater for at least five days.
Four to six inches of rain resulted in several secondary roads across the southern portion of the county to be flooded.
Many roads in the eastern portion of the county were flooded.  A few roads had two to three feet of water covering them in places.
Portions of Highway 207 were reported flooded south of Silverton.
Portions of Highway 256 were reported flooded.
A very slow moving thunderstorm produced excessive runoff that flooded several roads north and northwest of Morton including Farm-to-Market Road 596.

A very slow moving thunderstorm dumped three to five inches of rain over the southern portion of the county in less than two hours.  Several secondary roads were flooded in and around Maple, Enochs, and Bula.
Several sections of Highway 168 were reported flooded.
Several roads throughout the county were reported flooded including Highway 54 west of Littlefield, Highway 70 west of Earth and several secondary roads in the southwest portion of the county.
Farm-to-Market Road 145 and Farm-to-Market Road 2301 were reported flooded in the southeastern portion of the county.
Highway 70 northwest of Floydada was flooded in several places.
Several secondary roads in the eastern portion of the county were reported flooded including Highway 86.
Several secondary roads in the western portion of the county were reported flooded including Highway 207.
Highway 84 was reported flooded in town.
Numerous roads throughout the county were reported flooded.
Highway 385 south of town was flooded.
A high water rescue was required at the 1000 block of Trinity Blvd.
The Hidalgo County Sheriff's Department reported that portions of U.S. Highway 83 near McAllen were under water.   Widespread flooding was also reported in the town of Pharr.
Widespread street flooding was reported around Harlingen by an off-duty NWS forecaster.  The most significant flooding was occurring along portions of U.S. Highway 77 and associated access roads.

Very heavy rainfall that fell in a short period of time from a high-precipitation supercell caused flash flooding that was up to 300 yards wide and five feet deep in some places in town.  The NWS cooperative observer for Paducah measured over three inches of rain from the storm but given the limitations of the instruments in high wind situations, that was likely an underestimate of the actual rainfall.  Several cars were stranded in high water and a few homes had water up to six inches deep in them.

Rainfall redeveloped on the morning of the 15th over the Edward Plateau and western Hill Country.  In addition to the accumulations on the evening of the 14th, general 3 to 4 inch totals fell across Edwards County, bringing total amounts since the 14th to as much as 10 to 12 inches southeast of Rocksprings.  Maximum amounts of up to 18 inches were reported near Barksdale in the southeast part of the county along the Real County line. A 22-year old woman drowned when the car she was riding in was swept off a low-water crossing across SH55 into Hackberry Creek. The driver of the vehicle was also washed into the creek.  Both exited the vehicle and were clinging to tree branches as rescuers attempted to reach them.  The young woman was pregnant and unable to maintain her hold.  She was swept into the flood waters and drowned.  The driver was rescued.  Two men drove a pickup truck into the flooded low water crossing only a few minutes later but were rescued.

Rainfall redeveloped over Bandera County in the early morning hours, with totals since the previous night approaching 5 inches in the western part of the county around 7 am.  Flash flooding developed just before sunrise and continued into the early afternoon.  Road closures were widespread, with most of the damage to bridges and roads.  Emergency officials noted that in spite of the widespread flooding and road closures across the county, only a few rescues were required.  Apparently that the public stayed out of vehicles and very safe.
Numerous roads were flooded.

The Willacy County Sheriff's Department reported widespread flooding in the town of La Sara.  High water was also reported to be covering portions of FM 490, FM 1015, and FM 88, as well as State Highway 186.

A man caught in his vehicle in high water suffered minor injuries before he could be rescued. The man hung onto a guide wire for 20 minutes before police and fire personnel could finally wade out to reach him.
Widespread flooding was reported between Hillsboro, Abbot, and Malone.
Flooding was reported on Highway 22 between Frost and Blooming Grove.

Extensive flooding in and around the Sharpstown area. One 17 year old female fatality with one 18 year old male injury when van they were driving became flooded outside of high school. Flooding extended into Houston metro with numerous flooded or completely submerged vehicles. 300 homes flooded.
Flooding in the New Caney and Porter areas.
Flooding in Coldspring.
Flooding in and around the town of Wharton.
Flooding across northern Galveston County.
Flooding across northern Brazoria County.
Extensive flooding in and around Kendleton. Flooding extended into the towns of Needville and Mission Bend.

High water resulting from flash flooding was widespread across eastern Dawson County late on the 7th and into the early morning hours of the 8th. As the supercell storm tracked southeast across the area, vehicles were stalled in high water on U.S. Highway 87 twelve miles north of Lamesa. Farm to Market Road 178 was also impassable three miles north of Key.
Reports indicated several cars stalled in flash flood waters on Loop 250 at Fairgrounds Road. No injuries were reported.

Rainfall from mid afternoon into the early evening produced general amounts near 1 inch with scattered totals to 3 inches.    Due to the saturated nature of soils across the county, brief flash flooding developed over low areas and low water crossings.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported high water covering the intersection of Highways 1210 and 178 in northern Dawson County.
Very heavy rain combined with ice blockage from hail resulted in flash flooding of a construction site along Highway 285 south of Fort Stockton.
Water over the intersections of highway 153 and 83.

Local law enforcement officials reported flash flooding which resulted in high water running over many area roadways, including city streets in Big Spring, and Farm to Market Road 2230 north of the city.  Over one foot of water covered Midway Road east of Big Spring.

A significant flash flood event affected the eastern part of Howard County. At least one vehicle was stalled in high water on the access road of Interstate 20 east of Big Spring. The occupants were rescued. Houses were flooded in both Forsan and Coahoma. Pavement on rural roadways was washed away. No injuries were reported.

Storm spotters reported flash flooding which resulted in high water flowing over Interstate 10 west of Fort Stockton. By late evening, two feet of water was reported flowing over the interstate service road eleven miles west of Fort Stockton.
Flash flooding washed out County Road 1090 near the Upton County line.
The intersection of Farm to Market Roads 612 and 2350 was under high water due to flash flooding.
Spotters reported flash flooding in the city of Odessa. Numerous city streets were impassable.
Flash flooding resulted in high water covering the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 2126 and 612.
Local officials reported flash flooding which resulted in high water in parts of Colorado City. One report indicated the water was "knee high" outside a partially flooded trailer home.
Flash flooding caused Farm to Market Road 1806 to be covered by high water.
Flash flooding resulted in flood waters running over many roadways in western Mitchell County including Highway 163 and Farm to Market Roads 1229 and 1808.
Flash flooding resulted in over a foot of water crossing Highway 137 south of Garden City.

The line of showers and thunderstorms moved into Lee County shortly before sunset, producing a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over the county.  Heaviest amounts were in the southeast part of the county, where up to 4 inches of rain was reported.  Flash flooding began and ended during the late evening period.

Heavy rain began falling over southern Real County shortly after midnight.  By 3 am CST, nearly 4 inches of rain had fallen over the area and low water crossings were beginning to collect water.  At 330 am CST, SH337 was closed between Leakey and Camp Wood due to the high water.  The rain ended over the county near 7 am CST and the flash flooding ended near 830 am CST.
Local officials reported flash flooding which resulted in flowing water on many city streets in Midland. Water was described to be one to two feet deep.
Storm spotters reported flash flooding resulting in high water making Farm to Market Road 669 impassable north of Big Spring. The water was reported to be between two and four feet deep.
High water was flowing over Highway 137 and Farm to Market Road 1064 as a result of flash flooding in northern Dawson County.
Widespread flooding was reported in and around Dimmitt.
Widespread flooding was reported in town.
Portions of Highway 86 and Highway 87 were reported flooded.
Roads were reported flooded in and around Kress.
Widespread flooding was reported in town.
Streets flooded in Robert Lee.

Major flash flooding in the city of Canyon. Numerous roads were closed and garbage dumpsters were reported floating down the street. Bar ditches were reported overflowing. One home received damage by flood waters on Country Club Road and two other homes had their basements flooded. There was a high water vehicle rescue performed in Canyon at the intersection of Country Club Road and Rockwell Road when a woman drove her vehicle into flood waters which then swept her vehicle into the ditch. The water was reported to be up to her vehicle's windows. The woman was rescued by the Canyon Fire Department and no injuries occurred.
Over three feet of water was reported flowing over the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 1357 and 1379 as a result of flash flooding.
Flash flooding resulted in high water flowing over County Road 337.
Flash flooding resulted in high water covering several rural roadways in southwest Glasscock County. Farm to Market Road 1357 was impassable.
Water over a highway.
Local officials reported flash flooding that resulted in high water covering city streets in Greenwood.
Extensive flooding of bar ditches three to four feet deep along Farm to Market Road 1061.
Extensive flooding to fields reported along State Highway 354.
Flooding was reported along U.S. Highway 285.  Street flooding was also reported in the city of Pecos.

A thunderstorm moving out of Pecos County produced flooding over portions of Ward County during the morning of Sunday, April 4th.  Several streets were flooded in the town of Barstow.  Flooding was also reported at the intersection of Interstate 20 and Farm to Market Road 1219 and along a four mile stretch southward along Farm to Market Road 1219.
Flash flooding resulted in high water that flowed over Farm to Market Road 1614 north of U.S. Highway 180 and over Camp Springs Road.
Flooding was reported along Highway 118, 2.5 miles south the Interstate 10.

A bridge along Interstate 20 just east-northeast of Toyah over the normally dry Salt Draw failed Sunday evening. This failure was the result of fast-moving flood waters originating from previous heavy rainfall over the Davis Mountains. Hydrologists also credited a residual flow of water through the draw from the Toyah dike break early Sunday for contributing to the gradual process that caused the bridge to collapse. Authorities said that advance warning of additional runoff and flooding allowed the interstate to be closed to both eastbound and westbound traffic at the first sign of danger to the bridge. A state official for the Texas Department of Transportation said that 86 feet of roadway in the eastbound lanes fell into the river, and that additional 40-foot segments on each side of the river were also damaged. On the westbound side, one of the upright supports holding the bridge had moved six to eight inches, opening a crack in the roadway.  No fatalities were reported with the bridge collapse, however, five indirect fatalities occurred in a multi-vehicle collision along a detour, U.S. Highway 285, south of Pecos.

A general inch of rain fell across Gonzales County, with amounts averaging 2 inches in the northern part of the county.  Heaviest amounts were along US90 where up to 3 inches fell.  Roads in the north part of the county were closed due to flash flooding.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in eastern Bexar County, closing many small feeder and rural roads through the late afternoon due to flash flooding.
General half-inch rain fell over Frio County, with up to 3 inches in the northwest portion of the county. Roads were closed near Frio Town due to flash flooding

Thunderstorms produced up to five inches of rain in western portions of Odessa, resulting in flash flooding.  Flash flooding was reported in the western and northeast portions of Odessa and also in the town of Gardendale.  The flooding finally subsided by late afternoon.
Flooding was reported along Farm to Market Road 2903 between Toyah and Balmorhea, making the road impassable.  Farm to Market Road 869 and State Highway 17 were also closed due to flooding.
Flooding was reported at a guardhouse in western Andrews county.  Additionally, reports indicated several feet of water on field roads.
Rainfall over Karnes County averaged near 1 inch, with up to 3 inches between Runge and Helena.  Roads in the Helena area were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced 1 to 2 inches of rain over southern DeWitt County and 2 to 3 inches over northern DeWitt County.  Roads were closed due to flash flooding between Westhoff and Hocheim.

Eight to twelve inches of rainfall resulted in the failure of a protective levee near Toyah.  With the failure of this dike, three to four feet of water inundated the town of Toyah and prompted the evacuation of the town's residents.  While 19 people in the town of 103 elected to stay through the flood event, the remainder of the town's residents were moved to a Red Cross shelter in the nearby community of Pecos.  The extensive flooding in Toyah left virtually every home with flood damage.  One home was completely destroyed.Flooding lingered until late afternoon on Sunday, April 4th with State Highway 17 and Farm to Market Roads 2903, 869, and 1450 remaining underwater.
Thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over Caldwell County, with up to 3 inches between Lockhart and Luling.  Several rural roads were closed due to flash flooding.

Showers and thunderstorms dropped an inch of rain over Comal County, with up to 3 inches in the northwest part of the county, along the Kendall County line.  Numerous roads were closed due to flash flooding.
Running water flooded roadways near Vincent.

Numerous roads were inudated by high water in the city of Snyder. In addition, Deep Creek flooded in the city. As a result, several vehicles stalled in high water. The Snyder Fire Department conducted several high water rescues. No injuries were reported.
I-45 northbound feeder roads flooded and impassable.
75 to 100 Livingston homes and businesses damaged from flooding at FM 146 and US 59; northbound and southbound lanes of US 59 closed.
A store near the Conch county line was flooded.

There were numerous reports of Flash flooding across southern portions of San Angelo to Dove Creek and near Christoval. A car 6 miles northeast of Christoval was swept of the road. The occupants were not injured.

Flooding across western and northwestern Tarrant County including numerous high water rescues.  Farmers Branch Creek in White Settlement flooded the town, causing major damage to 50 homes and minor damage to 150 homes.
Highway 287 south of Decatur was down to one lane due to flooding.
Low water crossings were flooded across the county.
Flooding was occurring in the Cundiff area.
Flooding was reported near Highwat 287 and FM 407.
Flooding was reported in the Reno area.
The town of Early had to close several roads due to high water.
A deputy reported nearly a foot of water flowing over State Highway 349 north of Rankin.

Storm spotters, law enforcement officials, and the local media reported several instances of flash flooding across Midland. At 10:00 CST Texas Department of Public Safety troopers and Midland Fire Department personnel rescued a woman and three children from a vehicle submerged in three feet of water near the intersection of West Industrial Avenue and South Midland Drive.Shortly before 10:30 CST rescue crews assisted stranded motorists on Illinois Avenue and at the intersection of Midkiff Road and Wadley Avenue. At 11:00 CST an elderly driver was rescued from a vehicle submerged in six feet of flowing water near Midland College. Flood waters reportedly covered the trunk and hood of the sports utility vehicle and entered the cab. Fire crews anchored a safety line across Wadley Avenue to reach the distressed motorist.   In addition, over a foot of water covered the Loop 250 access road between Thomason and State Highway 191 near Grandecom Stadium. Over two feet of water covered the Interstate 20 access road at the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1130. Two traffic accidents on Interstate 20 in Midland were indirectly related to the wet weather when cars lost control on the wet pavement. One such accident resulted in an injured motorist. No injuries or fatalities resulted from the flash flooding.
A bridge on Highway 395 was under water.
A few roads were closed around the county due to high water.

Flooding caused three bridges to be washed out around 8 AM.  These bridges were at Tioga, Central Sherman, and on Old Luella Road.  Numerous county roads were also washed out and in bad need of repair.
Flooding closed Brand and Campbell Roads in Garland.
Flooding caused FM 271, FM 100, and FM 1396 to close.   State Highway 56 was also being closed at the time.  Numerous roads near Bonham were washed out and in bad need of repair.
Flooding was reported on FM 71 at the South Sulphur River Bridge.
Several roads were closed due to high water, including: FM 36, FM 118, FM 1565, and the Interstate 30 north and south frontage roads at East Caddo and West Caddo Creeks.
The Interstate 30 north and south service roads were closed between FM 35 and the Hunt county line due to flooding.
Exit ramp in town is flooded.
Streets flooded in Royse City.
Two streets in town have several inches of water over them and are closed.
I-45 exit closed due to high water.
Creeks near Bonham were flooded and several bridges were washed out.
Flooding caused bridge over FM 55 to collapse.  Several other secondary roads were also closed due to flooding.
Several city streets closed or impassable due to flowing water.
Pecan Grove area.

Low lying areas in Refugio were flooded.  Portions of the city park in Refugio were closed due to flooding.  Water flowing over U.S. 77 north and south of Refugio resulted in several accidents.  Highway 35 and FM 774 intersection, south of Tivoli, was closed due to flooding.  Water covered some roads in Woodsboro.
Flooding occurred along Highway 35, north of Lamar, in northern Aransas county.
Heavy rain filled the ditches and had started flowing over highway 277.
Significant street flooding in Coleman.
Water flowing over the roads at several low water crossings.
Water running over the road in several locations.
County road was closed due to water over the road.

Heavy rain from the severe thunderstorms produced accumulations of up to 2 inches over the saturated soils of northern Atascosa County.  The rainfall produced brief flash flooding that forced the closure of FM3175 and FM2790.  Officials reported that at least one vehicle was washed off the road on FM3175.  There were no injuries.
Several roads in the Fort Boggy State Park closed with water over them.
Several roads under water and barricaded across far northern portions of county, including FM 218 and Highway 16.

Heavy rainfall produced accumulations of nearly 2 inches in about one hour over very saturated soils southwest of Fredericksburg.  Officials reported that a car was washed off Alfred Petsch Rd. at a low water crossing where Pedernales River crosses.  The driver escaped and there were no injuries.

Thunderstorms produced general 2 inch rain accumulations over northern DeWitt County and southern Gonzales County.  Nearly 3 inches was indicated in the area between Westhoff and Nordheim in DeWitt County and Smiley in Gonzales County.  Through much of the evening, flash flooding closed FM108 on both sides of the DeWitt-Gonzales County line, as well as M240 in DeWitt County.
Slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding over northeast Wise county.  2-3 feet of water was reported over county roads.
Slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding over northwest Denton county.  2-3 feet of water was reported over county roads.

Thunderstorms produced general 2 inch rain accumulations over northern DeWitt County and southern Gonzales County.  Nearly 3 inches was indicated in the area between Westhoff and Nordheim in DeWitt County and Smiley in Gonzales County.  Through much of the evening, flash flooding closed FM108 on both sides of the DeWitt-Gonzales County line, as well as FM240 in DeWitt County.

Heavy rainfall from slow-moving thunderstorms in DeWitt and Gonzales Counties spilled westward into Karnes County near 2100 CST.  Between 1 and 2 inches fell over the eastern part of the county, with heaviest amounts near 3 inches between Helena and Gillett.  Flash flooding briefly closed FM887 and SH119 near Gillett.

Slow-moving thunderstorms in DeWitt and Gonzales Counties spread eastward into Lavaca County, producing a general 2 inch rain over the western half of the county.  Highest totals were nearly 4 inches between Hallettsville and Yoakum.  Flash flood developed briefly, closing SH77 and SH90 in the Hallettsville area.

The storms in Gillespie County spread northward into eastern Llano County, producing between 1 and 2 inches of rain between Llano and Kingsland.  Highest totals were near 3 inches about 10 miles southeast of Llano. Flash flooding was reported along SH721 southeast of Llano and FM1431 was closed north of Kingsland.

Widespread thunderstorms produced a general rainfall of between 1 and 2 inches over most of Gillespie County.  Highest totals were near 4 inches between Fredericksburg and Willow City. Flash flooding closed SH16 just northeast of Fredericksburg. SH965 was also closed just north of Fredericksburg. FM1323 was also closed at Willow City.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain generally fell between Castell and Llano, with highest totals near 3 inches 5 miles southwest of Llano. CR152 was flooded at its intersection with SH29. CR2323 was closed southwest of Llano.

Thunderstorms from central Edwards County to the Real-Edwards County line produced a general rainfall of 1 to 2 inches, with up to 4 inches along the county line from 10 miles north of Barksdale to Camp Wood.  FM335 was closed in several locations along the county line and FM337 was closed near Camp Wood.
Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell in Del Rio, causing brief flash flooding that closed several low water crossings.  Cisneros and Academy Streets, among several others, were closed.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in southwestern Edwards County, causing flash flooding across SH674 southwest of Rocksprings.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in the mid afternoon in the area around Quemado and Normandy.  Flash flooding closed FM1908 northeast of  Quemado and SH131 east of Normandy.

A general 1 inch rain fell across the northern half of Frio County, with up to 4 inches south of Big Foot.  Both FM140 and FM472 were closed near where they intersect.  FM462 and FM2779 were also closed northeast of Pearsall.

Thunderstorms from central Edwards County to the Real-Edwards County line produced a general rainfall of 1 to 2 inches, with up to 4 inches along the county line from 10 miles north of Barksdale to Camp Wood.  SH55 was closed between Rocksprings and Barksdale.  FM335 was closed in several locations along the county line and FM337 was closed near Camp Wood.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell between Comfort and Sisterdale, with up to 4 inch totals just south of Comfort. FM473 was closed due to flash flooding east of Comfort. FM1376 was closed south of Sisterdale.

Thunderstorms dropped from 1 to 2 inches or rain across the area from Concan to Utopia in the late morning.  Flash flooding closed FM187 closed south Utopia and FM1050 between Concan and Utopia. Flash flooding was also reported through Garner Park.

From 1 to 2 inches of rain fell across the area from Cuero to Yoakum, with as much as 7 inches southeast of Hocheim. SH183 was closed near Hocheim, with SH119 closed near New Davy and FM1446 closed at Cuero.

Thunderstorms produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain over southern Gonzales County.  Highest totals were near 5 inches just southeast of Gonzales.  SH183 was closed south of Gonzales with FM108 closed from Wrightsboro to Smiley.
A general inch of rain fell between Fedor and Lexington, with up to 6 inches in isolated spots between the two towns.  Flash flooding closed FM112, FM696, and FM1624 near Lexington

Thunderstorms produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain between Moulton and Shiner, with up to 5 inches in the area around Moulton. SH95 was closed between Moulton and Shiner and FM1444 was flooded near Yorktown.

Thunderstorms developing just before midnight produced widespread 1 inch rain totals between Langtry and Juno in the north central part of Val Verde County.  Highest totals were between 2 and 3 inches between the two towns.  FM1024 was closed due to flash flooding approximately 25 miles southeast of Pandale. SH163 was closed near Juno

Thunderstorms from Bandera to Medina to Tarpley to Vanderpool dropped general 1 inch rainfall during the morning.  Isolated locations between the four towns reported up to 3 inches of rain. FM337 was closed west of Medina and FM470 was closed both to the east and the west of Tarpley. FM187 was closed sough of Vanderpool.

A general 1 to 2 inch rain fell between Jourdanton and Charlotte, with the highest totals near 4 inches just southeast of Jourdanton.  SH16 and SH97 were closed due to flash flooding near Jourdanton. FM140 was closed southeast of Charlotte.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in the Batesville area during the mid afternoon.  FM117 and FM1025 were closed south of Batesville, with FM187 closed northeast of Batesville.

Flash flooding prompted residents to create make-shift culverts and dams to keep the water from entering their homes.  Many homes were damaged by the high water, which was several feet high in some places.
Significant street flooding was reported in Abilene.
Eight inches of water reported over the road from Lakeside Drive through the on-ramp to Interstate 40 west with ten inches of water over the road at 34th Avenue and Bolton Street.

The Odessa Fire Department conducted thirty-five high water rescues as flash flooding of city streets stranded motorists in two to four feet of flowing flood waters. The Odessa American reported that the worst flooding occurred along Dixie Boulevard, Eighth Street, 42nd Street, and Muskingum Street.

Reports of flash flooding in Midland were received as very heavy rainfall moved over the city. Initial reports indicated high water flowing through city streets, including Anetta and Eisenhower Streets near the intersection of Midland Drive in southern Midland. Several vehicles stalled in high water at the intersection of Wadley Drive and Godfrey Street by 06:53 CST, where water flowed over the hood of a pickup truck.

Very heavy rainfall associated with the severe storm over Marathon resulted in street flooding of many city streets. Motorists traveling along U.S. Highway 385 between Fort Stockton and Marathon reported intermittent flash flooding along that route in northern Brewster County. The Texas Department of Transportation was dispatched to barricade portions of the highway.
A general 1 inch rain fell from Thomaston northeastward, with up to 3 inches in places.  Flash flooding closed CR104 and CR114 northeast of Thomaston.
In extreme northern Lavaca County, thunderstorms produced up to 4 inches of rain between Moravia and Hackberry.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM957 near Moravia and FM532 near Hackberry.

Local residents reported debris from overnight flash flooding covering portions of Farm to Market Road 2400 in northern Terrell County. Large amounts of caliche, rocks, dirt, and other debris was deposited across the highway near several low water crossings. The event time is estimated based on radar.
Plains Highway closed; numerous cars under water.
CR380 between Plains and Brownfield closed due to water.  CR1780 5 miles north of Plains flooded.
Highway 62/82 near Ropesville flooded with 5 vehicles.  CR385 north of 114 closed due to water.
CR380 closed due to water.  CR1780 flooded north of Highway 82 and CR380.
Several flood roads.  FM3858-CR137, Plains Highway, and Seagraves Highway flooded.
Flooded roads in Plainview.
Heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in the Girvin vicinity, with many city streets filled with flowing flood waters.

The same slow moving severe storm that produced large hail south of Monahans resulted in localized flash flooding as prolonged heavy rainfall occurred over several highways in southern Ward County. Initial reports indicated flash flooding along a low water crossing on Farm to Market Road 1776. At 18:14 CST, additional flash flooding was reported along Farm to Market Road 1219 just northwest of Grandfalls, where half a foot of water flowed over the driving surface.

Numerous reports of flash flooding were received from southern Upton County during the morning of the 10th. Initial reports indicated urban flash flooding with high water flowing through many city streets in McCamey. By 09:55 CST the local broadcast media reported a stalled car with water flowing through the windows at the 200 Block of East 6th Street in McCamey.  By 10:59 CST, up to eight inches of water was reported flowing across U.S. Highway 67 west of Rankin. Additional reports of flooding were received from McCamey at 10:50 CST.
Law enforcement officials reported that sections of Texas Highway 329 were barricaded for at least ninety minutes due to flood waters that inundated the driving surface.

A strong thunderstorm that moved over the southern part of Fort Stockton during the early morning hours of the 7th produced locally heavy rainfall that resulted in flash flooding. The public reported that several city streets were impassable due to flowing flood waters near the downtown area.

Storm spotters and local law enforcement officials reported intermittent flash flooding along U.S. Highway 87 between Ackerly and Lamesa. More than six inches of rapidly flowing flood waters covered the highway near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 828 just south of Lamesa. In addition, several streets in Ackerly were inundated by high water.
Very heavy rains produced flooding on Farm to Market road 1773 and Highway 83 south of Menard.

Very heavy rains in association with a stationary supercell thunderstorms dumped several inches of rain over the eastern portion of Callahan County resulting in flooding. Numerous roads were flooded and a portion of interstate 20 was closed for a time during the height of the event.

Strong thunderstorms affected parts of the west Texas Big Bend region during the late afternoon and evening of the 18th. Locally heavy rainfall east of Panther Junction resulted in flash flooding along Texas Route 118. Running water was reported to have rendered the highway impassable between Panther Junction and Rio Grande Village.

Flash flooding in Odessa resulted in significant traffic problems on many city streets. Stalled vehicles were reported at several locations within the city, including the intersection of Dixie and 23rd Streets. The Odessa Fire Department conducted six high water rescues during the event. No injuries were reported during the rescue efforts that occurred at the intersection of 17th and Tom Green Streets, and along Muskingum Street.

Thunderstorms from eastern Edwards County across northern Real County and into western Kerr Counties produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain.  Highest totals were near 3 inches west of Hunt. SH41 and SH39 were closed due to flash flooding near the Real County line. FM1340 was also closed  west of Hunt.

Thunderstorms from eastern Edwards County across northern Real County and into western Kerr Counties produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain.  Highest totals were near 3 inches in extreme northeast Real County. FM336 was closed due to flash flooding near the Edwards County line. SH41 was closed near the Kerr County line.

A second round of showers and thunderstorms moved over Ector County during the late morning hours. Additional heavy rainfall resulted in renewed flash flooding in parts of Odessa. High water was reported flowing through several city streets, including the intersections of 16th and Moss Streets and VFW and Stephenson Streets.

Thunderstorms from eastern Edwards County across northern Real County and into western Kerr and Bandera Counties produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain.  Highest totals were near 4 inches in the Tarpley area.  FM462 and FM470 were closed due to flash flooding near Tarpley. FM187 was closed north of Vanderpool.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell in the early morning hours between Boerne and Comfort in western Kendall County.  Highest totals were near 3 inches between the two towns.  Flash flooding closed FM473 east of Comfort, as well as FM474 and FM1376 near Boerne.

Flash flooding along Interstate 10 East in the Uvalde and Cloverleaf areas and also in and around Downtown Houston and the University of Houston areas. Ten homes and two apartments in the Cloverleaf area had flood damage. Some rainfall amounts/rates measured by Harris County rainfall gages included: 0.75" in 5 minutes, 1.81" in 15 minutes and 2.64" in 30 minutes at Carpenters Bayou@Wallisville (Gage ID 1440), 3.31" in 1 hour at Buffalo Bayou@Shephard (Gage ID 2240) and 4.84" in 3 hours at Carpenters Bayou@I-10 (Gage ID 1420).

Initial reports indicated that flash flooding resulted in up to six inches of rapidly flowing water over several city streets in Fort Davis. By 15:18 CST, high water was reported flowing over Texas Highway 118 near the Prude Ranch north of Fort Davis.

A complex of strong to severe thunderstorms moved over Odessa during the pre-dawn hours of the 3rd and produced brief but very heavy rainfall. The local media reported up to eight inches of rapidly flowing flood waters at the intersection of West County Road and University in Odessa. No damage was reported.
A general rainfall of 1 inch around Stinson Airport, with up to 4 inches in spots, caused flash flooding through the late afternoon that closed Spur 536 and Spur 122.
Storms dropped a general 1 to 2 in rain between Juno and Langtry, with up to 3 inches in places.  SH163 was closed due to flash flooding near Juno and FM1024 was closed between Juno and Langtry
Very heavy rains caused flash flooding in southern and eastern Haskell County. Numerous roads were closed across the southern and eastern portions of the County including highway 380.

The first heavy rainfall and flood event of June occurred during the late evening of May 31 and early morning of June 1 as a large complex of thunderstorms moved through parts of western north Texas. Strong to severe thunderstorms dropped rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches over an isolated area in Knox County, including a rainfall report of 3.09 inches at the river gage site 4 miles north of Benjamin, TX.The subsequent heavy runoff produced brief flooding along the South Wichita River in Knox County. At the river gage site 4 miles north of Benjamin on Texas State Highway 6, the South Wichita River crested at 13.2 feet, 1.2 feet above flood stage, at 7:45 am CST on June 1, and was above flood stage from 3:00 am CST to 10:30 am CST on June 1. Minor rural flooding occurred over rangelands near the river.

Flash flooding along Beals Creek rendered several city streets near downtown Big Spring impassable. The worst flooding was reported near the intersections of Sixth and Circle Streets, and Second and Denton Streets.

A local radio station relayed a report of flash flooding that affected a rural homestead in southwestern Mitchell County. Local residents reported that more than two inches of rain fell in a short period of time. This resulted in high water that briefly threatened a home.
Flash flooding resulted in half a foot of water flowing through many city streets in Loraine. Storm spotters reported that the street flooding was brief and that no damage or injuries occurred.

Urban flash flooding occurred throughout Midland during the pre-dawn hours of the 3rd. A complex of strong thunderstorms produced brief, but very heavy rainfall over the city and resulted in more than six inches of flowing flood waters through Midland Drive and Wadley Avenue. Numerous other streets were reportedly under water, but no reports of damage or injuries were received.
Up to 3 inches of rain in the northern part of greater San Antonio caused flash flooding.  FM78 was closed at Salado Creek and Starcrest Drive in northeast San Antonio was also closed.
Heavy rains flooded County road 126 near Nolan.

Thunderstorms from eastern Edwards County across northern Real County and into western Kerr and Bandera Counties produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain.  Highest totals were near 3 inches in the extreme northeast corner of the county. US377 and SH41 were closed due to flash flooding northeast of Rocksprings.
Heavy rains caused a flash flood near Anson in central Jones County. Highway 6 was closed due to water flowing over the road.
Local officials reported that heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in Iraan. Numerous city streets were reported to be inundated with flowing flood waters. No damage was reported.

Law enforcement officials reported flash flooding along State Highway 349 north of Rankin. Flowing flood waters inundated the highway seven miles north of the city. By 19:56 CST residents in Rankin reported that heavy rainfall and flash flooding resulted in high water that entered several homes. A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported that up to five inches of rain had fallen during the past forty-eight hours.

Local law enforcement officials reported that heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in the streets of Seminole. Six vehicles were reported to be stranded in the flowing flood waters. Several motorists were rescued by fire department personnel. No injuries were reported.

Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain between Buda, in Hays County, and Creedmoor, in southeast Travis County.  Highest rainfall amounts were near 4 inches.  Flash flooding closed FM2001 near Buda and FM 1327 between Creedmoor and IH-35.

Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain between Buda, in Hays County, and Creedmoor, in southeast Travis County.  Highest rainfall amounts were near 4 inches.  Flash flooding closed FM2001 near Buda and FM 1327 between Creedmoor and IH-35.
Highway 321 underpass flooded and closed with vehicles stranded in the area. Numerous streets and secondary roads flooded.
Flooding in the Aldine area.

Local officials reported flash flooding across a large part of central Pecos County during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 27th. The initial reports indicated several city streets were inundated with flood waters, including James and Jackson Streets, and the Sanderson Highway. County roads also were reported to be impassable north of the city. By 19:01 CST over six inches of water was reported flowing across U.S. Highway 285 southeast of Fort Stockton. High water additionally was reported flowing over portions of U.S. Highway 385 between Fort Stockton and Marathon.

Storm spotters reported that flash flooding caused high water to inundate the intersection of U.S. Highway 87 and Farm to Market Road 33 south of Big Spring. More than one foot of flowing water covered the driving surface.

A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported that high water from flash flooding threatened her home just northwest of Rankin. Water was entering the back of her residence at 18:30 CST. The water receded before causing significant damage.

The Texas Department of Transportation closed a stretch of State Highway 349 just south of the Midland and Upton County line, as heavy rainfall and the resulting flash flooding inundated portions of that highway.
A rural resident reported that heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding that washed out a cotton crop and inundated secondary roadways off U.S. Highway 87 in northern Dawson County.

Law enforcement officials in Big Lake reported that flash flooding resulted in high water flowing through several city streets. At 06:00 CST, water was reportedly up to the doors on several vehicles. Water flowed over the curbs on many streets. By 08:40 CST nearly six inches of water flowed over Farm to Market Road 1676 just south of U.S. Highway 67.

Ector County and Odessa officials reported flash flooding from near Goldsmith to Odessa. At 06:48 the Odessa Fire Department barricaded the intersection of Dixie and Center due to flowing water. Nearly half a foot of water also was reported flowing across Farm to Market Road 181 near the intersection with State Highway 302.

Multiple reports of flash flooding were received from the Rankin area. Initial reports indicated that flood waters were inundating the porch at the Rankin Airport offices. by 06:30 CST, flowing water had inundated several area highways. The intersection of State Highway 349 and U.S. Highway 67 was impassable, as were several city streets. By 08:00 CST flash flooding had rendered State Highway 349 impassable with more than two feet of water flowing over the roadway north of Rankin.

Several reports of flash flooding were received from areas in and around Midland during the afternoon of the 28th. The intersection of County Road 60 and State Highway 158 was inundated by almost a half-foot of flowing water. Similar flash flooding conditions were reported along several city streets in the north part of the city, including at the intersection of Briarwood and Northcrest. At least one foot of flowing flood waters covered the intersection of Midkiff and Andrews Highway. No damage or injuries were reported.
Numerous areas of flooded roadways.
Flash flooding occurred on numerous streets in Midland as a cluster of thunderstorms moved slowly across the city.  Flooded streets included Mark Lane and Wadley Avenue.
Officials closed I-20 near the Eastland/Callahan county line due to flooding; relayed by WFO SJT.
Flooding occurred between Denton and Sanger.

Thunderstorms formed across southeastern Llano County in the mid afternoon and remained nearly stationary for three hours.  The storms produced a general 1 inch rainfall, with up to 4 inches falling near Sunrise Beach.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM2900 and FM2233 near the Sunrise Beach area.

Thunderstorms from Llano County spread southward into Gillespie County by mid afternoon. The storms produced a general 1 inch rainfall over the county, with up to 3 inches for the maximum, located near Fredericksburg.  SH16 was closed at several locations due to flash flooding between the Llano County line and Fredericksburg.

Thunderstorms formed across southwestern Llano County by mid afternoon and remained nearly stationary for two hours.  The storms produced a general 1 inch rainfall over the southwestern half of the county, with up to 4 inches falling immediately south of Llano along SH16 just north of the Gillespie County line.  The resulting flash flooding closed SH16 and FM2323 south and southwest of Llano.
A nearly stationary thunderstorm remained over the city of Odessa for over two hours. Flash flooding was reported across the city, including outside of Music City Mall on 42nd Street.

Major street flooding occurred in Pecos as a line of thunderstorms passed over the city.  Many streets were flooded including Stafford, Waphall, and Eddy Streets.  Water was over three feet deep on Eddy Street.  The police department performed a high water rescue when a vehicle slid into a bar ditch at the intersection of Country Club Road and Palmer Street.
The public reported that roads were flooded with four to six inches in low places and one to three inches across all roads.
The Winkler county Sheriff's office reported that State Highway 302 was inundated by flood waters west of Kermit.  Several roads were flooded in Kermit.
Numerous flooded areas on Highway 145, FM 1731 and FM 333.  One motorist was stranded on a flooded road and local First Reponders performed successful rescue efforts.

With soils soaked from heavy rainfall on the previous day, thunderstorms produced an additional 2 to 3 inches of rain in the Loma Alta area during the early afternoon.  Flash flooding developed in the mid afternoon and ended in the early evening.

A National Weather Service trained spotter reported water flowing over portions of Farm to Market Road 652 in northern Loving County.  The public also reported high water threatening homes on the Loving County, Texas/Lea County, New Mexico county line.

The public reported flash flooding in the city of Midland, along the Loop 250 service road.  An off-duty National Weather Service meteorologist reported that a car was stranded in high water at the intersection of Bluebird and Midkiff Streets in Midland.  Flooding was reported by the sheriff's office on Wadley Avenue, Loop 250, Texas Highway 191, A Street, Cuthbert, Andrews Highway, and I Street.  Many cars were submerged, leaving their occupants stranded.  Nineteen high water rescues were reported by the Midland Fire Department.  The broadcast media reported two to three feet of water flowing across the intersection of Garfield and Golf Course Road, where eight additional rescues were conducted by media personnel and the public.  Several streets around Midland were barricaded including County Road 1150 between Texas Highways 158 and 307.
Nearly a foot of water was running across Farm to Market Road 26 for half an hour southeast of Lamesa.
Local law enforcement officials reported that three feet of water was flowing across Farm to Market Road 612 making it impassable.
Roads in Big Lake were inundated by flood waters along with Texas Highway 137 south of Big Lake.

Thunderstorms forming between Loma Alta, Rocksprings, and Leakey remained nearly stationary for up to 3 hours in the mid to late afternoon.  The storms produced a 3 inch rainfall near Loma Alta that closed US377.
Slow-moving thunderstorms in the late afternoon produced general 2 to 3 inch rainfall in the Langtry area.  Several roads in and around Langtry were closed through the early evening.

Thunderstorms southeast of Brackettville produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain in the southeast quarter of the County.  Highest amounts were 4 inches about 10 miles east of Spofford.  Flash flooding closed FM1572 through the late night hours.

The broadcast media reported that Midland county road 1150 was barricaded between Farm to Market Road 307 and Texas Highway 158 because of flash flooding.  Also, water was entering a home on Texas Highway 349 and Midland County Road 1379 south of Midland.  Three feet of water was running across Texas Highway 349, 15 miles south of Midland.  Law enforcement officials reported flash flooding on Midland County Road 1160 between Farm to Market Road 1213 and Midland County Road 300.  The public reported Farm to Market Road 1379 was flooded from Texas Highway 158 south of Spraberry.
Portions of Texas Highway 137 were inundated by flood waters between Stiles and the North Reagan Fire Station.  The public also reported that streets in Big Lake were flooded.

Thunderstorms in northeastern Gonzales County near the Fayette County line produced general 1 to 2 inch rain totals with up to 4 inches falling near Waelder.  Flash flooding developed in the late afternoon and continued into the early evening.  Officials reported that SH97 and FM1115 were closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms in northeast Fayette County produced up to 3 inches of rain near Ledbetter, near the Washington County line.  Flash flooding began in the early evening, ending by mid evening.  FM1291 was closed near Ledbetter due to high water.

Following the flash flooding on August 5th, storms formed again the next morning from where US277 and US377 split north of Del Rio southeastward into northwestern Kinney County.  Rain totals averaged between 1 and 2 inches, with up to 4 inches where the two roads split. US277 was closed during a portion of the morning due to high water.

Thunderstorms formed in the mid morning over southern Edwards County and most of Kinney County, spreading by late morning into western Real County and southern Val Verde County.  The storms produced general 1 inch totals over the four county area, with up to 3 inches along the Real Edwards County line between Camp Wood and Barksdale. FM337 and FM335 were closed due to high water north of Camp Wood.

Thunderstorms formed in the mid morning over southern Edwards County and most of Kinney County, spreading by late morning into western Real County and southern Val Verde County.  The storms produced general 1 inch totals over the four county area, with up to 3 inches along the Real Edwards County line between Camp Wood and Barksdale and between Barksdale and Rocksprings. FM335 was closed northeast of Barksdale due to high water.  SH55 was closed between Rocksprings and Barksdale.

Thunderstorms formed in the mid morning over southern Edwards County and most of Kinney County, spreading by late morning into western Real County and southern Val Verde County.  The storms produced general 1 inch totals over the four county area, with between 2 and 3 inches in the city of Del Rio.  The Del Rio Police reported brief flash flooding in the city during the mid afternoon.
Flash flooding was reported on Farm to Market Road 1233 west of Crane.

Thunderstorms formed over Gillespie and Kendall Counties in the mid afternoon and produced a general 1 inch rainfall over the two counties.  Heaviest amounts in Gillespie County were 4 inch totals about 3 miles north of Fredericksburg and near Luckenbach.  Flash flooding was reported from the intersection of FM2323 and FM648 southeastward through Fredericksburg to Luckenbach.  Also closed due to high water were FM1376 and FM1888 near Luckenbach.

Thunderstorms formed over Gillespie and Kendall Counties in the mid afternoon and produced a general 1 inch rainfall over the two counties.  Heaviest amounts in Kendall County were 4 inch totals about 10 miles north of Sisterdale. Flash flooding was reported over much of the northern half of Kendall County.  Officials reported that FM1376, FM1888 and FM473 were closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms produced nearly 3 inches of rain in the early afternoon near Llano.  The resulting flash flooding closed SH16 south of Llano.  Thunderstorms produced nearly 3 inches of rain in the early afternoon near Llano.  The resulting flash flooding closed SH16 south of Llano.

Following the flash flooding on August 5th, storms formed again the next morning from where US277 and US377 split north of Del Rio southeastward into northwestern Kinney County.  Rain totals averaged between 1 and 2 inches, with up to 3 inches where FM2523 crosses the Val Verde County line.  FM2523 and FM3008 were closed due to flash flooding northwest of Brackettville.

Evening thunderstorms over central Fayette County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals with up to 5 inches falling between LaGrange and Fayetteville. Several roads in central Fayette County were closed due to high water, including SH159, FM955, FM1291, and FM155.

Evening thunderstorms over southern Lee County produced general 1 inch totals with highest amounts between 2 and 3 inches in the Giddings area.  Flash flooding blocked roads in and around Giddings during the late night hours. Water briefly flooded several homes in Giddings.

The Glasscock County Sheriff's Office reported that low water crossings on Texas Highway 137 between Texas Highway 158 and Farm to Market Road 2401 were flooded with a foot and a half of flowing water.

Thunderstorms in the late evening period produced rainfall totals between 2 and 3 inches in the area of northeast Williamson County along the Bell County line between Jarrell and Bartlett.  Flash flooding developed near midnight and ended in the early morning hours.  Among the roads closed due to high water were FM487 and FM972.

The late evening thunderstorms over northeast Williamson County produced rain totals near 3 inches between Granger and Hare near the Milam County line.  Flash flooding developed shortly after midnight, ending in the early morning hours. FM973 was closed due to high water.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell near the sunrise period around Pflugerville, causing flash flooding that closed FM1825 and FM1325 just west of Pflugerville.

Flash flooding redeveloped in Williamson County in the mid morning, this time in the west and southwest part of the county.  Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain over the western half of the county, with up to 3 inches near Florence. Flash flooding developed between Florence and Round Rock, closing SH195, SH136, and FM487, among other roads.
Numerous roads and Farm to Market roads flooded in the Post area out to 6 miles west of Post.
Several flooded roadways in the Tahoka area out to 10 miles west of Tahoka.
Major street flooding occurred from north of Anthony NM into northwestern El Paso County, including Anthony TX and Canutillo. Numerous stalled cars were observed from Interstate 10.

Slow moving thunderstorms over eastern Edwards and western Real Counties produced a general 1 inch rainfall between Rocksprings and Camp Wood.  Camp Wood received nearly 4 inches of rain in just two hours.  The resulting flash flooding closed SH55 and FM337.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in south Austin in less than one hour, causing flash flooding at the intersection of Ben White and IH-35.
Thunderstorms in northern Burnet County produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain over the area with up to 4 inches just west of Oakalla. FM963 was closed due to high water west of Oakalla.
Early morning thunderstorms produced widespread 1 inch rainfall over southwestern Travis County, with up to 3 inches near Oak Hill.  Flash flooding closed several roads in Oak Hill.

Thunderstorms across the northwest part of Gillespie County produced between 3 and 5 inches of rain just southeast of Cherry Spring. The flash flooding resulting from the heavy rainfall closed FM2323 and FM648 near Cherry Spring.

Flash flooding from thunderstorms that produced 2 inches of rain in less than one hour closed several streets in the western part of Bexar County and the city of San Antonio, including Callaghan Road, Culebra Road, McNeel Road, Prue Road, and Timberhill Road.

Slow moving thunderstorms over eastern Edwards and western Real Counties produced a general 1 inch rainfall between Rocksprings and Camp Wood.  Up to 4 inches of rain fell near Rocksprings, closing SH55 between Rocksprings and Barksdale.
Flooded roadway on FM 37.
Roadways flooded between 4 and 8 miles north of Petersburg on FM 789.
Numerous roads flooded across the county.  Flooded roadway on FM54 between FM387 and U.S. Highway 62.
Early afternoon thunderstorms produced up to 3 inches of rain near Kingsland. Flash flooding closed FM1431 north of Kingsland.

Heavy rainfall resulted in several streets flooded in Bishop.  NWS Doppler radar estimated nearly 5 inches of rain fell in portions of Bishop and an NWS Cooperative Observer in Bishop reported 3.79 inches of rain.
Heavy rainfall resulted in low water crossings flooded on the southeast side of Victoria, including Lone Tree Road.  NWS radar estimated between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall fell in about 1 hour.

Several intersections across the north and northeast side of town were flooded from heavy rainfall.  NWS radar estimates between 1 and 3 inches of rain fell in this area over a one to two hour time frame.

Thunderstorms forming in the northern Texas Hill Country in the late afternoon moved southward into the evening hours.  The storms produced a general 1 inch rainfall across northern Llano County, with 4 inches near Valley Spring.  Flash flooding closed SH16 east of Valley Spring.

Heavy rainfall from the thunderstorms that had formed across the northern Texas Hill Country spread into the Tow area by late evening.  The storms produced a general 1 inch rainfall across northeastern Llano County, with up to 4 inches at Tow.  FM2241 was closed near Tow due to flash flooding.
The public reported flash flooding at the intersection of Midkiff and Wadley.

Thunderstorms forming between Loma Alta, Rocksprings, and Leakey remained nearly stationary for up to 3 hours in the mid to late afternoon.  The storms produced a 3 inch rainfall near Leakey.  FM337 was closed west of Leakey, with FM336 closed north of Leakey, and FM337 closed east of Leakey due to the high water.

Thunderstorms formed from eastern Bandera County across western Kerr County into the Kerrville area in the late afternoon.  The storms produced a general 1 inch rainfall over eastern Bandera County, with up to 3 inches near Bandera.  Flash flooding closed SH173 south of Bandera and FM2828 northwest of Bandera, as well as FM1283 south of Pipe Creek

Thunderstorms formed from eastern Bandera County across western Kerr County into the Kerrville area in the late afternoon.  The storms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over the western half of Kerr County, with up to 4 inches near Kerrville.  FM1341 and FM783 were closed in the Kerrville area.

Thunderstorms forming between Loma Alta, Rocksprings, and Leakey remained nearly stationary for up to 3 hours in the mid to late afternoon.  The storms produced a 3 inch rainfall northeast of Carta Valley. US377 was closed between Carta Valley and Rocksprings. FM674 was closed southwest of Rocksprings.

Heavy rainfall with embedded thunderstorms persisted over Presidio county.  Storms caused Farm to Market Road 170 to flood and subsequently be closed by the Texas Department of Transportation due to the high water.
Flash flooding was reported along Comanche Creek in Fort Stockton. Law enforcement officials barricaded a road that runs through City Park.

Thunderstorms in western Kerr County dropped a widespread one inch rain over the west half of the county, with up to 3 inches just west of Hunt. SH39 was closed west of Hunt and SH41 was closed southwest of Mountain Home due to high water.
The public reported that flowing flood waters had washed away high water markers in low water crossings on several roads.
Numerous roads flooded.  Highway 1760 under water from 10 miles west/northwest of Muleshoe, TX to the New Mexico State Line.
Flooded roadways in the vicinity of 16 miles northwest of Muleshoe, TX or approximately 1 mile to the southwest of Lariat.
Numerous areas of flooded roadways along Highway 289.
Several areas of flooded roadway stretching from 4 to 8 miles west of Amherst, TX.  One stranded motorist was rescued by First Responders.
Numerous reports of flooded roadways between South Loop 289 to 82nd Street and the 9700 block of Boston Street.
The Texas Department of Public Safety reported flash flooding along a secondary roadway north of Interstate 20 in rural areas west of Pecos.

Local law enforcement officials reported intermittent flash flooding along Farm to Market Road 669 south of Gail. High water was reported flowing over the highway at several locations from five miles south of Gail southward to near the Borden and Howard County line.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported that several secondary roads near Vealmoor were inundated by high water.

Storm spotters reported flash flooding during the late evening hours from the Snyder area southwestward toward Lake J.B. Thomas. High water flowed through several city streets shortly before midnight CST. Runoff caused the flash flood threat to persist through the early morning hours of the 6th. A rancher in southwestern Scurry County reported more than half a foot of rapidly flowing flood waters that inundated County Road 1298 just east of Lake J.B. Thomas.

A shield of heavy precipitation extended across much of Andrews County on the evening of the 26th.  This resulted in street flooding in the town of Andrews and ponding of water along many roadways including U.S. Highway 385 south of Andrews.
Tenth street in Killeen closed due to high water.
Several roads closed due to high water.
Streets flooded west of Cisco.
Highway 218 closed due to water over the road.
As thunderstorms continued to move across portions of northwest Sterling County, heavy rainfall resulting from the storms caused additional flooding of area roads.
Flooding on Interstate 35 at mile markers 318 and 322.
Flooding on Interstate 35 at mile marker 306.
A small bridge was washed out.
The public reported that water was flowing over the curbs on Cedar Street in Pecos.

Madera Canyon, near Fort Davis, which was affected by wildfires in May, experienced heavy rains during the early evening on Saturday, August 20.  This resulted in rapid flash flooding and necessitated the high water rescue of fifteen hikers.  However, no injuries were reported.

The Colorado river near Silver flooded due to heavy rains upstream of Silver the afternoon before. The river gauge at Silver rose above the 15 foot flood stage just before 10 P.M. local time and crested at 17.32 feet just before midnight. The river fell back below flood stage near 3 A.M. the following morning.
Showers and thunderstorms continued to repeatedly move over the same areas producing more flash flooding across much of Nolan County. County roads 170 and 236 were closed due to flooding.

Numerous vehicles were swept into Mountain Creek along highway 16...about 1 mile south of Comanche.  Water rescues were performed...however two bodies were found in the creek.  Also, a couple who lived along the creek lost their home to the flood waters.  Highway 16 was closed between the Comanche and Mills county line.
Turkey Creek came out of its banks in Thorndale, causing road closures.  Also, FM 486 near Conoley was closed at Little River.

Numerous roads were underwater and barricaded across the northwestern portion of the county.  In Killeen, the following roads were closed: Imperial Drive, Elms Road, Shawn Drive, and the intersection of 28th and Avenue H.  In Harker Heights, Indian Trail was barricaded at at least two intersections, as was Morning Glen, Greenlee, and Misty Lane.  Cemetery Road and Berry Road in Moffat were also closed.
A woman was swept into Greenbriar Creek while trying to cross on foot.
The intersection of county roads 306 and 307 was flooded as well as a few other nearby roads.
Route 320 underwater near Westphalia.
FM 2495 closed between Cisco and Putnam due to flooding.  Numerous other streets flooded in Cisco.
Interstate 35 was closed due to high water.  Reported by the Lampasas Department of Public Safety.
Widespread street flooding in town.
Highway 16 near Priddy closed due to high water.  Water was also flowing over Highway 183 near Mullin.
Flooding of roads near Spring Creek.
Portions of Interstate 30 were underwater.  Street flooding was also reported in Sulphur Springs.
Five to ten inches of rain over the past couple of days produced a period of flooding in portions of Jones county, especially along highway 83 where various locations were inundated.
Another round of showers and thunderstorms on already saturated ground produced additional flooding in the community of Rule and flooded some homes.
Very heavy rains continued to fall on the western and southern portions of Nolan County producing flash flooding and causing several roads to become inundated.
Heavy rains associated with Hurricane Emily produced flash flooding of intersections near and around Nolana and 10th Streets.  Some of the water caused minor damage to businesses in the vicinity.

Thunderstorms over the north half of Burnet County dropped between 1 and 2 inches or rain, with up to 4 inches falling between Burnet and Okalla near the Lampasas County line. High water closed FM963 through the late morning.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell over northern Uvalde County.  Highest totals were 5 inches west of Concan. US55 was closed northwest of Uvalde. FM1050 was closed west of Utopia and FM187was closed near Utopia.
Runnels and Winters law enforcement officials reported up to a foot of water flooding streets in the town of Winters. Several vehicles stalled out in the flood waters.
Water covered roads near Sylvester for a few hours and one road had a culvert washed away.
City streets flooded rapidly in the city of Brownwood and numerous streets were closed.
One street reported with high water over it.
At 1:20 pm CST, a county emergency management official reported that Texas Farm Road 2393 was closed due to high water 6 to 8 inches deep near a local creek, 4 miles south of Jolly, TX.

A general 1 to 2 inch rain fell over Williamson County in the morning, with up to 6 inches northeast of Georgetown. About 3 miles northeast of Round Rock a vehicle became trapped in high water.  The occupants were rescued just before it washed off the roadway into deep water. Most rural roads in northern Williamson County were under water through the late morning and early afternoon.  Among roads closed were SH95 and FM338 north of Taylor.

Morning thunderstorms and showers in eastern Medina County produced widespread 2 to 3 inch totals.  Highest amounts were between 6 and 7 inches near Mico.  Roads in the Mico and Rio Medina areas were closed through the early afternoon, including FM2107.  Two homes were evacuated due to rising water in the Mico area.

Thunderstorms dropped up to 2 inches over much of the eastern half of Real County, with up to 4 inches falling east of Leakey.  FM337 was closed east of Leakey and FM336 was closed north of Leakey through the early afternoon.

Thunderstorms produced 1 to 2 inch rain amounts over the city of Austin, with isolated totals near 4 inches.  Low water crossings were closed at Lakewood Drive and Loop 360.  Four crossings were also reported closed by Austin Emergency Management north of Austin along Waters Park Road.

Thunderstorms formed from El Indio in southern Maverick County through Eagle Pass and northward into southwestern Kinney County.  They produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain over much of Maverick County, with up to 4 inches east of El Indio.  SH131 was closed due to high water near Normandy. FM1908 was closed near Quemado, and FM2644 was closed east of El Indio.

Thunderstorms formed from El Indio in southern Maverick County through Eagle Pass and northward into southwestern Kinney County.  They produced general 1 inch totals over the southwest part of the county, with up to 3 inches along US277 west of Spofford. FM693 was closed due to high water through the mid afternoon.
Simms Creek and roads around it were closed due to flooding.
Nearly 10 inches of heavy rains over the past couple of days produced flooding of many roads over the western half of Throckmorton County.
State highway 158 was closed for a time west of Robert Lee due to flooding.
State highway 163 from Sterling City north to the county line was closed due to 2 feet of water reported on the highway.

At 1:35 pm CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas State Highway 240 was impassable due to flooding along a tributary of China Creek at the intersection with old Lake Road, one mile west of Haynesville, TX. The Crooked Creek Golf Course was also flooded and closed during the event.

Moderate flooding occurred along Beaver Creek in Wilbarger and western Wichita counties on August 15-18. Storm total precipitation amounts of 3 to 7 inches kept Beaver Creek in flood for over 3 days and produced two crests above flood stage. An initial crest of 27.2 feet, 3.2 feet above flood stage, occurred at 10:00 am CST on August 15, but more rainfall on August 15-16 produced a second, higher crest of 27.3 feet, 3.3 feet above flood stage, at 8:30 am CST on August 17.  Beaver Creek remained above flood stage from 12:00 am CST on August 15 to 6:00 am CST on August 18. Some secondary roads and agricultural lands near the creek were inundated during this period.

Locally heavy rainfall amounts produced flash flooding in the Wichita Falls area during the mid morning hours of August 15. At 8:25 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that numerous roads were closed due to high water from small creeks and localized street flooding. Old Iowa Park Road and Texas Farm Road 369 were closed about five miles northwest of Wichita Falls, TX. Cars were stalled in Wichita Falls at the intersection of Ruskin and Lansing. Cottonwood Road was also closed in Wichita Falls due to flash flooding.

Showers and thunderstorms again reformed in Medina County in the early afternoon, producing an additional inch of rain over the south part of the county. Between 2 and 3 inches fell in the area from D'Hanis to Hondo to Yancey.  Flash flooding developed quickly over the saturated soils, closing FM2200 between D'Hanis and Yancey and FM462 between Hondo and Yancey.

Showers and thunderstorms produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain over northwestern Burnet County.  The heaviest rain fell north of SH29 and west of FM693, where up to 4 inches was reported.  In the mid morning, the Sheriff's Department closed US281 around 10 miles north of Burnet due to flash flooding.

Showers and thunderstorms that formed in northeast Atascosa County in the early afternoon were very slow-moving through the mid afternoon period.  They produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall in the northeast part of the county, with highest totals of 4 inches just east of Espey. Roads were closed due to high water from Espey and Leming northeastward to the Bexar County line, including FM536 and FM1784.

Showers and thunderstorms through the late morning and early afternoon in southeast Bexar County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals.  Highest amounts were 3 inches southeast of Losoya to where Priest Road intersects IH-37 south of Loop 1604.  Mathis Road just west of IH-37 near the 122 mile marker was closed due to flash flooding along West Lucas Creek.
At 3:00 pm CST, a county law enforcement official reported that floodwaters from Holliday Creek had covered Texas Farm Road 368 at the intersection with Gose City Road, 5 miles south of Holliday TX.

Showers and thunderstorms formed in the early evening over western Medina and northern Frio Counties.  They showed little movement through the evening, weakening and dissipating near midnight. The storms produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain in the northeast part of Frio County.  The highest accumulation was 4 inches near Big Foot. FM462 and FM472 were closed due to high water near Big Foot.

After showers and thunderstorms had dissipated near midnight, additional storms began to develop in the early morning hours across the central part of the county.  This activity began to dissipate in the mid morning, after having produced between 1 and 2 inch rain totals across central Medina County.  Maximum rainfall totals were 4 inches near D'Hanis, where soils were already saturated from the previous night's rainfall. FM1796 was closed again north of D'Hanis.

Slow-moving showers and thunderstorms formed in southwestern Travis County in the late morning and produced a general 1 inch rain over the area.  Highest rain totals were 3 inches just east of Bee Cave. FM2244 was closed due to flash flooding just east of Bee Cave.

Showers and thunderstorms formed in the early evening over western Medina and northern Frio Counties.  They showed little movement through the evening, weakening and dissipating near midnight. The storms produced a general 1 inch rain over the west and central parts of Medina County, with the heaviest amounts near 3 inches just north of D'Hanis and near Yancey. FM1796 was closed north of D'Hanis. Flash flooding closed FM2200 and FM462 near Yancey.

At 1:15 pm CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that floodwaters from the West Fork Bluff Creek and West Fork Sunflower Creek had washed over Texas Farm Road 1811 between Texas Farm Road 2326 and the Wilbarger County line, 6 miles southeast of Harrold, TX.
At 1:25 pm CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that floodwaters from Adams Creek had washed over Texas Farm Road 1763, one mile south of Elliott, TX.

Minor to moderate rural flooding occurred along the Brazos River and its tributaries in Knox and Baylor counties on August 16-18. The Brazos River at Seymour, TX crested at approximately 18.6 feet, 6.6 feet above flood stage, at 11:00 am CST on August 17, and remained above flood stage from 7:00 am CST on August 16 to 12:00 am CST on August 19.Millers Creek, a tributary to the Brazos River that runs northward into southern Baylor, also saw heavy rainfall. Rainfall totals of 7 to 10+ inches fell over the headwaters of Millers Creek which is upstream of the Millers Creek Reservoir that straddles the Throckmorton/Baylor county line. Major inflows into Millers Creek Reservoir caused the lake elevation to rise above the conservation pool elevation and eventually the emergency spillway elevation. Millers Creek Reservoir crested at a record elevation of 1342.52 feet MSL at 12:00 pm CST on August 18. The flood flows from Millers Creek eventually traveled into the Brazos River, and exacerbated flooding on the Brazos River in extreme southern Baylor County, and at points further downstream.A second round of flooding also occurred along the South Wichita and Wichita Rivers on August 16-17 (first round Aug. 14-15). Minor rural flooding occurred again along these rivers. The South Wichita River in Knox County near Benjamin, TX had a second flood crest of 14.5 feet which occurred at 1:00 pm CST on August 16, and remained above flood stage from 1:30 am CST to 9:45 pm CST on August 16. The Wichita River in Baylor county near Seymour, TX and just upstream of Lake Kemp had a second, higher crest of 16.5 feet which occurred at 5 pm CST on August 16. The river remained above flood stage from 9:00 am CST on August 16 to 9:00 am CST August 17. The heavy runoff from the Wichita and South Wichita Rivers was beneficial for the Wichita Falls area as the reservoir levels at Lake Kemp rose to within a foot of the conservation pool level.The Little Wichita River basin in Archer and Clay counties also saw significant rises during mid August. The reservoir levels increased at both Lake Kickapoo and Lake Arrowhead. Moderate to major flooding occurred along the Little Wichita River in Archer County between Lake Kickapoo and Lake Arrowhead near Archer City, TX on August 16-19. The Wichita River crested at 25.37 feet (flood stage unknown) at 7:00 am CST on August 17. This flood crest was the tenth highest crest of record at the USGS gage site. The flooding occurred from 6:00 pm CST on August 16 to 12:00 pm CST on August 19.Moderate to major rural flooding also occurred along the Little Wichita River in Clay County near Henrietta, TX on August 16-20. The Little Wichita River crested at 23.5 feet, 6.5 feet above flood stage, at 8:30 pm CST on August 18, and remained above flood stage from 11:00 am CST on August 16 to 3:30 am CST on August 20. Some secondary roads and agricultural lands near the river were inundated during this period.
At 10:30 am CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that U.S. Highway 183 was closed due to high water along Millers Creek, 9 miles south of Seymour, TX.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas State Highway 422 was closed due to floodwaters along Godwin Creek, 17 miles east of Seymour near the Archer County line.
The Baylor County Emergency Manager reported flooding along Seymour Creek through the east side of Seymour. Seymour Creek inundated local roads and half of Seymour City Park in Seymour.
At 10:30 am CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas Farm Road 2070 was closed due to floodwaters along several creeks, including Lake Creek, 3 miles north of Bomarton, TX.

California Creek to the east of Stamford flooded due to the very heavy rains of around 10 inches the past several days. California Creek rose above its 28 foot flood stage around 3 P.M. local time on the 16th and crested to near 28.44 feet just before 10 P.M. on the 16th.  The river the fell below flood stage on the morning of the 17th around 5 A.M. local time.
Flash flooding of town streets was reported due to heavy rains from Hurricane Emily.

At 10:30 am CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that one lane on U.S. Highway 287 near Texas Farm Road 369 was closed due to floodwaters from the West Fork of Pond Creek, 2 miles east of Iowa Park. One vehicle had also been washed off of U.S. Highway 287.
After the thunderstorms ended across Throckmorton County around 10 A.M. on the 16th, area roads continued to remain flooded for another 24 hours.

Law enforcement officials reported many roads across Fisher County were flooded from Sunday August 14th through August 17th. On the 14th, up to 3 feet of water was reported on the roads in Rotan. Many vehicles were also stalled in Rotan in the high water. Numerous roads around the county had water on them and several were closed. Heavy rains to near 10 inches over the past couple of days combined to produce flooding of many roads over the western half of Throckmorton County. Five to ten inches of rain over the past couple of days had combined to produce a period of flooding in portions of Jones county, especially along highway 83 where various locations were inundated.The Colorado river near Silver flooded due to heavy rains upstream of Silver the afternoon before. The river gauge at Silver rose above the 15 foot flood stage just before 10 P.M. local time and crested to 17.32 feet just before midnight. The river fell below flood stage near 3 A.M. the following morning. The North Concho river at Sterling City flooded due to heavy rains of up to 10 inches in the upper reaches of the North Concho river basing.
