The river gauge at Sterling City shows the river going above the 17 foot flood stage around 630 A.M. local time and cresting at 7 A.M. The river receded below flood stage at 8 A.M. The North Concho river at Carlsbad flooded due to very heavy rains of up to 10 inches in the upper reaches of the river basin as well as local rainfall amounts of 5 to 10 inches. The river rose above the 12 foot flood stage just after noon on the 15th and crested at 15.53 feet around 6:15 P.M. local time. The river feel below flood stage just before 3 A.M. on the 16th.  This caused some secondary roads to flood at low water crossings. Grape Creek in northern Tom Green County also caused some flooding of secondary roads to the east of Carlsbad.Law enforcement reported numerous roads including highway 380 and U.S. 277 from Stamford to Haskell were flooded from Sunday August 14th until August 17th. On Sunday August 14th, Red Cross and local law enforcement reported that several homes were flooded in Rule. From Monday August 15th through August 17th rapidly rising waters from Lake Stamford flooded About 70 homes around the lake. Heavy rains of 10 to 12 inches over much of Haskell county caused the lake to rise 7 vertical feet in one night. Due to the recently low lake levels, homes were placed well into the lake bed causing about 70 homes around the lake to flood shortly after going over the principle spillway and well before it trickled over the emergency spillway. Approximately 150 people were displaced from their homes as many of the homes had five feet of water in them. Very heavy rains of 5 to 10 inches over the past several days produced flooding over much of Jones county. Numerous roads were closed for several days due to the high water and Lake Stamford just to the north of Jones County continued to rise. After the thunderstorms ended across Throckmorton County around 10 A.M. on the 16th area roads continued to remain flooded for another 24 hours after the rains had ended.

At 5:50 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that water was running into houses in downtown Munday due to localized flash flooding. Emergency management personnel in Munday assisted stranded motorists during the flash flooding, and helped rescue dogs from a local veterinarian clinic that were stranded in floodwaters up to 1.5 feet high.
At 5:50 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that water had run into some homes in Knox City during this period.
At 6:42 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that a car was stalled in high water on Texas State Highway 114, one mile southeast of Megargel.

At 7:30 am CST, a county law enforcement official reported that Texas State Highway 267 was completely under water due to flooding from the Brazos River, 7 miles north-northwest of Munday, TX, and that all roads in the county were closed due to high water.

At 11:15 am CST and 11:55 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that U.S. Highway 287 was closed due to high water along Bennett Creek 1.5 miles and 4 miles southeast of Jolly, TX. At 1:20 pm CST, a county emergency management official reported that the southbound lane was still closed on U.S. Highway 287 due to the high water.
Heavy rains from the outer rainbands of Hurricane Emily produced flash flooding that resulted in the closing of Highway 4 seven miles north of F.M. Road 511.

Thunderstorms with heavy rainfall trained across far eastern San Patricio, Aransas, and southern Refugio counties.  Doppler radar estimated between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell across Aransas county in a 1 to 2 hour timeframe, resulting in flooding of several roadways in and around Rockport.  Most notable was the State Highway 35 bypass at Market Street.

At 9:10 am CST and 10:30 am CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas State Highway 210 was closed due to floodwaters from the Middle Fork of the Little Wichita River, 9 miles west of Archer City, and the South Fork of the Little River, 2 miles west of Archer City.
At 10:30 am CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas State Highway 422 was closed due to floodwaters along Briar Creek and Kickapoo Creek 14 miles west of Archer City.
At 10:30 am CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas Farm Road 368 was closed due to floodwaters along Panther Creek, 4 miles south of Holliday, TX.

At 7:40 am CST, a county law enforcement official reported that Texas State Highway 114 was closed between Seymour and 3 miles southeast of Seymour due to high water along Rock Creek and Little Rock Creek.

Minor rural flooding occurred along the South Wichita River in Knox County near Benjamin, TX on August 14-15. The South Wichita River crested at 14.0 feet, 2.0 feet above flood stage, at 6:45 pm CST on August 14, and remained above flood stage from 9:00 am CST on August 14 to 12:30 am CST on August 15.Further downstream below the confluence of the South Wichita River with the Wichita River, minor rural flooding occurred along the Wichita River in Baylor County near Seymour, TX and just upstream of Lake Kemp on August 14-15. The Wichita River crested at 16.2 feet (flood stage unknown) at 10:00 pm CST on August 14. The area remained flooded from approximately 6:00 pm CST August 14 to 6:00 am CST August 15.

Flash flooding initially occurred along the South Wichita River in Knox County during the afternoon of August 14 when the river overtopped its banks, 4 miles north of Benjamin, and flooded areas near the river.

A local radio station reported that flash flooding was inundating yards and businesses in Alpine.  The public reported nearly half a foot of water running over Holland Street.  Portions of Eighth Street also were closed due to flash flooding.
At 10:45 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that Texas State Highway 222 was closed by floodwaters along Lake Creek, 3 miles southeast of Munday, TX.
At 10:45 am CST, a local law enforcement official reported that Texas Farm Road 2365 was closed due to 3 feet of water over roadway from a local creek 4 miles east of Knox City, TX.
Additional heavy rains produced another round of flooding across northern Sterling County. This caused some roads to become flooded again that had dried out from the day before.
At 1:00 pm CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that major flooding along China Creek had closed Texas State Highway 25, one mile south of Haynesville, TX.

Very heavy rains of around 6 inches fell in addition to 6 inches of rain that had already fallen the past two days to produce flash flooding near the Rotan area.  High water was reported across many low lying areas of Rotan. Highway 611 west of Rotan was also closed.
Water flooded homes and businesses along Walker Street.
Several vehicles stranded due to high water over roads.
Numerous streets flooded with several cars stranded in town.

Very heavy rains of 5 to 10 inches over the past several days produced flooding over much of Jones county. Numerous roads were closed for several days due to the high water as Lake Stamford continued to rise.

A period of very heavy rains in the morning hours produced flash flooding over a good portion of Throckmorton County. Most of the main highways were closed in and out of Throckmorton during this event.

Thunderstorms formed in the mid morning over southern Edwards County and most of Kinney County, spreading by late morning into western Real County and southern Val Verde County.  The storms produced general 1 inch totals over the four county area, with 2 inch amounts over much of Kinney County and 4 inch totals near Brackettville. Most of the rural roads in Kinney County were reported to be closed due to flash flooding through the mid and late afternoon.
Street flooding reported in SE Dallas and Mesquite.

Numerous roads closed due to flooding in and around town.  Some roads were washed away.  High water rescues were needed for people stranded in cars.  Several homes were evacuated as well.  The bridge on FM 107 at Station Creek suffered minor damage.
Flash flooding reported along Interstate 35 between Waco and Bruceville-Eddy.
Two to three inches of rain resulted in flooding from downtown El Paso to the eastern portion of the city.Several street closures were reported by law enforcement.

The thunderstorms in Uvalde County continued to spread eastward through the late night hours. They began producing heavy rain just before midnight in the southwest part of Medina County, where between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell. FM2200 was closed due to high water between D'Hanis and Yancey.

Heavy rain over eastern Bandera County spread into the western part of the county in the mid morning, producing between 1 and 3 inches.  Highest totals were 5 inches east of Vanderpool. FM187 and FM337 in the western part of the county under water through late morning.
Flooding on FM 147.
Fast moving water over Highway 77 south of Golinda.

The public reported nearly half a foot of water flowing across a county road north of Westbrook.  Water also was accumulating under the overpasses on Interstate 20.  The Mitchell county sheriff's office reported that county roads 145, 147, and 149 were "flowing like a river" in northeastern parts of the county.  They were in the process of barricading those roads.  Also reported was an 18-wheeler that hydroplaned on the wet pavement of Interstate 20 a mile west of Loraine.
The Pecos County emergency manager reported flash flooding along 22 miles of Farm to Market Road 2119.

The Snyder Police department reported widespread flooding of streets in Snyder and on rural roads around Snyder.  Several cars had floated off roads into bar ditches.  One high water rescue was performed by local officials in Snyder.
Flash flooding in and around Harker Heights.  Highway 190 under water and barricaded in several places.  At least three homes were evacuated.  Vehicles were stranded across the county.
The Colorado City Police Department and the Mitchell County Sheriff's Office reported that low-lying intersections in the city had six inches of water running across them.

Showers and thunderstorms over eastern Kendall County began producing heavy rainfall in the early morning hours, with between 2 and 3 inches falling over the east half of the county.  Highest totals were 6 inches near Kendalia.  Most rural roads in Kendall County were under water through the morning, including FM1376 and FM474 between Boerne and Sisterdale.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell during the early morning hours over the eastern tips of Bandera County, with additional rain falling through the mid morning hours.  Up to 5 inches fell in the Pipe Creek area.  FM1283 was closed due to high water through the early afternoon.

Thunderstorms across northern Bexar and southern Comal Counties produced a general 2 to 3 inch rainfall along the county line.  Highest totals in Bexar County were 6 inches between Leon Springs and Helotes.  Most rural roads in the northern half of rural Bexar were closed through the noon period, including the SH46 and US281 intersection just south of Bulverde.

Thunderstorms across northern Bexar and southern Comal Counties produced a general 2 to 3 inch rainfall along the county line.  Highest totals in Comal County were 6 inches around Bulverde. Most rural roads in the southern half of Comal County were closed through the late morning.
Roads under two feet of water.
The Colorado City Police Department reported that a road through Ruddick Park was barricaded due to flash flooding.

Very heavy rain in a short time caused water to cover portions of highway 206 in Cross Plains. State highway crews had to put out pylons to route traffic around flooded roads. Numerous unimproved roads were washed and eroded away by flood waters.

Flash flooding was reported in all low lying areas of Snyder.  Additionally, Farm to Market Road 612 between Snyder and Fluvanna was inundated by flood waters.  The Snyder Fire Department reported that 26th Street in Snyder was submerged and barricaded due to flash flooding.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported water flowing over Farm to Market Road 33 between Texas Highway 158 and Farm to Market Road 2401.

A Big Spring police unit was stranded in two feet of water at a low water crossing on Old Colorado City Highway.  Other secondary roads were inundated by flash flooding.  The intersection of U.S. Highway 87 and Farm to Market Road 33 had nearly half a foot of water running over it.

The thunderstorms in Kinney and Maverick County spread northeastward into western Zavala County in the early afternoon.  They dropped between 1 and 2 inches of rain across the area, with up to 3 inches just west of LaPryor. Flash flooding was reported at low water crossings along US57 east of LaPryor and US83 north of LaPryor.
The Odessa Fire Department reported that a police cruiser was stalled in high water.  Local bus service also was cancelled due to water covered roadways.
The Borden County sheriff reported that floodwaters inundated most of the Farm to Market roads in the county.
FM 1702 from Indian Gap to the Comanche county line closed due to high water over the roadway.
The Texas Department of Public Safety reported that water was flowing over most roads in northern Reagan county.

Thunderstorms developed in the morning between Lometa in Lampasas County, Killeen in Bell County, and Rockdale in Milam County.  As these storms moved southward into Williamson County, they produced a general 2 to 3 inch total over the western portion of the county.  Highest rain amounts were 5 inches near Andice.  Most rural roads in northwest Williamson County were reported to be under water through the mid and late morning.

Thunderstorms that formed in the morning between Lometa in Lampasas County and Killeen in Bell County moved southward into Burnet County, producing general 3 to 4 inch rainfall. FM2657 and FM693 were reported closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms that formed in the morning between Killeen in Bell County, Rockdale in Cameron County and Caldwell in Burleson County moved southward into Lee County through the mid morning.  They produced widespread 1 to 2 inch rainfall along the Williamson County line, increasing to 3 to 4 inches near Lexington. Flash flooding developed along Middle Yegua Creek, closing low water crossings on FM112 and FM696 north and west of Lexington.

The public reported over half a foot of water running across the intersection of Texas Highway 329 and Farm to Market Road 1601.  The Crane county Sheriff's office reported water flowing over low water crossings across the county.
Flooding in and around the town of Groveton. Flood waters on Highways 287, 94, and FM Road 355.

The Glasscock County Sheriff's Office reported that water depth across Farm to Market Road 2401 and Texas Highway 137 was over half a foot.  The public reported that nearly half a foot of water was running across Coop Road northeast of St. Lawrence.
Several roads flooded and closed off in and around Lampasas.  Cars were stranded in the flood waters.

The Upton County Sheriff's Office reported flash flooding along portions of Texas Highway 349 north of Rankin.  The local broadcast media reported one foot of water running over Farm to Market Road 2401 just outside of Midkiff and three feet of water running over Texas Highway 349 in northern Upton County.  The Texas Department of Transportation closed Farm to Market Road 1357 near Midkiff because of two feet of water running over it.

The following intersections were flooded in Ennis: Lampasas Street and Gaines Street, Northwest Main Street at Baylor Street, Creechville Road and Interstate 45, and State Highway 34 and Interstate 45.  The 900 block of Martin Luther King was also flooded.  Roads in Palmer were beneath several inches of water.
Flooding caused people to abandon their vehicles and a building roof to collapse.  Flooding was also reported in at least one home.
Several cars were stranded in two-foot deep water.  Three inches of rain fell in 45 minutes.

Thunderstorms that formed in Kinney County continued to move eastward through the evening hours.  They produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain from southwest Uvalde County southward into northwest Zavala County.  Up to 4 inches fell near Dabney, producing flash flooding that closed FM481 and FM1022 through the late evening.

Thunderstorms that formed in Kinney County continued to move eastward through the evening hours.  They produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain from southwest Uvalde County southward into northwest Zavala County.  FM481 was closed through the late evening in the northwest corner of Zavala county.

The Odessa Fire Department performed three high water rescues, two at the intersection of West County Road and Interstate 20 and the other on the service road of Interstate 20 just north of the intersection with Meadow Avenue.  Other roads in Odessa affected by flooding included: 36th Street and Dixie.

The Ector County Sheriff's Office reported that the intersection of Mockingbird and Atura Streets in Odessa had caved in due to floodwaters.  The frontage road of Interstate 20 was covered by one foot of water, just west of Odessa.
Numerous city streets were flooded.

Morning showers and thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over the eastern half of Atascosa county.  Highest amounts were 4 inches near Pleasanton and also near Campbellton.  FM541 was closed north of Campbellton and FM140 and FM791 were closed southwest of Campbellton along Atascosa River.

Late morning thunderstorms over northeast Dimmit County produced between 3 and 4 inches of rain in the Big Wells area. FM1019 and FM468 were closed briefly southeast of Big Wells due to flash flooding.

In the early afternoon, the thunderstorms moving eastward from the Del Rio area to Brackettville had slowed.  They then began to spread southeastward into southern Kinney county.  The storms brought general 1 to 2 inch rainfall from the Val Verde County line to Spofford.  Highest rain totals were near 5 inches, about 5 miles west of Spofford. FM693 and FM1908 were closed west of Spofford through most of the afternoon.

Showers and thunderstorms produced a general 1 inch rainfall in the area from Hallettsville to Sheridan to Speaks.  Highest totals were near 3 inches just north of Speaks.  FM530 and FM2437 were closed along Navidad River through the mid afternoon.

Thunderstorms moved northeastward out of Mexico on the morning of the 12th and increased rapidly in intensity while slowing over the city of Del Rio.  By 11 am the city had received up to 4 inches of rain and flash flooding was reported in the downtown area.  Shortly after noon, rain totals had reached up to 7 inches in Del Rio.  Emergency management officials reported that several cars had been caught in the flood waters.  Fortunately, no one was injured or killed.  The storms began to dissipate in the mid afternoon and by late afternoon the flash flooding had ended.
High water was reported across numerous streets and highways across the southwest side of the county.

The thunderstorms in the Loma Alta area continue to spread eastward, bringing general 1 to 2 inch totals from north of Carta Valley to near Rocksprings, eventually including the northern half of Edwards County.  Highest rain totals were 5 inches around 10 miles west of Rocksprings. US377 was closed west of Rocksprings and SH55 was closed northwest of Rocksprings due to high water.

As the thunderstorms in the Del Rio area spread eastward and expanded in the late morning and early afternoon, they produced widespread rainfall of between 1 and 2 inches between Del Rio and Brackettville.  The heaviest rainfall was near 5 inches just northwest of Brackettville. FM3008 was closed along Sycamore Creek near the Val Verde County line.  FM674 was closed north of Brackettville, and FM334 was closed northeast of Brackettville near West Fork of Nueces River.

Additional thunderstorms began forming north of Del Rio in the area from Juno to north of Loma Alta.  These storms dropped general rain amounts between 1 and 2 inches during the morning.  Highest rain totals were near 5 inches in the area about 20 miles north of Loma Alta.  SH277 was closed due to flash flooding through the early and mid afternoon.

The showers and thunderstorms in southern Kinney County continued to spread southward, moving into northwestern Maverick County in the early afternoon.  By mid afternoon, rain totals were between 1 and 2 inches over the western part of Maverick County.  The Sheriff's Department reported US277 closed near Normandy due to water over the road.  Many of the county rural roads were flooded in by late afternoon, including SH131 closed due to high water about 20 miles north of Eagle Pass.

Thunderstorms from Edwards County continued to spread eastward into Real County in the mid afternoon.  By late afternoon the area from Camp Wood to Leakey had received between 1 and 2 inches of rain, with 3 inches in many locations.  Flash flooding forced the closing of US55 at Camp Wood and FM337 between Camp Wood and Leakey.
A few city streets had to be closed due to excessive heavy rainfall and the resulting high water.
The local broadcast media reported flooding on several major roads in Odessa, including Dixie, 42nd Street, and Muskingum.
A trained spotter reported that all county roads were under water near Greenwood.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported half a foot of water flowing over the north frontage road of Business 20 at the intersection of Loop 250 and Business 20.

Two off-duty National Weather Service employees reported up to one and a half feet of running water over the intersection of Polo Parkway and Caldera and portions of Wadley Ave. between Midland Dr. and Midkiff Rd.  The Department of Public Safety also reported that the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1788 and Business 20 was under water.
The Reagan County Sheriff's Office reported water running over portions of Farm to Market Road 1675 near Texon.

A trained spotter reported one and a half feet of water on County Road 2600 running over a railroad crossing.  The public also reported six to eight inches of water running over U.S. Highway 67 in Texon.
Flooding in Porter with numerous roads impassable.
Flooded streets in and around Hardin.
Water was over the roadway near the Jones Road Bridge.
Hwy. 80 was barricaded due to high water from excessive rainfall.
Flooding in and around the Houston area from 3.50 to 4.00 inches of rain. Water was up to one foot deep in Clear Lake area.
8.46 inches of rainfall fell across Center, Texas as a result of Hurricane Rita.  The excessive heavy rainfall led to widespread flooding through the city with numerous roads underwater.
Flooding was reported across Hwy 96 just south of Center as the outer feeder bands of Hurricane Rita moved northward into east central Texas.

Thunderstorms and showers produced rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches over parts of western north Texas during the evening of October 5 and morning of October 6 and produced minor to moderate flooding along the Little Wichita River in Archer and Clay counties. The USGS river gage site recorded a crest of 23.9 feet, 1.9 feet above flood stage around 1:00 am CST on October 8, and the river remained at flood stage from 11:30 am CST on October 6 to 2:30 am CST on October 9.Further downstream on the Little Wichita River and just downstream of Lake Arrowhead, the USGS river gage site near Henrietta, TX also recorded a crest above flood stage on October 8. The Little Wichita River near Henrietta crested at 20.5 feet, 2.5 feet above flood stage, at 3:00 pm CST on October 8, and remained above flood stage from 12:30 pm CST to 9:30 pm CST on October 8. Only minor lowland flooding occurred along the Little Wichita River in Archer and Clay counties during this event, and beneficial inflows into Lake Arrowhead helped raise lake elevations and conservation storage in the reservoir.

Numerous city streets flooded on south side of Corpus Christi.  Up to 1 foot of water was observed over the frontage road of S.P.I.D. at Everhart.  Radar estimates, as well local rainfall spotters, confirmed 3 to 5 inches of rain fell across much of the south side of Corpus Christi.

Heavy rainfall led to flash flooding of numerous city streets throughout Laredo.  A few cars became stuck in the water, leading to high water rescues.  At one point, water was over Loop 20 near the Laredo International Airport.  1.72 inches of rainfall was recorded at the airport in 33 minutes.

An NWS storm survey that was docummenting wind damage in Rosita observed indications that a flash flood occurred along Rosita Creek in the town of Rosita.  Residents also confirmed that the low water crossing over the creek became impassable.
FM Road 915 from Mertzon to Eldorado was flooded in both southeastern Irion County and northwest Schleicher County.
FM Road 915 flooded for a time in Northwestern Schleicher County.
A cluster of thunderstorms dropped 1.5 to 3 inches of rain on mainly east El Paso, where numerous water rescues were performed due to major street flooding.
Over 5 inches of rain fell in Olney, and 6 inches were reported east of town.  Several roads were barricaded.
The Reagan County Sheriff's Office reported one foot of water running over Texas Highway 137 between Stiles and Farm to Market Road 33.
Local newscast showed video of flooded streets with police officers closing intersections.
Flash flooding along San Martine Draw inundated County Road 225 with water.  This was reported by the Reeves County Emergency Manager.
Water covering the road along Farm to Market 46.

The Odessa Police Department reported that a motorist was stranded in the intersection of Muskingum and 11th Streets.  This motorist remained stranded for 45 minutes because the water was too high for rescuers to reach him.
A NWS trained spotter reported six inches of flowing water at the intersection of Andrews Highway and Midkiff Road.

Thunderstorms moved into the Austin area near sunrise and became nearly stationary over the area for the next four hours.  Rainfall accumulations reached general 1 to 2 inches in the western half of the city by 8 am, with an additional inch of rain falling by 9 am.  Media and emergency responders reported that many of the streets in the city were running curb-deep with the usual low water crossings flooded.  Authorities noted that Shoal Creek rose briefly out of its banks. Several crossings were closed in the morning period over Spicewood Springs Rd.

Thunderstorms formed along a slow-moving cold front in the mid afternoon as it crossed Lavaca County.  The storms produced between 1 and 2 inches per hour, with accumulations of up to 4 inches southeast of Sweet Home near where FM531 intersects US77.  The Sheriff's Department reported that FM531 was closed due to flash flooding in the area of US77 through the early evening.
Scatter Creek flooding over FM 909.  Cut Hand Creek flooding over FM 1487.  Mustang Creek flooding over FM 410.  All roads were closed for a period of time.

Mid afternoon thunderstorms produced general 1inch rainfall in the Pflugerville area, with up to 3 inches falling in isolated locations.  The police department reported numerous streets closed through the late afternoon due to flash flooding.
Flooding reported along FM 116.
Water over FM 1838 and Highway 79 between Buffalo and Oakwood at Keechie Creek.
Flooding reported in Sherman and also on numerous farm roads between Denison and Pottsboro, including Lewis Lane and FM 121.

Late afternoon thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over the northern part of Gillespie County, with the maximum totals of up to 3 inches near Doss and just west of Willow City.  Flash flooding forced the closure of FM965 and FM648 through the evening.

Early evening thunderstorms spreading eastward from Gillespie County dropped general 1 to 2 inch rains over the central part of Blanco County.  Highest totals were 3 inches between Blanco and Johnson City.  Flash flooding closed FM1323 and FM2766 through much of the evening.

General 1 to 2 inch rainfall across the city of San Antonio, with up to 5 inches in places, produced widespread flash flooding.  As many as 18 rescues were required in one hour alone. Flash flooding was reported over much of the city, with some of the worst near IH10 and Wurzbach Road, as well as in the Olmos Creek area  near Basse Road and US281.  A tourist bus was stranded in high water in downtown San Antonio near US281, prompting the rescue of 47 passengers.  By shortly after midnight, as many as 18 ladder trucks and half of the city's fleet of pumper trucks, 49 of them, were involved in rescues.  Fire officials commented that this was the city's heaviest rain since the October flood of 1998.
General 1 to 2 inch rainfall, with spotty totals to 4 inches caused flash flooding between Fredericksburg and Doss, closing several roads. Including FM648 and FM783.

A general 1 to 2 inch rain fell over Gillespie County in the early morning hours, with highest totals of 4 inches just west of Willow City.  Many of the secondary roads were closed due to flash flooding, including FM648 and FM966.

Locally intense rainfall over the city of Post resulted in flash flooding along U.S. Highway 380. Fire crews rescued motorists from a submerged vehicle after it was washed off of the highway in flowing flood waters up to one and half feet deep. No injuries were reported.
Storms dropped between 2 and 3 inches of rain in the Twin Sisters area just before sunrise, resulting in flash flooding that closed FM473 as well as other rural roads.
Early morning showers produced 2 inches of rain that caused flash flooding where Cottonwood Creek crosses FM1339 southwest of Staples.
Thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over Kendall County.  Up to 4 inches was reported 10 miles northeast of Sisterdale. The resulting flash flooding closed FM473 and FM1888.

Several roads were washed out due to flood waters, including FM 456, FM 460, and FM 937 near Groesbeck.  Parts of a railroad crossing were also washed away near FM 456.  Also, CR 463 near Mexia was barricaded, as was FM 462 and CR 243, due to flood waters.
Highway 84 West near the Limestone/Freestone border were barricaded due to flooding.
FM 1956 between Nocona and Nocona Hills and numerous other county roads were closed due to flooding.  Some low lying homes were flooded.
Part of Interstate 35 was closed due to flash flooding.  One home was evacuated due to flooding.
Bear Creek Parkway closed due to high water.
A house was flooded with at least one to two feet of water in it.
Flooding was reported on Highway 281.
Highway 79 and FM 645 were closed due to high water.
Law enforcement officials reported major flooding at various locations across the city of Brownwood.  High water rescues were performed at several flooded intersections.

Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over the western part of Travis County, with up to 4 inches in the extreme west section.  Several rural roads were closed due to flash flooding, including FM2322.

Multiple, slow-moving thunderstorms traveled over southern Wichita County during the early morning hours of May 2 and dropped heavy rainfall amounts of 3 to 6+ inches in the area. The intense rains and subsequent heavy runoff caused some small creeks to overflow their banks and some local roads were closed by flash flooding in the southern Wichita County. At 525 AM CST, an emergency management official in Wichita County reported that numerous roads had been closed due to high water in and around the town of Iowa Park. Another report by Wichita County emergency management officials at 700 AM CST indicated that flash flooding was still present in and around Iowa Park, and that Farm-to-Market Roads 367 and 368 were closed in the vicinity of Iowa Park. In addition, emergency management officials reported that a 1-mile stretch Texas Farm-to-Market Road 368 was closed due to high waters from Antelope Creek about 3 miles southwest of Iowa Park.

Local broadcast media reported flooding at multiple locations in Midland, including the intersection of Midkiff Road and Wadley Avenue, the Wadley Avenue entrance to Midland College, and the intersection of Scharbauer Drive and Carver Street.
Several county and farm to market roads closed due to flooding, including CR 428, CR 425, CR 418, FM 1538 and FM 2295.  High water also reported on FM 625 near U.S. 281.|
The thunderstorm line produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain over northern Bastrop County, with up to 4 inches between the towns of McDade and Paige. Flash flooding closed SH95 and FM2336.

The thunderstorms dropped between 3 and 4 inches over Lee County, with totals of up to 8 inches near Mainheim as well as just west of Giddings.  Many rural roads in northern Lee County were closed.  Nearly all roads were reported to have been closed around Blue in northwest Lee County.

Rainfall in the thunderstorms averaged between 2 and 3 inches over Gillespie County.  The highest totals were 5 inches in Willow City in the northeast part of the county, as well as east of Harper in the west part of the county.  SH16, FM965, and FM1376 were closed due to high water.
Sheriff's office reported water flowing across U.S. 180 east of Seminole.

A 36 year old mother and her 16 year old daughter drowned in an SUV at the underpass of Interstate 45 and Tellepsen Road. The victims were discovered several hours later as flood waters began to slowly recede when law enforcement noticed the top of their vehicle. The SUV was pulled out of the water and the two victims were discovered in the back of the vehicle.
Two day rain totals of 12 to 16 inches resulted in long duration flooding across portions of Tyler County. The hardest hit areas were near Fred, where some roads weere flooded.
Highway 1293 was closed between Honey island and Thicket due to high water. Vehicles were stranded in the water. Water was approaching homes near Kountze.
Several underpasses were closed in Beaumont due to high water.
FM 1005 near Magnolia Springs, and FM 1408 near Jasper was closed due to high water.
US Highway 69 was closed near Rockland due to high water.

Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in numerous road closures including some secondary roads which were washed out. The rainfall which began during the late evening hours of the 15th and ended during the overnight hours of the 16th resulted in rainfall totals near 5 inches across the northern portion of the county to near 10.5 inches across the southern portion of the county.
Many roads near Silsbee were closed due to high waters.
Highway 96 and 62 near Buna were flooded. Highway 82 near Kirbyville was flooded.
Six to eight inches of water was reported over Highway 92 near Fred.
Excessive heavy rainfall led to flash flooding in town resulting in many city streets under water. Flooding was also reported along Hwy 705 and 1751 near the Ayish Bayou.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in numerous city streets under water.

Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in numerous flooded roadways with some roads having to be closed due to washout.  The rainfall which began during the evening hours of the 15th and ended during the overnight hours of the 16th resulted in rainfall totals near 6 inches across the northern portion of the county to near 10.5 inches in the southern portion of the county.
Several highways around Kountze were closed due to high water.
Feeder roads on Interstate 10 near Beaumont were closed due to high water. Cars were stranded in the deep water.
Thunderstorms produced an average 1 inch rain over the northern part of Blanco County, with up to 4 inches near Round Mountain.  Flash flooding closed FM962 and FM1323.
Rainfall over the northwest corner of Edwards County averaged around 1 inch, with isolated totals of up to 4 inches.  SH55 was closed due to flash flooding about 20 miles northwest of Rocksprings.

Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inches of rain from Lago Vista westward to the Burnet County line.  Highest amounts were 4 inches at Lago Vista. Law enforcement reported that FM2222 and FM1431were were closed due to flash flooding.

The line of thunderstorms stalled as it moved into central Williamson County, producing between 2 and 3 inches at most locations.  Highest totals were 5 inches between Granger and Thrall.  Officials reported that many of the county roads were closed due to flash flooding, including CR123, CR152, CR177, CR272, and Brushy Bend Drive.
Residential streets had 2-3 feet of water on them and were impassable.
County Road 1041 was closed due to high water.
Heavy rain caused numerous roads to flood. There were 10 to 15 road closures.
Widespread street flooding.
High water on portions of Bell Road.
High water rescue from vehicle on Walnut Creek Road outside of Stagecoach.
Water rescues at FM 249 and Hardin Store Road.

Four impassable roads in NW Cleveland; Joyce, Tony Tap, East Cherry Creek, and Meekins Roads were either closed or washed out due to flood waters. Two residential subdivisions were reported to be partially flooded.
Numerous roads flooded between Old Waverly and Evergreen.
Two road closures (150E and FM 1375 at Chicken Creek) due to heavy rainfall.
A portion of Bristol Rd. between Atlanta Dr. and Norwich Loop was closed due to drainage creek flooding over the roadway.

Significant flooding across county with several roads closed due to high water. Report of one flooded subdivision (Big Thicket Lakes). Flooding reported on FM 834 between the towns of Hardin and Hull, on State Road 321 between Cleveland and Dayton, and on FM 563 south of the town of Liberty. Other road closures include, but are not limited to, portions of FM 2518, FM 163, and FM 787.
Flash flooding was reported in and around Cleveland as secondary roads went under water.
FM 223 along with County Roads 2132 and 2212 were closed due to flooding.
Several roads in and around Cleveland remain closed due to flooding. FM 223 and Low Water Bridge Road near Cleveland, County Roads 2132 and 2212 along FM 787 remain closed due to high water.
Highway 244 closed due to high water. Flood water over several county-wide roads including, but not limited to, FM 2620 and portions of Highway 90.
FM 2989 between Interstate 45 and FM 247 was closed due to flooding.
County-wide roads closed due to high water. A few subdivisions (Wild Country & Big Thicket Estates) were flooded in and around the Livingston to Big Thicket area.
FM 3128 closed due to high water. Water over Shell Oil Road near FM 2025 in the Sam Houston National Forest.
FM 1485 closed due to high water. Flooding also reported on Ford Road between Highway 59 and Loop 494 between Humble and Woodbranch Village.

Flooded furniture store with six inches of water. Few Tomball area businesses and homes were reported flooded. Houston Flood Control District rain guages were measuring near four inch per hour rainfall rates.
Decker Oaks Subdivision flooding with units being evacuated.
Several Farm to Market roads underwater.

A school bus became stuck and required a high water rescue after attempting to cross a flooded low water crossing. The Fire Department responded and reported water up to their knees. Nobody was injured.
Heavy rain caused some street flooding and flooded a few homes.
Heavy rain caused widespread county and metro flooding of numerous roads. There were approximately 125 flooded homes and 92 flooded apartment units.
Heavy rains caused widespread flooding with water in homes. There were five water rescues from vehicles.
The 25 year old female driver of a vehicle drowned when she drove into a flooded ditch off of FM 1410. The vehicle turned upside down in the ditch.

A 56 year old male driver of a vehicle drowned when he lost control on a water covered roadway on FM 1462 near the Fort Bend-Brazoria County line. The vehicle overturned and landed upside down in a deep ditch filled with water. The victim was discovered after 6 AM.
One home received water damage due to flash flooding.

Approximately 115 homes flooded in several locations around the county including Pearland. Several roads flooded including County Road 5995 near Bastrop Bayou, Highway 36 and County Road 304 near Jones Creek, and near County Road 769B.
Heavy rains flooded numerous roads with one completely washed out. Two homes received minor flood damage.
Heavy rains impacted five to six homes. There were numerous flooded roads with several eastern county road closures. Several bridges were under water.
Heavy rain caused numerous roads to flood.
Five locations were flooded near the intersection of Highway 287 and Berry Street.
Up to two feet of water was reported in and between Wortham and Kirvin along CR 27.

Flooding reported on CR 429, FM 2727, FM 2578, FM 987, and CR 140 southeast of Terrell, while in Mabank the roof of a car service center collapsed from the weight of the rainwater.  The collapse of the roof damaged a car, some equipment, and the brick support walls.
West Weatherford Street barricaded due to continued flash flooding.
A car was submerged in flood waters at the intersection of FM 1365 and CR 901 with water up to its headlights.  A high water rescue was required.
FM 937 just south of Groesbeck was under water due to flooding.
Flooding was reported at CR 1565 and CR 35.

A car stalled in rising flood waters Friday night as heavy rains accompanied thunderstorms.  The passengers all managed to get out of the car but were immediately swept away.  The woman who was driving and her daughter made it to safety, but the other passenger, a small boy, was not found until several days later.
Flash flooding was reported on Seventh Avenue and Oaklawn by the Corsicana Police Department.

Storm total precipitation amounts of 3 to 7 inches over western north Texas and southwestern Oklahoma generated heavy runoff along the Red River mainstem and its tributaries, and produced minor flooding along the Red River in the vicinity of Burkburnett, TX on October 17-19. The Red River crested at 10.5 feet, 1.5 feet above flood stage, at 9:00 am CST on October 18, and remained above flood stage from approximately 6:00 am CST on October 17 until 12:00 am CST on October 19. Low-lying areas and agricultural lands along the Red River were inundated during this period.

The Garza County Emergency Manager reported that widespread heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding along several area highways. Flowing flood waters washed out a portion of a new driving surface along U.S. Highway 380 east of Post. A vehicle hydroplaned off of U.S. Highway 84 southeast of Post and came to rest in a flooded playa lake. The driver was rescued by local emergency officials, but did not sustain injuries. Flood waters were reported to be six to eight inches deep over several roadways. Minor flooding also was reported over the western half of the county.

Heavy rains during the late evening of October 14 and morning of October 15 produced heavy runoff and flash flooding along China Creek in northwestern Wichita County near Haynesville, TX during the late morning and early afternoon of October 15. At 1030 AM CST, the Texas Department of Transportation reported that Texas State Highway 25 was closed about 0.5 miles south of Haynesville due to floodwaters from China Creek. In addition, Texas State Highway 240 was closed by floodwaters from China Creek about 0.5 miles east of Haynesville.

A moderate flood crest occurred along the South Wichita River in Knox County near Benjamin, TX on October 15-17. The South Wichita River crested at 15.9 feet, 3.9 feet above flood stage, at 7:00 am CST on October 16, and remained above flood stage from 2:30 am CST on October 15 to 10:00 pm CST on October 16. Flooding of agricultural lands along the river in Knox County occurred during this event.
Locally heavy rainfall resulted in numerous city streets under water. Some streets had to be closed of a while.
Locally heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of County Road 332 southwest of San Augustine.

A moderate flood crest occurred along the North Wichita River near Truscott, TX in northern Knox and southern Foard counties on October 16-17. The North Wichita River crested at 18.3 feet, 4.3 feet above flood stage, at 6:30 pm CST on October 16, and remained above flood stage from 1:00 am CST on October 16 to 9:00 pm CST on October 17. Flooding of agricultural lands along the river occurred during this event.

Local law enforcement officials reported that heavy rainfall caused flash flooding along numerous roadways in southern Cottle County. By 21:30 CST, portions of U.S. Highway 83 were closed near the Cottle and King County line. Other secondary roadways were reported to be impassable and covered by flowing flood waters. A National Weather Service cooperative observer measured 5.62 inches of rainfall in the Delwin community.

Moderate flooding occurred along Beaver Creek in southern Wilbarger and southwestern Wichita counties on October 15-17. Storm total precipitation amounts of 3 to 6 inches kept Beaver Creek in flood for over 2 days. Beaver Creek crested at 27.4 feet, 3.4 feet above flood stage, at 8:30 am CST on October 16, and remained above flood stage from 2:00 pm CST on October 15 until 11:45 pm CST on October 17. Some secondary roads and agricultural lands near the creek were inundated during this period.

Moderate flooding occurred along Beaver Creek in southern Wilbarger and southwestern Wichita counties on October 15-17. Storm total precipitation amounts of 3 to 6 inches kept Beaver Creek in flood for over 2 days. Beaver Creek crested at 27.4 feet, 3.4 feet above flood stage, at 8:30 am CST on October 16, and remained above flood stage from 2:00 pm CST on October 15 until 11:45 pm CST on October 17. Some secondary roads and agricultural lands near the creek were inundated during this period.

Storm total precipitation amounts of 4 to 7 inches over the Pease River basin in western north Texas generated minor rural flooding on the Pease River along the Hardeman/Foard county line and in Wilbarger County on October 16-17. The Pease River crested at 16.1 feet, 1.1 feet above flood stage, at 2:45 am CST on October 17, and remained above flood stage from 8:45 pm CST on October 16 until 6:45 am CST on October 17. This was the first crest above flood stage since June 3, 2000, and the highest crest since July 11, 1999, when the Pease River crested at a stage of 18.4 feet.

A moderate flood crest occurred along the North Wichita River near Truscott, TX in northern Knox and southern Foard counties on October 16-17. The North Wichita River crested at 18.3 feet, 4.3 feet above flood stage, at 6:30 pm CST on October 16, and remained above flood stage from 1:00 am CST on October 16 to 9:00 pm CST on October 17. Flooding of agricultural lands along the river occurred during this event.

Three moderate flood crests occurred along the Wichita River in northwestern Baylor County near Seymour, TX and upstream of Lake Kemp on October 15-18. The Wichita River initially crested at 16.4 feet, 3.4 feet above flood stage, at 4:15 pm CST on October 15, with a higher, secondary crest occurring at 2:30 pm on October 16 as the Wichita River crested at 16.5 feet, or 3.5 feet above flood stage. A third crest of 16.3 feet, 3.3 feet above flood stage, occurred on October 18 at 6:30 am CST. The Wichita River remained above flood stage from 9:00 am CST on October 15 until 7:00 pm CST on October 18. Flooding of agricultural lands along the river occurred during this event.

Storm total precipitation amounts of 5 to 7 inches produced rural flooding along Groesbeck Creek near Quanah, TX in northern Hardeman County on October 15-17. Groesbeck Creek crested at 20.0 feet, 6.0 feet above flood stage, at approximately 6:00 am CST on October 16, and remained above flood stage from 9:00 pm CST on October 15 until 8:00 am CST on October 17.

Storm total precipitation amounts of 4 to 7 inches over the Pease River basin in western north Texas generated minor rural flooding on the Pease River along the Hardeman/Foard county line and in Wilbarger County on October 16-17. The Pease River crested at 16.1 feet, 1.1 feet above flood stage, at 2:45 am CST on October 17, and remained above flood stage from 8:45 pm CST on October 16 until 6:45 am CST on October 17. This was the first crest above flood stage since June 3, 2000, and the highest crest since July 11, 1999, when the Pease River crested at a stage of 18.4 feet.

Storm total precipitation amounts of 4 to 7 inches over the Pease River basin in western north Texas generated minor rural flooding on the Pease River along the Hardeman/Foard county line and in Wilbarger County on October 16-17. The Pease River crested at 16.1 feet, 1.1 feet above flood stage, at 2:45 am CST on October 17, and remained above flood stage from 8:45 pm CST on October 16 until 6:45 am CST on October 17. This was the first crest above flood stage since June 3, 2000, and the highest crest since July 11, 1999, when the Pease River crested at a stage of 18.4 feet.

Storm total precipitation amounts of 3 to 7 inches over western north Texas and southwestern Oklahoma generated heavy runoff along the Red River mainstem and its tributaries, and produced minor flooding along the Red River in the vicinity of Burkburnett, TX on October 17-19. The Red River crested at 10.5 feet, 1.5 feet above flood stage, at 9:00 am CST on October 18, and remained above flood stage from approximately 6:00 am CST on October 17 until 12:00 am CST on October 19. Low-lying areas and agricultural lands along the Red River were inundated during this period.
The line of storms dropped between 3 and 4 inches of rain in the Mendoza area in extreme northern Caldwell County.  FM1854 was closed due to high water.
Flash flooding was reported in east Fort Worth near Trinity Boulevard.  Low water crossings were flooded with some cars stranded.
Rainfall from early morning thunderstorms in the Mountain Home area varied between 2 and 4 inches.  Law enforcement reported that streets in the area were flooded for about an hour.
Flooding was reported near the intersections of U.S. Highways 67 and 287 in Midlothian and along Interstate 45 and South Kaufman Street near Ennis.
Flooding continued to be reported in Hearne, but was considered manageable.

Very heavy rainfall associated with severe downbursts resulted in flash flooding along Interstate 27 near Plainview. Ponding of water over the driving surface resulted in multiple accidents between Hale Center and Plainview. By 11:35 CST, local officials reported that high water was up to the hoods of a few stalled vehicles at an underpass in Plainview. No injuries were reported.

Local law enforcement officials reported that flood waters inundated numerous roadways near the King and Cottle County line, including portions of U.S. Highway 83 and a number of secondary roadways near Finney and Grow.

Two day rain totals of 12 to 18 inches resulted in long duration flooding across portions of Hardin County. The hardest hit areas were along near Village Creek near Lumberton, where many roads were flooded for almost a week and homes were cut off by high water. Between 20 to 25 homes near Brushy Creek had flood damage. Another 75 homes were damaged across the county.

Two day rain totals of 12 to 16 inches resulted in long duration flooding across portions of northern Newton County. The hardest hit areas were just around Burkeville, where roads were flooded. At least three county road bridges were washed out.
One home was flooded in Morgan's Point.
FM 1013 was closed between Hillister and Spurger due to high water.

Two day rain totals of 12 to 16 inches resulted in long duration flooding across portions of Jasper County. The hardest hit areas were just south of Jasper to the Tyler County line, where roads were flooded.

Two day rain totals of 12 to 16 inches resulted in long duration flooding across portions of Orange County. The hardest hit areas were near Mauriceville, and along the Neches River near Lakeview. At least 40 homes were destroyed and another 60 were damaged.
Streets were flooded and closed in Calvert and on FM 1644 between Calvert and Franklin.
Flooding of creeks and streams reported in and around town.
Significant flooding occurred on several roads near Milano.
The Irving police department reported high water along Highway 183, Loop 12 at Highway 114, and side streets.
An additonal 10 to 12 inches of rain in less than 24 hours resulted in significant flooding in the Mauriceville area. Roads were closed and some homes had water enter them.
Flood waters entered five homes.
Several streets in town were flooded by at least a foot of water.
One road was closed in Anna due to floodwaters, and the Anna Police Department was flooded.  Highway 75 service roads just south of Melissa were flooded.
Officials reported loss of livestock and tens of thousands of dollars of fencing along the Bosque River washed away.
One house was flooded on Walcott Street.
Public reported nearly two feet of water crossing county road 1101 near the community of Rusk, Texas.
Hwy. 84 had to be closed due to high water across the roadway.
Reports of three feet of water across Hwy. 110.
Media reports of county road 336 closed between the communities of Deberry and Elysian Fields, Texas.  Portion of the road had been washed out.
CR 1130 closed due to high water.
Several roads flooded and closed across the area.
Highway 82 west, FM 2071, and FM 1201 were underwater.
FM 903 at Highway 69 and FM 2194 near Merit closed due to high water.
Several farm-to-market roads were closed due to high water including FM 1915 at Elm Creek Road.
Old Mexia Road and Hog Creek Road were both closed due to flooding.
The following roads were closed due to water: FM 487 at San Gabriel Creek, FM 486 at Little River, and FM 908.
County Road 26 was washed out between TX-850 and County Road 21.
Portions of County Road 411 was under water. High water rescues had to be made as vehicles became submerged.

Reports of several road closures across Smith County due to very heavy rainfall. County Road 2260 under four feet of water.  FM 724 is closed three miles from US 64.  FM 757 and 2767 also closed.  County Road 472 closed between County Road 433 and 411.
TX 155 was closed from Big Sandy to Gilmer.  Numerous county roads closed across the entire county.
Two roads closed due to high water.  Water was up to the guardrails on Bolton Road.
Two feet of water reported in front yards.
Flooding occurred on the Interstate 35 service roads south of Valley View.  The roads had up to two feet of water across them.
A railroad had to shut down portions of its line through town due to high water.
CR 1229 and CR 1232 off of Highway 84 were flooded by Stills Creek due to heavy rains.
High water across Hwy. 451 east of town.
Hwy. 59 was closed in the city of Marshall, Texas due to high water.
Flooding reported over Belknap Street.
Cars were stranded in high water downtown.
Water was three to four feet deep on Walker Street and on Elliott Street at South Dunegan.
The upper branch of the Nolan River was flooding portions of Highway 171 near CR 1126.
Water was over roads in the northeastern portion of the county.
Multiple roads flooded and closed throughout the county.
Additional roads closed due to runoff accumulating on roadways.
Intersection of county roads 129 and 113 under two to three feet of water.
About six roads were closed in the western portion of the county from heavy rainfall.
Numerous roads with high water in Granbury.
Street flooding reported in town.
Flooding continued from earlier rains on Highway 190 between Killeen and Harker Heights and also along CR 440.
A high-water rescue was reported.
A road was closed due to high water.
Numerous roads were closed due to high water.  Significant flooding occurred with high water rescues required.
Roads were closed near Highway 380 due to high water.
Mustang, Mobberly, and North Coffee Roads were flooded and closed.
Several secondary roads closed throughout the county.
Six to eight inches of water on Hwy 64 east and north of town.

Moderate flooding was reported in the areas surrounding Jacksonville, Texas.  Local law enforcement closed some city streets.  One vehicle was seen floating down a flooded roadway.  Stretches of Hwy 69 and 79 near town were flooded as well.
Several roads were closed due to flash flooding including county roads 2301...474...496 and 472.  A large sinkhole sits on county road 2301 after a culvert gave way.
Additional roads being closed as runoff accumulates on roadways across the county.
Several cars were stranded in Gainesville with water halfway up their sides.  Also, Interstate 35 was closed at the Weaver Street exit due to high water.
High water closed CR 1130.
Live Oak Road and FM 147 were flooded and barricaded.
The Interstate 35 service road south of Weaver Street was closed due to high water as well as FM 1201 at CR 451.
Exit 307 on Interstate 35 was flooded and barricaded.
A bridge was washed out on CR 265 between FM 929 and CR 264.
FM 2755 was underwater and closed.
CR 707 was closed due to high water.
FM 1189 N at Falls Road was washed out.
Two sections of FM 2657 were briefly flooded and closed.
Some businesses sustained flood damage on Highway 281 South, in the Circle neighborhood on 2nd Avenue, and along Highway 180.  Two high water rescues were required on 2nd Avenue and FM 4.
Water covering the roadway of county road 213.
Street flooding reported in town.
Several streets and roads flooded around town.
High water was again reported across the intersection of US 67 and US Hwy. 259.
High water was reported across US 259 in the city.
FM 724...TX 110...FM 2015 and numerous other county roads across the northern portion of the county were closed or washed out.
Water over US 271...McComic Road and multiple secondary roads in the northwest portion of the county.
Water reported over multiple secondary roadways in the northern portion of the county.
Water was reported over Highways 281 and 199.

The following roads were closed due to high water: Highway 185 one mile east of Crawford, FM 317 just north of Crawford, the 200 block of Compton School Road northeast of Crawford, and the intersection of Highway 185 and Anderson Lane east of town.
FM 590 was flooded near the Brown/Comanche county line.
North and southbound service roads along Interstate 35 between Palmer and Ferris were closed due to high water.
Gibson Road was barricaded with about a foot of water on it.
Roads were closed due to flooding and voluntary evacuations occurred.
County and farm roads were flooded north of Palestine.
Several streets in town were flooded.
Several streets in town were flooded and closed.
Farm and secondary roads were flooded in the eastern part of the county.
Numerous residents were evacuated, and at least 24 homes were affected by floodwaters from the Leon River.
Numerous county roads flooded and had to be closed.
Numerous county roads flooded and closed.
Portions of Hwy. 84 flooded and closed.
Several low-water crossings underwater and closed.
FM 572 and FM 2005 were flooded and closed.
Cowhouse Creek flooded Highway 218 at Indian Gap and Pottsville.
County road 2590 was underwater.
A few roads were flooded.

CR 425 was underwater and had to be barricaded.  In addition, a large section of CR 2232 washed away, leaving residents stranded without another road to use.  The flooding broke a large pipe under the road and left a hole about eight feet wide and twelve feet across.  The school bus could not pick up children, the mail could not be delivered, and the trash could not be picked up.
Several roads were closed due to flooding.

A man and his pick-up truck were swept into Fall Creek after he tried to cross a flooded low-water crossing.  A high water rescue was required.  Nearby residents were unable to go home in the evening due to the fact that their road, along the same creek, was flooded by as much as twelve feet.
Flooding reported across US 80 with minor street flooding in the northern portion of the city.
Intersection of Highway 1002 and Aspen Road underwater and closed.
Streets were flooded.
Roads were flooded by one to two feet of water.
Roads were closed due to high water near Farmersville and Highway 5 was flooded at Railroad Bridge in Fairview.
FM 486 and FM 1600 were closed at Little River, and FM 1915 and FM 2269 were closed at Big Elm Creek.
Street flooding in town.
FM 1531 and FM 3388 were closed due to flooding near Ratton.
Several county and secondary roads flooded.
Interstate 35 lanes were closed at exit 299 due to flooding.
Additional roads are closed due to high water.  Runoff accumulating on roadways.
Highway 36 between Hamilton and Whiteway had water over the road.
Highway 164 flooded in town.
Several roads in the northern part of the county were underwater.
Four to five inches of rainfall has resulted in flash flooding throughout the county. Reports of high water rescues from motorists stranded in high water.
Several homes flooded throughout the county including some residents needing to be rescued from high water in their homes.
Several county roads underwater. Reported by local law enforcement.
Flooding reported on roads.
Flooding was reported in the San Carlos subdivision, with water in some homes.|
Shoal Creek near Lamar Street crested at 14.76  feet at 0915cst on January 13, where 10 feet is flood stage.

Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell late on the 23rd and during the early morning hours of the 24th across rural, western Bee county.  Several Farm to Market roads were flooded and closed, including F.M. 796, F.M. 888 and F.M. 797.|

Between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall fell during the early morning across central Victoria county.  City streets in Victoria flooded around Second Street and Liberty and Second Street and Williams.  At least 10 homes had up to 6 inches of water in them from the flooding.|

Flash flooding of a low water crossing along U.S. 59 was reported roughly 10 miles southwest of Goliad.  U.S. 59 was reduced to one lane.  Law enforcement reported one vehicle was swept off the road, but the driver was able to escape unharmed.|
Water reported to be in some homes as well as the Fire Department and Civic Center. Water at least one foot deep on city streets.

Both the Nueces River at Calallen and the Nueces River at Bluntzer recorded major flooding in July.  Several homes were flooded forcing evacuations.  Disaster declarations were declared for both San Patricio and Nueces counties due to this river flooding.  Dollar estimates on the damage were not known at the time of this writing.  Flooding of the Nueces River in this area began on June 29th and continued through August 25th.

Nearly 2 inches of rain feel across Beeville resulting in flash flooding of Poesta Creek.  Later during the early morning of the 14th a motorist had to be rescued after driving around barricades and becoming stranded in the South Tyler St. low water crossing at Poesta Creek.|

Between 3 and 7 inches of rain fell during the early morning hours across northwest La Salle County.  Interstate 35 was eventually closed from mile marker 69 to 74 due to several feet of water over the roadway in several spots.|

Between 1 and 3 inches of rain feel quickly over already saturated ground in southwest Corpus Christi.  Many frontage roads near the Crosstown Expressway and S.P.I.D. interchange were under 1 to 2 feet of water and impassable.  Weber road out near Hwy 286 was also flooded and impassable.  Frontage roads at S.P.I.D. and Kostoryz were under several feet of water and impassable.|

About 2 inches of rain fell in less than an hour over the western and downtown portions of El Paso. This caused major street flooding with numerous car rescues required. Rock slides occurred and and a few vehicles were submerged.
Two inches of rain fell within 30 minutes in Socorro. A couple of roads were closed and a home was flooded with knee-deep water.
Heavy rainfall resulted in water covering some roads in Laredo.  Loop 20 at Century City was closed and well as Loop 20 at Los Presidentes due to high water.|
Between 2 and 4 inches of heavy rain resluted in flash flooding of many low lying roads in Laredo.

Between 1 and 3 inches of heavy rain fell over portions of Corpus Christi.  Hardest hit were several city streets in and around Mcardle at Nile as well as the Pharaoh Valley subdivision, were flash flooding occurred.  NAS Corpus Christi was forced to close incoming and outgoing gates at one point when floodwaters caused several vehicles to stall.  The Crosstown Expressway underpass near Mexico Street and Leopard was also flooded and barricaded.
A quick 2 to 3 inches of heavy rainfall resulted in city-wide flash flooding of streets in Bishop.|
A quick 2 to 3 inches of heavy rainfall reslted in street flooding in Kingsville.  Hardest hit was an impassable North Loop 772 and Trent Road.

Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell across western Kleberg county.  4.5 inches of rainfall was recorded in the city of Kingsville where flash flooding occurred.  Creeks running through the city flooded.  U.S. 77 frontage roads were flooded with 1 to 2 feet of water.  High water rescues were done around the city.  Reports were received of a few businesses and a church along U.S. 77 with minor flooding.|
Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell across western Kleberg county.  Most city streets in Kingsville became flooded and impassable, with several cars stranded in the high water.|

Both the Nueces River at Calallen and the Nueces River at Bluntzer recorded major flooding in July.  Several homes were flooded forcing evacuations.  Disaster declarations were declared for both San Patricio and Nueces counties due to this river flooding.  Dollar estimates on the damage were not known at the time of this writing.  Flooding of the Nueces River in this area began on June 29th and continued through August 25th.||
Several county roads in the central and northern part of the county were reported flooded.  Radar estimated between 2 and 4 inches fell during the evening hours across this area.|
Flooding was reported on many roads in the city of Victoria, including Navarro at Rio Grande, Ben Wilson St. near the University of Houston-Victoria and the Laurent Street underpass.|

Thunderstorms moved slowly across northern Gonzales County during the evening of November 17 producing very heavy rainfall. Radar estimates showed in excess of 4 inches of rain from 6 PM until midnight and CoCoRAHS observer Gonzales 6.7NNW reported 6.45 inches in 24 hours ending at 7 AM on November 18. The heavy rain led to flash flooding which closed FM 794 from Gonzales to near Harwood due to water over the road.
Water reported over U.S. 59 west in Goliad.

Thunderstorms moved slowly across southern Fayette County during the evening of November 17 producing very heavy rainfall. Radar estimates showed in excess of 4 inches of rain from 6 PM until midnight and CoCoRAHS observer La Grange 10.2NW reported 7.96 inches in 24 hours ending at 8 AM on November 18. The heavy rain led to flash flooding which closed Highway 90 from Flatonia to Schulenburg due to water over the road.

Thunderstorms moved slowly across southern Fayette County during the evening of November 17 producing very heavy rainfall. Radar estimates showed in excess of 4 inches of rain from 6 PM until midnight and CoCoRAHS observer La Grange 10.2NW reported 7.96 inches in 24 hours ending at 8 AM on November 18. The heavy rain led to flash flooding which closed Highway 77 from La Grange to Schulenburg due to water covering the road.
Street flooding occurred in the downtown and southwest portions of El Paso, with some intersections closed.
Interstate 10 was closed briefly near Fort Hancock due to flooding, as was Highway 20 from McNary northwest to the Hudspeth/El Paso County line.

Locally heavy rainfall fell across mainly the northern portions of the county resulting in numerous roads closed. CR 472 at the intersection of CR 463 was reported flooded in the Wood Springs Community. Portions of CR 411 just south of I-20 was reported flooded. In addition...CR 343 near the intersection of CR 313 near Winona was flooded.
Locally heavy rainfall resulted in widespread road closures across the county. One motorist had the be rescued from his vehicle from high water. There were no report of injuries.
Heavy rainfall resulted in the flooding of Hwy 909 between the towns of Clarksville and Bogota.
Widespread heavy rainfall resulted in numerous roads flooded across the county. Some of the roads include CR 2375, 1563, 3880, 2688 and 4575.
Locally heavy rainfall resulted in several road closures in the town of New Boston.
Locally heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of Hwy 125 just south of town.
High water was reported over FM 2497 and had to be closed.

Localized heavy rainfall resulted in excessive flooding across mainly the eastern half of the county. Six county roads were closed due to flooding.     A car was trapped by flood waters on CR 2789 and CR 3009 was washed out. Several CR were closed near Hwy 59 on the southwest side of Liberty Eyleau. CR 4126 was also closed near New Boston, Texas.
FM440 east out of Holliday was closed due to high water.
HWY 16 Cutoff was closed one mile south of HWY 281 due to high water.
FM 2650 was closed near junction with RTE 1954 due to high water.
Thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over Karnes and DeWitt Counties.  Up to 4 inches fell near Gillett, causing flash flooding that closed FM119 and SH80.
Thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over Karnes and DeWitt Counties.  Yorktown received up to 4 inches and the resulting flash flooding closed FM119 and SH72.
Early morning thunderstorms produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain across central Val Verde County.  Up to 5 inches fell near Comstock, closing SH163 and FM1024 due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms in Real County caused general rainfall over the western half of the county of between 2 and 3 inches, with up to 4 inches in isolated locations.  SH55 and FM337 were closed due to flash flooding during the early morning.

Slow-moving thunderstorms between Tarpley and Bandera in Bandera County and D'Hanis in Medina County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals.  Highest amounts in Medina County were 4 inches north of D'Hanis near the Bandera County line. FM462 was closed north of D'Hanis due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms over Guadalupe County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals with amounts of up to 3 inches near Seguin. Flash flooding closed FM78 and FM467 through the early afternoon.
Thunderstorms over Guadalupe County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals with amounts of up to 3 inches near Seguin. Flash flooding closed FM78 and FM467 through the early afternoon.

Thunderstorms moved slowly over southern Lavaca County in the mid and late afternoon, producing between 1 and 2 inch rainfall.  Highest totals were 5 inches west of Speaks.  Numerous county roads, including CR420, SH111 and FM531, were closed due to flash flooding.  Several high water rescues were reported off CR420.
Rainfall of between 1 and 2 inches, with spotty amounts of up to 4 inches near Cuero caused flash flooding in the city that closed streets during the late afternoon.
Morrison Road exit at U.S. Highway 77 under three feet of standing water.

Thunderstorms across much of Kendall and Bandera Counties produced general rainfall of 2 to 3 inches, closing FM187 from Vanderpool southward through early evening.  SH16 was also closed from Medina to Kerr County line.
Thunderstorms in the Cheapside area dropped between 3 and 4 inches of rain in two hours, causing flash flooding that closed FM766 and FM2067.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain in the area between Wimberley and Buda, closing FM12, FM2325, and FM150 through the late evening period due to high water.

General 2 to 3 inch rain amounts were received between Frio Town and Big Foot in the morning of July 29.  Highest totals were near 8 inches in the Frio Town area.  Flash flooding developed in the morning and continued into the mid afternoon, closing many roads in the area, including US57 and FM462.

Scattered thunderstorms over northern Gillespie County and western Kerr County produced rain totals of 1 to 2 inches.  Highest totals in Gillespie were 4 inches east of Cherry Spring.  FM965 and SH16 were closed due to high water.

Scattered thunderstorms over northern Gillespie County and western Kerr County produced rain totals of 1 to 2 inches.  Highest totals in Kerr were 4 inches southwest of Mountain Home.  FM479 and SH41 were closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch totals from Leakey in Real County eastward to Medina and Vanderpool  in Bandera County.  Highest totals in Bandera County were 5 inches at Vanderpool.  FM187 and FM337 were closed to high water, with severe flooding along FM187.
Backbone Creek at Marble Falls crested at 19.7 feet at 0300cst on June 27, where 16 feet is flood stage.
The Frio River at Concan crested at 18.5 feet at 1015cst on June 26, where 11 feet is flood stage.
The South Fork of the San Gabriel River at Georgetown crested at 31.2 feet at 0715cst on June 27, where flood stage is 9 feet.

Thunderstorms between over southern Gonzales, northern Lavaca and northern DeWitt Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals with up to 5 inches near Smiley.  US97 and US87 were closed near Nixon.

Thunderstorms over Williamson and Travis Counties produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain on the morning of July 20, with up to 5 inches near Taylor.  SH95, FM973, and FM112 were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch rainfall over eastern Atascosa County, with up to 5 inches near Pleasanton.  Closed to high were SH97, FM541, FM791, FM140, and FM1099.

Persistent thunderstorms on the morning of June 28 over northwest Bexar County and south and central Comal County produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Highest rain totals in Bexar County were 5 inches between Leon Springs and Helotes.  Most of the rural roads in northern Bexar County were closed due to high water, including FM1560 and FM3351.  The city of San reported that more than 50 streets were closed due to flash flooding, with over 40 high water rescues required.
Cibolo Creek at Falls City crested at 26.6 ft on 07/22 at 0245cst where flood stage is 17 ft.

General 2 to 3 inch rain totals were reported over Karnes, Atascosa, Frio, and Zavala Counties.  Up to 4 inches fell in the southwest corner of Zavala County.  Roads were flooded around Cometa and west of Crystal City.
Thunderstorms in Maverick County and northwestern Dimmit County dropped 3 to 4 inches of rain.  US83 and FM2644 were closed northwest of Carrizo Springs.
Thunderstorms in Maverick County and northwestern Dimmit County dropped 3 to 4 inches of rain, with up to 5 inches 25 NE Eagle Pass near the Zavala County line.  FM481 and SH131 were closed.

General 2 to 3 inch rain totals fell over northwest Bexar County, with up to 6 inches near Shavano Park.  Most low areas and at least two dozen roads in northwest Bexar County were closed due to flash flooding.  More than twenty high water rescues were completed.  In one case, a vehicle carrying two young men and two young women was washed off a road into Leon Creek.  The occupants climbed into trees and clung to branches for several hours until they were finally rescued by boats.
Between 3 and 4 inches of rain fell northeast of Eagle Pass, with highest amounts near 6 inches.  FM481 was closed due to high water.
Hondo Creek near Tarpley crested at 22.9 ft on 07/21 at 0700cst, where flood stage is 15 ft.
San Marcos below Luling crested at 31.3 ft on 07/21 at 1300cst, where flood stage is 25 ft.
From 3 to 5 inches fell in the southeast quarter of Gillespie County, with the heaviest rain just southeast of Fredericksburg.  US87 and FM1376 were closed.
A general 1 to 2 inch rain fell over Hays County, with up to 4 inches northeast of Wimberley.  FM12, FM150, and FM3237 were closed due to high water.
From 3 to 4 inches of rain fell between Cedar Park and Round Rock, causing widespread flash flooding along Upper Brushy Creek.  FM620 and FM1325 were closed due to high water.
Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell in the western half of Gillespie County with up to 6 inches near Doss.  FM648, FM783, and FM783 were closed in Gellespie County due to flash flooding.

Rain totals between 2 and 3 inches fell in the late afternoon, causing flash flooding over the southern part of Caldwell County between Lockhart and Luling.  Closed due to high water were SH183, FM20 and FM86.
From 3 to 4 inches of rain fell southeast of Westhoff in the early evening, closing US87 and FM240 due to high water.

General 1 to 2 inch rains fell across southern Kendall County, with the highest amounts near 5 inches southwest of Kendalia.  It was reported that 3 inches of that amount fell within one hour.  Widespread flash flooding developed.  FM473 and FM474 were closed, among many others.

Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell in southern Guadalupe County and southeastern Bexar County, with up to 5 inches near St. Hedwig.  Numerous roads were closed in southeast Bexar County, including FM1346, FM1518.
A general 2 to 4 inch rain in the Wimberley area caused widespread flash flooding that closed FM32, FM3424, and FM2325.
Thunderstorms over Gonzales, Lavaca and DeWitt Counties produced general 3 to 4 inch totals.  Flash flooding closed SH111 in both Gonzales and Lavaca Counties, along with many other rural roads.

Thunderstorms over Gonzales, Lavaca and DeWitt Counties produced general 3 to 4 inch totals, with up to 5 inches southwest of Speaks.  Flash flooding closed SH111 in both Gonzales and Lavaca Counties, along with many other rural roads.
Heavy rain over Caldwell and Bastrop Counties averaged between 2 and 3 inches in the early morning hours.  Flash flooding in Caldwell County closed FM86, FM713 and SH304.
Heavy rain over Caldwell and Bastrop Counties averaged between 2 and 3 inches in the early morning hours, with up to 7 inches between Elgin and Bastrop.  SH95, FM1704, and FM2336 were closed.
Onion Creek in Austin at SH183 crested at 22.97 feet at 1245cst on January 13, where 17 feet is flood stage.

Thunderstorms accompanying the cold front moved particularly slowly across Williamson County, with general rain totals of 1 to 2 inches and highest amounts of 4 to 5 inches between Taylor and Bartlett.  SH29, FM971,  FM972, and FM1331 were closed due to high water.

Flooding that had occurred earlier in the New Braunfels area ended in the mid morning with a brief break in the rainfall.  Around 1130 am, additional storms associated with the cold front began producing more rainfall.  This second event produced between 2 and 3 additional inches of rain in New Braunfels and streets and roads in and around the city again were closed due to flash flooding.

A cluster of thunderstorms over Fayette, Gonzales, Karnes, DeWitt, and Lavaca Counties produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall with up to 4 inches near Belmont.  US80 and FM2091 were closed due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms across Edwards and Uvalde Counties produced general 1 to 2-inch rainfall.  Highest totals in Edwards County were 4 inches where SH55 nears the Llano River northwest of Rocksprings.  SH55 was closed by flash flooding.

Thunderstorms across Edwards and Uvalde Counties produced general 1 to 2-inch rainfall.  Highest totals in Uvalde County were 6 inches south of the city of Uvalde.  High water forced the closing of FM117, FM481 and US83.
