Scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northern Atascosa, eastern Medina and western Bexar Counties produced rain totals of 2 to 3 inches.  Highest totals in Atascosa County were 4 inches near Lytle and south of Campbellton.  SH132, FM2790, FM140, and FM791 were closed due to high water, among other roads.  Two people in a pickup were swept off FM463 in the late that evening.  They abandoned the truck and clung to trees for nearly 2 hours until they were rescued.

Scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northern Atascosa, eastern Medina and western Bexar Counties produced rain totals of 2 to 3 inches.  Highest totals in Medina County were 5 inches from south of Castroville to Natalia.  Closed due to high water were FM1343, FM471, and SH132.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 4 inches of rain over west and central Guadalupe County, closing FM78, FM467, and FM477 due to flash flooding.
Scattered thunderstorms produced a general 3 to 4 inch rainfall in eastern Fayette County, which resulted in the closing of SH159, SH237, FM1291, FM955, and FM2714.

Thunderstorms over Williamson and Travis Counties produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain on the morning of July 20, with up to 4 inches near Del Valle.  36 roads were reported to be closed in eastern Travis County due to flash flooding.

Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell across much of northeastern Comal County, with up to 8 inches in New Braunfels .  Flash flooding closed FM306 and FM758.  Comal County reported 4 high water rescues.

Widespread 3 to 4 inch rainfall was reported over the county, with up to 8 inches in the area from Zorn to Seguin to McQueeny.  Widespread severe flooding was reported, with damage to more than a dozen homes.  Nearly all rural roads in northwest part of county were closed, including SH46 and SH123.
General 1 to 2 inch rains fell over eastern Bexar County, with up to 5 inches near Converse.  FM1976, FM1516, and FM1518 were closed due to high water.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain over Hays County, with up to 6 inches near Wimberley.  FM12, FM150, FM3237, and FM32 were closed due to high water.

Extremely heavy rainfall was reported from eastern Bandera County into northern Medina County.  A general 3 to 5 inch rainfall was reported from persistent, nearly stationary thunderstorms in the northwest quarter of Medina County, with up to 12 inches inside the county just south of Tarpley.   Highest totals were 17 inches just north of D'Hanis.  More than 300 people were evacuated along Hondo Creek, Seco Creek and Verde Creek.  Some were snatched from the roofs of their homes by helicopters.  Nearly all roads in the north and east halves of the county were closed.  Seco Creek overflowed in D'Hanis causing widespread damage to over 100 homes and businesses.  Some buildings had up to 4 feet of water in them.  Six homes were completely destroyed.  Damage to roads and bridges was estimated at around $1.3 million.

From 1 to 2 inches of rain fell across western Comal County, with up to 5 inches from Spring Branch to Fischer.  Widespread flash flooding developed and two cars were washed off FM306.  Just before 9 pm CST, a woman and her husband were attempting to cross a low area along FM306 when their vehicle stalled in high water and was carried into Rebecca Creek.  As the couple attempted to leave the vehicle, the woman was washed away and drowned.  Her body was found the following day.

From 1 to 2 inches of rain was generally indicated over the western half of Bandera County.  Highest totals were 4 inches north of Medina, with most of that falling in 2 hours.  Widespread flash flooding was reported across the western part of the county.  SH16 was closed and 3 cars were reported washed off of the highway.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell over the eastern third of Kerr County, with highest totals near 5 inches southeast of Center Point.  Widespread flash flooding closed most roads in southeast Kerr County, including FM480.
Between 1 and 3 inches of rain fell in the Lago Vista area during the late evening of March 11. Flash flooding closed FM1431 as well as many other roads.

Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in the area from Kingsland to Sunrise Beach with widespread flash flooding through the late evening.  FM2147 was reported closed due to flooding near Horseshoe Bay.
A second round of storms produced an additional 3 inches of rain just east of Pearsall, redeveloping the flash flooding from earlier that morning.  FM2779 and FM140 were reported to be under water.
Thunderstorms over northern Maverick County produced general 3 to 4 inch totals.  The resulting flash flooding closed SH131.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms over Kendall, Comal and Bexar Counties produced general 2-3 inch rains, with up to 5 inches near Hill Country Village.  West Avenue and Blanco Road were closed to due flash flooding.

A cluster of thunderstorms over Fayette, Gonzales, Karnes, DeWitt, and Lavaca Counties produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall with up to 4 inches east of Gonzales.  FM2091 and FM532 were closed due to flash flooding.

A cluster of thunderstorms over Fayette, Gonzales, Karnes, DeWitt, and Lavaca Counties produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall with up to 5 inches near Muldoon.  FM154, FM609, and FM2237 were closed due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms dropped general rain totals of 2 to 3 inches with up to 5 inches near Serbin and 6 inches in the western part of Giddings.  US290 was closed and parts of CR205 had up to 3 feet of water over the road in places.

A cluster of thunderstorms over Fayette, Gonzales, Karnes, DeWitt, and Lavaca Counties produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall with much of the rain falling in only 2 hours.  In Lee County, US87 and FM236 were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced from 3 to 4 inches of rain in the Granger area causing flash flooding that closed FM971 and SH95.

A cluster of thunderstorms over Fayette, Gonzales, Karnes, DeWitt, and Lavaca Counties produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall with up to 5 inches east of Moulton.  FM532 was closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 4 inches of rain over northeast Gonzales County, closing FM1115 and FM1296 due to flash flooding.

Storms produced a general 2 to 4 inch rainfall between San Antonio and Universal City.  At least 15 roads were closed in San Antonio with the northeast portion of Loop 1604 closed east of Lookout Road.

Thunderstorms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain over much of Llano, Burnet, Blanco and Williamson Counties, with up to 4 inches near Johnson City.  FM2766 and US281 were closed north of Johnson City.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell over Bandera, Kerr, Edwards and Real Counties, with up to 4 inches between Mountain Home and Hunt.  SH41 and SH39 were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain over Comal County, with highest totals near 5 inches just east of Spring Branch.  FM311, FM3159, and FM2722 were closed due to flash flooding.

Scattered thunderstorms produced general rain totals of 2 to 3 inches over Kinney, Uvalde, Zavala, Medina, and Frio Counties in the afternoon of July 3, with up to 8 inches between Hondo and Devine.  Widespread severe flash flooding resulted from the rainfall, closing most roads in the southern part of Medina County.

Scattered thunderstorms produced general rain totals of 2 to 3 inches over Kinney, Uvalde, Zavala, Medina, and Frio Counties in the afternoon of July 3, with up to 4 inches in the southeast corner of Uvalde County.  FM187 and FM140 were closed.

Scattered thunderstorms produced general rain totals of 2 to 3 inches over Kinney, Uvalde, Zavala, Medina, and Frio Counties in the afternoon of July 3, with highest amounts in Zavala County near 5 inches to the northeast of Batesville.  FM187, FM1178, and FM1025 were closed.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms over Kendall, Comal and Bexar Counties produced general 2-3 inch rains, with up to 5 inches in the Garden Ridge-Schertz-Cibolo area.  Flash flooding closed numerous roads, including FM3009, FM2252, and Evans Road.
Storms produced 2-4 inch totals in a northwest to southeast oriented line across central Dimmit County.  Closed were US 83 and FM2644, and FM191.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in western Gonzales County, closing FM1117 due to flash flooding.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms over Kendall, Comal and Bexar Counties produced general 2-3 inch rains, with up to 4 inches near Sisterdale.  FM473 was shut down between Sisterdale and Kendalia due to high water.
The northern half of Frio County received 2 to 3 inches of rain in general, with up to 5 inches near Big Foot.  Flash flooding closed FM462 and FM472.

The northern half of Gillespie County received from 2 to 3 inches of rain in general, with up to 4 inches in the area around Willow City. FM783 and FM965 were closed due to flash flooding through the late afternoon and early evening.
Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell in the afternoon and evening over northwestern Lavaca County.  Numerous rural roads were closed due to flooding, including FM530.

Thunderstorms stretching from northern Fayette County southward through Lavaca and DeWitt Counties produced widespread 1 to 2 inch rain totals as the moved eastward.  Highest totals in Fayette County were near 4 inches just west of LaGrange and near Warrenton.  Flash flooding closed FM609 and SH159.

Thunderstorms stretching from northern Fayette County southward through Lavaca and DeWitt Counties produced widespread 1 to 2 inch rain totals as the moved eastward.  Highest totals in Lavaca County were near 5 inches just east of Sweet Home along US77.  Flash flooding closed FM531 through the early morning period.

Persistent thunderstorms on the morning of June 28 over northwest Bexar County and south and central Comal County produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Highest rain totals in Comal County were 5 inches just south of Canyon Dam.  Closed to high water were FM311, FM2673, and FM3159.
Leon Creek at IH35 crested at 21.3 feet at 2200cst on June 28, where 15 feet is flood stage.
Thunderstorms produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain over western Kerr and northern Real Counties, with up to 4 just north of Leakey.  FM336 and FM337 were closed due to flash flooding.

Rainfall in thunderstorms over DeWitt and Lavaca Counties averaged 2 to 3 inches, with up to 7 inches  between Yorktown and Cuero.  Flash flooding was widespread over the central part of the county with many rural roads closed.  The Cuero Police Department reported that many of the streets in Cuero were also flooding.

Rainfall in thunderstorms over DeWitt and Lavaca Counties averaged 2 to 3 inches, with up to 6 inches southwest of Speaks.  Flash flooding closed SH77 closed between Hall and Victoria.  SH111 was closed east of Yoakum.
Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over Karnes County, with up to 4 inches southwest of Kenedy.  FM99 and SH72 were closed due to flash flooding through the early afternoon.

Rainfall averaged from 2 to 3 inches between Marble Falls and Spicewood with isolated areas receiving up to 4 inches.  Flash flooding developed quickly and continued into the evening.  A volunteer firefighter was returning to Marble Falls from Austin when his car was washed off SH71 into Double Horn Creek.  He was unable to summon help and had to save himself, which he did with great difficulty.
A general 3 to 4 inch rain was reported in western Kerr County, closing SH27 and SH39 near Ingram.
Rainfall between 2 and 3 inches caused flash flooding in the late evening period from Gonzales southwestward, closing FM108 and SH111.||

Thunderstorms over northwestern Caldwell County produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain in the late afternoon, causing flash flooding from Mendoza to McMahan.  Many rural roads were closed, including FM1322.

Parts of northern Guadalupe County received up to 3 inches of rain in less than 3 hours, closing numerous roads due to flash flooding.  FM1977 was reported to be closed due to flooding from the San Marcos River.  The FM775 bridge was also closed at Cibolo Creek.
Rain totals of up to 4 inches in just 2 hours caused flash flooding that closed US87 near Bankersmith in the late afternoon.
Southeast Travis County received from 2 to 3 inches of rain, with near 4 inches in the Creedmore area.  Flash flooding closed many roads through the mid evening, including FM812 and FM973.
Thunderstorms over Gonzales, Lavaca and DeWitt Counties produced general 3 to 4 inch totals, with up to 5 inches along the Goliad County line.  Flash flooding closed SH119 and US183.
A general 3-5 inch rainfall caused widespread flash flooding over eastern Caldwell County.  FM20, FM86 and FM713 were closed through the early morning.

A cluster of thunderstorms stretching from near Pearsall in Frio County across southern Bexar County and northern Atascosa County, through Seguin and Stockdale to Gonzales produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals and spotty flash flooding problems.  Highest rain amounts in Atascosa County were 5 inches northwest of Charlotte.  SH173, FM1549, and FM2504 were closed due to high water.

A cluster of thunderstorms stretching from near Pearsall in Frio County across southern Bexar County and northern Atascosa County, through Seguin and Stockdale to Gonzales produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals and spotty flash flooding problems.  Highest rain amounts in Guadalupe County were 4 inches in the southwest portion of county.  FM78, FM467, and FM539 were closed due to high water.

A cluster of thunderstorms stretching from near Pearsall in Frio County across southern Bexar County and northern Atascosa County, through Seguin and Stockdale to Gonzales produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals and spotty flash flooding problems.  Highest rain amounts in Bexar County were 5 inches near St. Hedwig.  Numerous roads were closed, including Pinn Road at FM151, Old Seguin Road at Salado Creek, Weidner Road, and O'Connor Road at Lookout.

A cluster of thunderstorms stretching from near Pearsall in Frio County across southern Bexar County and northern Atascosa County, through Seguin and Stockdale to Gonzales produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals and spotty flash flooding problems.  FM2772 and FM775 were closed due to high water in Wilson County.

Thunderstorms formed in southern Val Verde County, spreading eastward into southern Edwards County in the early morning hours.  Rain totals over the south part of Val Verde County averaged from 3 to 4 inches with the highest totals of 6 inches just northeast of Del Rio.  Many streets in Del Rio were reported to be closed due to flash flooding.

During the early morning, thunderstorms spread from both Uvalde and Frio Counties into Medina County.  The storms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain across Frio County, with up to 5 inches just west of Devine.  FM2200 and FM462 were closed due to high water.

The thunderstorms that developed in Frio County spread westward during the morning into Zavala County, producing generally 2 to 3 inches of rain.  The highest totals were at Crystal City where up to 7 inches fell.  Widespread flooding developed in and around Crystal City that required the evacuation of about two dozen families.  Many of the roads in the Crystal City area were closed through mid-afternoon.

The thunderstorms from Zavala County moved into Dimmit County during the late morning, producing between 2 and 3 inches of rain over the county.  Highest totals were around 5 inches north of Carrizo Springs near the Zavala County line and south of Catarina near the Webb County line.  US83 was closed south of Catarina and US277 was closed north of  Carrizo Springs.  US85and FM190 were also reported to be closed due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms from Val Verde County moved into Kinney County by late morning, producing between 3 and 4 inches of rain over the northern half of the area.  Flash flooding was reported to have closed FM3008 and FM2523.

Two lines of thunderstorms, one moving south from the Dallas area and one moving southeast from the Abilene area, intersected and stalled near Marble Falls, producing 5 to 8 inch rain amounts over eastern Llano County, with up to 12 inches between Llano and Sunrise Beach.  Flash flooding was extremely severe in southeastern Llano County and all roads in that quarter of the county were closed.

Thunderstorms over western Llano County and southern Burnet County produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals, with up to 6 inches between Kingsland and Marble Falls.  Most roads in southern Llano County were closed, including FM2147, FM1431 and US281.

Thunderstorms over western Llano County and southern Burnet County produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals, with up to 6 inches between Kingsland and Marble Falls.  Most roads within a ten mile radius of Kingsland were closed, including FM1431, FM2342, and FM2900.
Thunderstorms produced 3 to 4 inch rainfall in the Lakehills area of far southeast Bandera County.  The resulting flash flooding closed the only entrances to Lakehills - FM1283 and Park Road 37.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain over extreme southern Kendall County, with up to 5 inches just east of Boerne.  Closed due to high water were SH46, FM474 and FM1376.
The San Antonio River at Loop 410 crested at 23.6 feet at 1245cst on June 28, where 20 feet is flood stage.
From 3 to 5 inches of rain fell west of Mountain Home on the early morning of July 21.  Flash flooding closed SH41 and FM1340 through the late morning.
Thunderstorms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rainfall over eastern Edwards County, with up to 4 inches north of Barksdale.  US55 and FM335 were closed due to high water.
The Sabinal River at Sabinal crested at 27.1 ft on 07/21 at 1100cst, where flood stage is 12 ft.
Thunderstorms dropped between 4 and 6 inches of rain in the Normandy area.  Flash flooding closed SH131 and FM1908.
King Waterhole near Hondo crested at 16.6 ft on 07/21 at 1045cst, where flood stage is 12 ft.
The Medina River at Bandera crested at 16.7 ft on 07/21 at 1115cst, where flood stage is 13 ft.
Storms produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain over the southern part of Kinney County, with up to 5 inches just southeast of Brackettville.  FM1572 was closed due to high water.

Scattered thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Karnes and Frio Counties produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain, with up to 4 inches from south of Lytle to just northwest of Charlotte.  Brief flash flooding closed SH173 and FM2504.
Scattered thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Karnes and Frio Counties produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain, with flash flooding that closed FM99 and FM791.

Scattered thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Karnes and Frio Counties produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain, with up to 5 inches near Pearsall.  FM140 was closed west of Pearsall due to flash flooding.
The San Antonio River at Elmendorf crested at 44.6 ft on 07/26 at 0030cst, where flood stage is 35 ft.
Thunderstorms dropped 2 to 3 inch amounts over southern Bastrop County, with up to 5 inches near Rosanky.  Flash flooding closed sections of US290 and SH21.
Thunderstorms produced up to 4 inches of rain between Twin Sisters and Blanco, causing flash flooding through the midnight hours that closed FM165 and FM32.

Up to 6 inches of rain was reported between Lockhart and Luling, with widespread flash flooding along Plum Creek that closed FM1322 and many other rural roads.  Over 100 livestock were reported to have been washed downstream.

Scattered thunderstorms over Lee and Bastrop Counties produced 1 to 2 inch general rain amounts with up to 3 inches north of Lexington.  Numerous county roads were closed, including CR309, CR315 and FM112, which was closed near Milam line.
Early morning thunderstorms dropped from 2 to 3 inches of rain over San Antonio, causing flash flooding that closed Austin Highway, Callahan Road, and McNeel Streets.

Scattered thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rainfall over Dimmit and Frio Counties in the early afternoon.  Up to 3 inches fell in 2 hours at Carrizo Springs, flooding many of the roads in the town.  FM2644 and US 85 were closed near Carrizo Springs.
Scattered thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rainfall over Dimmit and Frio Counties in the early afternoon, with most of the rain falling in 2 hours.  US85 and FM117 were closed near Dilley.
Rainfall between 2 and 3 inches in 2 hours in southwest Bexar County caused flash flooding that closed FM327 and Stuart Road.

A cluster of thunderstorms stretching from near Pearsall in Frio County across southern Bexar County and northern Atascosa County, through Seguin and Stockdale to Gonzales produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals and spotty flash flooding problems.  Highest rain amounts in Gonzales County were 4 inches near Leesville. US80 was closed south of Belmont, along with FM1117.

Showers and thunderstorms accompanying the cold front produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain in the area between Johnson City and Twin Sisters, with up to 4 inches in the Twin Sisters area.  FM473 was closed in the early afternoon due to flash flooding.   Fm2766 was also reported closed near Johnson City.

Storms with the cold front dropped between 1 and 2 inches over eastern Kendall County with up to 4 inches in places between Sisterdale and Kendalia.  FM473, FM474, and FM3351 were closed in the early afternoon for a short time due to flash flooding.
Wilbarger Creek in Elgin crested at 34.10 feet at 2100cst on January 13, where 27 feet is flood stage.
Storms dropped from 2 to 3 inches of rain in Austin with flooding reported around MoPac near Steck Lane and Far West, as well as along Shoal Creek Boulevard.
Bull Creek at Loop 360 crested at 6.4 ft on July 26 at 0840cst, where flood stage is 5 ft.
Thunderstorms in northeast Frio County dropped between 3 and 5 inches of rain in 2 hours, closing FM462 and FM472 due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms formed across northern Val Verde, Edwards and Real Counties and moved slowly southward into Kinney and Uvalde Counties.  Rain amounts generally averaged from 2 to 3 inches, with up to 5 inches in the southwest corner of Edwards County.  FM2523 and FM674 were closed due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms formed across northern Val Verde, Edwards and Real Counties and moved slowly southward into Kinney and Uvalde Counties.  Rain amounts generally averaged from 2 to 3 inches, with up to 4 inches northwest of Brackettville.  FM674 and FM3008 were closed due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms formed across northern Val Verde, Edwards and Real Counties and moved slowly southward into Kinney and Uvalde Counties.  Rain amounts in Val Verde County generally averaged from 2 to 3 inches, with up to 4 inch.  FM454 and FM349 were closed due to flash flooding.

Scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northern Atascosa, eastern Medina and western Bexar Counties produced rain totals of 2 to 3 inches.  Highest totals in Bexar County were 5 inches near Loop 1604 and Marbach Road.  FM471, FM1957, and Marbach Road, among others, were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 3 inches of rain over eastern Travis County, with up to 5 inches near Manor.  Closed due to high water were Dessau Road, FM969, and FM973.
Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals over extreme eastern Williamson County with up to 4 inches near Coupland.  Among the Williamson County roads due to high water were FM619 and FM973.

Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals over northwest Bastrop County, with up to 4 inches between Cedar Creek and Utley.  Many roads in Bastrop County were closed due to high water, including FM969 and FM1704.

Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals over the southwest quarter of Bexar County with up to 4 inches along US90 from San Antonio to the Medina County line.  Closed due to high water were FM1957 and FM471.
Thunderstorms in eastern Medina County produced from 2 to 4 inches of rain along US90 from Dunlay to the Bexar County line.  FM471, FM1343, and FM1957 were closed due to high water.

Two lines of thunderstorms, one moving south from the Dallas area and one moving southeast from the Abilene area, intersected and stalled near Marble Falls, producing rainfall of 8 to 10 inches in extreme northern Blanco County with up to 14 inches near Round Mountain.  Flash flooding developed in the early morning hours and continued into mid morning, resulting in the closing of most roads in northern Blanco County.  Among the major roads closed due to high water were FM962 and US281.
Sandy Creek at Kingsland crested at 15.2 feet at 1215cst on June 27, where flood stage is 12 feet.

General 2 to 3 inch rain totals were reported over Karnes, Atascosa, Frio, and Zavala Counties.  Highest amounts in Karnes County were 5 inches near Gillett.  FM99, SH123, and SH119 were closed due to high water.
General 2 to 3 inch rains fell over Blanco, Gillespie, Kerr and Kendall Counties, with up to 4 inches between Blanco and Twin Sisters.  FM32, FM165, and FM473 were closed due to high water.

Extremely heavy rainfall was reported from eastern Bandera County into northern Medina County.  Most parts of eastern Bandera County reported  3 to 4 inches of rain, but the highest amount was in Bandera where up to 8 inches fell.  Flash flooding was both widespread and severe, closing SH16, SH173, FM1283 and FM470.
Thunderstorms near midnight produced between 3 and 4 inches of rain from Sattler northeastward to the Hays County line.  Flash flooding closed FM306 and FM32.
Generally from 2 to 3 inches of rain fell in the early morning hours.  Highest totals were 4 inches near Hochheim. US77 and US183 were closed due to flash flooding near Hochheim.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in central Guadalupe County, with up to 5 inches just south of Kingsbury.  FM477, FM466, and Alternate US90 were closed.
A general rainfall of 2 to 3 inches was reported in western Gonzales County, with up to 5 inches near Leesville.  US80 and FM466 were closed.

Rainfall over the northern part of Uvalde County averaged from 4 to 6 inches, with up to 12 inches from northwest of Uvalde to Utopia.  High water shut down a 36-mile stretch of tracks around Knippa, halting a westbound Amtrak train with 176 passengers for several hours.  SH127, FM1050, and SH55 were closed due to high water and Garner State Park was evacuated due to flooding.
The Frio River below the Dry Frio near Uvalde crested at 22.0 ft on 07/21 at 1245cst, where flood stage is 12 ft.
The Nueces River below Uvalde crested at 17.2 ft on 07/21 at 1700cst, where flood stage is 11 ft.
The Medina River at US 281 South crested at 24.2 ft on 07/22 at 0015cst, where flood stage is 20 ft.

Widespread 2 to 3 inch rainfall over western Bastrop county in the late night hours caused widespread flash flooding.  Highest totals were 6 inches near Rockne. Bee Creek overflowed, cutting FM20, and swept at least on car off the roadway.  Rescuers brought two occupants to safety but had to swim around 100 yards to reach one of them.  FM812 was closed by Walnut Creek, sending one car into high water and requiring a rescue.
Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over northwestern Williamson County, with up to 5 inches in the Georgetown area.  The resulting flash flooding closed CR268 and FM1869.
The Blanco River at Wimberley crested at 20.79 ft at 0315 CST on March 12, where flood stage is 13 ft.  This was the 5th highest crest on record.

Scattered thunderstorms produced general rain totals of 2 to 3 inches over Kinney, Uvalde, Zavala, Medina, and Frio Counties in the afternoon of July 3.  Highest amounts in Frio County were 5 inches in the northwest part of the county and also near Pearsall.  US57, FM140, and FM2779 closed.

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell over southern Burnet County with up to 5 inches in the Marble Falls area.  Most of this rain fell in a one-hour period. Widespread flash flooding was reported with US281 being closed in and around Marble Falls.  FM2147 was also reported closed.
Thunderstorms across much of Kendall and Bandera Counties produced general rainfall of 2 to 3 inches, with up to 4 inches in the Sisterdale area.  FM473 and FM1366 were closed through the evening.

Thunderstorms from the early morning into the mid morning across eastern Val Verde County and western Edwards County produced widespread rain amounts of 3 to 5 inches from Loma Alta to Del Rio.  Streets in Del Rio were closed due to flash flooding from 0400CST through 0800CST.   At 0700 CST, the Val Verde County Sheriff's Department reported that cars had been washed off US277 south of Loma Alta.

Thunderstorms from the early morning into the mid morning across eastern Val Verde County and western Edwards County produced widespread rain amounts of 3 to 5 inches from Carta Valley to Rocksprings.  Roads across southwestern Edwards County were closed, including FM674 and FM2523.
The Devils River at Pafford Crossing near Comstock crested at 9.4 feet at 1015cst on June 10, where 5 feet is flood stage.

Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals from Kyle eastward to the Caldwell County line, with up to 4 inches just east of Kyle.  FM150 and FM2001 were closed through the early afternoon due to high water.
Thunderstorms over southern Gonzales, northern Lavaca and northern DeWitt Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals with up to 5 inches near Moulton.  Flash flooding closed FM532 and SH95.

Thunderstorms over southern Gonzales, northern Lavaca and northern DeWitt Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals with up to 4 inches near Westhoff.  FM240 and US87 were closed due to flash flooding.
The Guadalupe River at Seguin crested at 24.75 ft on 07/20 at 1755cst, where flood stage is 19 ft.
General 2 to 3 inch rains fell over Blanco, Gillespie, Kerr and Kendall Counties, with up to 4 inches near Boerne.  FM474 and FM1376 were closed due to high water.

General 2 to 3 inch rain totals were reported over Karnes, Atascosa, Frio, and Zavala Counties.  Highest amounts in Frio County were 5 inches between Divot and Derby.  Flash flooding closed FM117, US85 and FM1581.
A general 2 to 3 inch rain fell over eastern Medina County, with as much as 5 inches around Riomedina.  FM1957 and FM471 were closed due to high water.
General 2 to 3 inch rains fell over Blanco, Gillespie, Kerr and Kendall Counties, with up to 4 inches near Center Point.  SH173 and  FM480 were closed due to high water.

Virtually the entire county received between 2 and 4 inches of rainfall.  Highest totals were 8 inches between Sisterdale and Boerne.  Nearly all rural roads in Kendall County were shut down due to the flash flooding.
The Guadalupe River at Gonzales crested at 40.3 ft on 07/22 at 1330cst, where flood stage is 31 ft.
Between 3 and 5 inches east of rain fell from east of Spofford southward to near Normandy in Maverick County.  FM1572 was closed in Kinney County due to flash flooding.

From 2 to 3 inches of rain fell over the southeast part of the county in the morning, with up to 7 inches near the McMullen County line.  FM1582, US85, and FM462 were closed through early afternoon due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rainfall, with up to 7 inches from Christine to Campbellton.  FM140 was closed from Charlotte to near Campbellton.  Most roads in southeast Atascosa County were also closed, including SH16 and FM791.

Widespread 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in Wilson, Gonzales, DeWitt, Karnes and Lavaca Counties, with up to 5 inches near Nordheim.  Many county roads in DeWitt County were closed, including SH72 and SH119 between Nordheim and Yorktown.
Widespread 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in DeWitt, Karnes and Lavaca Counties, with up to 7 inches near Gillett. Flash flooding closed US80, SH72, and FM792.
Widespread 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in Wilson, Gonzales, DeWitt, Karnes and Lavaca Counties, with up to 4 inches southwest of Speaks.  US77 was closed near the Victoria County line.
Widespread 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in Wilson, Gonzales, DeWitt, Karnes and Lavaca Counties, with up to 5 inches near Sutherland Springs.  FM539, FM775, and SH97 were closed.

Rainfall south of a line from Wimberley to Buda averaged between 2 and 3 inches, with between 5 and 7 inches in the San Marcos area. Widespread flash flooding closed FM12, FM150 and FM621,among many other rural roads and city streets through the morning period.  This flood was a large factor in making recovery efforts from the wind and tornado damage even more difficult.

Thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Wilson, and Guadalupe Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals with up to 5 inches near Elmendorf.  Most rural roads in south Bexar County were closed due to high water, including Somerset Road, SH16, and Pleasanton Road.

Thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Wilson, and Guadalupe Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals with up to 5 inches near Pleasanton and just northwest of Fashing. FM537, FM1333, and FM1470 were closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Wilson, and Guadalupe Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals with up to 4 inches near Floresville.  SH97, FM536, and FM1304 were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms over Bexar, Atascosa, Wilson, and Guadalupe Counties produced general 2 to 3 inch rains. FM78 and FM3009 were closed in Guadalupe County due to high water.
Thunderstorms produced widespread rain totals of 2 to 3 inches in western Gillespie County.  Highest totals were 4 inches from Doss to Harper.  FM783 and SH16 were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms produced widespread rain amounts of 2 to 3 inches in northwest Kerr County with up to 5 inches near Ingram.  Closed due to high water were SH39, SH41, and FM479, among other roads.
Spotty rain totals of 2 to 4 inches in central DeWitt County caused problems between Nordheim and Cuero.  SH72 SH119, and FM240 were closed due to flash flooding.
Thunderstorms in Medina County dropped from 3 to 4 inches of rain, closing SH132, SH173, and FM2200 due to flash flooding.
Scattered thunderstorms over Bandera, Real and Uvalde Counties produced from 3 to 4 inches of rain, causing flash flooding of SH16 at FM2107 northwest of Medina.
Scattered thunderstorms over Bandera, Real and Uvalde Counties produced from 3 to 4 inches of rain, causing flash flooding in Real County along FM337, FM336, and FM2248.

Scattered thunderstorms over Bandera, Real and Uvalde Counties produced from 3 to 4 inches of rain, causing flash flooding along FM187 from Lost Maples State Park to Utopia.  FM337E and FM1120 were also closed, as was SH127 at the Frio River, FM2690 at the Frio River, and FM1023 northeast of Uvalde.
Thunderstorms in eastern Medina County produced rain totals of 3 to 4 inches, causing flash flooding that closed FM1343 and SH173 closed.
Rainfall in Hays County averaged from 2 to 3 inches.  Highest totals were 5 inches near Henly.  Flash flooding closed FM165, FM112, and FM150.
Two to 3 inches of rain falling over eastern Uvalde County in the early morning of July 3 caused flash flooding between Knippa and Sabinal that closed FM1049 and SH127.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell over Bandera, Kerr, Edwards and Real Counties.  The heaviest amounts in Bandera County were in the western part.  Flash flooding closed FM187 and FM337.
Thunderstorms produced from 3 to 5 inches of rain around Fredericksburg, causing flash flooding that closed FM965 and FM2323.

General 1 to 2 inch rainfall was produced across Bastrop County, with up to 4 inches near Red Rock and 7 inches just south of Paige.  Many of the southern Bastrop Country roads were closed due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms in Frio County produced general 2 to 3 inch rains over already saturated soils.  This re-developed flash flooding very quickly between Pearsall and Derby.  FM1581 and FM1582 were closed due to the flooding.
From 2 to 3 inches of rain fell in the early afternoon of July 25 causing flash flooding that closed FM150 and FM2001.

Thunderstorms in the late afternoon and evening produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over much of Gonzales County, with totals near 5 inches around Thompsonville.  Parts of SH183 were closed due to flash flooding in the Gonzales area with sections of SH87 under water near Nixon.  Widespread street flooding was also reported in Gonzales.
From 2 to 3 inches of rain fell in the afternoon and evening over western Lee County, closing rural roads for much of the early evening.  FM1624 was closed near Fedor.
The area between Tarpley and Medina received from 2 to 3 inches of rain in the late afternoon.  Rapid flash flooding developed that closed FM470.
Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell on the saturated soils between Lockhart and McMahan early on the morning of July 15, closing FM20 and FM713.
Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inches of rain near midnight over southern Comal County, closing FM311 and FM1863 due to high water.

Thunderstorms formed just east of El Indio in the late afternoon and dropped between 2 and 3 inches of rain in the area through the early evening.  Flash flooding closed FM2644 through the evening period.

The thunderstorms from Kinney County spread northwestward into Val Verde County by mid morning and covered an area from Del Rio to Comstock.  A general 2 to 3 inch rain along this part of the Rio Grande River, with flash flooding closing SH163, FM2523 and several roads in the city of Del Rio through late morning.
The Frio River at Derby crested at 9.3 ft on 07/31 at 1045cst, where flood stage is 6 ft.

Scattered to numerous thunderstorms over eastern Medina and Frio Counties and produced general 2 to 3 inch rainfall.  Highest rain totals in Frio County were 4 inches northwest of Moore and southeast of Pearsall.  Closed due to flash flooding were FM1582, FM462, and FM2779.
The San Antonio River at Elmendorf crested at 41.0 feet at 1230cst on June 29, where 35 feet is flood stage.

Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell over Bandera, Kerr, Edwards and Real Counties, with up to 4 inches north of Rocksprings near the Sutton County line.  Flash flooding closed most roads in northwestern Edwards County, including US55 and FM674.
Thunderstorms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain over much of Llano, Burnet, Blanco and Williamson Counties, with up to 4 inches south of Kingsland.  FM1431and FM2900 were closed south of Kingsland.

Thunderstorms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain over much of Llano, Burnet, Blanco and Williamson Counties.  Up to 4 inches was reported in the extreme northwest part of Burnet County.  Flash flooding closed most rural roads in that corner of the county, including FM2341.
Thunderstorms over Bexar County produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain, with up to 4 inches in parts of San Antonio.  Numerous streets in downtown San Antonio were blocked due to flash flooding.
Rainfall from Brackettville northeastward averaged from 2 to 4 inches.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM334 and FM674.

Thunderstorms in southern Edwards County produced a general 3 to 4 inch rainfall in a little over 2 hours.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM674 between its intersection with US377 and the Nueces River.
Thunderstorms produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain over northern Uvalde County, with up to 5 inches in the extreme northwestern part of the county. Flash flooding closed US55 and FM1050.
General 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in thunderstorms over Lavaca and DeWitt Counties, with up to 5 inches east of Moulton.  FM532 and SH95 were closed near Moulton.
General 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in thunderstorms over Lavaca and DeWitt Counties,.  Several county roads in the southeast corner of DeWitt County were closed due to flash flooding.
The Guadalupe River at Gonzales crested at 40.53 ft at 1030 CST on March 13, where flood stage is 31 ft.  This was the 5th highest crest on record.
Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell in southern Atascosa County with up to 4 inches at Pleasanton.  Five cars were washed off the road on SH97 near Christine.

CR258, CR268, CR305 were all closed due to high water, among many others.  A husband and wife were driving home in the Georgetown area near 1920 pm CST.  Their vehicle stalled in high water in Berry Creek.  Rescuers reached the couple and attempted to bring them to safety, both were swept downstream.  The woman was successfully rescued but the man drowned.
Cibolo Creek near Falls City crested at 26.26 ft at 1800 CST on March 13, where flood stage is 17 ft.
The Guadalupe River at Cuero crested at30.59 ft at 1215 CST on March 16, where flood stage is 24 ft.
Sandies Creek near Westhoff crested at 12.08 ft at 0800 CST on March 26, where flood stage is 21 ft.  This was the 5th highest crest on record.
Scattered storms in Gonzales and Wilson Counties dropped from 2 to 3 inches of rain, with up to 5 inches near Leesville.  FM108 and FM466 were closed in Gonzales County due to flash flooding.
Scattered storms in Gonzales and Wilson Counties dropped from 2 to 3 inches of rain, causing flash flooding that closed FM536, FM2579, and FM1344 in Wilson County.

Thunderstorms formed across northern Val Verde, Edwards and Real Counties and moved slowly southward into Kinney and Uvalde Counties.  Rain amounts in Uvalde County generally averaged from 2 to 3 inches, with up to 5 inches in the extreme northwest part of the county.  SH55 and FM481 were closed near Uvalde with FM1051 closed just south of Camp Wood.

Thunderstorms formed across northern Val Verde, Edwards and Real Counties and moved slowly southward into Kinney and Uvalde Counties.  Rain amounts generally averaged from 2 to 3 inches in Real County, with the highest amounts in the Leakey area.  FM336 and FM337 were closed briefly due to flash flooding.
Seco Creek at Ranch Rowe near D'Hanis crested at 32.4 ft on 07/21 at 0715cst, where flood stage is 15 ft.
Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 4 inches of rain between Fentres and Kingsbury.  Flash flooding forced the closure of both FM20 and US 80.
Wilbarger Creek at Elgin crested at 30.2 feet at 2300cst on June 20, where 27 feet is flood stage.

Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 4 inches of rain between Canyon Dam and the city of New Braunfels. Many of the New Braunfels streets and Comal County rural roads were closed due to flash flooding, including FM306, FM2673.
Oxford Creek at crested at 12.4 feet at 1000cst on June 27, where flood stage is 8 feet.

Scattered to numerous thunderstorms over northern Travis and southern Williamson Counties produced 2 to 4 inches of rain.  Highest totals in Travis County were 6 inches near Jollyville.  Closed due to high water were FM1325, FM260, and FM1431.

Scattered to numerous thunderstorms over northern Travis and southern Williamson Counties produced 2 to 4 inches of rain.  Highest totals in Williamson County were 8 inches in Cedar Park. Ten evacuations were required along Smith Branch Creek and Brushy Creek due to the high water and several county shelters were opened.  Most rural roads in southern Williamson County were closed, including FM260, FM1431, and SH29 where it intersects with SH95.  At least 8 high water rescues were made in the Liberty Hill area.
The Medina River at US 281 South crested at 24.9 feet at 0445cst on June 29, where 20 feet is flood stage.
The Devils River at Bakers Crossing crested at 9.9 feet at 0700cst on June 29, where 6 feet is flood stage.
The Llano River at Llano crested at 20.4 feet at 1045cst on June 26, where 10 feet is flood stage.

Thunderstorms moving southeastward over Dimmit county produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain in 90 minutes.  Heaviest rain was in the western half of the county, with up to 3 inches in the southwest portion.

Thunderstorms produced general 3 to 4 inch amounts over eastern Gillespie County, with up to 7 inches near Willow City.  The resulting flash flooding closed most of the roads in eastern Gillespie County, including FM1323, FM965, and SH16.
Bull Creek at Loop 360 crested at 6.6 ft on July 21 at 0430cst, where flood stage is 5 ft.
Between 3 and 5 inches east of rain fell from east of Spofford southward to near Normandy in Maverick County.  SH131 and FM1908 were closed in Maverick County due to flash flooding.
The Frio River at Derby crested at 19.7 ft on 07/23 at 1445cst, where flood stage is 6 ft.
The Nueces River at Asherton crested at 24.5 ft on 07/23 at 1515cst, where flood stage is 20 ft.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in southern Bexar County, causing widespread flash flooding.  Among the many rural roads that were closed was FM2579.

Thunderstorms through the afternoon and early evening produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall over Wilson County, with up to 5 inches in the Stockdale area.  The resulting flash flooding closed numerous roads, including FM81and CR218.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell across northwestern Karnes County, with as much as 4 inches in the Falls City area. SH123 and FM81 were closed due to flash flooding.

Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in the afternoon and evening over northern Burnet County, with the highest totals near 4 inches in the Oatmeal area.  FM2147 was closed, partly because of a rockslide that was caused by the flash flooding.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell across much of DeWitt County, with the highest totals near 5 inches in near Cuero.  FM1447 and FM236 were closed due to high water.
Widespread 2 to 3 inch rain amounts fell in Wilson, Gonzales, DeWitt, Karnes and Lavaca Counties, with up to 4 inches west of Gonzales.  US97 and FM466 were closed.
Two to 3 inches of rain fell in the late afternoon over northern Comal County, causing flash flooding in the Sattler area which closed FM2763 and FM306.

Evening thunderstorms dropped 3 to 4 inches of rain over western Travis County, causing flash flooding that closed FM2244 and FM1826.  Late that evening a 62-year old marathon runner was reported missing after having left his home on a run.  His body was found in Barton Creek near the Capitol of Texas Highway.  He had apparently drowned in the flash flooding that took place.
Thunderstorms dropped from 2 to 4 inches of rain in the southeast corner of Dimmit County, closing US83 and FM133 due to high water.

A cluster of thunderstorms stretching from near Pearsall in Frio County across southern Bexar County and northern Atascosa County, through Seguin and Stockdale to Gonzales produced general 2 to 3 inch rain totals and spotty flash flooding problems.  Highest rain amounts in Frio County were 6 inches southeast of Pearsall, where FM1582 and FM140 were closed due to high water.

The thunderstorms produced a general 1 inch rain over southeast Comal County, with up to 3 inches in just over an hour in the city of New Braunfels.  Loop 337, FM306 and FM2722 were closed briefly due to high water through the mid  morning period.

A strong storm system brought a round of thunderstorms which produced very heavy rainfall over the south central Texas Panhandle. National Weather Service Doppler radar estimated that one to two inches of rain fell in a seven mile wide strip across the Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River just upstream of the river gage site located thirteen miles northeast of Wayside Texas. The runoff from the intense heavy rain caused a rise on the river to just over the flood stage of ten feet. There was no reports of damage or injuries.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over southern Atascosa County.  Many of the county's rural roads were closed due to flash flooding, including FM140 and FM791.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced 4 to 6 inches of rain over southeast Llano County.  Flash flooding developed in the early evening with high water closing SH71.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts over northern Burnet County.  Flash flooding put water over SH183 at Mesquite Creek.  FM963 was closed at CR233 and FM243 was closed at Oatmeal.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts between Mountain Home and Kerrville with up to 6 inches near Ingram.  IH10 was closed due to the high water, with some cars washed off the road.  One high water rescue was made on Turtle Creek.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over Comal County, with up to 4 inches near Sattler.  Rural roads across the county were reported to be closed due to flash flooding, including FM2673 and FM306.  Several cars were reported to be washed off FM306.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over Lavaca County, with up to 4 inches near Moulton.  Flash flooding closed many roads in the county, including CR14 and FM532.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced from 2 to 4 inch rain totals around McMahan.  Flash flooding closed FM713 and FM304.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts in western Fayette County with up to 4 inches near Flatonia. FM609 and FM154 were closed due to flash flooding.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 4 inch rain amounts east of Lexington, which closed FM696 closed due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in Llano in less than two hours.  Brief flash flooding closed several streets in the city in the morning.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in northern Edwards County, with up to 6 inch totals.  US377 was closed both north and south of Rocksprings due to high water.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts between Lake Amistad and Del Rio with some areas receiving up to 6 inches.  Roads were closed all around the city of Del Rio.
The Pecos River at Langtry crested at 17.69 ft at 0330 CST on May 25, where flood stage is 7 ft.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts between Loma Alta and Carta Valley. US377 was closed, along with FM2523.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts in southeast Frio County and southwest Atascosa County with isolated totals to 5 inches.  SH97 and FM140 were closed due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts around Lakehills. Flash flooding closed Park Rd 73 in two places.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in the northern part of San Antonio.  Flash flooding closed many roads in the city, including Callaghan, Hausman, McCullough, Prue, and Woodlawn.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts over northeast Medina County with up to 5 inches near Rio Medina. SH173 closed due to high water at Verde Creek and FM471 was closed near LaCoste.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts in southern Fayette County, with up to 4 inches falling near Engle.  Flash flooding closed many of the roads in the southern half of the county, including FM609 and FM154.
The Colorado River at LaGrange crested at 30.14 ft at 1315 CST on May 28, where flood stage is 26 ft.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts north of Del Rio that closed FM2523, SH164, FM1024, and FM189 due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts in southwest Uvalde County that closed several roads due to flash flooding, including FM1022.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in western Dimmit and western Zavala Counties.  FM65 was closed east of Crystal City due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in western Dimmit and western Zavala Counties.  FM2644 was closed near Carrizo Springs.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts in western Lavaca County with up to 6 inches near Hallettsville.  FM111, FM530, and FM1447 were closed due to flash flooding.  Many roads in Hallettsville were reported to be under water with several vehicles washed off the roads.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over southern Karnes County with up to 4 inches near Kenedy.  Many of the roads in Kenedy were reported to be under water and SH792 was closed near Kenedy.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts over Bandera County with up to 4 inches between Medina and Bandera.  SH16 was closed near the Kerr County line due to high water and SH187 was closed between Vanderpool and Utopia.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in eastern Real County, with up to 4 inches near Leakey. Flash flooding closed FM337 east of Leakey.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts across the southwest quarter of San Antonio. Numerous roads and streets were closed through the early morning hours due to flash flooding.
Widely scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in the Eagle Pass area.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM1021.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 3 to 4 inch rain amounts between Liberty Hill and Round Rock.  Spotters reported 2 feet of water over SH29.
Guadalupe River at Cuero crested at 31.74 ft at 0345 CST on May 1, where flood stage is 24 ft.
Devils River at Bakers Crossing crested at 9.87 ft on 0700 CST on May 7, where flood stage is 6 ft.
The Pecos River at Langtry crested at 18.15 ft at 0345 CST on May 10, where flood stage is 7 ft.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced 3 to 4 inch rain amounts in the Blewett area. FM1022 was closed due to flash flooding.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in southeast Kinney County. FM1572 was closed near Spofford.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts in northern Dimmit County with up to 5 inches between Big Wells and Asherton.  FM468, FM1019, and FM1558, among many others, were closed due to flash flooding.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts in southeast Frio County and southwest Atascosa County with isolated totals to 5 inches.  Flash flooding closed SH85.
The Devils River at Bakers Crossing crested at 8.65 ft on 0845 CST on May 10, where flood stage is 6 ft.
The Pedernales River at Johnson City crested at 20.36 ft at 1315 CST on May 25, where flood stage is 14 ft.
The Guadalupe River at Hunt crested at 15.00 ft at 0200 CST on May 25, where flood stage is 10 ft.
The Guadalupe River at Kerrville crested at 15.22 ft at 0315 CST on May 25, where flood stage is 9 ft.

The Texas Parks and Wildlife Service reported that the low water crossings in Palo Duro Canyon State Park were flooded with two and a half feet of water flowing over low water crossing number six and three and a half feet of water flowing over low water crossing number five. No damage or injuries were reported.
Reported widespread flash flooding of roads in the southwest section of the town of Higgins with water of four to six inches deep.
All underpasses in downtown Amarillo were flooded. No damage was reported.
Fifteen vehicles reported stalled at the intersection of 45th Avenue and Fulton Drive. No damage was reported.
Vehicles were reported stalled at the Instate 40 and Bell Street underpass with flowing water curb to curb. No damage was reported.
Two feet of water flowed over Big Bend National Park Route 15 north-northwest of Panther Junction.
Flash flooding caused the closure of portions of Farm to Market Road 1992 and Texas Highway 208 north of Colorado City.

Six to twelve inches of water was reported on Texas Highway 176 in Andrews, U.S. Highway 385 in andrews and on Texas Highway 176, 16 miles east of Andrews.  By 12:42am CDT March 26, five to six feet of standing water was reported on roads in Andrews.  Several roads in Andrews were closed.
Local television meteorologists reported one and a half to two feet of water running over streets in the city of Wink, including Texas Highway 115.
Six inches of water was flowing acros Texas Highway 176, one and a half miles east of that highway's intersection with Texas Route 349.
Several motorists were stranded in high water in Odessa.
Several roads in Colorado City are flooded and impassable.

Storms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch totals in Lavaca County, with the highest amounts of 4 inches near Yoakum.  Flash flooding closed FM531 and SH111 for a few hours in the morning.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across Bastrop County, with up to 4 inches near Elgin.  FM1704 and SH95 were closed through mid-morning due to flash flooding.

Rescue crews were busy due to high water levels at intersection of Robert E. Lee & Interstate 10, as well as with residential flooding on Ascarate Street where a canal overflowed. One man was swept away but then rescued with no serious injuries.

The area of extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin continued to spread northwestward across Bexar County, with a general 4 to 5 inch rain over the county.  Totals of up to 8 inches were reported at several locations in the south and west parts of San Antonio as well as between Helotes and Leon Springs.  By 1400 CST, most roads in the northwest part of the county were closed.  By 1530 CST that afternoon, more than 39 high water rescues were reportedly underway in San Antonio.  Water was almost waist-deep at Southcross Boulevard in San Antonio.  Floodwaters were so deep and running so swiftly at the San Antonio High School West Campus that they collapsed a masonry wall and filled the school with almost five feet of muddy water.  Hallways were flooded, and desks, computers and boxes were tossed and thrown together. The students were moved to classrooms in another building across the district. A young man was driving to work in the mid afternoon of August 16 when his vehicle struck a guardrail on Southwest Military Drive and was knocked into Six Mile Creek near South Flores Street.  The young man called his family to say he had had an accident, then exited the vehicle but drowned as he attempted to move to higher ground.  Near midnight a young woman was driving with three friends and a baby near North Star Mall when she accidentally drove her sport utility vehicle into deeper water where it was slammed against a bridge and then was swept into a drainage ditch.  The three other adults in the vehicle were able to get baby out of the vehicle through the window and escape.  But when the three looked back for the driver, she was gone.  Her body was found later by emergency responders when the water receded.

From Bexar County the extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin spread in Bandera County.  Between 3 and 5 inches of rain was reported in general, with up to 7 inches to the northwest of Medina near the Kerr County line.  Roads across the north part of county were closed due to high water requiring several high water rescues.  High water also closed bridges north of Medina on SH16 and northwest of Medina on FM2107.  Residents were evacuated from over 50 homes in the Lakeshore area. Three cars were washed off bridges and numerous rescues were required.  A bystander noted that one truck attempted to cross Privilege Creek and was warned away by everyone nearby, but the truck continued along and was quickly washed into the creek.  The driver and his wife were able to leave the truck and were rescued.  Their vehicle finally came to rest almost a half-mile down the creek.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across Guadalupe County with up to 4 inches in the Cibolo area.  Flash flooding closed FM78 and FM3009 briefly during the late afternoon.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across Edwards County, with up to 5 inches falling in the extreme northeast corner of the county.  US377 and FM41 were closed from midnight into the early morning hours.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin spread across the northwest half of Val Verde County in the mid-afternoon.  Rain totals averaged between 3 and 4 inches with up to 8 inches east of Juno and around Pandale.  Flash flooding began in the evening and continued through midnight into the early morning hours.  SH163, FM189, and FM1024 were reported closed due to high water.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin developed over the northwest quarter of Edwards County in the late-afternoon.  Rain totals averaged between 3 and 4 inches in the northwest corner of the county, closing US277 and SH55 near the Val Verde County line in the late evening hours.

Extremely heavy rainfall associated with Erin spread into the east and north sections of Medina County.  General rain totals in this area were between 3 and 5 inches, with up to 8 inches reported around Castroville and near the Bandera County line south of Tarpley.  Most county roads north of US90 were closed due to high water.
Some secondary roads were closed in the Hamshire area due to heavy rains.
The Highway 105 underpass in Vidor was closed due to high water, and the access road along I-10 near Rose City was closed due to high water.

The extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin moved into Blanco County in the late afternoon, producing a general 3 to 5 inch total over the southwestern part of the county.  Highest rain amounts were 6 inches between Blanco and Twin Sisters.  All roads from Blanco southward were reported to be closed due to high water.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3  inch rain amounts over north and east Uvalde County.  Highest totals were near 5 inches north of Sabinal toward the Bandera County line.  Flash flooding closed FM187, FM1050, and SH127 through much of the evening.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across Hays County, with up to 4 inches near Dripping Springs and to the northwest.  FM12 was reported closed in several places due to high water.

The area of extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin continued northwestward into Wilson County.  General rain totals over the county varied from 3 to 4 inches.  The highest amounts were 8 inches and stretched northwestward from Floresville to the Bexar County line.  Roads across the northwest part of the county were closed due to flash flooding, including FM1303, FM536, and FM2579.
Three cars stalled in flood waters at the entrance ramp to Highway 377 off of Loop 820.
Six to eight inches of water was flowing across a frontage road.
A few streets were closed temporarily, including Avenue B.  Some cars stalled and water entered at least one home.

The extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin moved into Kendall County in the afternoon, producing between 3 and 5 inches over most of the county.  Highest rain totals were 8 inches between Boerne and Sisterdale.  Most roads in the county were closed and several families had to be evacuated along Cypress Creek due to flooding.  City Lake was reported to be only six feet below the spillway.  It had only been topped twice in the past 10 years.  Near 1900 CST on the evening of April 16, a man and his son were in a truck traveling along FM473 when they attempted to drive across a bridge near FM1376 that was already flooded by Sisterdale Creek.  The truck stalled and both men crawled out of the cab through the rear window and stood in the truck bed.  Rescuers who arrived within minutes were unable to pass them life jackets or to secure a rope to the truck before a surge of water lifted the vehicle and swept it over the bridge.  The father and son were washed into the creek and drowned.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across Real County with up to 5 inches just east of Leakey.  Many of the roads in the county were closed due to flash flooding, including FM336, FM337, and FM2748.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across the south and west portions of Travis County.  This rainfall was in addition to general 1 to 2 inch amounts from earlier in the day.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM2244 and FM620 for a short time in the late evening.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across the south and west portions of Llano County.  FM2323 was reported to be closed due to high water through the late evening.

Thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rainfall totals over the northern third of Williamson County, with up to 4 inches near Jarrell. Flash flooding closed several roads including FM787 and FM972.

Thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3inch rainfall totals over the northern half of Bastrop County, with the highest amounts near 4 inches in the area around Paige. FM21074 and SH21 were closed through part of the afternoon due to flash flooding.

Extremely heavy rainfall associated with Erin spread into the western sections of Comal County in the evening period.  General rain amounts of 3 to 4 inches were reported along and west of US281, with up to 7 inches falling near Spring Branch.  Flash flooding was reported in the western part of the county, closing SH46 and FM311.

The extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin moved into Gillespie County in the late afternoon, producing general 3 to 5 inch amounts.  Highest were 9 inches at Cain City just south of Fredericksburg.  Most roads in the southern and western part of the county were closed due to flooding.  High water rescues were made on Bear Creek Road in the county and on East College Street and Goehmann Lane in Fredericksburg.  US290 was blocked by the Pedernales River by early Friday morning and the LBJ Ranch was closed to visitors all day on Friday.

The extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remains of Tropical Storm Erin moved into Kerr County in the afternoon.  A general 3 to 5 inch rainfall was indicated across the northeast part of the county, with up to 8 inches falling north of Center Point.  Most roads and bridges in northeast Kerr County were closed due to flash flooding.  Two women were turning onto Town Creek Road when their vehicle became stalled in high water, then swept into Town Creek and finally lodged in some trees about 50 years from the bridge and 30 yards from the banks of the creek.  Fire and rescue personnel were only able to get them to safety by forming a human chain in the flood waters and then pulling them to safety.
A few secondary roads closed due to flooding.
A woman was rescued from floodwaters coming from the Leon River near Strauss Mill Road.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts over northeast Gonzales County, with up to 4 inches near Waelder. Many rural roads, including FM1115 and SH97, were closed due to flash flooding.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts in western Travis County just west of Austin.  Highest totals were 3 inches near Bee Caves.  Among the many roads closed due to flash flooding were FM2244 and FM2222.

Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell on the western side of San Antonio from midnight into the early morning hours.  Elm Creek quickly inundated Shepherd Road in Southwest Bexar County.  A 911 call brought rescuers to the scene to find an SUV with a mother and five kids stranded in rising water around 0520CST. The family of six was saved from the top of the stranded Dodge Durango, thanks in part to the swift water rescue efforts of the first responders.  As the rescues progressed, they spotted a second vehicle submerged at the location.  The driver of this vehicle was a 57-year old woman who had apparently been washed into Elm Creek in the heavy rain.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts over southern Val Verde County, with up to 5 inches near Del Rio. Many of the roads in the southern part of the county were closed, including FM1024 and FM163.

Thunderstorms through the late afternoon produced a general rainfall of 1 to 2 inches over western Llano and Gillespie Counties.  Up to 4 inches fell just east of Harper.  Flash flooding closed roads across northwest Gillespie County through the late night, including FM648.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts over western Kinney County, with up to 4 inches just west of Brackettville. Most rural roads in the western part of the county were closed due to flash flooding, including FM3008, FM674, and FM693.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over northern Dimmit County, with up to 4 inches north of Carrizo Springs. Flash flooding closed FM191 and FM65 through the evening.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts in southwestern Uvalde County, with 3 to 4 inches southwest of the city of Uvalde. Among other roads, FM481 and FM117 were closed due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts in western Zavala County with 3 inches between Crystal City and La Pryor. FM1025 and FM65 were closed due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts over northern Val Verde County, with up to 4 inches near Juno.  SH163 was closed near Juno due to flash flooding.

General rain amounts of 1 to 2 inches were reported in thunderstorms over southeast Uvalde County during the evening of May 2.   Highest toals were near 4 inches.  FM187 was closed due to flash flooding along the Sabinal River.

Showers and thunderstorms through the late evening produced general 1 inch rainfall over northwest Frio County with isolated 3 inch totals near Pearsall.  Several roads, including FM140 and FM1582, were closed due to flash flooding.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts in northwest Edwards County, with highest totals near 3 inches.  SH55 closed was northwest of Rocksprings due to high water.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts between Loma Alta and Carta Valley. US377 was closed at its junction with US277 south of Loma Alta.
Roads in rural Brooks County reported under water due to 2 inches of rain in and hour and saturated soils.

General rainfall of 1 to 2 inches caused brief flash flooding in the area just east of Kendalia.  Between 2100 CST and 2130CST, a woman was returning home and while driving on Crabapple Lane in eastern Kendall County and attempted to cross a low water crossing on her drive.   The vehicle was apparently washed off the road or partially off the road.   Sometime later, her husband noticed the headlights and got in his vehicle to check.   He attempted to wade through the water to rescue his wife.  Both were drowned in the flood.

Rainfall between Johnson City and Twin Sisters averaged from 1 to 2 inches in showers and thunderstorms, with up to 5 inches falling near Johnson City.  Many of the rural roads, including FM2766, FM165, and FM32, were closed due to flash flooding.  As a father and his two daughters, aged 6 and 7, attempted to drive through a low water crossing on the Blanco River just after 0500 CST on County Road 407, his pickup truck was caught in high water.  He tried to back out of the water, but the current carried the vehicle across the bridge where it flipped over, landed upside down and was immediately submerged.  The father grabbed onto both daughters and attempted to swim to safety, but lost his grip on the younger daughter.  The father and his older daughter were able to swim to safety but the younger daughter drowned.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over Caldwell and Guadalupe Counties.  Highest amounts in Caldwell County were 4 inches near Lockhart.  Among several roads closed due to high water were FM20 and SH142.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over Caldwell and Guadalupe Counties.  Highest rain amounts in Guadalupe County were 4 inches near Kingsbury. Many rural roads were closed, including FM20 and SH123.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts between Serbin and Giddings. FM141 was closed due to high water briefly through the early morning hours.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 2 inch rain amounts in western Fayette County with up to 4 inches near Flatonia. Flash flooding closed FM609 and FM154.
County Road 116 closed due to high water.
High water rescue required due to flooding.
One to two feet of water over Highways 19 and 198.
There were reports of flooding along Interstate 35.
There were reports of flooding in town.
Widespread flooding reported. Numerous roads closed including Highway 380 East and Highway 199.
Water up to four feet over roads.  One business flooded as well.
Significant flooding occurred countywide.  High water rescues were required in Alvarado, a car was stranded in Burleson, and dozens of roads were closed and barricaded.
Homes and businesses flooded with several feet of water.
Flash flooding reported on roads.

Heavy rains caused Nolan Creek to swell and flow quickly.  A boy's body was found two days later downstream near Harker Heights.  He apparently fell into the creek behind his house on the Fort Hood military base.
Numerous roads flooded.
Three feet of water over Crawfish Ranch Road.
Highway 279, CR 4044 and CR 4042 were closed and barricaded.  Numerous high water rescues were required.
Flooding reported in Corsicana along Highway 22 and also Interstate 45.
Continued flooding at low water crossings and low-lying bridges.  No road closures.
An 8-foot tall by 30-foot long culvert covered with 7 feet of dirt was washed away, leaving a 20-foot gap in a road.  The culvert had been in place for about 45 years.
FM 66 between the two towns was flooded.
Torrential rains led to flooded roads in many sections of El Paso. A roof collapsed in the northeast part of the city from the weight of accumulated rain water.
At least 6 houses were flooded in Sierra Blanca, with one of them evacuated. Most of the secondary roads in the area were washed out and closed.

Recent very heavy rainfall caused the Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River at the gage site located thirteen miles northeast of Wayside to rise to almost a foot above the flood stage of ten feet. The river crested at ten point eight feet. No damage or injuries were reported from this river flooding.
Heavy rains (2.5 inches) caused flash flooding in the Sierra Blanca area. Skunk Canyon Road was washed out, and arroyos were over bankfull.
High water was reported over city streets.
The east fork of the Trinity River was at least a foot out of it's banks along the Dallas/Kaufman County line.

Rainfall rates at 1 inch/30 minutes along with intense hail whcih clogged drainage channels resulted in one to two feet of rapidly moving water on some streets from the UTEP campus area through the downtown section of El Paso. Stalled vehicles were reported.
Street flooding with approximately a foot of water over impassable roads.
Flooding caused numerous road closures north of Houston. Road closures were reported along FM 1960 and the Cypress Creek area.
Flooding along Interstate 45 feeder roads in and around Huntsville. Flooding was also reported to the west of Huntsville on FM 1791, FM 1696, and SR 30.
Flooding reported between the towns of Weldon and Lovelady.

Numerous county-wide roads and some downtown Brenham streets were closed due to flooding. FM 1155 at New Years Creek and a portion of FM 2935 were closed due to high water. Some of these roadways were closed due to high water over them through Wednesday evening.
SH 60 near Matagorda, along with secondary roads off of FM 521, in the southern part of the county are impassable due to water over the roadways.
Flooded and impassable streets near Interstate 45 and Gulf Bank Road.

Numerous flooded vehicles. An estimated 100-plus vehicles trapped due to impassable Interstate 45 feeder road flooding. Flooded vehicles near Kirkwood Road and Briar Forest Drive. Streets were flooded and impassable along Aldine-Bender Road northbound.
Flooded and impassable streets.
Flooded and impassable streets.
Numerous reports of flooding through the towns of Texas City and La Marque.
One to two feet of water over Highway 87 causing road closure.

Fire Department performed three high water rescues at the intersection of the Northwest Freeway and Pinemont Drive, Northwest Freeway and Gessner Drive, and Interstate 10 and Wilcrest Drive. Flooded and impassable roads included Hammerly Boulevard and Beltway 8 north, Gessner Drive and Interstate 10, and on West Tidwell Road at Highway 290.
Water entering a few homes on Blankenship Drive near Bingle Road.

Brickhouse Gully exceeded its banks and resulted in house flooding upstream of US 290 in the Langwood Subdivision. Six to eight homes were flooded with 1 to 2 of water at Antoine Dr and Chantilly. Up to 10 homes were flooded in the Spring Shadows Subdivision. Most homes received less than 6 of flooding. Total flooded northern Houston metro home count for the event was between 70 to 90 homes.
Flooding forced the closure of portions of Highway 59 in and around New Caney.

Flooding in and around the intersection of Rinn Road and FM 109. Three vehicles were swept off the road. Three occupants were successfully rescued from one of the three vehicles after it became pinned against bridge pilings. One home in the area suffered water damage.
Water entered a Post Office building.

Numerous reports of street flooding around Houston metro. Reports of flooding at the intersection of Mesa Road and the Sam Houston Parkway. Flooding also reported around downtown Houston and northward up Interstate 45 toward the West Mont Houston area, where various roads were closed due to high water making them impassable.

Numerous road closures in and around Northern Jackson County due to heavy rain causing water over roadways. Majority of the flooded roads extended from the Morales and Cordele area eastward to the Jackson-Wharton county line.
Flooded and impassable roads in and around Jones Road and Grant Road.

Approximately 12 homes in North Bryan were flooded with 2 to 3 inches of water. These homes were located at the intersection of Louisiana Avenue and McHaney Drive. Reports of 4 to 5 feet of water covered Old San Antonio Road a mile west of Highway 6.
Portions of SR 21 were temporarily closed due to high water.
Sections of US 90 were temporarily shut down due to high water.
Three to four feet of water over downtown streets bounded by the 100 to 400 block of North May Street. Flood waters entered a few structures.

A vehicle drove into a low water crossing and was swept 100 yards downstream. Of the three persons in the vehicle, one escaped to shore while the other two perished due to drowning. Their bodies were discovered between 3/4 of a mile and 2 miles downstream from the mostly-submerged vehicle.
Flooding occurred between Wehdam and Cat Spring and also extended westward towards Industry. The following roads were closed due to flooding: FM 109 at Williams Creek and FM 497 at SH 36 in Kenney.
Flooding on FM 949 north of Interstate 10.
