County-wide flooding from Iola to Navasota and eastward around Anderson. Flooded roads included FM 1774 two miles south of Anderson, FM 3094 at the intersection of Victoria and Coleman Hill, and FM 244 between Iola and Carlos.
Over thirty reports of county-wide roads or bridges effected mainly across central and western portions of the county. Towns impacted included Brenham, Independence, and Gay Hill.
Flooding at the intersection of FM 1486 and CR 212 with around two feet of water on road.
Metro traffic reported several cars underwater at Old Greenhouse Road and Kieth Harrow Boulevard near Bear Creek.
Roads flooded around the area.
Flooding in the Corrigan area.
Flooding along FM 190.
Flooding along FM 356 in and around Trinity.
Water across Highway 30 North and Highway 75 west and northwest of Huntsville.
Three flooded homes with over a foot of water in them off of Henderson Road. Reports of 50 more flooded homes, or homes with water damage, in Angleton.
Flooding reported on FM 155 and surrounding county roads. Water also entered businesses at the intersection of Main and North Exchange.
High water over Flintdale Street causing the road to close.
Water over FM 155 making it impassable.
Water over impassable FM 109.
Flooding across Highway 288 near the intersections of FM 523 and County Roads 340 and 341. Flooding also reported on Highway 35 between Angleton and West Columbia.

Very heavy rainfall caused tremendous runoff into the Wolf Creek in Ochiltree and Lipscomb Counties. The flooding caused road closures along the south Wolf Creek in Ochiltree County and along the main stem of the Wolf Creek as it passed through Lake Fryer on into Lipscomb County. The flooding caused damage to some fifth wheel campers at Lake Fryer as they were drawn into the lake. The crest on the Wolf Creek at the gage site on the north side of Lipscomb was just over fifteen feet on the morning of May 24. The creek at Lipscomb was out of its banks for nearly four days and was running above the flood stage for almost thirty hours. This crest was the highest crest for the period of record. There was no reports of deaths or injuries from this flooding.

Very heavy rainfall from thunderstorms resulted in flash flooding with water two feet deep on Hurst Road with water over the car hoods at Coulter Street and Hollywood Road (Loop 335). High water was also reported at Western Street and Farmers Avenue. 58th Avenue and Georgia Street had water up to the car doors. Basements were reported flooded.
Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding on Interstate 40 between Coulter Street and Georgia Street. No damage or injuries were reported.

Water was reportedly flowing over the road where U.S. Highway 83 crosses the south fork of Wolf Creek. Stranded motorists on U.S. Highway 83 were pulled from the high water by rescue workers. No damage or injuries were reported.
Curb to curb flooding was reported in the vicinity of Georgia Street and 34th Avenue.
Between 4 and 6 inches of rain fell overnight. FM1021 was closed.  Several schools were also closed.|
Six feet of water covered Wilson Road about four miles south of the Ochiltree County line. No damage or injuries were reported.

Water was reported flowing across County Road 8 south of Farm to Market Road 281. State Highway 70 from Pampa to Perryton was closed due to two areas of flooding over the road. No damage or injuries were reported.

State Highways 83 and 70 remain closed due to high water about seven miles south of Perryton to the county line. Farm to Market Roads 281 and 759 were also closed south of Perryton. Farm to Market Road 759 was closed from State Highway 70 to Spearman due to two to three feet of water over the road surface. No damage or injuries were reported.

U.S. Highway 83 closed from Perryton to Canadian due to five to six feet of water over South Wolf Creek Bridge. North Wolf Creek Bridge was almost flooded. Law enforcement were unable to reach Lake Fryer due to flooding into the park. Water was well over the spillway at an unknown depth. No damage or injuries were reported.

Ochiltree County Sheriff's Office reported flooding across southern Ochiltree County for several days due to recent heavy rainfall. U.S. Highway 70 south of Perryton remained closed along with County Roads 11 and W due to flooding. No damage or injuries were reported.

Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding at Palo Duro Canyon State Park. Park Rangers reported that water crossing number one was closed due to three feet of water flowing across it with an estimated four hundred people trapped on the other side of the crossing. No one was reported to be in any danger. Also...water crossing number five had greater than five feet of water flowing across it.

The underpass at 900 North Loran Street in Victoria was completely flooded with several feet of water and impassable.  Additional city streets were flooded, including Sam Houston, Lilac and Mockinbird with several vehicles stranded.|

Heavy rainfall resulted in widespread road closures across portions of the county. Road closures were reported in the town of Talco and three people had to be rescued from their car on CR 4410 which was flooded. There were no report of injuries.

Over a 1 to 2 hour period 3.19 of rain fell in the city of Kingsville  causing flash flooding.  Several cars became stalled in flood waters throughout the city.  Tranquitas Creek flooded in the city.  The heavy rain also resulted in a roof collapsing at the Kingsville Recycling Center. See the Heavy Rain event for more information.
Two to three inches of rain led to numerous road closures in Robstown and stranded motorists.  In addition one home was evacuated on Perkins Street due to the flooding.
Two to four inches of rainfall resulted in U.S. 77 southbound flooded with several feet of water, just south of Odem.
Up to 5 inches of rain fell south of Llano around the Oxford area in the mid and later morning.  TxDOT reported several roads closed due to high water.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in the mid afternoon over the southeast quarter of the city.  Flash flooding closed Basse Road as well as several other city streets through the late afternoon.
TxDOT reported many roads and highways in the Comstock area under water and closed due to rainfall in the early morning hours of between 3 and 5 inches.
The Pecos River near Langtry crested at 12.08 ft at 0800 CST on March 26, where flood stage is 7 ft.  This was the 10th highest crest on record.

Thunderstorms from Brackettville through the extreme northwestern corner of Uvalde County and into the Barksdale and Camp Wood areas produced between 3 and 5 inches of rain in the early morning hours. SH55 and FM335 were reported to be closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms from Brackettville through the extreme northwestern corner of Uvalde County and into the Barksdale and Camp Wood areas produced between 3 and 5 inches of rain in the early morning hours. Flash flooding continued until mid morning with FM674 and FM334 were closed due to the high water.

Thunderstorms from Brackettville through the extreme northwestern corner of Uvalde County and into the Barksdale and Camp Wood areas produced between 3 and 5 inches of rain in the early morning hours reported that FM334 was closed for several hours during the morning due to the flash flooding.
Scattered thunderstorms over Lee and Bastrop Counties produced 1 to 2 inch general rain amounts with up to 4 inches between Red Rock and Bastrop.  Flash flooding closed SH304, FM535, and FM812.
The Guadalupe River near Cuero crested at 28.4 ft on July 25 at 9:30 AM CST, where flood stage is 24 ft.

A cluster of thunderstorms over Fayette, Gonzales, Karnes, DeWitt, and Lavaca Counties produced general 1 to 2 inch rainfall with up to 5 inches near Coy City.  FM99 and FM791 were closed due to flash flooding.
The San Antonio River at Falls City crested at 17.0 ft on July 27 at 4:45 PM CST, where flood stage is 12 ft.

Thunderstorms formed north of Uvalde and continued to move slowly southeastward across the county, producing general rain amounts of 2 to 3 inches. Highest totals were 5 inches in the extreme northwest corner of Uvalde County, as well as just north of Knippa and also in the extreme southeast corner of county. Many county roads were closed due to flash flooding including FM140, SH55, and SH127.

Thunderstorms formed in the morning around the Brackettville area and spread northwestward through the morning producing from 3 to 4 inches of rain in central and western Kinney County. The highest totals were 6 inches near Brackettville. Flash flooding closed FM3199, FM2804, and FM1572.

Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell across Comal County from Canyon Lake southward to the Bracken area.  Highest rain totals were near 5 inches at Smithson Valley. Flash flooding closed Purgatory Road and Rebecca Creek Road.

Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell across northwest Hays county with the heaviest rainfall observed near Henley.  Flash flooding closed FM12, FM165, and FM150.  A man was traveling northward in his truck toward Dripping Springs when it was swept into Onion Creek.  He was unable to make it to safety and drowned.

Thunderstorms produced from 2 to 4 inch rainfall in central Travis County with up to 6 inches near Oak Hill. Many Austin streets and rural roads were closed due to high water, including FM2244 and FM1825.
One to two inches of rain fell during the evening, over already saturated grounds from morning rainfall.  Portions of Hwy 188 east of Sinton became impassable and was closed, due to the high water.

One to two inches of rain fell during the evening, over already saturated grounds from morning rainfall.  A few city streets in central and northern Corpus Christi were flooded and impassable due flooding.
A general 2 to 3 inch rain over northern Kendall County resulted in numerous rural roads cut by flash flooding through the afternoon.  FM473 and FM1376 were closed near Sisterdale.

Thunderstorms produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain over much of northern Blanco County, with highest amounts near 5 inches in the Johnson City area.  Flash flooding closed FM1623 and FM1323 through much of the afternoon.
Southern Burnet County received between 1 and 2 inches of rain from repeat thunderstorms with up to 4 inches in the Marble Falls area.  The resulting flash flooding closed FM1431 and FM2147.

Four to six inches of heavy rainfall, with isolated amounts up to ten inches, resulted in flash flooding in northern Aransas County.  State Highway 35 was closed from Holiday Beach to Highway 359 in Refugio county due to flooding of low lying areas.  F.M. 2040 near the Aransas Wildlife Refuge was also flooded.

Northeast Caldwell County received between 2 and 3 inches of rain in the late afternoon that resulted in flash flooding through the early evening.  Many of the small rural roads were closed, including FM1854.

Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell in the late afternoon around Pleasanton.  Flash flooding developed and continued into the early evening, closing SH97 near IH-37.  The Atascosa Sheriff's Department reported that several cars were washed off SH97 by the flooding.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell in the late afternoon around Kingsbury, closing FM20 due to flash flooding.

Thunderstorms produced a general 2 to 3 inch rain over much of Llano, Burnet, Blanco, and Williamson Counties. Flash flooding developed in the afternoon that closed FM112 and FM619 in Williamson County.
Thunderstorms produced from 3 to 4 inches of rain over eastern Williamson County closing FM486, FM1063, and FM112 due to flash flooding.
Three to five inches of heavy rainfall across far northwest Live Oak county led to flooding near Whitsett.  Highway 99 at Whitsett was flooded with several feet of water over it.
Three to four inches of heavy rain resulted in flash flooding of a few streets and low water crossings in Beeville.  Ellis Road and Ridgeway Lane were barricaded due to high water.
Three to four inches of heavy rain caused flooding of a few Farm to Market Roads in the county.  F.M. 534 was closed due to high water.

TXDOT reported a large section of F.M. 624 in rural southeastern La Salle county closed due to flooding.  A culvert along 624 was washed out due to the heavy rain.  The road remained closed into the next day.|

Widespread road closures due to flash flooding were reported across northwestern Gillespie County after general 2 to 3 inch rains, with isolated totals to 6 inches just east of Harper.   FM648 was one of the roads closed.

Thunderstorms from Brackettville through the extreme northwestern corner of Uvalde County and into the Barksdale and Camp Wood areas produced between 3 and 5 inches of rain in the early morning hours.  FM335, FM336, and FM337 were closed due to high water.

Most low water crossings reported to be in flood after a general 2 to 3 inch rain over eastern Kerr County.  Up to 5 inches fell near Kerrville and most streets in the city were reported to be under water in places, including Francisco Lemo and G streets.  Eighteen motorists were stranded on Hill Country Drive and Lois and Sidney Baker Streets due to the high water and more than 19 high water rescues were performed.
General rainfall along a north-south stretch across the central part of Bandera County ranged from 2 to 4 inches.  Flash flooding closed FM470 near Tarpley and FM2828 near Medina.

During the morning of November 18 thunderstorms moved over northern parts of Fayette County and produced 3 to 3.5 inches of rain after the county had seen over 4 inches overnight (CoCoRAHS observer La Grange 10.2NW reported 7.96 inches in 24 hours ending at 8 AM). Runoff from this additional rain led to flash flooding. Farm to market road 155 south of La Grange was closed due to water over the road.

During the morning of November 18 thunderstorms moved over northern parts of Fayette County and produced 3 to 3.5 inches of rain after the county had seen over 4 inches overnight (CoCoRAHS observer La Grange 10.2NW reported 7.96 inches in 24 hours ending at 8 AM). Runoff from this additional rain led to flash flooding. Farm to market road 957 southwest of Schulenburg was closed due to water over the road.
Widespread street flooding occurred in the Bryan and College Station areas. Water was up to the doors of cars and businesses, and some vehicles were stranded.
A high water rescue was required in North Arlington near Interstate 30.
Park View Avenue at Highway 75 was closed due to flooding.

Flash flooding was reported over much of the central and southern portions of the county.  A total of 51 roads were closed, one bridge was washed out, and numerous creeks were flooded from Richland, to Navarro, to Corsicana.  Two cars were washed off roadways.

Flooding was reported near Indian Creek in the Bartlett area, on the Interstate 35 southbound and northbound service roads between Midway and Temple, and along Kegley Lane, First Street, Shallowford Road, and between FM 317 and Pea Ridge.
Several roads were reported with water over them, including FM 147 off of Highway 114.  Flash flooding caused an accident on FM 39 south of Highway 164.  The water did not recede for several hours.
Flooding was reported on secondary roads in the western half of the county.  A motorist was stranded near Streetman, and two bridges were closed.
Water was reported over the western half of the county near Rosebud and also near Guda.
Flooding was reported on Farm-to-Market and County Roads east of Mart.

A woman drowned after attempting to cross a flooded low-water crossing in her truck.  The truck was found on January 15, but the woman's body was not located until the 18th.  She was found off CR 147 near the Marak community.  Water was also reported over roads near Davilla.

Heavy rain over the weekend caused a dam along a private pond to begin to crumble.  Officials closed Highway 334 along the dam in case it was breached.  The road was closed for about a day as crews worked to relieve pressure from the dam.
Several roads closed due to flooding including Highway 164 near the Freestone/Limestone border.
Water over numerous roads across the county.
Water over numerous roads across the county.
County Road 495 was closed due to flooding.
Low-water crossings and bridges barricaded due to flooding.  Water was reported over Highway 56 near the southern county line.
Continued flooding and barricading of a few secondary roads.
Widespread flooding across the county with up to three feet of water across roads and yards.  Forty people were forced from their homes.
Bridges were flooded on FM 718.  Numerous roads were flooded and closed including FM 101 and FM 810.
In China Spring, a woman was trapped in a mobile home due to flood waters.  In Bosqueville, about twenty families were forced from their homes along the Brazos River outside of Waco due to flooding.

Thunderstorms dropped between 1 and 2 inches over eastern Travis County with up to 4 inches at Manor. Flash flooding was reported by Austin/Travis Office of Emergency Management east of IH-35, closing FM973 and FM969.  Nearly one dozen high water rescues were reported along Caesar Chavez, Guadalupe Street, Steck and MoPac, just south of Ben White.  A woman was reported to have been swept into Waller Creek.  Although rescue and recovery personnel searched the area for several hours, they were unable to find her.  Her body was finally recovered at Longhorn Dam on March 23.  |

In Clifton, the intersection of State Highway 6 and FM 219 was under about two feet of water.  Near Smith's Bend, FM 2490 was flooded and closed, stranding a state trooper.  Numerous motorists were also stranded.
Highway 105 between Bevil Oaks and Sour Lake was under water due to three to five inches of rain.
Highway 105 between Bevil Oaks and Sour Lake was under water after three to five inches of rain.
Between 10 and 20 homes had 1 to 3 inches of water in them after three to five inches of rain had fallen.
Highway 105 in front of Wal-Mart was completely flooded.

Numerous streets were flooded in and around the town of Marshall, Texas.  Flood waters rose quickly...especially in town where a few high water rescues had to be made from people driving their vehicles into flooded roadways.
The southbound service road on Interstate 820 was closed due to high water in Hurst.  In addition, Pafford, Berry, and McCart Streets were closed in Fort Worth.
The Snyder Daily News reported two motorists stranded by high water.  One motorist was stuck under the College Avenue bridge.  The other motorists location was not disclosed.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell across northern Wilson County, with up to 4 inches near Stockdale.  Flash flooding closed SH119, FM537, and SH123.
The San Marcos River below Luling crested at 26.19 ft at 1730 CST on March 31, where flood stage is 20 ft.
Flooding reported on Bridge Street in Brady.
Texas Department of Transportation reported flooding along Farm to Market Road 504 from Highway 283 to Farm to Market Road 503.
Texas Department of Transportation reported flooding along Farm to Market Road 1028 from Highway 377 to Farm to Market Road 503.

Several high water rescues were required.  A truck was washed off a bridge near Marak; the occupants were able to escape through the windows of the truck.  One of the men got to safety immediately, and another was carried downstream and was later found safe clinging to a tree.  Two hog hunters had to be rescued when they were stranded by rising water near Pond Creek.  No injuries were reported.

Flash flooding was widespread in the western and northwestern portions of Lubbock. Flowing flood waters ran down a number of city streets including: Frankford Avenue, Quaker Avenue, 4th Street, 18th Street, 66th Street, and Spur 327. |The Lubbock Police Department reported that twenty-one vehicles were disabled in the flood waters. At least thirteen accidents were attributed to the weather. No major injuries were reported, but a few motorists were assisted in evacuating their flooded vehicles. Property damages were estimated to total $120,000 in the city.|

Local newspapers reported widespread flash flooding in the Levelland vicinity. More than one foot of water was reported flowing over parts of Farm to Market Road 2130 north of Texas Highway 114. Eight inches of water flowed over Texas Highway 114 in the city, numerous city streets also were inundated.|
Many streets in Itasca and Hillsboro were closed due to flooding. Five homes and three bridges were damaged by the floodwaters, and eight high water rescues were required.

Numerous roads closed due to flooding countywide, including Old Christian Road and Highway 254 East near Graford, and FM 2270 near Salesville.  Numerous high water rescues were required.  A boy who was trying to wakeboard in the flood waters was dragged several blocks and hurt his leg.  A man who was believed to be driving on Hell's Gate Drive near Possum Kingdom Lake during the storms was found dead three days later in the lake.

A swift water rescue was required in downtown Italy after two occupants abandoned a flooded vehicle.  Numerous other roads were flooded and closed countywide, including Highway 77, portions of Interstate 45, CR 878 near Palmer, Edmonds Road, East Pecan Road, and West Pecan Road in Forreston.  Water also flooded a house to a depth of several feet in Waxahachie.  Several roads and bridges were washed out due to the heavy rains.

Numerous roads including Highway 190 was closed with water over it.  A swift water rescue was required when a woman and two toddlers were trapped with waist-high water in the house.  Severals cars and trucks were stranded and the occupants needed rescuing.
Big Bend National Park staff reported one to two feet of water flooding Castalon Canyon.

Highway 36 was closed due to high water.  Six homes were damaged and twenty high water rescues were required.  Several vehicles were washed away, and trailers were forced off their foundations by the force of the water.  Portions of roads were also washed away.
Numerous roads were flooded with water as high as two-feet across the county.  Highways 6 and 281 were closed, and people were stranded in a car.  At least one car was submerged in floodwaters.

Extreme flash flooding was reported across the southern half of the county.  In Whitney, CR 1245 and Highway 22 were flooded.  Cars stalled and were abandoned along Interstate 35 near Hillsboro, and high water rescues were required near Abbott.  Roads were washed out near Mertens, and near Penelope and Malone, Ash Creek was reportedly 10-17 feet over CR 308 and Highway 171.

Significant flooding occurred in Bowie as heavy rain fell and storm drains backed up.  Several houses had water inside, and a pick-up truck had to be parked on top of a manhole cover to keep it closed.  One to two feet of water was reported over Highway 82 west of Nocona and Interstate 75 south of Nocona.

Several roads were under water and closed across the county.  In addition, four briges were washed out, and sinkholes developed on North Johnson Loop, Poss Dyer Road, Lake Valley Road, and Denver Road.  The sinkhole on Denver Road was six feet deep and twenty-five feet wide.

Thunderstorms across the northern half of Guadalupe County produced general 2 inch rainfall with up to 6 inches near Kingsbury.  Flash flooding closed FM20 and FM621, among many other area roads through the early morning hours.  Three men and a woman were attempting to drive through a low area on Laubach Road around 0120 am CST on Laubach Road that was experiencing flash flooding from nearby Geronimo Creek.  Their car stalled and the three men attempted to push the car to safety while the woman steered.  Unfamiliar with this area, and in the dark, they became confused and moved the car the wrong direction, causing it to be swept into Geronimo Creek.  The men escaped the flash flooding safely but the young woman was swept downstream and drowned.

Flash flooding resulted in high water flowing over U.S. Highway 380 west of Tahoka and U.S. Highway 87 north of Tahoka.  Local law enforcement officials reported that at least four vehicles were stalled in the high water.  No injuries were reported.
Flooding occurred on county roads in the northern part of the county due to river flooding.
One and a half feet of water flowing over Interstate 20 service roads and bar ditches near Barstow.  Six to eight inches of water flowed across roads in Monahans.

Numerous reports of flash flooding were reported along U.S. Highway 62/82 between Lorenzo and Crosbyton.  Flowing flood waters along that highway contributed to a vehicle accident that resulted in two injuries.

A local television meteorologist reported six inches of water running over U.S. Highway 87 near the Walmart in Lamesa.  City employees reported flooding at the park on the south side of Lamesa.  They were in the process of putting up high water barricades on Bryant Street.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell across northern Blanco County, with near 4 inches at Johnson City.  Flash flooding closed FM2766 and FM962.
The exit ramp and Frontage Road of Interstate 27 was closed in the vicinity of McCormick Road due to flooding.

Drainage ditch along the Interstate 27 Service Road between Hillside Road and Bell Street is bankfull with water which several feet deep. Also...the northern side of Arden Road is curb deep under water.
On the corner of Stardust Lane and Georgia Street...a vehicle was stuck in the bar ditch with water flowing into the vehicle.

Numerous secondary roads were reportedly inundated by flood waters in northwestern Bailey County.  By 22:50 CST, law enforcement officials reported that Farm to Market Road 1760 had been closed due to flash flooding west of U.S. Highway 84.

Significant flooding occurred across the county.  In Watauga, a bridge was washed out on Starnes Road.  Two cars were stranded by floodwaters in Saginaw, and numerous roads were flooded and closed in Colleyville and Mansfield.  About forty people were evacuated in Haltom City.   Numerous high water rescues were required, and several homes were damaged by floodwaters.  Ambulances were stranded in flood waters in Fort Worth, and firefighters trying to help residents had to be rescued when they became stranded as well.  The body of a man who's car was washed into Marine Creek during the storms was found 3 days later.
FM 937 and FM 39 were underwater, as well as several other Farm-to-Market roads.

Numerous roads were closed across the county, including Interstate 45 near Ferris and Palmer.  Across the county, several homes were flooded, and fifteen bridges were damaged by flood waters.  Cars were also submerged near Waxahachie.
The Interstate 35 service road south of Gainesville was closed due to earlier rainfall.
Baker Crossing on the Paluxy River was underwater.
Flash flooding was reported in Fannin, with water entering a few homes and a business along U.S. 59.|

Flash flooding was reported along Interstate 45, with two cars submerged just north of Corsicana.  Two feet of water was reported on Interstate 45 and on Highway 31 east of town.  Several businesses in Corsicana were flooded and about sixty people were evacuated from an assisted living center.  Several roads and bridges were damaged during this event, and county officials estimate repairs could cost as high as $19 million.
Multiple reports indicated that flash flooding resulted in flood waters in city streets in Ralls and Lorenzo.
Significant urban flooding resulted from heavy rains across Abilene. Water rescues had to be performed and many vehicles were left stranded.

Flash flooding became widespread over the eastern half of Lubbock county including the city of Lubbock during the evening hours of the 25th.  Heavy rainfall rates in excess of one inch per hour caused flash flooding in many city streets including the intersection of Memphis Street and 93rd Street.  A vehicle was stalled along 3rd Street where high water threatened a number of residences.  Flash flooding also resulted in the closure of U.S. Highway 87 south of Lubbock where several vehicle were inundated with flood waters.  The Lubbock Fire Department conducted a high water rescue at the intersection of 82nd Street and U.S. Highway 87.  No serious injuries were reported.
Onion Creek near Driftwood crested at 11.04 ft at 1620 CST on March 30, where flood stage is 7 ft.
Portions of Highway 287 near Decatur were closed due to high water.  Also, CR 3585 south of town was flooded.
Flooded roadways were barricaded in both the Authon and Peaster areas.

Slow-moving thunderstorms along the southern half of Real County produced widespread 1 to 2 inch amounts with isolated totals to 4 inches through the late afternoon and evening.  Flash flooding was reported over most roads from Leakey southward, including FM337.
Between 3 and 4 inches of rain fells around Reagan Wells, about 5 miles northwest of Concan.  Flash flooding developed that closed SH127 and FM1051.
Water was reported over roads in Celina and Blue Ridge.
Barricades were needed over Highway 56, FM 121, and other streets in Tioga and Van Alstyne due to high water.
Flooding was reported on roads in town.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in the northwestern corner of Medina County, causing flash flooding that closed FM462 and FM1796.

The rest area on Interstate 20 at mile marker 25 was flooding and traffic problems were occurring due to flooding along Interstate 20.  Street flooding was also experienced in Pecos.  Pecos police shut down the intersection of 14th and Cedar Streets, after a motorist was stranded due to high water.  A motorist was stranded on Farm to Market Road 1216, six miles south of Interstate 20.  Farm to market Road 1934 was also flooded.
Johnson Draw that runs through Ozona flooded several low water crossings in Ozona. Highway 137 northwest of Ozona had several areas that were flooded as well.
Farm to Market Road 1828 was closed due to flooding.
Highway 206 in northeast Coleman County was flooded. Additional county roads were flooded including 1147 and 1026.

General 3 to 4 inch rainfall over the southwestern two-thirds of Hays County resulted in widespread flash flooding.  An NWS survey found FM2325 closed northwest of Wimberley and FM165 closed near Henly.  In addition, parts of US290 was reported to be under water between Dripping Springs and Henly.  CR295 was also closed near San Marcos.
Tarpley received up to 4 inches in less than an hour, causing flash flooding that closed FM470 and FM462.
Up to 4 inches of rain fell between Fredericksburg and Willow City, causing flash flooding that closed   FM1323 through the mid afternoon.
The Glasscock County Sheriff's Office closed Farm to Market Road 33 north of Garden City to the Glasscock/Howard County border because flash flooding made the road impassable.
Thunderstorms produced rainfall of 2 to 3 inches in northern Kendall County, causing flash flooding that closed FM1376 through the mid afternoon.

Thunderstorms in the early and mid afternoon produced between 3 and 4 inches of rain over northern Burnet County.  Highest amounts were in the Okalla area where FM963 and FM2657 were closed due to high water.
Farm to Market roads 503 and 2131 were flooded in several locations.

Local law enforcement officials reported that most city streets in Brownfield were inundated with flood waters after 18:30 CST.  Three vehicles became stranded in high water and the occupants were rescued.  No injuries were reported.  Additionally, high water flowed over portions of U.S. Highway 380 east of Brownfield to the Lynn County line by 19:30 CST.
Several cars were stalled in one to two feet of water at the intersection of U.S. 385 and Texas Route 329.

Slow-moving thunderstorms between Tarpley and Bandera in Bandera County and D'Hanis in Medina County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals.  Highest amounts in Bandera County were near 4 inches near Tarpley.  FM470 and FM462 were closed due to high water.

Thunderstorms over Karnes County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals with amounts of up to 4 inches southwest of Coy City near the Atascosa County line. Flash flooding closed FM99 and FM791 through the early afternoon.

Thunderstorms over Atascosa County produced general 1 to 2 inch totals with amounts of up to 4 inches near Fashing and along the Karnes County line. Flash flooding closed FM98, FM2994 and FM791 through the early afternoon.
Farm to Market Road 11 was impassable due to flooding.  In addition, the Exxon Station in Bakersfield was flooded.
Third and fourth streets in Big Spring were flooded with three feet of water.  In addition Farm to Market Road 820 on the north side of Coahoma was flooded.
Five to six inches of water flowed over the road into Monahans Sandhills State Park.  Also, in Grandfalls on Texas Highway 18, six to twelve inches of water flowed over the road.

An off-duty NWS employee reported a foot of water on Bentwood Street between Thomason and Anetta and on Wadley near Midland Drive.  The Midland Police Department reported that the intersection of East County Road 90 and South County Road 1160 was closed due to flooding.  The Midland Fire Department reported eight inches of water flowing over the intersection of Loop 250 and Business 20.  The Texas Department of Transportation closed Texas Highway 307 under Interstate 20 due to flash flooding.
Six to eight inches of water was flowing over roads in Fort Stockton.
Numerous roads were closed and barricaded due to high water.
Water was flowing over a road just southwest of Kent.

Several thunderstorms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding across the city of Odessa.  |One foot of water was flowing across the intersection of Texas Highway 302 and Farm to Market Road 1882 and across 22nd St.  Andrews Highway and Yukon Road also were flooded.  A high water rescue was conducted by the Odessa Fire Department at the intersection of Interstate 20 and Grandview where water was two and a half feet deep.  The intersection of Knocks and 3rd Street had four to six inches of water flowing over the road.
Heavy rains over the past couple of days combined with heavy rains of about 2 inches in 50 minutes resulted in water rising into a home in Grape Creek.
Texas Department of Transportation closed Farm to Market Roads 2136 between highway 617 and 2229 due to flooding. There was also water reported over 380 between Highway 6 and 2407.
Heavy rains from a slow moving thunderstorm fell on Buffalo Gap in southern Taylor County. This caused quite a bit of localized flooding in and around Buffalo Gap and Tuscola.
Water over six inches was flowing over the roads in Whitewright, and at least two roads had to be closed.  In Van Alstyne, county roads and yards were underwater.  A trailer was also flooded.
Service roads along Loop 12 in northwest Dallas were flooded.
Widespread flooding occurred in West Odessa due to heavy rainfall.
Farm to Market Road 846 just off State Highway 137 and Farm to Market Road 1212 at State Highway 176 were under water and impassable due to heavy rainfall.
Highway 190 west of Menard was flooded after very heavy rains caused a draw to flow out of its banks and onto the highway.
A road that paralleled Interstate 10 just east of Sonora was flooded.
Texas Department of Transportation reported water over the road at Farm to Market Road 503 and 504 in Northwest McCulloch county.

The U.S. Highway 75 frontage road underpass was flooded just north of Weston Road.  Several other intersections were closed throughout the day, including Howell and College Streets, Church Street and McDonald Avenue, CR 123 and Lake Forest Drive, and portions of Hardin and Woodlawn Roads.  At least one home sustained water damage.
Smith Street and other roads near Pecan Creek were submerged by several feet of water and barricaded.  A few residents were asked to evacuate.
Texas Department of Transportation reported Farm to Market Road 2596 in northwest Sutton County was closed due to one foot or more of water over the road.
Kimble County reported water was over Highway 377 south of Junction along the South Llano river and they reported that Department of Transportion closed the highway.

The Texas Park and Wildlife Service at Palo Duro Canyon State Park reported that the water crossings were inundated with several feet of rapidly flowing water. There was two and a half feet of fast flowing water which was continuing to rise over water crossing number one.
Several roads were flooded.
Numerous roads were flooded including FM 913 in Selden.
Several streets were flooded in town.
Flooding reported near Highway 121 and 360.
Law Enforcement Officials reported County Road 151 was impassable due to flooding in Buffalo Gap.
Four feet of water was reported over the access road of  Interstate 20 near Clyde.
Quite a bit of urban flooding was reported on the eastern side of Abilene along with several street closures.
Flooding was reported on Trinity Boulevard in west Fort Worth.
Minor to major street flooding as a result of heavy rainfall was reported in Colorado City.
Reports of flooding were received near the city of Ira on Farm to Market Road 1606.
Flash flooding reported.
Heavy rains caused a creek to overflow it's banks along Highway 158 just to the east of Bronte. One foot of water covered 158.
Heavy Rains of 2 to 5 inches fell in the immediate vicinity of Carlsbad and produced enough rise to flood the East Carlsbad Loop in a short amount of time.
Very heavy rains produced flash flooding throughout Brownwood. Severe street flooding occurred and rescues of people from homes was also reported.
Several small creeks out of their banks.
Four feet of water was over the intersection of FM 581 and CR 2600.

A woman and four children had to be rescued when their SUV stalled in high water on Foundation Street near Highway 377.  The water was halfway up the sides of the vehicle.  Old Stony Road near the Wise County line was closed after parts of it washed out.
Flooding reported along East Broad Street between Highways 287 and 360.
Water was running over roads and yards.  Also, FM 1565 south of Highway 276 was closed due to flooding.
Flooding reported in town and along Highways 6 and 485.
FM 486 at Mustang Creek closed for high water.

Local emergency management officials reported that most Farm to Market Roads west of New Home in northwestern Lynn County were covered by fast moving high water. Newspaper accounts suggest that between four and six inches of rainfall was measured by several locals along the storm's path. Reports indicated that a number of people were stranded in flooded vehicles. No injuries were reported.
Streets had to be closed and cars were stranded in Olney.  Two high water rescues were required.  Water rushed through the back door of a convenience store and down the aisles.
Skywarn spotters reported flash flooding that resulted in flowing water over Farm to Market Road 54 east of Petersburg.

Thunderstorms through the late afternoon produced a general rainfall of 1 to 2 inches over western Llano and Gillespie Counties.  Up to 4 inches fell in the area from Castell to the Gillespie County line.  Rural roads in west and southwest Llano County were closed, including FM152 at the Llano River.
|Fire department officials reported that minor flooding resulted in up to eight inches of standing water in many city streets in Ralls.

Cars were stranded in high water near Quinlan.  Three homes were flooded and had to be evacuated in the Rolling Oaks subdivision on the south shore of Lake Tawakoni.  Several roads were flooded and barricaded, and a culvert on Northshore Road near Lake Tawakoni was washed out.

A sixteen-year-old girl was pulled under by strong flood waters after her and her friends went swimming in the swollen Paluxy River.  The girl's body was found early Friday morning.  A game warden drowned while searching for her body after the search boat capsized.
Numerous roads underwater.  Two cars were stranded in high water and rescues were required.

Parking lots were flooded and a creek was out of its banks near the intersection of Highways 121 and 360.  Also, water 8-10 inches deep on Interstate 30 near Hulen Mall in Fort Worth.  Multiple vehicles were stalled in high water, and officials estimate about 50 people had to be rescued.  Less than ten homes received water damage.  In Arlington, three schools were flooded.
Several cars were stranded in high water.  Local residents reported some damage due to the high water.

Local officials reported that numerous roadways in southern Bailey County were impacted by high water following torrential rainfall from strong thunderstorms. The most significant flash flooding was reported to be along Texas Highway 214 near the Muleshoe Wildlife Refuge. No damage was reported.

Flooding was reported along Highways 183 and 190 near the city.  Water was as high as four feet on Highway 183.  Evacuations were required near Mesquite Creek.  Numerous low water crossings were barricaded.  About twenty apartments and several homes were damaged by high water and deemed unihabitable.  Many of the residents lost most of their possessions.  In addition, the School Creek Bridge was washed away, with the road closed indefinitely.

Numerous high water rescues were required in Killeen.  Downtown roads were impassable and several roads were closed.  Also, a high water rescue was required near Harker Heights on FM 3249.  Many residents were forced to evacuate their homes.  Several people had to wait on their roofs for help to arrive.  A woman had to be rescued from a tree after her car was washed off of the bridge on FM 2484.
One-and-a-half-feet of water over roads.
Two high water rescues required. Bowie Road was flooded and barricaded in Mart.
Major flooding was reported in South Fort Worth in the Candleridge subdivision.  A community center was opened for residents who needed shelter.
Barricades needed for the Lake Kiowa area; water flooded at least one home.
Widely scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts between Lake Amistad and Del Rio.  Flash flooding closed FM454 and FM349 west of Del Rio.

Between 4 and 6 inches of rain fell in thunderstorms along the Burnet-Lampasas County line in the northwest part of Burnet County. Flash flooding closed US281 through the early morning hours.  Many rural roads, including FM2341, were also closed.
FM 730 between Boyd and Decatur had high water, as did FM 248 near Boyd.  Trees were also downed due to the saturated soil.
FM 437 at Cypress Creek was closed due to flooding in Buckholts, and a flooded house was evacuated in Cameron.  The house and some of its contents were considered a total loss.

Several roads remained flooded and closed from earlier rains, including FM 1915 at Big Elm Creek, FM 1915 at Little River, CR 143, 147, 119, 120, and 240; FM 486 at Little River, FM 487 at San Gabriel River, and FM 908 at Brushy Creek; CR 407 at Clay's Creek, and CR 443 at Turkey Creek north of Thorndale.  The culvert on CR 330 in Milano was washed out.
Old Alton Road in Denton was closed due to flooding as was the Interstate 35 service road in Denton.
Flash flooding of streets in and around the city of Decatur was reported.

Major flash flooding was reported across the county, and more than 60 people were rescued from floodwaters.  One observer reported over 10 inches of rain for the day.  A roof of an elementary school collapsed due to the weight of the water.  About a half foot of water was reported over streets in Shady Shores, Little Elm, the University of North Texas campus, and along I-35 east service roads.  A nursing home and a mobile home park were both evacuated due to threatening flood waters.  Several roads remained closed for more than 24 hours, including Corbin Road, Mayhill Road, and East Hickory Street.  Several roads and guardrails were damaged by the water.  Denton County was declared a disaster area and was therefore able to recieve federal aid.  At least a hundred people reported flood damage to their local jurisdictions.  Some had water 3 feet high in their homes and businesses.
Several houses flooded in town.
Neighborhood streets were flooded, and at least one car was stranded.  The Collin County Health Department was flooded as well, damaging the computer system.
Two to three feet of rushing water across city streets in Gainesville resulted in several stalled vehicles and high water rescues.

Several roads were flooded in Killeen and Harker Heights.  The Killeen Police Department urged residents to stay off flooded roadways.  Mobile home parks were flooded, and one permanent residence near Nolan Creek had four feet of water inside.  A mobile home was washed into Nolan Creek and caught fire when the gas line hit a bridge.  At least two cars were swept away into the creek.  A man who was near a culvert when the rain began also drowned.
High water closed Highway 190 near Clear Creek. A minivan was washed off FM 3046 about one-half mile south of Highway 116.  The occupants exited the vehicle but drowned.
Standing water was reported to inundate many roadways, including the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1328 and U.S. Highway 380.
Old Mart Road, South Third Street, Tradinghouse Lane, and Boys Ranch Road were closed due to flooding.

Law enforcement officials reported that a number of streets in the Levelland vicinity were blockaded due to flood waters. The intersection of Avenue U and West Avenue was reportedly impassable by 13:43 CST. Additional flooding was reported along U.S. Highway 385 and Texas Highway 114.

|Local officials reported that heavy rainfall caused between one and two feet of water to accumulate and pond in a construction zone at the bottom of the U.S. Highway 83 underpass in Childress. A vehicle became disabled as it tried to navigate through the high water. Rescue crews extracted the occupants from the flooded vehicle. No injuries were reported.
|Low-lying areas across Denver City were flooded, with water more than curb-deep in most city streets. A vehicle was stalled in high water during the late morning hours. No injuries were reported.
In Royse City, FM 548 at Lakes Drive was flooded.  Parker Creek was over its banks.  FM 549 north of Highway 66 and FM 2642 were flooded near Fate.
Bee Creek Road near Maypearl and Highway 34 at FM 1181 near Ennis were closed due to flooding.
High water was reported on FM 2190 and on several other roads in the western and northwestern portions of the county.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over southern Fayette County with highest amounts of 4 inches near Schulenburg. SH95 and FM609 were closed due to high water.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts over northern Lavaca County, with highest totals of 6 inches north of Hallettsville. Flash flooding closed several roads, including FM532.
Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 1 to 3 inch rain amounts with up to 6 inches near Northrup.  Flash flooding closed many rural roads, including FM141 and FM448.

A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station near Floydada recorded 2.60 inches of rainfall in a thirty minute period just before 22:00 CST. By 22:05 CST, the heavy rainfall began to cause a rapid rise of water in the city. A number of homes and businesses were threatened by the rising water. Water isolated the Dairy Queen, along with a few mobile homes and the ACE Hardware store. Road crews had to repair damage caused by the water on some main city streets.

Relayed that the Amarillo Police Department shut down both the east and west bound lanes of Interstate 40 and Washington Street underpass and rerouted traffic. Also...curb to curb flooding was reported at Crockett Street and 42nd Avenue. Water three feet deep was reported on Northeast 24th Street just inside Loop 335. Water was reported to be two to three feet deep at the intersection of Julian Boulevard and West 15th Avenue. The eastbound exit of Interstate 40 and Ross Street was closed due to high water.

Persistent and heavy rainfall resulted in flooding across portions of Lubbock. The flooding was characterized by a gradual increase in water level near many playa lakes, in construction zones, and in typically flood prone city streets.|Initial reports at 12:53 CST indicated that water was over the curbs along Elgin Street between 75th and 78th Streets, and also at the intersection of University and 82nd. By 13:34 CST up to two feet of water was reported in many of the city streets in Idalou. At 13:38 CST, local officials blockaded several blocks of Peoria Street due to high water.|Between 14:00 and 14:30 CST reports were received of road closings at Frankford Avenue and 98th Street and Erskine Avenue between the 4800 block and Loop 289.|Water continued to rise across Lubbock, and by 15:04 CST, at least one vehicle stalled in standing water that was up to the doors on 98th Street between Quaker and Slide. Several automobiles were reportedly stalled in heavy flooding at Milwaukee and 34th Street, and also at Avenue U and 50th Street, and the intersection of Erskine and Milwaukee.|No injuries were reported. However, the Lubbock Police Department attributed thirty-one traffic accidents to the weather.

A car was swept into a creek near CR 370 off of FM 1702 near the Hazeldell community.  An 82-year-old man was rescued.  A female occupant in the vehicle drowned.  Also, in Proctor, a woman drove a truck into a flooded creek at Old Fleming Road at the Proctor cut off.  She was rescued by two citizens who broke the back window of the truck out.  She suffered minor injuries from broken glass and some bruises.

Many reports of flash flooding were received from near the Hale and Floyd County line northeastward to Floydada. Many secondary roads were inundated by flowing flood waters including Farm to Market Road 54. In Floydada, a playa lake on the south side of the city flooded and caused high water to threaten a number of mobile homes and two businesses. High water also flowed over Highway 62 south of the city.

Flooding of numerous streets in Ozona due to flooding from the draw that runs through town. Highway 163 south of Ozona and highway 290 east of Ozona were closed due to flooding. The intersection of highways 163 and 137 located 3 miles to the north of Ozona was also flooded.
Flooding was reported along Clyde Lake Road and the access road to Interstate 20.
Highway 864 one half mile south of U.S. 190 was closed due to flood waters.
The radio station in Colorado City reported that streets in Loraine were flooded.
Numerous county roads were reportedly inundated by flowing flood waters from just south of Farwell to the Parmer/Bailey County line.  No damage was reported.

Several county roads in and round Alice were closed due to flooding.  Alice city officials reported that some residents were evacuated for minor flooding near low lying creeks, mainly over the northeast portion of the city.  Water was reported in several business around town.|
Several Farm-to-Market roads flooded in and around Hearne and Highway 79.
Numerous Farm-to-Market roads flooded in the southeastern part of the county.
Part of a bridge washed away on Possum Trot Road and left a large sinkhole half the width of the road.  One other road was washed away, and several others were flooded.
Flash flooding reported on roads in Arlington.
A bridge between Terrel and Crockett County in southwest Crockett County was impassable due to high water across the Pecos River.
Highway 377 southwest of Juntion was closed due to flooding.
Water was over the road on Highway 87 near the Concho County line. Traffic was backed up due to the flooding.
Water was reported flowing out of the ditches and across Highway 87 near Posche.
Water continues to flow across Highway 87. Road was impassible.
Two feet of water was reported flowing over County Road 180 between Brownwood and Bangs.

Flooding reported around the Richland-Chambers Reservoir.  Emergency rescues were needed for residents in Powell, including one high water rescue.  Numerous roads were closed, including CR 2160, CR 3143 and CR 3144.
Highway 315 was flooded.

A man who had drove into high water on CR 3827 was found dead two days later.  He had originally left his pick-up truck in the high water, then went back to help a passenger.  The passenger was able to reach safety.
Road closed in town due to flash flooding.
Water was reported over the road at the intersection of 2111 and Highway 83.
Highway 2129 was closed off of Loop 312 due to high water across the road.
Farm to Market Road 2569 between Eldorado and Sonora was closed because of flooding.
Farm to Market road 915 between Eldorado and Mertzon was closed due to high water.
A road was closed because of flooding near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 604 and Highway 36.
County Road 244 was closed due to flooding just east of Eula School.
Significant street flooding was reported in Brady. Many streets were closed.

Excessive heavy rainfall fell across Smith County during the early morning hours of May 25th. Flash flooding was reported across parts of the county...especially in Tyler where major street flooding was reported near the local hospital.
Three feet of water was reported at Hillside Road and Hampton Drive.
Flooding reported on CR 341 and CR 328.  Both roads were closed.  The city park was also evacuated due to flooding.

A high water rescue was required due to flooding at the 3500 block of East Main Street.  A car was trapped under a railroad trestle.  The occupant was rescued and treated for minor injuries.  High water was also reported at Loop 12 and Highway 183, and on I-35 East under the Mockingbird Lane bridge.
Flash flooding was reported in north McAllen on Pecan Street.
Texas DPS reported water covering U.S. Highway 77 in Combes.
Texas DPS reported water covering U.S. Highway 77 in Raymondville.
Several streets in the city were closed due to high water.
St. HWY 79 at FM 2224 was closed due to high water.
St. HWY 79 closed due to high water.
FM 1197 was closed due to high water. Water from Long Creek was four feet deep over the roadway.
HWY 283 was closed due to high water.
TXDOT reported several roads flooded in western Bee county, including portions of F.M. 796, 1349 and 797 south of Beeville and F.M. 799 west of Beeville.|

A widespread 4 to 6 inches of torrential rainfall fell across Laredo during the early morning hours with localized amounts possibly up to 8 inches.  4.29 was recorded by a television station on the north side of town.  5.41 was recorded at the Laredo International Airport between 1 and 3 AM CDT before lightning knocked out the AWISS site.  Widespread flash flooding occurred on many city streets and several creeks and storm drainage ditches across Laredo.  Over 100 vehicles were stalled in high water and many vehicles were carried off of streets by the high water.  A van with 6 family members drove into high water near Century Blvd and Loop 20.  The van became buoyant and was swept into Chacon Creek shortly before 330 AM CDT.  The family abandoned the van and 5 members were able to escape to higher ground, however a 14 year girl drowned in the creek.  Another vehicle was also swept into the same creek.  All four occupants of this vehicle were able to escape to higher ground.||The high water resulted in major damage to 18 homes and minor damage to 50 others.  An unspecified number of businesses in sections of the city also had damage from the high water.|||
US 283/183 was closed due to high water.
St. HWY 148 was closed due to high water.
Water covered many roads in Odell, making them impassable.
US 287 near Oklaunion, US 70 between Oklaunion and the Red River Bridge, and the intersection of US 70 and FM 2073 west of Lockett were closed due to high water.

Widespread street flooding was reported in Greenville, and Highway 69 southeast of town was also flooded.  FM 1564 and FM 2101 were also flooded.  Flooding was reported around Cedar Creek and Club Lake.  A man who's car stalled in high water was rescued after clinging to a tree for four hours.
The following areas were closed due to high water: CR 2200 at CR 2600, School Creek Crossing at CR 2200, and Barkley Road at CR 2080.
Street flooding was reported in Waco and along Interstate 35 service roads.
FM 3079 was impassable due to high water.
Major flooding was reported in Rockdale with several stranded motorists.  FM 1600 near Cameron was also closed due to high water.
FM 0422 was closed from the center of town to the high school due to high water. Other roads were closed as well.
The roadway that approaches City Lake at Archer City was flooded due to continued heavy rainfall.
Falfurias law enforcement reported water covering the intersection of Highway 285 and FM 1418 one and one half miles east of Falfurias.
Highway 34 was flooded near Ennis, and roadblocks were set up for high water near Crisp and outside of Bristol.  Novy Road and FM 660 had several feet of rushing water across them.
Six feet of water flowed through Comanche Creek across Farm to Market Road 170 just northeast of Lajitas.

The heavy rainfall flooded several F.M. roads east of I-37.  Flooding was also reported over U.S. 59 just west of the Bee county line.    Rushing water was also reported along frontage roads of I-37 near George West.  A vehicle was reported by media floating in a creek near Goynes Junction at I-37 and U.S. 59.  All passengers escaped.|
Dewey Street was closed due to high water as were several other county roads.  A couple roads were damaged.
HWY 79 was closed due to continued high water.
HWY 148 was closed due to high water between Henrietta and Petrolia.
HWY 368 was closed between HWY 25 and Holliday due to high water.
Flooded roads were reported.
High water was reported over Highway 46.
Two streets were closed in town due to flooding.
Local street flooding reported on Highway 34 north of Highway 80 and on State Street.
Highway 31 between the two cities was flooded.
Several roads were flooded including Highway 175, Highway 31 at FM 3441, and FM 59 near Athens.
Moderate street flooding reported in Harlingen by an NWS employee near Ed Carey road and U.S. Highway 77.
Moderate street flooding reported in Harlingen by an NWS employee near Ed Carey road and U.S. Highway 77.
Highway 380 was closed due to flooding as were roads in Hawk Cove.

Several roads and highways were closed, including CR 448 in the Montalba area and CR 425 off of FM 322.  A few bridges were washed out across the county.  A 20' x 40' swath of CR 4034 was washed away, stranding several households.  A water line servicing about twenty homes was also swept away.
Willow Creek flooded McLeroy Boulevard and Longhorn Drive in Saginaw, and Comanche Creek flooded Comanche Trail and Marina Drive by three feet of water.  All roads were barricaded.
Flooding was reported on Virginia Street.

Highway 22 near Meridian was flooded, and the Bosque River flooded the city park and forced the evacuation of a jail.  Near Valley Mills, Highway 56 was flooded and a bridge on CR 3491 was damaged.  The Bosque River also flooded Riverside Drive and Whipple Bridge.
Texas General Land Office reported an estimated one foot of water covering the streets in downtown Harlingen.
A bridge was washed out and flooding reported in the city.
The heavy rain caused a creek to flood county roads with fast moving waters, between F.M. 1203 and FM 1358.|
Rio Grande City Police Department reports heavy rain and street flooding.
Willacy County Sheriff's Office reported water covering the intersection of Highway 186 and Farm to Market Road 1420 in San Perlita.
Texas DPS in McAllen reported water covering Farm to Market Road 1925 east of U.S. Highway 281 in Edinburg.
Texas General Land Office reported flash flooding of U.S. Highway 77 and its frontage road in San Benito.
Texas General Land Office reported flash flooding of Ed Carey Road in Harlingen near Business Highway 77.
Significant flash flooding was reported in the Mariposa subdivision of north Harlingen with water up to car headlights.
Flash flooding was reported in San Benito on Business Highway 77 and Farm to Market Road 510.
Texas Department of Transportation reported flash flooding of Farm to Market Road 506 and Farm to Market Road 107 in Santa Rosa with one and a half feet of water covering the roads.
Flash flooding was reported on Farm to Market Road 1925 between FM 1423 and FM 493.  Flooding was also reported on Business Highway 83 between FM 1423 and FM 907 with several cars stalled.
Two houses on Coleman Road were evacuated due to continued high water. Monetary damages were estimated.
Streets were closed due to flooding.
Widespread flooding occurred throughout the city of Alpine. Low water crossings had up to 1.5 feet of water running over the road. Several streets had to be closed due to high water from heavy rains.

Eighteen inches of water accumulated in the underpass of Interstate 20 and Farm to Market Road 1788.  While water normally gathers here, pumps are available to pump the water out of the pass.  Because the power was knocked out by 93 mph winds, the pumps were inoperable and water remained throughout much of the following day.  The underpass was closed to traffic until the water was able to be pumped out.
City hall and the municipal plaza buildings were flooded in downtown Odessa.
A high water rescue was required at White Settlement Road and also on Jacksboro Highway near Loop 820.
Several roads were under water and closed.
High water was over Highway 581 between Adamsville and Lometa.
The east fork of the Trinity River rose as high as the bottoms of bridges.
Street flooding occurred in town and also at the intersection of Highway 6 and Interstate 20.

A series of thunderstorms moved through south and central Travis County, producing 2 to 3 inch rain totals and isolated amounts as high as 4 inches just west of Manor.  Flash flooding closed Loyola Lane, Oneil Drive, Bee Caves Road in Oak Hill, and Mopac near Loop1 and Parmer Rd.
Thunderstorms over Bastrop County produced between 1 and 2 inches of rain, with highest amounts near 4 inches in the Bastrop area.  FM20 and FM1441 were closed due to high water.

Torrential rain fell across the central and northern portions of the county, causing very significant flooding in some locations.  Four-and-a-quarter inches of rain fell between midnight and 1:45 AM in Keller, where more than twenty homes suffered flood damage.  A food bank in Keller also sustained significant damage.  A foot-and-a-half of water was reported at the intersection of Highway 377 and Bear Creek Parkway.  In Watauga, people were stranded on roofs as water rose very quickly.  Several homes were damaged by floodwaters in Haltom City.  Hundreds of high water rescues were required.  Nine mobile homes were destroyed and ninety were damaged by floodwaters in Haltom City, and one girl drowned after her rescue boat capsized.  Several fires were reported as the trailers were pushed from their electrical wires, and at least one trailer burned completely.  Two people were hospitalized after their home caught on fire.  The force of the water ripped up asphalt and pushed cars into each other.  Seven baseball fields in Haltom City were destroyed.  They were valued at $200,000.  Water was also reported over Interstate 820 near North Richland Hills.

Several roads were closed due to flooding near Callisburg, Gainesville, and Valley View, including FM 371 at FM 2986, FM 678 north of Highway 82, FM 2071 at FM 922, FM 922 east of Valley View, and Interstate 35 access roads near Gainesville.

Water was reported over Highways 51 and 114 in Boyd, and up to two feet of water was over FM 2123 and CR 3188 southwest of Decatur.  Several houses were flooded and had to be evacuated in Decatur.  West Thompson Street was also flooded in Decatur, where a high water rescue was needed.
Highway 51 between Decatur and Slidell was closed due to high water.

Two lines of thunderstorms, one moving south from the Dallas area and one moving southeast from the Abilene area, intersected and stalled  near Marble Falls, producing a 6-8 inch rainfall over western Williamson County, with up to 14 inches between Florence and Liberty.  Most roads in the west and south portion of the county were closed through the mid morning, including highly traveled thoroughfares such as US183 and SH29.

Two lines of thunderstorms, one moving south from the Dallas area and one moving southeast from the Abilene area, intersected and stalled near Marble Falls, producing a sustained heavy rainfall over Burnet County from just before midnight into the early and mid morning hours.  General rainfall over the southern half of Burnet County was between 10 and 15 inches with the highest rain totals in the Marble Falls area, where up to 19 inches fell. The hardest hit area was Marble Falls, where more than 315 homes and businesses were damaged or destroyed.  The worst of the damage occurred along Whitman Branch Creek.  This included businesses and even a day care facility.  Personnel from Texas Military Forces were mobilized and sent into Marble Falls to help with rescues and evacuations.  The military personnel, along with swift water rescue and other first responders, completed 32 high water rescues and evacuated hundreds of residents.  Shelters were set up at the Marble Falls Middle School.  At least eight bridges in Burnet County were destroyed with some amount of damage to nearly every road and structure in the southern half of the county.  Most roads remained closed all day, but a few were re-opened in the late afternoon.  Cars and vans were strewn all up and down US281 in the Marble Falls area.  Nearly all parks and lakes were closed.  Businesses in Marble Falls were also closed. Drinking water in Marble Falls was contaminated by the flood and over 1000 residents were without water for at least a week. Total estimates of the damages were placed at $130,000,000.  One swift water rescue team member was forced to save himself when his vehicle was washed off SH71 near Double Horn Creek.  He was able to get to dry land after a prolonged struggle.  A couple in Marble Falls awoke to find their home flooded and with the water rising rapidly.  They scrambled to the highest point in the one-story house as the water continued to rise.  Finally, they had to use a shotgun to blast holes in the ceiling so they could break through to climb up on the roof.  They waited with their two dogs on the roof in the dark for 2 hours, then were able to climb down and take shelter in a barn as the water receded slightly.  They waited for an additional 12 hours until they were finally rescued by boat.  Two young men were attempting to drive from a home in Marble Falls to Leander via FM 1431 sometime in the early morning hours of June 27 when their jeep was swept into high water east of Marble Falls. The vehicle was located a few days later in a creek about 10 miles east of Marble Falls.  The body of one of the young men was recovered several days later but the remains of the other young man have not been found.

Scattered to numerous thunderstorms over eastern Medina and Frio Counties and produced general 2 to 3 inch rainfall.  Highest rain totals in Medina County were 6 inches west of Mico.  Flash flooding closed FM471, FM1283, and SH173.

Highway 6 was shut down due to flooding between Clifton and Valley Mills.  Also, the intersections of CR 3455 and CR 3125, FM 219 at Womack Street, FM 2490 and FM 1637L were flooded.  Two high water rescues were required.

Numerous streets and the intersection of Loop 281 and Hwy. 80 under water.  A tree fell on top of a home in town resulting in moderate damage to the home.  The prolonged heavy rain and the super saturation of the soil allowed the tree to fall as the weight of the tree was too heavy for the root system to support it.

Several roads closed due to flooding across the county.  A couple had to be rescued from their home in Winona, Texas when Harris Creek near county road 354 came up suddenly.  Some of the roads that had to be closed included county roads 262...2122...1156...146...165...2180... 2276...2143...461 and 289.  Other closed roads included county roads 2103...1114...1308...490...1143...2195...1145 and 179.
Interstate 35 at exit 366 near Abbott was under water, and a bridge on CR 2415 south west of Peoria was washed away.  Street flooding was also reported in Hillsboro.
FM 590 was flooded near the Brown/Comanche County line.
High water was reported at the intersection of CR 1151 and CR 1154 near Celeste.
Numerous roads were closed near Lindsay including CR 303, CR 460, Cheney Road, and Chapparal Lane.
Several streets were flooded and barricaded, including the intersection of Main Street and Grand Avenue.  Water was also in houses on Bluebonnet and Grove Streets.

Local law enforcement official reported that flash flooding resulted in rapidly flowing water over U.S. Highway 380 west of Tahoka. In addition, flowing flood waters inundated several county roads near New Home.

Several homes and apartments were flooded in Trophy Club, and two elderly couples had to be rescued from their apartments.  Water was flowing swiftly across roads in Ponder, and Hickory Creek was out of its banks in the central part of the county.  A vehicle was swept away on Mingo Road at Cooper Creek.

Significant flooding occurred with cars and mobile homes moved by the force of the water.  Numerous roads were closed across the county, including Highways 377 and 75, and more than 450 people were rescued from high water.  One woman died in floodwaters as she drove on Texoma Parkway under the U.S. Highway 75 overpass.  Another fatality occurred when a truck flooded at the intersection of FM 1417 and Highway 11.  A bridge on Highway 11 south of Sherman suffered extensive damage.

Numerous roads were closed across the county due to flooding.  Also, portions of a railroad track washed out, causing a train derailment the next day.  Four cars fell over and the line had to be shut down.
A flooded creek washed out a bridge on CR 2721.  A truck was driven into the water and had to be retrieved.

High water was reported on FM 219 west of Highway 281, at FM 1602 three miles east of Highway 281, and on 5th Street in Hico.  The water was several feet deep.  County Commissioners estimated road damage at $2 million.
Flooding occurred on city streets and low water crossings.  County Commissioners estimated damage at $0.6 million.
Highway 92 west of town was under water and barricaded, as was FM 103 north of town.  Several other roads were closed due to high water as well.
Several spots on Highway 36 were flooded, as was FM 2318 and FM 587 near DeLeon.
Highway 34, FM 986, Rockwall, Catherine, and Main Streets were closed due to high water.  There were several stranded motorists.  Trash cans and other items were seen floating down streets.
Highway 79 north of town closed due to flooding.

Significant flooding occurred in the central portions of the county with numerous high water rescues required.  People were forced to cut holes in their roofs in order to escape floodwaters in Gainesville, and several mobile homes were damaged.  A mobile home along Pecan Creek was thrown into the floodwaters and came to stop only when it hit a bridge.  Four family members were dumped into the creek and three of them drowned.  Interstate 35 service roads and the northbound lane were flooded near Valley View.  Interstate 35 had to be closed between Highway 82 and the Oklahoma border just north of Gainesville.  Water was 2-3 feet deep over streets in Lindsay.  A total of 300 homes and 75 businesses suffered water damage across the county, and 37,000 acres of crops were destroyed.  The mayor estimated damages around $28 million, and the governor issued a disaster declaration for the county.

Up to 3 inches of rain was produced by showers and thunderstorms in less than one hour between Plum and LaGrange.  As a result of the heavy rainfall, FM609, FM154 were closed through the late night and into the early morning.

FM 1602 between Highway 281 and Highway 22 was flooded northeast of Hamilton, and Highway 218 was flooded between Hamilton and Pottsville.  County Commissioners estimated road damage around $2 million.
Several county and secondary roads were under water.  Vehicles were in high water on Hilltop Road near Cleburne State Park.
Many county roads around town flooded.
The intersection of CR 341 and CR 335 was barricaded due to high water.
In Hamilton, McCaleb Lane and Pipes Street were flooded by at least two feet of water.
Streets and yards were flooded by several feet of water.  A few roads were washed out and bridges were damaged.
Minor street flooding reported.
FM 47 near Lake Tawakoni flooded as well as many county roads.
Streets were flooded and vehicles stranded.
A foot-and-a-half of water was reported over FM 2823.
Secondary roads were closed due to flooding in the eastern portion of the county.
A quick 1 to 3 inches of rain resulted in flooding of Canal Street, Mines Road and McPherson Drive in Laredo.|

Interstate 820 had water flowing over the road which impeded traffic in one direction.  Major flooding was reported over roads in Watauga and Haltom City.  Six department stores, including Sears, were flooded at the mall, and eight homes were flooded in Watauga.  Firefighters performed forty high water rescues.  The hardest hit areas were near Trinity Boulevard and Precinct Line Road, Vickery Boulevard and Bishop Street, and Mark IV Parkway and Loop 820.  Several athletic fields were under water.
Water was reported over Highway 6 south of Perry.
High water was reported over FM 246 and FM 80.
Thunderstorms in the Round Mountain area dropped up to 4 inches of rain, causing flash flooding that closed FM962 through the late evening.
Jim Hogg County sheriff Department reported standing water om FM 1017 and Highway 16. Fm 1017 from Hebbronville to 18 miles south is impassible.

Up to three feet of water was reported at the intersection of Bonner and Ferguson Streets. A car was stalled with occupants inside needing police assistance.  County road 2301 was also washed out due to excessive heavy rainfall and flash flooding.

Hwy. 79 was closed near Jacksonville, Texas due to high water.  Nearly 20 homes suffered flood damage when Lake Jacksonville rose two feet above normal.  The lake had to be closed as several secondary roadways leading into and around the lake were flooded.
The Brazos River flooded due to continued runoff from recent heavy rainfall, causing damage to several homes and vehicles.
Pecan Branch Creek flooded causing water to reach the steps of several nearby homes.  The Division Street Bridge was impassable.
Roads were flooded.

Storms produced general accumulations of 2 to 3 inches over southern Williamson county, with up to 5 inches in the Round Rock area.  Water was reported to be over Parmer Road near Kings Village. FM620 was also closed due to high water in the Round Rock area.
Flooding continued over the northwestern portion of the county from previous rainfall.  Several roads were damaged and two bridges were washed out.

Runoff from heavy rains caused Mills Creek to flood portions of Salado, including Mill Creek Drive and Smith Bluff.  About 30 homes were evacuated and one man had to be rescued from his rooftop.  A water rescue was required on the Little River, and Salado Creek flooded the Interstate 35 access roads and the bridge on Main Street by four feet of water.  One vehicle was washed off the road and a high water rescue was needed.
Robinson Creek flooded homes in Lake Granbury Harbor Estates due to runoff from earlier rainfall.  Four people were rescued from a stranded van in a low-water crossing by the lake.
Highway 79 southwest of Olney was under water, and debris was floating in the water at FM 209 and Highway 3109.
Streets flooded and a couple roads closed in and around town.

Thunderstorms in southeast Llano County produced a general rainfall of 1 to 2 inches, with up to 4 inches near Sunrise Beach.  FM2900 and FM2233 were closed through much of the evening due to high water.
A high water rescue was required for three children who had been playing in Johnson Creek and were swept away.  The children were treated for minor injuries.
Loop 820 was closed near the Lancaster Road exit due to flooding.  Also, several roads were closed in Arlington due to high water.  One home in Arlington was partially flooded.
CR 31 and Barton Chapel Road were closed from previous flooding.
A high water rescue was required.
Roads were flooded in several places around town.

Hwy. 84 near Rusk was closed due to high water.  Numerous areas flooded and the Texas State Railroad track between Maydelle and Rusk sustained serious flood damage as an embankment washed out near county road 2108.
Two feet of water was over Highway 22 west of town.

Multiple high water rescues were required in Lake Granbury Harbor near Robinson Creek.  Several people were stranded in their homes and some were stuck in trees.  About fifty homes sustained flood damage.
Flooding continued from previous rains on FM 2823 northeast of Gustine and along Highway 36 from Gustine to the Comanche/Hamilton County line.

|The Texas Department of Transportation used road graders to clear mud flow debris of more than one foot in depth that resulted from flash flooding over a number of southeast Hockley County roadways. The worst flooding occurred along Farm to Market Roads 2646, 3261, and 1585.
FM 437 near the Bell County line was partially washed out and closed.  Numerous other roads were also closed due to high water.
Several roads remained closed including FM 4 south of Interstate 20, South Lake View Road, FM 2201 and FM 919 north of Gordon, and Highway 281 south of FM 4.
Heavy rains caused flooding and the eventual closing of Highway 586 near Thrifty and FM 2492 near Bangs.
Highway 864 was closed for a time near Fort McKavett due to flooding.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated that Farm Roads 2163 and 618 as well as Highway 380 were flooded across parts of the county.|
The public reports extensive flooding is occurring in the city of Roma. Numerous streets are impassible. Local streams and arroyos are flowing and their banks are full.
Heavy rains produced urban flooding in San Angelo with many of the low water crossings flooded on the west side of town. There were some swift water rescues performed during this heavy rain event.
Heavy rains of about 3 inches caused some flooding around Throckmorton with water reported over the road just north of the town.

Winters Fire Department performed a high water rescue of a motorist whose vehicle was swept off County Road 300 just northwest of Winters. The fire department also reported numerous flooded roads in and around Winters.

Early on the 25th, heavy rainfall across northern Runnels County near Winters, created a significant rise along Elm Creek.  The Elm Creek at Ballinger climbed quickly above flood stage (7 feet) and crested just over eight feet during the afternoon of the 25th.  Additional rises occurred over the next several days as showers continued to linger across the region.
Swift water rescues were required, and a boy drowned during a rescue attempt in Duck Creek in Garland.
Flooding of residences around Lake Leon continued from residual floodwaters flowing into the lake.  Over 200 homes sustained flood damage.
A skywarn spotter reported street flooding in north McAllen on Ware Road.
