Law enforcement officials reported six feet of water at Pine street and South First at the underpass. Many other streets around the shopping mall were flooded by two feet of water. Also Cat Claw creek was bankfull and about one foot from overflowing its banks.
Law enforcement reported that County Road 611 west of Rotan was flooded and impassable.
Heavy rains caused Tiger Creek to go over the road.

Significant street flooding occurred in Brownwood with cars stalled in the high water. Other roads in the county around Brownwood were closed due to flooding including Farm to Market Road 2525 and County Roads 257 and 234.
Local law enforcement officials in Throckmorton County indicate that water was over Highways 209 and 380.

Numerous periods of heavy rain over the Pecan Bayou watershed caused Lake Brownwood to climb on the 26th.  Overnight of the 28th into early on the 29th, the lake crested at 4.2 feet above the spillway.  As the water flowed downstream through the City of Brownwood, streets were flooded as the water backed up as it flowed into the local creeks.

Several farm to market roads across Coleman County were closed because of high water. FM2805 from the junction of U.S. 67 to State Highway 153 was closed. FM2131 from Shields to Coleman was closed. Also FM0503 from the intersection of State Highway 206 to the McCulloch County line was closed.

Very heavy rains over the southwest side of San Angelo caused water to rise on the side streets just off of Loop 306 in Southwest San Angelo.  The water depth was up to the floor board of vehicles. Law enforcement also reported a water rescue as well.
Runoff from earlier rains caused Salt Creek to crest and flood a parking lot near Highway 61.  The creek was up to the bottom of the Highway 67 bridge.

Houses and roads were flooded in town.  Four cars were reportedly under water.  Three to four feet of water was reported over Highway 4 between Lipan and Granbury, and Kickapoo Creek was washing pavement off roads in Lipan.
Flooding was reported along FM Roads 152,386 and 1871 in Mason County.|
A few roads around Brady, and several farm to market roads were closed across McCulloch County because of flooding from heavy rains that fell across the county.
Law enforcement reported one and a half feet of water was over the road at U.S. highway 67 between Valera and Talpa.
High water was reported on Highway 281 near Antelope and Highway 4 near Bartons Chapel.  Portions of Erwin Road were washed away into a culvert.
Heavy rain caused flooding of Belton Lake, closing numerous nearby parks and recreation facilities.
FM 730 north of Boyd was flooded and CR 2845 was washed out.
High water rescues were required in Celina, and water was over the road near Highway 75 and Belt Line Road, and at Wilmeth Road east of Interstate 75.
Interstate 20 at exit 406 had two feet over water over it.
Water was reported over Interstate 35 service roads.

In Stephenville, water was several feet deep over McCart, Frey, Vanderbilt, and Ollie Streets.  Homes and businesses were flooded in Morgan Mill with CR 146 washed out.  Several families were evacuated.  Flooding was also reported over Highway 281 north of town.
Flooding was reported over roads in town.
Highway 144 north of town was flooded, as were streets in town.  Basements of houses along the Paluxy River were also flooded.
Heavy rain flooded the parking lot of Dollar General by about a foot-and-a-half of water at the intersection of Masch Branch Road and Jackson Road.
Highway 6 was flooded.
Several streets had to be barricaded due to flooding, including Highway 183.
Between 50 to 100 homes in Horseshoe Bend sustained flood damage from the Brazos River.
Flooding continued from previous rains on FM 587 west of town, FM 2318 south of town, and FM 679 north of town.
Flooding continued from previous rains on FM 1447 north of Sidney.
FM 2808, FM 2657, CR 3220, and CR 4804 were impassable due to high water.
FM 1392, CR 235, and Colquitt Road at CR 236 were all flooded and impassable.
Several roads near Cedar Creek Lake were flooded.
Numerous roads flooded countywide.  Cowhouse Creek was out of its banks and about a foot of water was over CR 142.
Highway 16 and CR 218 were closed due to high water.
Portions of Highway 29 were closed near the Brazos River.  Also, Highway 4 near Buck Creek was closed.
The Brazos River flooded the Pecan Plantation RV Campground, damaging six RVs and several cars and trailers.
Flooding of Highway 16 southwest of Hebbronville near Randado was reported.
Streets in Walnut Springs were closed due to flooding; FM 2650 and CR 1120 between Meridian and Morgan were also closed.

High water was reported in Lake Worth on Jacksboro Highway from Boat Club Road to Interstate 820.  Flooding was also reported at the insection of Alta Vista Road and Golden Triangle north of Fort Worth, and over Denton Highway and Broadway Road in Haltom City.  Homes which were flooded recently were flooded again.  Cars were submerged up to their windows near Interstate 820 in Haltom City.  Fort Worth responded to about 75 reports of high water.
Service roads in town were closed due to flooding.
Side streets were flooded in the city.
Interstate 35 service roads were covered with water, as were Waco Drive and Highway 84.
Several streets were flooded and closed.
Highways 16 and 218 were flooded near Priddy.  Numerous roads near Priddy had high water.
Flooding from previous rains continued across the county.  Harmon Road was flooded in the northeastern part of the County and Old Granbury Road and FM 1187 were flooded in the southern part.
Interstate 35 service roads were flooded north of FM 2484.
Several streets were flooded in town.
Lake Proctor rose due to heavy rains and flooded docks and camping areas around its banks.
The Eastland Fire Chief reported about 150 homes were evacuated in the Lake Leon area due to flooding.
Streets were flooded in Plano.
Street flooding was reported in Addison.
Forty to fifty cars stalled along Boca Chica Boulevard with water over the wheel wells in some places.
Several streets were flooded in Abilene and some roads were closed because of the high water.
Water was reported over the road on Farm Road 2834.
Water was reported over the road at US 83 and County Road 159.
One foot of water was reported over the road north of Avoca.
Standing water three feet deep was reported at the intersection of FM 510 and FM 803.
Standing water three to four feet deep was reported on Palm Boulevard.
Numerous streets and roads under standing water 2 feet deep.
Strong thunderstorms produced from 5-7 inches of rain over southwest and western Willacy County.  The rains resulted in the closure of Farm to Market Road 1015 south of Highway 186.
Flash flooding of Farm to Market Road 88 and Highway 107 was reported.
Flash flooding of Farm to Market Road 1015 and Highway 107 reported.
Water was reported over FM1082.
Water was reported over FM604.
Hwy 79 was was closed when six inches of water was running over the pavement.
Water was over Farm Road 613 between Buffalo Gap and Tuscola.
Farm Road 89 at Elm creek is reported to be impassable.
Widespread flooding occured in Big Spring, including 6 inches of running water on several roads.
Flooding was reported along Cedar Creek. Water entered homes along FM1750. Water entered approximately 10 homes and washed out several roads.
Water was reported over FM1085.
Farm Road 604 had about two feet of water over the road, south of Highway 351.

Water was about eight inches deep on roads in Duncanville.  In Dallas, Love Freeway and South Hampton Street were closed due to flooding.  Five children became stranded under a bridge in Cedar Creek and had to be rescued.
FM 514 and several other roads were flooded.  CR 4470 and CR 4480 had two to three feet of water over them.

Highway 377/67 had water several feet deep across it and had to be closed.  Also, the Arctic Glacier Ice Plant sustained damage from floodwaters on CR 2861.  Ice boxes, trucks, and pickups were flooded.

Many streets flooded in Midland, including: Garden City Highway and Business 20 access road. A car was submerged at the intersection of A street and Neely. There were also cars submerged at the intersection of Business 20 and Farm to Market Road 1788 and on Wadley Avenue. The underpass at Loop 250 and Texas Highway 191 was also submerged and impassable.  Six to eight inches of water covered the intersection of Farm to Market roads 307 and 1379.

Widespread flooding occurred in Odessa on Wednesday morning including damage to at least 100 homes.  The number of homes affected, vehicles stranded in high water, and several county buildings damaged by flooding prompted the Ector County Judge to declare a state of emergency in the county the following day.||Damage to homes ranged from minimal wind and rain damage to up to two feet of water inside homes. Several vehicles were stranded in anywhere from two to four feet of water.  Eleven inches of water pooled in the basement of the Ector County Library while two to three inches was found in the Ector County Health Department. On the following day, newspapers reported that 25 to 40 families sought assistance from the American Red Cross.  Ector County Road, Bridge, and Traffic Department employees worked overtime pumping water out of flooded streets on subsequent days.||During the storm, high schools closed their campuses to off campus travel, prompting a need for food to be delivered to the campuses to feed all the students who normally travel off campus for lunch.  Odessa firefighters and EMS personnel responded to 95 calls for high water rescues during these storms.
One foot of water across US 67 at 144 north.  A car was stranded in high water with occupants needing to be rescued under a railroad bridge at the intersection of US 67 and US 259.
Street flooding occured within the city of Kermit with curb to curb flooding on Texas Highway 18.  Several cars were stranded in high water in Kermit.

Moderate street flooding with two feet of water flowing through the streets in the city of Seminole occurred due to heavy rainfall and resulted in local officials closing many streets. Several vehicles were underwater. Water damage occurred at Seminole Primary School from floodwaters. U.S. Highway 385 was closed due to high water just north of Seminole.  The eastbound lanes of U.S. Highway 180 out of Seminole also were closed.  At least one high water rescue was performed in Seminole.  Numerous intersections were flooded and closed by police in Seagraves.
Highway 84 was closed at Cowhouse Creek.  Flood waters also threatened Highway 116 at Pidcoke.
Street flooding was reported in Howe with one home threatened by flood waters.  In Sherman, North Travis Street was shut down north of Lambert Street due to high water.
Law enforcement barricaded many roads in Snyder due to high water.
Three foot deep water covered multiple roads in Sand Springs.
Hidalgo County sheriffs office reports flood water up to hoods of cars on Highway 281 north of FM 490.  Flood water over FM 2812 1.25 miles east of Doolittle Road. The water depth unknown.

Showers and thunderstorms associated with Erin produced general 2 to 3 inch amounts across DeWitt, County.  The highest rain totals were 5 inches between Nordheim and Yorktown.  Several roads in the western part of the county were closed due to high water, including FM108 and SH119.
Starr County sheriff reports Los Olmos Creek through Rio Grande City over bank full.
Willacy county emergency manager reported 4 inches of floodwater on FM186 and 10th street in downtown Raymondville.
Four to five inches of rain flooded much of the city of Raymondville. Road 186 closed from 3rd to 10th Streets.

Some street flooding with water into a few homes. Water over Highway 16 north of Zapata City one inch deep. Two to 3 inches of water over Highway 83 northwest of Zapata beyond the city of San Ygnacio.
High water over several streets and water in a few homes.
Minor street flooding was reported by law enforcment in San Benito.
State RLO in McAllen reports widespread street flooding in McAllen and Edinberg.
Rio Grande City law enforcement reports water inside homes from flooding in the Las Lomas and Los Trevinos subdivisions.
The Roma Police Department reported water in houses and flooding on U.S. Highway 83 at Garceno. Only the center lane of U.S. Highway 83 was visibile.

Texas Department of Transportation reports two feet of water on expressway 83 in Rio Grande City. Texas Department of Transportation reports 5 feet of water on Embassy road, Hernandez road and Roca Guerra road in Rio Grande City and one foot of water in homes on these roads.
Flooding on Business Hwy 77 1/4 mile north of FM 490 and at the intersection of FM490 and 1834.

Bands of showers and thunderstorms associated with the remains of Erin formed over the Hill Country in the early morning hours.  One band developed southward into the western part of Llano County before sunrise.  It produced 2 to 3 inch rain totals that very quickly caused additional flash flooding over the already saturated soils. FM2323, FM152, and SH71 were closed in the western part of the county through mid-morning.
The Texas Department of Transportation placed high water signs for water crossing over State Highway 163 located about 9 miles northwest of Sterling City.
Interstate 20 was down to one lane in both directions due to high water.
DPS trooper reported 6 inches to 1 foot of water on FM 3167 near El Sauz.
Farm road 1085 closed south of Trent.
Heavy rain and flooding washed out a graveled road just south of Sterling City.
The Potosi Fire Department reported parts of Highway 36 were closed as well as portions of Farm Road 1750.
Water over the road was reported at various places on |FM126 between Merkel and FM86.
The Texas Department of Transportation had to put high water signs for water over the road on Ranch Road 2139 located about 6 miles southwest of Sterling City.

Many creeks were running out of their banks and all lakes were rising across Nolan County. Lake Sweetwater had risen 26 feet. Lake Trammel located south of Sweetwater was over the spillway near Farm Road 1809.

Excessive rainfall from heavy rains Friday night into Saturday morning across southwest Taylor County caused water to spill over the main spillway at Lake Abilene. This water flowed into Elm Creek and flooded several streets, homes, and businesses in the City of Abilene Sunday morning, prompting the Abilene Emergency Operations Center to call for a mandatory evacuation of the affected locations.

Abilene Police Department reported both Catclaw and Button Creeks were out of their banks. This flooding along with runoff from the heavy rain continued to flood numerous streets across the city. About 50 high water  rescues were reported.

The area of heaviest rainfall associated with Tropical Storm Erin in South Central Texas began in Karnes County.  General rainfall over the county ranged from 3 to 5 inches with up to 7 inches near Helena.  Most of the roads in Karnes County were closed Thursday afternoon, including FM887, SH119, and US80.

The Abilene Emergency Operations Center officials reported that Elm Creek at Farm Road 89 and Bell Plains Road was 8.5 feet above normal and rising. Taylor County Judge recommended voluntary evacuations for residents living along Ohlhausen Road near Elm creek.

About 215 homes in Hamlin were flooded at low lying areas located near California Creek. Several residents had to be evacuated as the water level in their homes increase to 3 to 4 feet. Farm road 57 and County Road 123 were also closed. Throughout Jones county, a total of about 400 homes were damaged, along with several road and bridge approaches washed out.
Farm Road 1085 closed from Highway 180 to the Nolan County line.
Abilene Police Department reported that Cedar Creek was flowing out of its banks.
Law enforcement reported road closures throughout the city of Andrews for at least six hours.

The Odessa Police Department reported flash flooding at the intersections of 36th and Dixie, 52nd and Dixie, Dixie and University Avenue, and 52nd and Esmund. Several high water rescues and road closures occurred throughout the night across the city of Odessa.
Evacuations took place in Hamlin. Farm Road 57 and County Road 123 were closed.
One foot of water flowed over Texas State Highway 115.
Two feet of water was reported over Farm to Market Road 1053.

Comanche Springs was running two feet deep and over the roads in and around Rooney Park. Roads were blocked in that area. Gomey Road in Fort Stockton was barricaded by law enforcement due to high water.
Local law enforcement reported road closures due to high water across many roads in the city of Andrews.
Law enforcement reported widespread flooding in Big Spring.
Ranch Road 1871 and 2389 was closed due to flooding with 5 feet of water reported over the bridge.
The Haskell County Sheriff's Office reported a portion of Farm Road 2407 closed between U.S. Highway 380 and Farm Road 3337 because of high water.
Several roads were closed due to flooding, including Farm Roads 479, 2169, and 385, as well as Highway 377 South.
Serious flash flooding was occurring along Elm Creek near Highway 277 and 606 where two houses were washed into the creek.
A woman was swept away by raging waters near the intersection of U.S. Highway 277 and Farm Road 89 as she attempted to escape her vehicle which had become stranded in flood waters.
Local law enforcement officials reported significant flooding along Elm Creek located in southern Taylor County. U.S. Highway 277 and Farm Road 89 was closed due to flash flooding.
Abilene Police reported widespread street flooding and numerous road closures across the city as a result of the very heavy rainfall. This extensive flooding continued through much of the evening.
Law enforcement officials reported State Highway 70 was closed near Sweetwater as a result of flooding.  State Highway 92 located in northeast Fisher County near Hamlin was also closed.
Sixteen inches of water covered U.S. Higway 180 for a seven mile stretch, stranding motorists.
Eight inches of water flowed rapidly across the intersection of Texas State Highway 137 and Farm to Market Road 846.

Law enforcement and fire department officals responded to 25 high water rescues, as several vehicles were submerged or washed off the road  throughout the city of Midland. These events took place at the intersections of Illinois and Stonybrook, Texas State Highway 191 and Loop 250, and Midland Drive and Wall Street.

Law enforcement reported several high water rescues in the city of Midland. The westbound lane of Business Interstate 20 at the Farm to Market Road 1788 exit was closed due to high water over the roadway.
Six inch pools of water accumulated on the ground and led to water protrusion inside the control room at Chevron-Warren Petroleum.
The media reported flooding throughout the city of Odessa, including a dumpster floating down 25th street between Adams and Eisenhower Streets.
Farm to Market Road 2163 from Haskell to Knox City was closed because of high water.

Law enforcement officials from Jones County reported  the road closures on Highway 83 and Farm Road 126 near Hamlin, Highways 83 and 57 near Hamlin, Highway 92 between Stamford and Hamlin, and Farm Road 600 and 102 near Fort Phantom Hill Lake.
At least 10 roads were closed in San Angelo due to flash flooding.
Ranch road 2407 was closed about 6 miles northwest of Haskell due to flash flooding.
Many roads across Abilene and Taylor County were closed due to flooding, including all roads in Mulberry Canyon. Serious flooding continues along Elm Creek west of Lake Abilene.
Vehicles were swept off of CR 2302 N near Aquilla and CR 1414 near Blum due to flooding.
South Crowley Road was flooded from Harris Street to the FM 1187 bypass.
Several high water rescues were required.
Two feet of water was reported on FM 1658 north of Highway 380.
A creek running through city of Haskell has some streets impassable.
Several intersections were closed in Denton due to flooding including North Bonnie Bray Road and West University Road.  In Lewisville, the floodwaters were over a foot deep.

Lake Palestine rose to a stage of 349.1 feet which was just a few inches short of its all time record crest. With the lake at this stage...the lake had to be closed to boating traffic due to the threat of boat wake damaging local camp homes along the lake.

Lake Tyler rose to a stage of 377.7 feet which was just a few inches short of its all time record crest. With the lake at this stage...the lake had to be closed to boating traffic due to the threat of boat wake damaging local camp homes along the lake.

Excessive heavy rainfall in the Middle Red River Valley of northeast Texas and southeast Oklahoma resulted in high stages on the Red River near Pecan Point.  The river rose and crested near 28.8 feet on July 14th.  Area ranchers and farmers responded to the threat of river flooding. however, and evacuated livestock and farming equipment to higher ground.  Increased awareness of river flooding prevented any livestock deaths.
Highways 51 was flooded and Highway 167 was reduced to one lane due to flooding.
A trained spotter reported water up to one and a half feet on local roads.
Several streets were closed in Sweetwater due to flash flooding.
A few cars were stranded in high water, mainly around UTEP and downtown.
Streets in northeast El Paso were submerged in water.

Highway 69 east of Denison was flooded and closed, as was Highway 75 north of town.  A few homes in Denison were flooded.  Several bridges were washed out in Sherman including bridges on Mayes Road and Ida Road.  An automotive shop in Denison had water damage to computers, furniture, and cars and expected damages to total around $250,000.
Multiple reports of flooding due to heavy rainfall near Big Spring were recieved.
Flooding occurred over both lanes of I-10 between mile markers 185 and 186 at the Reeves/Jeff Davis County line.
Highway 6 was flooded in Iredell with only one lane open, and several roads in Valley Mills were closed including FM 56.

Widespread flooding was reported across the eastern portion of the county.  Several roads were under water including US 259 in the south bound lane.  Water was reported in one home east of town.  Rainfall estimates of 5 to 6 inches were common east of town.  Several motorists had to be pulled from their vehicles when fast moving flood waters swept their vehicles from the roadway.

|The broadcast media reported standing water that covered portions of 98th Street during the late evening hours of the 3rd. The water accumulated in a construction zone as heavy rainfall fell over the southern portions of Lubbock. At least one vehicle became stranded in the flood waters.
Emergency management officials reported that heavy rainfall resulted in minor flooding of many city streets in Plainview. A few roads were reportedly impassable.
The Interstate 35 service road just south of Valley View was flooded and closed.
Many low water crossings in Big Lake had water flowing up to one foot deep from heavy rainfall.
Widespread flooding occurred across the city of Andrews resulting in one high water rescue after a motorist became stranded in high waters.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding which washed out a bridge in the northern portion of the county. Several secondary roads were also under water as well.

Local emergency officials reported that heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding along several city street in west Lubbock. Reports indicated that several vehicles were stalled in flood waters. No injuries were reported.

CR 2136 was closed at Highway 66 due to high water.  Also creeks were flooded in the central and western parts of the county.  Service roads along Interstate 30 were flooded by nearby Brushy Creek and West Caddo Creek.

Heavy rainfall resulted in minor flooding along several roadways in central and eastern Terry County, including Farm to Market Roads 403 and 168, and County Road 1076. No reports of serious travel problems were received.

Numerous streets in Midland were flooded with roads in downtown Midland experiencing curb to curb flooding while other streets in Midland were impassable except for the center turn lane.  Some other roads that flooded include the North Service Road of Business 20, Farm to Market Road 1788 south of Interstate 20, Texas Highway 349, and Farm to Market Road 307.  At least one home south of Midland had water up to one inch deep inside the house.
The Martin County Sheriff's Office advised against traveling anywhere in the county north of Texas Highway 176 as most of the roads were underwater.

Significant street flooding, up to 3 feet, occurred in the town of Wink due to heavy rainfall. Several vehicles were stranded in high water. At least one home had floodwaters on the 1st floor that had to be pumped out.

Water up to one and a half feet deep flowed across roads in Ackerly.  Flash flooding was also reported in Lamesa with six to eight inches of water flowing over U.S. Highway 180. Several vehicles were stranded in high water after trying to drive through low water crossings. An additional vehicle had to be towed after the driver misjudged the location of the water covered road and drove into a ditch.
Hwy. 271 was closed due to excessive heavy rainfall resulting in flooding.

Flash flooding was reported in many areas of Odessa.  Six to eight inches of water was flowing along Penbrook Street behind the Target.  Grant Street was reported as impassable between Interstate 20 and Business 20.  The service road on the north side of Interstate 20 near Farm to Market Road 1936 was closed by local officials because of a foot to a foot and a half of water flowing over the road.  The intersection of University and Adams was also affected by flooding.  At least one high water rescue was performed by the Odessa Fire Department.  This occurred at the intersection of Tom Green Avenue and 21st Street.||The Knox Village community in West Odesssa is in a naturally low spot and accesible by one road that crosses the Monahans Draw.  West Odessa firefighters asked residents to voluntarily evacuate as continued flooding in Monahans Draw would limit their access to the community.  Residents who evacuated were sent to a nearby firehouse.
Widespread flash flooding occurred in Midland including along Farm to Market Road 662.
Flash flooding in Omaha and the Naples area resulting in some street closures.
Numerous county roads flooded and closed near Cameron, including FM 1915 at Big Elm Creek.

Ochiltree County Sheriff's Office reported flooding across southern Ochiltree County for several days due to recent heavy rainfall. U.S. Highway 70 south of Perryton remained closed along with County Roads 11 and W due to flooding. No damage or injuries were reported.
Several roads were closed due to flooding.  A pasture was flooded by three to four feet of water after a creek overflowed near Highway 79.

From 2 to 3 inches of rain fell in the eastern part of Hays County.  Highest totals were 5 inches between Buda and Kyle.  Flood waters got into the Wimberley Village Library, causing widespread damage.  Most county roads were shut down, including RM12 between San Marcos and Wimberley.  A woman was arrested in San Marcos after driving her van with two children around a barricade.
The Nueces River at Laguna crested at 14.3 ft on 07/21 at 0730cst, where flood stage is 10 ft.
FM 71 near Sulphur Bluff was under water, as was CR 4760 north of Sulphur Springs.

Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell in southern Guadalupe County and southeastern Bexar County, closing many rural roads due to flash flooding.  Among those closed in Guadalupe County were SH123 and FM539.
Flooding was reported on several roads.
North Pearl Street, FM 815, and Ann Street were flooded.  Water was flowing down streets and through yards.
Several roads were closed due to high water, including the Highway 69 underpass, part of Ida Road and Highway 11 West.
Ham Branch breached its banks in central Rockdale, neccesitating water rescues and evacuations.  A few houses were threatened by flood waters.
Several roads east of Kemp were flooded and closed.

Numerous county and secondary roads were under water across the eastern and southern portions of the county.  Some of these roads were: FM 56,  FM 202, CR 406, CR 419, and Highway 144 south of Glen Rose.  Flood waters knocked down fences and damaged some county roads.

Water was reported over CR 219 near Carlton.  Flooding was widespread in Hico, with FM 1602 washed out and Highway 281 north of town impassable.  Flooding was worst at the intersection of Highways 6 and 220.  Three high water rescues were required, two for motorists and one at a house.  Hico First National Bank, Jersey Lilly's restaurant, and the Koffee Kup restaurant sustained flood damage.

Several roads were flooded along the southern county border, and a high water rescue was needed on FM 914 six miles south of Alexander.  Also in Alexander, CR 284 had about four feet of water over it's bridge.  Five parts of Highway 1602 at Honey Creek were washed out, and Highway 281 was closed due to flood waters.  There were a few reports of damaged driveways and culverts.
FM 38 was flooded and closed near Rowdy Creek.
Several roads were flooded in and around town including Highway 377 at Highway 56.

Tarrant, Patterson, Mill, Rock, and Nelson Streets were flooded by about a foot of water.  More than two inches of rain fell in 45 minutes.  Saturated limbs fell from trees and hit power lines, causing outages for about an hour.
About two feet of water covered the Cameron Avenue/Meadow Street intersection after four inches of rain fell in about three hours.

The following roads were closed due to high water: Highway 164 east of Groesbeck, Highway 14 south of Thornton, FM 937, FM 1247, FM 147, FM 2489, FM 1533, CR 761, CR 460, CR 420 at CR 450, and CR 417.

Highway 77 between Burlington and Cameron, FM 485 at CR 255 near Maysfield, and Highway 190 in Cameron were all flooded by about eight inches of water.  FM 485 was partially washed out.  Numerous roads were closed in the Buckholtz/Cameron area including FM 1915 at Big Elm Creek, South Elm Creek, and Little River, FM 486 at Little River, and FM 1600 at Bear Creek.  A dozen homes sustained water damge in Cameron, and four homes were flooded in the Thorndale-Thrall area.  Four people were rescued from high water on the FM 2095 Snapdragon Bridge west of Hanover.  One man refused help and elected to stay with the flooded vehicle.

High water damaged FM 1146 and CR 339.  FM 1146 was completely washed out just past Mill Creek Road, and the culverts on CR 339 were washed out and had to be replaced.  The repairs for FM 1146 cost $223,357.
A few roads were flooded and one high water rescue was needed on Highway 380 in town.
City streets experienced flooding.
Flooding occurred along Interstate 35 in Temple and on several roads in Holland.

Northwest Highway was barricaded in downtown Dallas, and a portion of Hall Road at Heard Park was closed due to flooding in Seagoville.  About eight inches of water was across Central Expressway in Richardson.
Law enforcement reported significant street flooding in Abilene.

Intense rainfall of about 3 inches in just over an hour produced localized flash flooding of a small, normally dry stream, just to the south of Grape Creek. Water was observed flowing rapidly across a low spot on Old Sterling City Highway.

The emergencey management official reported several roads around Brady were closed due to high water up to two feet. He also reported that many small streams were over their banks and several roads across the eastern and central portions of the county were closed because of high water caused by runoff from heavy rain that fell overnight.

Thunderstorms dropped generally 2 to 3 inches of rain over the eastern part of the county, with up to 4 inches near Granger and southeast of Thrall.  US79 was closed at Thrall.  FM2243 was closed around Granger, and 2nd Street was flooded in Taylor.

Highway 11 at FM 1417, Highway 91 between Sherman and Denison, and several other roads were flooded.  A high water rescue was required in Sherman, and Choctaw Creek was over its banks.  High water was reported on Texoma Parkway under Highway 75, and on North Branch and Travis Streets.  An auto store on Texoma Parkway suffered flood damage, as well as several cars.
Several secondary roads were closed due to flooding.
Thunderstorms produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain over western Kerr and northern Real Counties, causing flash flooding west of Hunt.  FM187 was closed for several hours in the evening.
Water was reported over several roads in Point, and FM 1325 near Flats was also flooded.
CR 542 was flooded near Keechi Creek and closed.  Roads were also flooded and closed in the extreme southern part of the county.

About 15 to 20 roads were flooded.  A 15' by 20' sinkhole developed, and a bridge was washed out on Cedar Oaks Drive in Payne Springs stranding about 30 households.  FM 2636 in Malakoff, Bunny Rabbit Road in Athens, and FM 773 north of Murchison were closed due to high water.  A bridge was washed out on CR 2803.

A civilian worker's body was found in Cowhouse Creek downstream from where his vehicle was pulled from the water.  The man had gone missing after a fireworks show.  At the time, Cowhouse Creek was over five feet above flood stage.
About twenty roads were flooded in the Sherman area, and Highway 69 was flooded between Bells and Whitewright.
A creek rose over a bridge at the intersection of Park Haven and Round Rock Roads, and flooding was reported along Parker Street at 15th and Coit Streets.
A foot of water covered roads in the downtown area.
Highway 317 was closed between Highway 36 and Cedar Creek Road due to flooding from Belton Lake.
A subterranean house on CR 2311 was flooded when a levy broke in a creek beside the house.  Most of the furniture and possessions in the 3,000 square-foot home were damaged.
Several roads were flooded and closed east of Palestine.
CR 528 was barricaded after fire fighters performed a high water rescue and retrieved a vehicle which was driven into deep water.

Between two and three inches of rain fell in less than an hour across portions of the county, causing significant flooding.  Several homes were evacuated and flooded, and at least two cars were filled to their windows with water.  One of the cars was located off Highway 50 between Campbell and Commerce Streets.  CR 4105 and the intersection of FM 1568 and CR 4312 were closed due to flooding.
Highway 34 was closed due to cars stalled in high water.
Law enforcement reported significant street flooding in Albany. In addition, Highway 576 to the east of Moran was closed due to flooding.
Law enforcement reported several county roads were flooded throughout the county.
Local newspaper reports indicated that high water and hail ponded over Texas Highway 86 between Dimmitt and Nazareth. The highway was closed by local authorities for several hours.
The Odessa Fire Department reported a highwater rescue at the intersection of Dixie and 42nd Streets.

Several vehicles were submerged near Dallas as well as a soccer field.  One high water rescue was required.  In Garland, ten golfers were stranded on a golf course when a creek quickly rose.  They were rescued by firefighters in a raft.  Interstate 635 near Mesquite had 12 inches of water over the road.
Cars were stranded on Highway 380 near Farmersville and Highway 5 and CR 377 near McKinney.  Numerous high water rescues were required in these areas and also near Plano.
Veterans Memorial Boulevard was flooded, and one car became stranded.
Six to eight inches of floodwater was reported in Forney as the east fork of the Trinity River rose over its banks.
The Odessa Fire Department reported a highwater rescue at the intersection of Dixie and 17th Streets.
The public reported wide spread flooding in Sparenberg. Water up to two feet deep flowed over many roads.
Reported waist deep water at Bell Street and Hillside Road in southwest Amarillo and that high water rescues were in progress.

Heavy rain and hail resulted in ponding water over many roadways and highways in western Hale County. Water covered portions of U.S. Highway 70 near Halfway through much of the morning hours on the 11th.
Water Rescue on FM 530 6 miles north of Speaks. CoCoRAHs observer Hallettsville 13.4SE measured 11.00 of rain in 24 hours ending at 7 AM October 16, 2007. Most of the rain fell between 1 and 4 AM.
A few roads were barricaded due to flooding.
Reported waist deep water at a restaurant on Coulter Street south of 45th Avenue in southwest Amarillo.
Four to six inches of water flowed across 7-D Road.

Heavy rain from thunderstorms in Terry County caused flash flooding in Brownfield. The Terry County Emergency Management Agency reported that Old Lamesa Road in Brownfield was completely inundated with flowing flood waters as were several other side streets in Brownfield.

Local newspapers and law enforcement officials reported that very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in rural areas northwest of Lubbock. News articles also indicated that numerous vehicles became stranded in high water flowing through city streets. The Lubbock County Sheriff's Office reported that a motorist escaped her car moments before it was swept away from a rural roadway in northwest Lubbock County. No injuries were reported.

Numerous roads flooded and impassable across the eastern half of Harris County from the Houston area to the La Porte, Pasadena, and Deer Park areas. Flooding in Deer Park included homes off of Hender, Martha, and Eight Streets, as well as Harvard Avenue, with two feet of water reported over portions of East Boulevard. Pasadena area flooding included Strawberry Park, Southmore, Red Bluff, and Burke Streets, as well as Beltway 8 exits being closed due to high water. House flooding also occurred in Pasadena. At least a dozen schools, majority of these being in East Houston, received water damage. There were reports of Vince Bayou exceeding its banks at Shaw Street. Homes and businesses were also flooded in the La Porte area where some structures were inundated with more than a foot of water. Heavy rainfall collapsed a warehouse roof in Houston on Harrisburg Boulevard. There were three fatalities. Two men died (one at the scene, the other several hours later in a hospital) when heavy rainfall collapsed the roof of a grocery store in Clear Lake. A third fatality occurred when an eighteen wheeler was accidentally driven into a 26 foot deep flooded retention pond in La Porte. The driver drowned.
Fourteen inches of water flowed across U.S. Highway 87.
Six to eight inches of water flowed across the intersection of Texas State Highway 83 and U.S. Highway 385.
The Crane Police reported flooding at the intersection of 8th and Gaston streets. Due to the high water, the interstection was rendered  impassible and therefore barricaded by the police.
The following roads were flooded and closed temporarily: Highway 927, Highway 219, CR 2490, CR 1190, CR 3125, and CR 3310.
Between 5 and 7 inches of rain fell in northwest Duval County.  Highway 44 west and northwest of Freer was closed due to flooding in several spots.|

Between 5 and 10 inches of heavy rain fell during the morning from Robstown to portions of Corpus Christi resulting in widespread flash flooding.  Numerous roads were flooded and impassable, including Up River Road, Leopard, Airline at S.P.I.D., Everhart at S.P.I.D., Kostoryz at S.P.I.D., Rockwood at Starlight, Clarkwood, Rand Morgan, Business 77 in Robstown, frontage roads along U.S. 77 in Robstown, Interstate 37 from Lantana to Southern Minerals Road and numerous other secondary roads throughout Corpus Christi.  A pregnant woman was rescued after her vehicle was washed into a shallow ditch along Interstate 37 and Corn Products Road.

Widespread flash flooding occurred across much of Victoria county during the early morning.  Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell across the southern half of the county and between 4 and 8 inches fell across the northern half of the county, with isolated amounts between 8 and 11 inches.  Flooding was reported at Benbow Road and Garcitas Creek and at U.S. 77 at Garcitas Creek, numerous roads throughout the city of Victoria and several Farm to Market Roads in the northern half of the county.  U.S. 77 was closed from the north side of the city of Victoria to the Lavaca/De Witt/Victoria county line due to flooding at the county line and at least one vehicle was completely submereged in a high water crossing along U.S. 77.  In Nursery, widespread flash flooding of creeks resulted in 25 homes with water in them as well as cars reported underwater.  Up to 10 homes in the Tropical Acres subdivision of Victoria had water in them due to flash flooding of Spring Creek.  Flooding of 3 homes along Benbow Road near Garcitas Creek also occured.  Several evacuations of families were needed.
Several streets were flooded in Lancaster, and at least one home was flooded.  Interstate 35 was flooded as well.
Shawnee Road was flooded where it crosses Red Oak Creek.  Interstate 35 east was also flooded.  Several vehicles had to be pulled out of high water.

Several roads between the two cities were flooded and closed including FM 309 and Highways 81, 171, and 22.  A man was swept down Cottonwood Creek after trying to cross FM 309 in his truck and abandoning it.  He had to be rescued from a tree about 250 yards downstream.

Between 4 and 6 inches of rain fell across northeast Golaid county during the morning resulting in flash flooding of low lying areas.  In addition, secondary roads in Ander and Schroeder were closed due to high water.|

Between 2 and 4 inches of heavy rain resulted in widespread flash flooding across central and western San Patricio county.  Flooding was reported between Mile Markers 23 and 24 along Interstate 37, resulting in six accidents.  Several Farm to Market roads were flooded and closed, including F.M. 234 and I-37, F.M. 188 and I-37 and F.M. 630 at F.M. 796 in West Sinton.|
One foot of water covered a four hundred foot section of road near the intersection of South Knox Avenue and West Edna Street.
High water was reported over FM 39 between Shiloh and Fallon.

FM 1256, FM 1861, and several other roads were flooded and impassable.  Numerous roads were closed due to culverts and bridges being washed out, including Highways 19 and 243 south of Canton, and Highway 110 east of Van.
Several county roads were flooded and impassable.  A vehicle was swept into a creek.
Flash flooding produced two feet of water over the intersection of Texas State Highway 191 and Loop 250. Multiple vehicles were stalled at the intersection due to the high water.

Very heavy rainfall, of up to 6 to 12 inches in some spots, led to numerous secondary roads underwater and impassable throughout the most of the Refugio county.  U.S. 77 became impassable with high water just north of the city of Refugio.  Highway 35 was closed due to many impassable spots.  Tivoli and Austwell had significant flash flooding, with almost all streets impassable.
The following intersections were barricaded due to flooding: Wynn-Joyce Road and Country Club Road and 1st Street and Avenue D.  Several cars were flooded.

Forty to fifty high water rescues were required in between Keene and Venus.  Portions of Highway 171 in Cleburne and Highway 287 were flooded, and a total of 17 roads were closed.  The worst flooding was reportedly between Highway 67 and FM 917 near Lillian.  One home in Lillian was flooded by about two-and-a-half feet of water.
Numerous roads were flooded across the county, including North Burnet Street and Seventh Avenue and Boston Street in downtown Corsicana.

Highway 36 was flooded near Flat. Plum Creek flooded CR 106 and CR 107, and Coryell Creek flooded CR 213, CR 274, and Winters Road.  The City of Gatesville closed Brown Park on West Leon Stret and Faunt Le Roy Park when the Leon River overflowed its banks.  FM 1829 was also flooded in Mound.
One and a half to two feet of water flowed rapidly across the intersection of Texas Highway 115 and Wildcat Drive in Wink.  Other roads were filled with water from curb to curb.
Eight to ten inches of water flowed over portions of Florida Street.
Eight to twelve inches of fast flowing water was reported over County Road E. No damage or injuries were reported.

Between 3 and 5 inches of heavy rainfall resulted in several city streets flooded and impassable throughout Corpus Christi.  In addition, Interstate 37 at Corn Products Road was flooded with several feet of water.

Between 3 and 6 inches of heavy rain resulted in flash flooding of small creeks and low lying areas along many Farm to Mark Roads thoughout the county as well Highway 99 in northeast McMullen county, which was closed.|
Several city streets became flooded with several feet of water in Port Oconnor and Indianola Beach due to heavy rain.|

A trained spotter just south of Canyon on U.S. Highway 87 indicated that the water was curb to curb. The spotter also estimated that the water depth was near twelve inches in some spots and was filling up the medians.
Lee Trevino Drive was flooded in east El Paso.

Between 3 and 5 inches of rain led to widespread flash flooding of roads in and around Corpus Christi.  Numerous cars became stalled.  Five water rescues were reported.  Some of the major flooding occurred along Interstate 37 near Annaville, where the interstate was closed with several feet of water flowing over it.  Hwy 286 (N.P.I.D.) at Leopard and Bates was closed with many feet of water over it.  Several other secondary streets throughout the city were flooded.|

Runoff from heavy rainfall the previous day along with already wet soils caused Wolf Creek to rise above flood stage at Lipscomb Texas. The creek crested just over ten feet around 1100 CST. Water flowed into Glen Turner Memorial Park on the north side of Lipscomb and some picnic tables were standing in water. There was no reports of injuries from the flooding.
Sheriff dispatcher reported stalled vehicles in the city limits of Alice in high water.|
Water was flowing across US HWY 287. 2.61 inches of precipitation was measured at the Goodlett Mesonet site in one hour.
FM road 1740 was under water from the Wichita county line, northeast to  FM road 2393.
Heavy rain associated with Hurricane Humberto caused flooded service roads along I-10 between Vidor and Orange.
Heavy rain associated with Hurricane Humberto caused water to enter some homes near Fannett, and also close some service roads along I-10 in the Beuamont area.

Extensive flash flooding was ongoing in and around Canyon with water flowing into some homes. Five to seven inches of rain fell during the time of the flash flooding. Dumpsters and large timber were floating down the streets with water entering the Junior High School and the Intermediate School. Vehicles and other storage items were washed out of the garages at the Palo Duro Retirement Village. Many streets in Canyon were flooded and impassable...including Russell Long Boulevard...which had several cars floating down the road and was closed down. Portions of U.S. Highway 87 and the intersection of 28th Street and 4th Avenue were also impassable due to flooding. The Canyon Fire Department had to rescue about a dozen stranded motorists. The northbound and southbound lanes of Interstate 27 east of Canyon were shut down and traffic along Farm to Market Road 1541 was rerouted. Hunsley Hills Boulevard was also closed. Runoff from the rainfall washed away three hundred yards of caliche from a construction site near the intersection of U.S. Highway 87 and U.S. Highway 60. Also...a section of Farm to Market Road 3331 between U.S. Highway 60 and Interstate 27 was washed away. Water entered many homes in Canyon and several homes had water entering into the basements. No injuries and no fatalities were reported.

Several high water rescues were needed in the county.  Numerous roads were closed in Dallas and Irving, including the intersections of Goodnight Road at Southwell Street, Tanner Street at X & Y Streets, Sylvan Road at Irving Road, and Interstate 35 East and Royal Lane.  Northwest Highway at Loop 12 was also flooded.  Citizens of northwest Irving reported torrential flooding as well.
Multiple high water rescues occurred along Dixie Street due to high water.
One foot of water flowed over the intersection of Wadley and A streets.
Eight inches of water flowed over Florida Street, two blocks west of Texas State Highway 349.

Up to 2 inches of rain fell over the northwestern part of the county. At around 1:00 AM a man and a woman were washed away in a four door sedan as they attempted to cross the Tower View Bridge on Scenic Loop Road which was in flood due to Helotes Creek. The man was later rescued with minor bruises to his arms and torso. The womans body was found less than a mile downstream at 3:19 PM.

A broadcast media storm chaser photographed rapidly flowing flood waters pouring from cotton fields west of Cotton Center. The flood waters covered portions of Texas Farm to Market Road 37 west of Cotton Center. No damage was reported.
Low water crossings flooded at Lakewood Drive, Bull Creek, Old Spicewood Springs Road, Bee Caves Road and Loop 360.
Between 3 and 4 inches of rain fell over the northwestern corner of the county. FM674 and FM334 were closed east of Brackettville by flash flooding.
In addition to 2 to 3 inch totals earlier that morning, an additional 3 to 4 inches fell around Normandy in the afternoon, closing FM131.
Six inches of water flowed across Cedar Street in Pecos.
Widespread flooding occurred throughout the city of Midland resulting in two submerged vehicles at the intersection of Schauburer and A Streets.
Locally heavy rainfall resulted in widespread road closures across the county. One motorist had the be rescued from his vehicle from high water. There were no report of injuries.
Up to 3 inches of rain fell at Payton in the late morning, closing SH32 and FM165 due to high water.
Flooding was reported at Highway 84 and FM 1366, and FM 1365 was washed out.  A car was submerged at Highway 75 North near FM 80.  The bridge at W.L. Moody Reunion Grounds was also flooded.

Thunderstorms stretching from northern Fayette County southward through Lavaca and DeWitt Counties produced widespread 1 to 2 inch rain totals as the moved eastward.  Highest totals in DeWitt County were near 4 inches just south of Hochheim. Flash flooding closed SH111 through the early morning.
Numerous roads were closed due to flooding, including FM 1915 at Big Elm Creek, FM 443 at Turkey Creek, and FM 407.

Thunderstorms produced 2 to 3 inch totals from Leakey in Real County eastward to Medina and Vanderpool  in Bandera County.  Highest totals in Real County were 4 inches just east of Leakey.  High water forced the closure of FM337, FM2748, and US83.

Thunderstorms moved into Lee County shortly after midnight and produced a general 1-2 inch rain over the county.  The heaviest amounts were in the Giddings area where 4 inches fell.  Flash flooding was widespread across the central part of the county with many rural roads closed.  Among those closed due to flash flooding were CR226, CR230, and CR231.
FM 209 south of town was flooded.
Thunderstorms produced a general 1 to 2 inch rain over southern Lee County.  Highest totals were 4 inches just east of Giddings. FM141 and  FM180 were closed due to flash flooding.

Bands of showers and thunderstorms associated with the remains of Erin formed over the Hill Country in the early morning hours.  One band developed southward into southeastern Blanco County before sunrise.  It produced 3 to 4 inch rain totals that restarted flash flooding over the already saturated soils very quickly in the southeast part of the county.  FM165, FM32, were FM473 reported to be closed due to high water into the mid morning.
CR 396 was impassable due to high water.  Numerous other county roads were damaged by flood waters and closed.
TX 135 near FM 2207 was closed due to high water.
Houses near the Brazos River were flooded as officials were forced to open flood gates at Possum Kingdom Lake.  Some houses were flooded as much as eight feet and were not habitable for a week.
Water over numerous roads in western Parker County.  Numerous high water rescues were required.  About 100 residents were evacuated due to flooding.  Numerous homes were damaged by the high water.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell over Bandera, Kerr, Edwards and Real Counties, with up to 4 inches north of Leakey.  SH41 and FM336 were closed by flash flooding.
The San Marcos River below Luling crested at 31.75 ft at 0715 CST on March 12, where flood stage is 20 ft.

Two to four inches of rain fell across eastern Jim Wells county.  Westbound Hwy 44 was closed from Bentonville to Hwy 359, with water flowing over the road.  San Felipe Creek was also reported flooded in the Rancho Alegre area.
Several roads underwater from excessive heavy rainfall.
Thunderstorms in southern Williamson County produced between 2 and 3 inches of rain, closing CR214, and CR100, along with several roads in Georgetown.

Gen 3 to 4 inch rainfall was reported in Wilson County, with up to 6 inches north of Stockdale.  US87, SH123, and FM1681 were closed, along with most roads in Stockdale area.  Several homes and businesses were also flooded, with more than a dozen people rescued by emergency services after being trapped in high water in homes and vehicles.
General 2 to 3 inch rains fell over Blanco, Gillespie, Kerr and Kendall Counties, with up to 4 inches near south of Stonewall.  FM1376 and Park Road 1 were closed.
Thunderstorms produced between 3 and 4 inches of rain in the Kendalia area, closing FM473 and FM3351 due to flash flooding.
Major street flooding was reported in Wolfe City, and a high water rescue was required in Cash.

High water rescues were required near Dry Creek and also Stroud Creek.  A pick-up was swept down Fall Creek.  One of the occupants of the truck swam to safety while the other two clung to a tree and waited for help.  Roads were also flooded in the county.  A woman who's car was being swept away escaped by pulling her convertible top down.
FM 489 was barricaded due to high water near Butler, as was FM 80 south of Teague.

Between 3 and 6 inches of heavy rain fell across portions of central and southern Bee county, resulting in widespread flash flooding of small creeks and low lying roads.  Many secondary roads and highways as well as Farm to Market Roads throguhout the county were flooded.  Water made it into some homes along West Bowie Street in Beeville.  Hardest hit areas in Beeville were streets along the flooded Poesta Creek.  Roughly 20 people were rescued from stranded vehicles and from homes in Beeville.

Thunderstorms trained across eastern Jim Wells county, dumping 3 to 6 inches of rain over saturated ground.  Highway 44 was closed northeast of Alice and west of Agua Dulce, due to both east and west bound lanes flooded with several feet of water in spots.|
Some city streets were reported flooded in Sinton.|
Water reported to be curb to curb and in the yard of a residence at the intersection of Eastern Street and 17th Avenue. No damage was reported.
Areas around Lewisville Lake were flooded, including Witt Road in Little Elm and Rose Lane south of King's Road in Hackberry.
Water was flooding cars at Majors Field.

Continued periods of showers and thunderstorms through the nighttime hours produced general 3 to 4 inch rain amounts over much of Gillespie County.  Amounts as high as 6 inches were reported near Willow City and also southwest of Fredericksburg.  Most rural roads were closed through both the late evening and in the morning hours due to high water.  A young man was swept away in his vehicle at a low water crossing on Goehmann Lane near Fredericksburg about 2100 CST.
Roads closed and barricaded across the county.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms produced general 2 to 3 inch rain amounts in the late evening in the Henley area.  Several roads, including FM165, were closed in the early morning hours by high water.
Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell in less than an hour in the Hallettsville area, causing flash flooding that was reported to have closed most streets and roads in Hallettsville.

Thunderstorms formed in southern Val Verde County, spreading eastward into southern Edwards County in the early morning hours.  Rain totals over the south part of Edwards County averaged from 3 to 4 inches with the highest totals in the southwest part of the county near the Kinney County line.  Flash flooding closed FM2523 and FM674.

Lake Palestine rose to a stage of 349.1 feet which was just a few inches short of its all time record crest. With the lake at this stage...the lake had to be closed to boating traffic due to the threat of boat wake damaging local camp homes along the lake.
HWY 79 was closed due to continued high water.
The Pecos River at Pandale Crossing crested at 11.73 ft at 2130 CST on May 10, where flood stage is 5 ft.
Heavy rain caused a bridge on CR 326 and a culvert on CR 354 to wash out.
There was significant street flooding reported in Brownwood as several of the streets were reportedly closed.
Haines Road washed out with creek flooding in the area.
Flash flooding was reported across the northern part of the county. High water was reported across county roads 940...915 and 204 near Trawick.

Scattered thunderstorms produced general rain totals of 2 to 3 inches over Kinney, Uvalde, Zavala, Medina, and Frio Counties in the afternoon of July 3. Flash flooding in Kinney County near Brackettville closed FM693 and FM334.
A car stalled out in high water along Cooper Street and Randol Mill Road.
Five houses were flooded in town.
A foot of water was reported at the intersection of Meacham Boulevard and Old Denton Road.
A high water rescue was required at Irving Mall.
Flooding was reported at Oak Lawn Boulevard and North Stemmons Freeway.
Flooding was reported along SR 7 east of the town of Crockett.
Several homes on Second Street had water enter them after as much as eight inches of rain fell in a short time.

Widespread flooding was reported on city streets throughout the city of Laredo.  The Laredo Fire Department responded to 29 calls of stranded motorists in high water.  Six homes in the western part of Laredo were flooded, as well as an unknown number of homes around Jacaman Rd.  Water also flooded parts of the Webb County Justice Center and Administration Building in the downtown area.
Winding View road along with a few other streets in the River Chase Subdivision were flooded.
Street flooding occurred near the Big Spring airport with water approximately ten inches deep.
Lakewood Drive at Bull Creek was closed due to flooding.
Joe Tanner road was reported closed due to high water.
The 1300 block of West Oltorff was closed due to high water.
Hoeke Lane at Poston was reported closed due to high water.
The 5100 block of Wesson Road was reported closed due to high water.
Lakewood Drive was reported closed due to high water in Bull Creek Park.
A road was washed out by floodwaters.
High water was reported on several roads and vehicles were stalled in Edgewood and Fruitvale.
A high water rescue was needed after a woman tried to drive through high water on CR 3567 where Crosstimbers Creek goes under the road.  The water was about a foot deep and moving swiftly.
About one foot of water was over the intersection of Western Center Boulevard and Beach Street.
FM 269 south of Interstate 30 was flooded as was FM 3105.  FM 3310 was damaged by floodwaters and had a large hole in it.
Water was reported over roads in Cisco and a nursing home was flooded in Gorman.
Street flooding was reported in Del Rio.
Highway 163 at Juno was closed due to 3 feet of water over the road.
Cienegas Road was barricaded due to high water covering the roadway.
Numerous residential streets were flooded in the city of Del Rio.
There were several roads that were reported flooded in the San Antonio metro area including Marbach and 410...southbound 140 and Highway 151...and a water rescue at San Pedro and West Kings Highway.
The emergency manager reported water in a few homes off of Highway 2504 and Garden Road.

The Lipscomb County Sheriff's Office reported that several main roads in Booker had curb to curb flowing water...and that traffic was not able to pass through the streets. No damage or injuries were reported.

The river gage at the Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River...located thirteen miles northeast of Wayside in southwestern Armstrong County...reached a crest of ten point thirty-seven feet. The flood stage is ten feet. No damage or injuries were reported.

The Deaf Smith County Emergency Manager reported that Park Avenue in Hereford was closed between U.S. Highway 385 and U.S. Highway 60. Also...water was reported in a few homes in the San Jose Community just south of Hereford. Water was four feet deep over Farm to Market Road 1055 about one mile south of Hereford. No injuries were reported.

Heavy rainfall led to flash flooding of several city streets and creeks in the city of Laredo, most notably in the west-central and northwest portions of the city.  In addition, two teenage boys and an adult male were playing near the flooded Zacate Creek, near Sanchez Street, when they fell into the creek.  The Laredo Fire Department successfully performed a swift water rescue and all three individuals were saved.

Local law enforcement officials reported that water was covering the road on Texas State Highway 15...and some water was flowing across Farm to Market Road 376 south of Farnsworth. No damage or injuries were reported.
Local law enforcement officials reported that some public streets in Booker remain closed. Also...Texas State Highway 23 north of Booker is closed. No damage or injuries were reported.
The heavy rainfall, poor drainage area, and a dry creek led to flash flooding and significant street flooding in and around the Green Acres and Ben Bolt areas.
Highway 36 at Waring Creek was closed due to high water.
Local law enforcement officials reported that the road east of Lake Fryer is closed due to high water. No damage or injuries were reported.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported fast flowing water over St. Francis Avenue just north of St. Francis Catholic Church.
Horizon Boulevard below Horizon City was impassable to due rapidly moving water and debris. Floodwaters entered at least one home in the Sparks subdivision.
Numerous reports of road closures across the northern and southern portions of Smith County.
The Odessa Fire Department reported flooding across southern parts of the city.  Six inches of flowing water crossed roadways.
Wide spread flooding was reported by the Big Spring Police department across most of the city limits.  Roads were barricaded by the street department.
Flooding extended from central Montgomery County, or around the Willis and Woodloch areas, westward to the southern portions of Grimes County, or in the Todd Mission and Plantersville area.

Garages and porches were flooded in River Oaks and a swift water rescue was required in Westworth.  High water was reportedly a foot deep on I-30 near Ridgmar Mall.  Vehicles were stranded by high waters on Bryant Irvin just south of I-20.
Vehicles were stranded at I-30 and North Collins Street.
Flooding extended from central Montgomery County, around the Willis and Woodloch areas, westward to the southern portions of Grimes County, including the Todd Mission and Plantersville areas.
A low water crossing was flooded near the intersection of I-20 and Highway 281.
Flooding was reported along county roads.
One motorist in Lingleville became stuck in flood waters and had to be rescued.
A creek in Van crested over its banks, covering streets and bridges with water.  At least one home was stranded by the flood waters.

A daycare on the west side of Houston Street west of downtown near a small creek had to be evacuated due to flash flooding.  Minor street flooding was also reported at Hwy. 59 and Bussey Road and also on Franklin Street.

Ten to twenty inches of rain fell in the San Augustine and Sabine County area causing record flooding of some local creeks and reservoirs.  Flash flooding was reported throughout the county and many bridges and roads were washed out.  A fatality occurred when two people drove off the side of the road into deeper water.  Only one of the occupants was able to get out.

Highway 87 was flooded north of Hemphill, Texas. Many roads across the northern part of the county were flooded.  Many roads and bridges also washed out. Numerous homes and businesses were flooded throughout the county as well.
High water was reported across CR 933.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in a portion of Holbrook Street flooded.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in numerous road closures throughout the town.  Very high water with stalled vehicles were reported at Henderson Street and Canal Street.
High water was reported across Hwy 154.  Several creeks were also out of the banks from excessive heavy rainfall.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in high water on area streets. The water closed some roads near the Tyler Junior College.
County Road 1030 as well as Tennison Road were flooded from excessive heavy rainfall.
Several streets in Terrell were closed due to flooding.
High water across FM 451 near the Elysian Fields Elementary School.
Flash flooding was reported over much of the city.  Flooding resulted to at least 24 temporary street closures in town.  Nine residents reported flooding in their homes as well.

A high water rescue was required in Gainesville and another was needed along FM 51 just south of Era.  Several roads were closed in Gainesville and one in Era due to flooding.  Loy Lake near Denison was also overflowing.
Portions of FM 3134 in the Cumby area were flooded.  FM 71 near the Hopkins/Hunt County line was flooded by the South Sulphur River.
Side streets were flooded in town and one motorist was stranded and had to be rescued.

Cars stalled on FM 1713 and CR 1212 north of Whitney.  Water was reported over Highway 22 in Peoria.  Water was also reported over several other county and farm roads.  Flood waters washed away road base in some cases.
Several roads were under water in Henderson, Texas.
Several roads were under water including Hwy 135.
High water was reported across Hwy 79 near De Berry, Texas.

High water was reported across several Farm to Market roads making travel impassible. Numerous creeks were exceeding their banks including Socogee Creek.  Flooded roads included FM 31 between De Berry and Elysian Fields as well as FM 31 and FM 9.
Hwy 79 was partially closed due to high water between Bethany, Louisiana and De Berry, Texas.
Numerous rural roads were flooded and not passable.
Highway 82 is flooded near the Bowie County/Red River County line. Truck was stalled out in high water. In all...17 roads were closed in Bowie county at one point in time from high water.
Many roads were flooded across the northern part of the county including Highway 174 where eight inches of water was reported.
Several roads were under water in Quitman, Texas.
FM 71 near the Hopkins/Hunt County line was flooded by the South Sulphur River.
Law enforcement reported minor flooding on Highways 97 and 16 and Spur 162 in Jourdanton. The co-op observer in Jourdanton reported 3.38 inches of rain during the event.
Cars were stranded in Stephenville by flood waters.  One occupant was saved by firefighters and a policeman before her vehicle was carried away by the water.
Three foot of water was encroaching a residence of Farm to Market Road 263.  Water up the the truck doors and swift flowing water was reported at Farm to Market Road 1794 and 267.
Highway 81 south of Itasca and FM 933 near the intersection of FM 934 were under water.
Streets were flooded in Royse City and FM 548 was flooded south of town.
A high water rescue was required in north Garland after an SUV drove into high water.
Water was reported over secondary roads east of Gatesville.
One to two feet of water was reported over FM 546.
High water rescues were required near Ferris and Red Oak.
Chest-deep water was reported near Lake Crook.

Numerous streets were closed due to high water after four to six inches of rain fell across the county, including Loop 12 near White Rock Lake.  Voluntary evacuations were in place for residents of DeSoto near Ten Mile Creek which overflowed its banks for the second time in less than four years.  A total of sixteen roads were closed in the area.  Another rescue was needed after a van stalled in high water near Lawnview Avenue and Military Parkway.  There was widespread flooding in Lancaster with numerous homes flooded.  Lancaster's fire department performed five high water rescues.  Two teenagers were playing near a creek near Interstate 635 and Bruton Road when one of them was swept into the water and then into a drainage pipe.  His body was recovered the next day.

Several roads were closed due to high water on the west side of the county, including Cox Road west of Waxahachie where a culvert was washed out.  Other closed roads included Morgan Road in Italy; Grand Avenue in Waxahachie; Barton, Smith, Ozro, Bell Branch, Bee Creek, and White Rock Roads in Maypearl; Country Ridge Lane, Bluebird Lane, and Shawnee Road in Red Oak.  A vehicle was washed off of Loma Linda Lane near Rockett.
A mobile home park was evacuated near Red Oak due to floodwaters.
A highwater rescue was in progress on Tigertown Road about one mile west of Loop 286. Flooding was also reported at FM 79 and FM 2820.
North and southbound service lanes along I-30 were closed due to flood waters.
Three foot of water on road near Highway 80 and Green Street.
High water rescue under a bridge on High Street and Cotton Street.
High water reported at Loop 281 and Interstate 20.
Cars stalled due to flooding at Ridge Road and McKinney Ranch Drive and at Highway 5 and McIntyre Road.
Portions of South Oak Avenue were barricaded due to flooding.  Part of SW 14th Street was washed out due to flood waters.

CR 2310 was washed out by 10 AM and had to be blockaded.  A section of road near the intersection of Highway 69 and FM 1537 was underwater.  In addition, firefighters from Dike helped move seventy dogs out of an animal shelter after it was flooded.

Widespread flooding reported across the northern portion of the county. Flooding was severe on County Road 21 in town and at the circle and along County Road 103.  Homes were also flooded around the city.  Three foot of water was also reported over Highway 3079.  Evacuations had to be made by boat from homes in the northern part of the county. Several roads were washed out and or closed. Over 30 homes in the county were completely flooded along with several businesses. Water was as high as five feet in some homes. One fatality was reported when two people were driving east on State Highway 21 and ran into a ditch and became caught in swift-moving water. One man was rescued in time but the other occupant was swept away in the vehicle. Flooding was so bad near San Augustine that one business was completely knocked from its foundation and carried across a street by the current, drifting into a grocery store's gas pumps.
Nolan Creek overflowed into a city park after more than two inches of rain fell in a short time.
Water was covering the roads across much of the western half of Harrison County including eastern Gregg County. Roads were also flooded around the Page Creek area.

River Road and High Street in Longview were both closed. In addition...17 other roads in and around Longview, Texas were closed due to excessive heavy rainfall. The downtown area had several businesses flooded with as many as two feet of water in them.
Several streets were closed in Wylie due to flooding.

Flooding was reported in the following areas: on Highway 11 between Sulphur Springs and Commerce; along FM 71 west, one mile from the Hopkins-Delta County line; along the southbound lane of Highway 19; FM 2653 at CR 4809 near Oakland; FM 69 south; CR 1178 off of FM 275; CR 4776 and 4766; and CR 2310 along FM 69 and 269.
Numerous roads were flooded across the county, including FM 38 between Tigertown and Maxey, FM 195 and FM 648 at Pine Creek, FM 905, and Highway 1497 between Taylortown and Cunningham.

Several high water rescues were required.  A family in Caddo Mills had to be rescued after their house was flooded by several feet of water.  Another family was rescued after their mobile home took on water on CR 4315.  High water rescues were needed after cars stalled in high water on the north I-30 service road at FM 1570 and also in the city of Commerce.  Several streets were closed in the county, including Monroe and Washington Streets, FM 3218, FM 118 at the Sulphur River, FM 1565, and FM 36.
Water flooded two homes on the east side of Ballentine Street and also a few homes on North Pearl Street.
Flooding was reported north of Highway 80 along Pinson Road.
Flash flooding occurred in the city of Victoria when 2-4 inches of rain fell over a two hour period.  Several low water crossings and underpasses were flooded, with cars reported stalled.
Severe street flooding across portions of Jacksonville, Texas.
Flash flooding was reported at Spring Creek and Highway 75.  The creek was over both north and southbound service roads.
Cars were stalled in high water at the intersection of Bryant Irvin and Interstate 20 and also on the 2700 block of West Berry Street.
Floodwaters removed portions of pavement from the road at the intersection of Pecan Street and North Avenue F.
High water was reported across State highway 315 and Farm to Market Road 95.
Water was reported over roads in town and also on Highway 4 south of Interstate 20 east of town.
Street flooding reported in the town of Diboll, Texas.
A duplex was flooded on Highway 5 in Melissa.
A couple of motorists became stranded at the intersection of East First Avenue and Business 45 due to high water.
Floodwaters rose to 16 inches deep at the intersection of Main Street and South Jefferson Avenue.  Several other streets as well as parking lots and yards were flooded as well.
The Spur Fire Department reported that heavy rainfall from thunderstorms resulted in more than one foot of water rapidly flowing through many city streets. No damage was reported.
Flooding caused road closures on Rancier Avenue and 38th Street and also on Watercrest Road and W.S. Young Drive.

Local newspapers reported that emergency officials conducted a swift water rescue of a stranded motorist in Lubbock. Heavy rainfall that accompanied severe storms, and associated runoff, caused many low lying areas in the northeastern portions of the city to become impassable due to high water. Around 20:00 CST the Lubbock Fire Department's Dive Team rescued a motorist from the hood of his stranded car in swiftly-flowing water at the intersection of Caesar Chavez Drive and Broadway Avenue. No injuries were reported.
Water was over county roads.
A section of NW Loop 286 and North Main Street was closed due to floodwaters.  Many businesses and residences were threatened by high water.
Approximately twelve vehicles were stranded in town.  Oaklawn Avenue in Community Park was flooded as well as Seventh Street and Beaton Avenue.
A few roads were flooded.
North Street and University Street were flooded from excessive heavy rainfall.
Flooding was reported at the Ripy Street Bridge north of Highway 380.
Flooding was reported in town.
Lamesa Police reported one foot of water across many streets in Lamesa. In addition, water up to three feet flowed through low water crossings.
U.S. Highway 83 was reported to be closed from Farm to Market Road 1046 north to the Hemphill County line with up to one foot of water on the roadway. No damage or injuries were reported.
U.S. Highway 83 was reported to be closed between Farm to Market Road 277 and Farm to Market Road 1268 with eight to ten inches of water on the roadway. No damage or injuries were reported.

Pecos County Sheriff's Office reported two feet of water flowing over I-10 near mile marker 273. Local media reported several sections of U.S. Highway 385/67 north of I-10 to have over one foot of water covering the road.
County Road 2035 and Bitter Creek Road near Lake Sweetwater were impassible due to high water.
Texas State Highway 83 just west of Seagraves was blocked off due to high water covering the roadway.
Local law enforcement reported one foot of water flowing across U.S. Highway 385 south of Fort Stockton.
Highways 1636, 92, 2834, and 277 each had water over a portion of the road just south and west of Stamford.
Low water crossings were reported flooded and impassible in southern sections of Crockett County. A rainfall observer reported over 4 inches of rain.
The public reported six inches of water flowing through the intersection of 16th st. and Farm to Market Road 1936.
Crane Police Department reported one foot of water flowing across several low water crossings in Crane.
Several roadways in and around Seagraves were under water and deemeed impassible by TXDOT.
The intersection of 18th and 5th streets in Sanderson was covered by water that was eighteen inches deep and therefore impassible.
Local law enforcement officials reported at least six inches of flowing water north of Garden City along FM 33, U.S. 87 just south of Big Spring and FM 821 between Forsan and Coahoma.

The broadcast media reported that water was one and a half feet deep at Farm to Market Road 2590 and U.S. Highway 60.||The Amarillo and Potter County Emergency Management reported that flash flooding was taking place south of Interstate 40 on Western Street and Georgia Street. The vehicles were reported to have water up to the bottom of the doors and the streets were becoming impassable.||The Canyon Fire Department reported that high water rescues were taking place in Canyon on 11th Street.
Six inches of water was flowing across County Road 1606 in Ira.
A skywarn storm spotter reported a farm road was washed out near Texas State Highway 137 and Farm to Market Road 2002.
There were a number of vehicles stalled along with one person having to be rescued from a vehicle at Railway and Highway 90 East.
Law enforcement and the City of San Antonio officials reported numerous roads across the city closed due to high water and flooding.

A thunderstorm formed in the residual moisture from the remnants of Dolly and dropped very heavy rain on northwest El Paso. Streets were flooded over the curb with run-off from the Franklin Mountain slopes mainly north of Redd Road.

The circulation from former Hurricane Dolly passed directly over west El Paso. Rainfall amounts ranged from an inch and a half in eastern El Paso County and extreme western Hudspeth County to well over 3 inches in west El Paso. Trans Mountain Road was closed between Interstate 10 and U.S. Highway 54 due to numerous rock slides. Many roads were flooded and several were closed from Fort Hancock to Anthony.

A slow moving thunderstorm complex dropped 2 to 3 inches of rain within an hour, which resulted in major street flooding and the flooding of buildings. One apartment complex in northeast El Paso was evacuated, and several streets were closed. In west El Paso, up to 4 feet of water covered roads at the base of the Franklin Mountains, with many streets in the area closed. Several cars were stuck, and at least one water rescue was performed.
