Flooding along secondary roads was reported in and around Leonard and Honey Grove.

Flooding of low lying streets and poor drainage areas occurred on several city streets in the city of Laredo, as well as a few low water crossings.  The Laredo Fire Department reported several vehicles stalled in high water as well a three high water rescues.
A midland man was rescued form his vehicle after it was submerged in more than 4 feet of water at the intersection of Dormard Avenue and Tyler Street.

Water and mud was covering portions of US Highway 83 near and north of San Ygnacio as a result of thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall in the area during the afternoon.  Water was also flowing across the highway during this time, as well.

Torrential rains redeveloped during the pre dawn hours in western Jim Hogg, much of Zapata, and northwest Starr County, early on the 24th. Rainfall estimated to be at least 4 to 6 inches, perhaps more, flowed south out of the El Sauz/San Carlos area and soon reached previously swollen Arroyo Los Morenos, which soon overtopped its banks once again, possibly flooding up to six homes in Escobares.||An additional band of heavy rain likely dropped another 1 to 2 inches or more across water logged neighborhoods in and near Roma, along Federal Highway 83 between 9 and 10 AM CDT, further exacerbating the flood conditions which were already in place.
Several roads were barricaded due to high water.
County Road 1145 was flooded between County Road 1443 and 1184.
County Road 2186 south of County Road 2138 was closed due to flooding.
Creeks were reported to be out of their banks, with flooding in the city of Alpine.
County Road 189 near FM 344 was closed due to flooding.

Though the rains tapered off shortly after noon, and sunshine peeked through the clouds during later in the day, floodwaters continued to cover much of Roma, but particularly Escobares and Garceno, as Arroyo Quiote continued to rise and remain in flood for several hours after the rains ended. Farm-to-Market Road 650 was closed due to the high water covering the roadway, and numerous local roads and some major thoroughfares were closed due to flooding. ||Federal Highway 83, the primary east-west highway connecting the Upper Rio Grande Valley with the Lower Rio Grande Valley, was closed with up to three feet of water covering portions of the highway into the evening of the 18th. Total structural damage and repair costs were estimated to be in excess of one million dollars from the entire flood episode.  At the peak of the flash flooding and areal flooding, an estimated 500 water rescues were undertaken by emergency management personnel.
Interstate 10 was closed near SH 61 due to heavy rains from Tropical Storm Edouard.

Torrential rainfall of at least 8 to 10 inches, but perhaps locally 12 inches,  produced significant flash flooding from mid morning through early afternoon of the 18th in a pocket of Starr County along Federal Highway 83, stretching from the east side of Roma through Garceo and Escobares. Initial urban flooding as far east as the Los Lomas colonia near Rio Grande City soon evolved into a flash flood.  The Roma Police Department reported one to one and a half feet of water throughout the city, with locally higher amounts, which has been confirmed by a number of home videos. ||Major flash flooding developed in these areas when several Arroyos, including the Arroyo Quiote (east of Rosita), Arroyo Los Morenos (near Escobares), and Arroyo Grande temporarily became raging rivers and aggravated the already high water. Starr County Emergency Management officials estimated at least 1100 homes had some degree of flooding ranging from 2 to 3 inches up to 5 feet at the peak of the flooding. A number of these homes were in newer communities near the Arroyo. First responders evacuated 234 or more people from the flooding areas. ||Structural damage and repair costs were estimated to be in excess of one million dollars.

At least three county bridges and several culverts were washed out along CR 257, CR 325, CR 343, and CR 268.  County Road 269 lost huge chunks of its rock and road base, and floodwaters in Polecat Creek washed away a two-lane bridge farther downstream.  A foot of water was over the intersection of Highways 6 and 46.  Areas along Highway 114, Highway 14, and FM 413 towards Kosse were also flooded.  FM 2413 was closed from FM 413 to the Robertson County line.  One tree fell over after six to eight inches of rain fell.  Caywood Center Park were flooded with water reaching the tops of picnic tables.

Neighborhoods were flooded and evacuations required in Kosse. Eight houses were at least partially flooded.  One vehicle was submerged in Kosse.  Floodwaters knocked down a retaining wall in front of a business.  Numerous bridges were under water between Kosse, Thornton, and Groesbeck.  Also, numerous roads were closed east of Thornton.  FM 339 was flooded northwest of Thornton.  FM 937 was also flooded near Davis Prairie.
Heavy rainfall, associated with remnants of Hurricane Dolly, caused flooding along Highway 44, near Clarkwood Rd.
Fifteen intersections in the City of Laredo were flooded and closed due to heavy rainfall, associated with the remnants of Hurricane Dolly.
The Hereford Fire Department made high water rescues of motorists caught in low spots along U.S. Highway 60 east of Hereford. No injuries were reported.
The Deaf Smith County Emergency Manager reported that water was still covering the roads...but was not reaching homes in the San Jose Community two miles east of Hereford.

The river gage site at the Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River...located thirteen miles northeast of Wayside in southwestern Armstrong County...crested at a stage of ten point thirty-nine feet. The flood stage at this site is ten feet. No damage or injuries were reported.
U. S. Highway 69 was flooded just north of town.

Heavy rainfall of up to 4 inches fell in a short period across southern Nueces County resulting in flooding.  Flash flooding was observed at F.M. 70 and Highway 286, were the roadway became impassable.  This rainfall was associated with the remnants of Hurricane Dolly.

Developing thunderstorms that initially affected Starr County during the late afternoon of the 22nd gradually spread north, generally along Federal Highway 83, helping to develop other torrential rains into western Zapata County. The Zapata fire department reported widespread flooding in the town of Zapata, ongoing at 730 PM CDT.  There was likely additional road flooding along portions of Federal Highway 83 between the Falcon Dam area and Zapata, where some of the heavier rains developed, into the mid evening.

Numerous thunderstorms developing in Starr and Zapata County during the late afternoon of the 22nd merged into a relatively small, but intense, complex across extreme western and southwestern Starr County, extending from across the west side of Roma northward toward, but just south, of Falcon Dam. Thankfully for residents living in the east side of Roma, extending into Escobares and Garceo, these torrential rains - estimated to be at least 7 inches or more in a few spots - never stretched east toward previously swollen arroyos from the east side of Roma toward Escobares and Garceno. ||While these torrential rains caused widespread street flooding in the western and northwestern portions of Roma (along the northward bend in Highway 83), as reported by law enforcement, no structures were threatened. Lighter rains followed overnight into early Saturday in Starr County, with little additional impact.||The heaviest rains, perhaps nearing 9 inches, fell just across the Rio Grande in Ciudad Aleman, Mexico.  No information on impacts to this location was received by the NWS office in Brownsville.

Torrential rainfall estimated by radar to be at least 4 inches over a two hour period, combined with continued poor drainage from Hurricane Dolly back in late July, compounded by additional rains since around the 17th of August, produce an urban flood which quickly became a marginal flash flood, with waters rising to at least one to one and a half feet on Canal Street generally between 6th and 9th Street in La Feria, between 1515 and 1615 CDT.  Structural or road damage details were not available as of this writing.

Slow moving thunderstorms with torrential rains affected portions of south central Hidalgo County which had only recently been recovering from floodwaters associated with Hurricane Dolly. In Mission, two feet of water was reported flowing across Inspiration Road; the road had to be barricaded due to the flooding.  In nearby San Juan, flood waters of unknown depth closed down Cesar Chavez Road between Sioux and Eldora; however, this situation was likely related to prior events.  According to law enforcement, several colonias also dealt with some flooding issues, mainly west of Edinburg.

The Garza County Sheriff's Office reported that persistent heavy rainfall resulted in rapidly flowing water over portions of U.S. Highway 84 between Post and Southland. Authorities conducted high water rescues when at least eight vehicles were swept off of the highway. No injuries were reported. In addition, a number of other roadways across Garza County were reportedly flooded.

Three separate intense thunderstorm cells developed near the Cameron/Hidalgo County line just north of the Rio Grande between 2 PM CDT and 4 PM CDT, each tracking northward and dumping heavy rains over western Cameron County, generally between Santa Maria and La Feria. Doppler radar estimated 4 to 5 inches of rainfall over prior flooded poor drainage areas from Hurricane Dolly, exactly a month earlier, over and just south of La Feria. It is likely that additional flooding developed in poor drainage areas affected by the heavy rainfall.

Widespread flooding continued, mainly as a result of heavy rainfall early that night. The main flooding was from the west side of Wichita Falls, into Burkburnett and Iowa Park. Interstate 44 was still closed at Burkburnett, with other city and county roads also closed.
Several roadways continued to be closed due to earlier heavy rainfall.

At 1306 CST, local law enforcement reported FM2886 was closed at I-10.  Up to 2 1/2 feet of water was covering the roadway.  At 1320 CST, law enforcement also reported Hwy 305 closed with water covering the road and Hwy 1901 impassable/closed.
At 1320 CST, local law enforcement reported that Hwy 305 south of McCamey was closed due to water flowing over the roadway.
At 1323 CST, local law enforcement reported that multiple roads in Iraan were closed due to high water flowing across them.
At 2255 CST, local law enforcement in Sheffield reported several high water rescues in progress in and around Sheffield.
At 0140 CST, local law enforcement continued to report ongoing high water rescues in the community of Sheffield.
Flood waters were over Highway 46 at the Walnut Creek Crossing.  The road had been closed.
Hickory Road South at FM 1173 as well as Jackson Road East and West were flooded and closed.

High water rescues were required in the 4000 block of Herring Avenue and North 19th Street where a high water rescue was required.  Water was two-feet deep on Waco Drive and 12th, 20th, and 24th Streets.  At least ten cars stalled near the intersection of Dallas Street and Carver Avenue, and Skeet Eason Drive and Flat Rock Road were also flooded.
Flooding was reported at Loop 12 and Stoneport Drive, the I-635 service road at South Lancaster Road, and along CF Hawn Freeway in East Dallas.

Numerous flooding reports were received from Allen and McKinney.  Industrial Boulevard east of Highway 5 in McKinney was shut down due to flooding.  Rain weakened the support beams of a bridge over Sloan Creek in Fairview, making it unsafe to use.
Service roads were closed along I-30 from previous rainfall.
Flooding was reported between the towns of Palo Pinto and Mineral Wells.
Flooding was reported between the towns of Brazos and Santo.
Parker Road was impassable due to high water.
Flooding was reported at West City Park were a few roads were barricaded.
Stacy Road nar Highway 75 was shut down due to flash flooding.
In south Temple, 57th Street was flooded between west loop 363 and I-35.  Also 31st Street from Market Place Shopping Center northward was flooded.

Lucas residents along Rockridge Road near Lake Lavon were evacuated due to floodwaters.  Two other roads were barricaded in Lucas.  Flash flooding was also reported near Wylie at FM 544 between Regency Drive and Hooper Road and McMillan Road between FM 1378 and North Lewis Lane.
Highway 79 was closed due to high water at the intersection of Highway 810. Other county roads were also closed.
Local law enforcement reported multiple stranded vehicles along Hwy 385N near Seagraves and Seminole due to high water flowing across roadways.
At 2340 CST, local law enforcement reported some flooding of city streets in the community of Andrews.  Barricades were setup along low water crossing were roadways were covered with flowing water.
At 0422 CST, a deputy reported that SH349 was flooded south of Lamesa.  He was in the progress of putting up barricades.

Water releases from an upstream reservoir in Mexico caused flooding along the Rio Grande in Del Rio. Vega Verde Road and several properties along the road were flooded. Evacutions did occur in order to get residents out of the area as roads became inundated and impassable.
Flash flooding occurred from east southeast of the Aldine area northeastward toward Humble. Several vehicles were partially submerged in the flood waters.
Local law enforcement reported flooding near Red Bluff Lake on private roads.  Water flowing over the roadways was up to a foot deep.

Emergency Management officials from Starr County reported that six inches of water was covering and flowing across Highway 83 near La Rosita. It is likely that other minor flooding occurred near Roma, where an estimated 6 inches more rain fell on top of prodigious rainfall of more than 15 inches during the last third of August.
Flood waters were two-feet deep near the intersection of Highway 175 and Highway 155 in Frankston.
The intersection of North Ross Avenue and Highway 14 was flooded and had to be barricaded.

Only a few hours after rains had tapered off Starr County, another complex of thunderstorms crept into the already flooded areas of southwestern portions of the area, and an additional 4 inches or more fell in or near areas impacted by the original floods during the evening of the 22nd, causing perhaps up to eight or nine neighborhoods to have a number of road closures, as well as homes having water pushed into them by passing vehicles. After the rains subsided, the event evolved into an area wide flood which continued well into the night, requiring additional water rescues.

A little after noon on the 23rd, the first torrents of blinding rains from a flare-up of convection in the southern and western eyewall of Huricane Dolly began heading into southeastern Willacy County. These torrents, falling on top of already heavy rainfall earlier that morning, likely began producing high water levels, likely 3 feet or more, starting near Porfirio.  Soon after the eyewall intensification, Dolly's center made landfall along the Cameron/Willacy County line, then very slowly edged west through central and southern Willacy County through the rest of the afternoon and evening, reaching the Hidalgo County line at around 9 PM CDT. ||Throughout the afternoon, blinding, torrential rains persisted over south central and eventually southwestern portions of the county, within the inner core of convection immediately west of the center of circulation. Flash flooding of increasingly high water - as high as 5 feet in some places - spread west into Raymondville, Lyford, Sebastian, and La Sara.  Parts of Raymondville and Lyford were under differening levels of water during the afternoon and into the evening.||Measured and estimated rainfall totals in the flash flood areas of Willacy County from Dolly ranged from 12 to 18 inches, though there was one unconfirmed report of more than 20 inches along the Cameron/Willacy County line north of Rio Hondo.  Dozens of homes likely sustained some level of inundation, and farmland was inundated across the flood zone as well.  High water and general flooding would continue for another day or two, except much longer in backed up drainage areas.||Property damage data are based on reported, insured values from the FEMA National Flood Insurance Program.  Actual values are likely significantly greater, due to the number of residences and businesses that flooded and were uninsured.  Crop damage data is also estimated, and will be adjusted as more accurate data are received. Please note that damage values have been split between the flash flood period, and the more general flood event which followed.

Torrential rains from Hurricane Dolly began pelting eastern Hidalgo County around 3 PM CDT on the 23rd, and flash flooding began soon after, probably at around 4 PM CDT in the Edcouch/Elsa/Mercedes area, spreading slowly west during the rest of the afternoon and evening.  The initial surge of torrential rains, which pounded these areas until around 7 PM CDT or so, became a more widespread area of moderate to locally heavy rainfall later in the evening and overnight, generally along a stripe of central Hidalgo County, along and just north of Federal Highway 83.  As with Cameron and Willacy Counties earlier on the 23rd, the heaviest rains were associated with the western and southern portions of Dolly's circulation, which edged into eastern Hidalgo County by around 9 PM CDT on the 23rd, then eased northwest overnight, reaching the four corners of Jim Hogg, Brooks, Hidalgo, and Starr County at little after 230 AM on the 24th.  ||The prolonged heavy rains quickly produced high standing water, particularly in poorly draining areas of eastern Hidalgo County by late afternoon of the 23rd, including Mercedes, Elsa, and Edcouch. Residential and business flooding with some areas having at least 3 feet of water, continued through the night.  Farther west, including the more populated portions of central Hidalgo County, minor to moderate flash flooding developed later in the evening and overnight, with worst conditions favoring poor drainage locations. ||Heaviest measured and estimated rainfall included a swath of 10 inches or more from rural western Hidalgo County through the Hidalgo/Cameron and Hidalgo/Willacy County lines, immediately west and south of Dolly's Center.  This included the northern portions of Mission, McAllen, Donna, and Weslaco, as well as Edinburg and Alton.  Estimated and measured storm totals of 12 to 16 inches were found from Monte Alto the Edcouch and Elsa; it's possible that more than 16 inches fell near the Willacy/Cameron/Hidalgo County line near Monte Alto.||High standing water, particularly in eastern portions of the county, continued for more than a day after the flash flood; some poor drainage locations near Elsa, Edcouch, and Mercedes would maintain flood conditions for another week or more.||Property damage values are those received on insured properties by the National Flood Insurance Program, and are likely well below the actual damages caused by the flooding, particularly in eastern Hidalgo County.  Crop and agricultural damage is based, thus far, on data as of October 3rd from the Texas Agrilife Extension Service, who reported Dolly's flood losses to cotton and sorghum as the worst agricultural disaster in decades.  Updated values will be provided as data are received.  Please note that damages have been split between the flash flood period, and the longer, general flood which followed.

Major flooding occurred over northern Wichita county. At Wichita Falls, numerous homes were flooded with residents having to be evacuated by boat. A 3.5 mile stretch of railroad track from Wichita Falls to Burkburnett was washed out in several spots, making it impassable. At Burkburnett, the Reilly Ranch Loop was closed just south of Morgan Road and Highway 368, as well Highway 240. Interstate 44 was closed from Wichita Falls to the Red River due to as much as two feet of water flowing over top of it. Significant residential flooding was also reported along Business Highway 287 at Iowa Park. In total over the affected areas, at least 118 homes were flooded, 19 of which were destroyed. Burkburnett and Iowa Park were completely isolated for a few hours during the initial flooding because of street flooding. There was no access to or from these two cities. Monetary damages were estimated, and based on input from Wichita County officials.

The combination of 14 to 18 inches of rain, poor drainage issues, and the overarching fact that the flat, saturated landscape of the Lower Rio Grande River Delta drains very slowly, maintained widespread flood conditions well after the rains ended during the early morning of the 24th.  Numerous roads and neighborhoods, particularly across southern Willacy County, remained flooded right through the weekend which followed Dolly's passage.  In some areas, where ground drainage mechanisms were exceptionally poor, the flooding persisted into August. ||Some of these areas included neighborhoods in Raymondville, Lyford, La Sara, and Porfirio.||Property damage data are based on reported, insured values from the FEMA National Flood Insurance Program.  Actual values are likely significantly greater, due to the number of residences and businesses that flooded and were uninsured.  Crop damage data is also estimated, and will be adjusted as more accurate data are received. Please note that damage values have been split between the general flood event listed here, and the flash flood period which preceded it.

The combination of 10 to 16 inches of rain, poor drainage issues, and the overarching fact that the flat, saturated landscape of the Lower Rio Grande River Delta drains very slowly, maintained widespread flood conditions well after the rains ended during the early morning of the 24th.  Numerous roads and neighborhoods, particularly across eastern and central Hidalgo County, remained flooded right through the weekend which followed Dolly's passage.  In some areas, where ground drainage mechanisms were exceptionally poor, the flooding persisted into August. ||Some of these areas included neighborhoods in and near Elsa, Edcouch, and Mercedes, and likely in others farther west from Edinburg to Alton, as well as parts of McAllen as well.  Near Mercedes, an employee of the International Boundary and Water Commission (IBWC) reported that a structure which allows the canal to drain into the Arroyo Colorado Floodway collapsed. This created an obstruction so the canal filled up and started flowing back into the adjacent community, exacerbating the ongoing flood. Pumping efforts began over the weekend of the 26th and 27th.  Other notorious neighborhoods with poor drainage, particularly in and near Elsa, had continued high water for several weeks after Dolly's passage.||Property damage values are those received on insured properties by the National Flood Insurance Program, and are likely well below the actual damages caused by the flooding, particularly in eastern Hidalgo County.  Crop and agricultural damage is based, thus far, on data as of October 3rd from the Texas Agrilife Extension Service, who reported Dolly's flood losses to cotton and sorghum as the worst agricultural disaster in decades.  Updated values will be provided as data are received.  Please note that damages have been split between the general flood listed here, and the flash flood period which preceded it.

After the rains had long ended, remaining flood waters around and near teh city of Roma continued to remain an issue for many. At least eight residents were rescued from the Las Flores subdivision, and a number of residents in the Robinson subdivision self evacuated as water continued to rise or remain high. Another resident was evacuated off of Ranchito Street from high water in a residence, and a rescue call was received for four children who may have been affected by the flood waters; thankfully, all were found unharmed.||Aircraft video confirmed that high standing water continued well into the 25th in many neighborhoods, particularly those which received the heaviest rains between the 22nd and 24th and were either low lying or had poorly draining streets. Other affected streets were caked with mud.  While most of the flooded roads and residences had 2 feet or less of water in them on the 25th, some pockets of 3 feet of water may have remained.||At least 67 residents sought shelter during the night, with several remaining for the next few days as the flood waters gradually receded.
Over a foot of water was reported flowing across Route 54 in Guadalupe National Park.

The slow west, then northwest, movement of Hurricane Dolly through Willacy County during the daylight hours of the 23rd generally kept the heaviest rains from moving into the western Lower Rio Grande Valley. However, overnight on the 23rd, and especially during the morning hours of the 24th, persistent heavy rain bands developed, initially just west and southwest of the immediate center of circulation as it moved into southern Jim Hogg County between 230 and 430 AM, then mainly around and after sunrise in bands stretching from Roma in southwest Starr County northeast toward La Gloria.  Arroyos in and near Roma filled quickly, and some minor flash flooding likely resulted from the rainfall, before the rains gradually tapered off toward noon on the 24th.  ||Measured and estimated rainfall in Starr County, particularly where the likely flooding occurred, 8 to 12 inches occurred, with perhaps a bit more just to the southeast of Falcon Heights and north/northeast of Roma.||Property and Crop damage are currently estimated. Property damage is estimated based on insured damage reports from FEMA's National Flood Insurance Program, but are likely a bit lower than actual damages since most impacted areas were likely insured.  Updates will be provided as additional data are received.
The intersection of Lamar Avenue and Loop 286 and areas southward were flooded by about 6 to 8 inches of rain.

Heavy rains from Hurricane Ike and from thunderstorms along a cold front the following day caused areas of flooding in the Houston area. This includes interstate 45 which was closed due to flooding near downtown.
Lajitas Resort and Spa owner reported flooding across most of his property.  This included the Ambush Golf Course, which was covered in water.

Reports from the Texas Department of Transportation indicated that a substantial portion of State Route 170 was closed due to high water, southeast of Presidio, TX to near Lajitas, TX.  The flooding was the result of water releases from the Luis Leon Reservoir in northern Mexico.||This portion of Route 170 remained closed for the entire duration of the event.  In addition, the high water levels resulted in back flow up various tributaries to the Rio Grande River.  City officials reported flooding in the Loma Peloma and Redford areas.  Homes, 5 miles east of Presidio, were also threatened by the flood waters.||Low lying portions of Presidio, TX were under a mandatory evacuation for several days, which affected nearly 500 people.

On September 9, the levees near Redford, TX failed.  This resulted in water covering the entire city of Redford.  A high water rescue was reported near Alamito Creek.||Heavy rain made matters worse by September 14.  Flash flooding was occurring in the city of Presidio and border patrol closed the International Bridge on September 16.  The Mexican side of the bridge was covered in water and levels continue to rise.  Water also topped the levees near Presidio Golf Course on the 16th and 17th.  Border patrol reported that nearly 15 feet of water was located in the fields near the golf course, with 3 to 4 feet of water covering the golf course itself.||The International Boundary and Water Commission reported cracks in the levees near the golf course on September 17 and water was beginning to approach Presidio High School.
Flooding in various parts of Houston from combined rainfall from Ike and heavy rain along front the following day. The heavy rains closed Interstate 10.
Heavy rains led to flooding of Brittany Bay Boulevard and service road near interstate 45.
County Road 304 was flooded near Highway 321.

At 0225 CST, Local law enforcement in Alpine reported 2 feet of water flowing across U.S. Highway 90 on the west side of Alpine.  They also reported several creek crossings closed in and around Alpine.
A couple of roads were closed near Klondike due to flooding.
Law enforcement officials reported six inches of water flowing over many streets in Colorado City.
Law enforcement officials closed U.S. Highway 385 north of Hereford due to three feet of water over the highway.
Several roads were flooded in Vidor, including the underpass under I-10. One vehicle was stalled in the high water.
Several intersections were flooded in west El Paso.
Texas State Highway 83 and U.S. Highway 385 in Seagraves were closed due to two feet of flowing water. Farm to Market Road 303 south of Loop was also closed due to high water flowing across the road.
FM 1476 at Highway 36 and at FM 2561 was closed due to flooding.  Numerous other roads were flooded as well including CR 340, 360, 376, and 392.
Heavy rainfall caused flooding along the Houston and Lamar Street exits off of Sam Rayburn Freeway.
Law enforcement reported that the roads were impassible at the intersection of 42nd and Dixie due to high water.
Several large rocks up to the size of basketballs were removed from SH 118 due to the flash flooding across the highway.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed several Farm to Market roads due to high water across the roadway.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 1681 due to water cover the roadway.
Heavy rain caused as much as 5 feet of water to flow across Old Castroville Road.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Jungman Road.
Heavy rain caused area creeks to flow over roads.

Widespread street flooding occurred across the city of Beaumont due to intense rainfall rates. Drainage District 6 Gauges reported 2.05 inches of rain fell between 11am and 12pm with rainfall totals in downtown Beaumont as high as 2.6 inches.
Heavy rain caused flooding which required high water rescues in several places around the San Antonio metropolitan area.
Heavy rain caused water to flow across the roadway of FM 537.
Hackberry Road was reported washed out by the public.
FM 3432 was reported closed due to high water in western Wilson County.
Portion of FM 539 was closed due to high water.
Spotters reported 6 inches of flowing water across roadways.  No damage or injuries were reported.
KFDM-TV and the public reported widespread flash flooding across Orange County. Several homes in Bridge City and West Orange received minor flooding.
Angelina County sheriffs office reported that most roads in the town were underwater.
Tyler County Sheriff Office reported major flooding along Highway 1745 near Chester.

Jefferson County Sheriff Office and the public reported flash flooding across Nederland and Port Arthur. The intersection of Highway 69 and Highway 365 was flooded, and cars were stalled on Jimmy Johnson Boulevard due to high water.
Flash flooding required various roads to be barricaded and four high water rescues in the city of Laredo.
Numerous reports of flooding and road closures across secondary roads throughout the county.
A few roads were closed due to flash flooding around Wood County.
High water was reported across 48th Street and FM 374.
Water was reported to be over several roadways across the county.
Law Enforcement and the city road crews reported 3 feet of water running over the roads in Sonora. County Road 202 just northeast of Sonora had a foot of water over the road.

The Red River at Pecan Point near Dekalb, Texas and downstream at Pecan Bend near Hooks, Texas suffered the most significant flooding for May as several homeowners became cutoff by high water.  Also, considerable relocation of livestock was required as the Red River crested near stages comparable to that of June and July of 2007.  As usual, area ranchers are keen to developing flooding on the Red River and avoided any drowned livestock, although, with the inconvenience and expense of relocating livestock and higher feeding expenses.  In addition, area ranchers lost grazing on several hundred acres of flooded pastures through at least mid June.
A 78 year old man drowned when flood waters swept away hit automobile on a rural northwestern Upshur County Road.  The man was found in his back seat on Fox Road.
Over seven inches of rain fell in Port Lavaca producing widespread flash flooding of low lying areas, small creeks, and streets.
Farm to Market 1487 was closed due to excessive heavy rainfall.
Numerous roads were flooded and closed throughout the county.
Farm to Market 412 was closed due to excessive heavy rainfall which flooded the road.
Streets were flooded near Lions Memorial Park.
Creeks and streams were flooded near the Pecos River.
County Road 4430 was closed due to excessive heavy rainfall.
Several road closures were reported by the fire department in Fort Davis, TX.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in water in a home near Bloomberg, Texas.
Many roads were flooded and closed throughout Wood County.
Several roads flooded and closed throughout the county.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in several streets flooded.

Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in several flooded intersections in the southwest side of town.  Several underpasses were closed due to high water. A high water rescue was made when a car was found in a swollen creek.  No injuries were reported.
Several county roads were reported to be under water and closed throughout the county.
FLash flooding reported across all of Wood County.  A car was washed off the road along County Road 1410.
Several roads were flooded and closed throughout the county.
Two to three inches of rainfall fell in a short time period over the city of Goliad, producing flash flooding of low lying areas and streets.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in several flooded roadways in Dekalb, Texas.

A Park Ranger from the Texas Parks and Wildlife Service reported five feet of fast flowing water in the water crossing number one in Palo Duro Canyon State Park. The road was determined to be impassable...however no damage or injuries were reported.
Heavy rain produced major street flooding in Dell City.
Hwy. 31 has water on the road at intersection of Green and Nelson.  A vehicle was stalled in the water on Hwy. 31.
Several roads flooded across the southern end of the county including Hwy. 37 just north of Hwy. 900.
Several roads underwater across the county.  Barricades were put out for area road closures.
High water from excessive heavy rainfall was in a few homes in the town of Alba, Texas.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced nearly 2 inches of rain in a short time, resulting in flooded streets in the Horizon City area. Gateway West was closed in the Sparks subdivision.
A warehouse was flooded in east El Paso near Rojas and Lee Trevino. Streets in the vicinity were also flooded.
Flooding was reported on US 59 and Gun Club Road southwest of Texarkana, Texas.
Flooding on Main Street resulted in cars being washed over into sidewalks.
Water was reported to be knee deep on FM 2856 near the town of Bronson, Texas.

Between November 3 and November 17, significant river flooding affected dozens of residences along the Sabine River in eastern Newton County. Although only a few homes were reportedly flooded, many residences were completely surrounded by flood waters and cut off from outside areas. Some of the worst flooding occurred in and near Deweyville in southeastern Newton County, especially the River Oaks and Indian Lakes subdivisions. A temporary earthen levee was constructed on the eastern side of Deweyville to protect the town from flooding. All schools in Deweyville were closed for two weeks due to the flooding. Numerous roads throughout eastern Newton County were underwater for several weeks and received significant damage.
River flooding along the Sabine River for the first three weeks of November 2009 caused significant damage to roadways in eastern Orange County. No homes were reportedly flooded.
Very heavy rainfall resulted in numerous road closures across the entire county.
Flooding was reported on Hwy. 125 southeast of Linden, Texas, resulting in a road closure.
Heavy rainfall resulted in very high water reported on Hwy. 79 east of Carthage, Texas.
Flooding was reported at the intersection of Hwy. 103 and FM 1277.

Several roads were closed in the Nevada, Josephine, and Blue Ridge areas due to flooding.  These roads were: CR 590@PR 5337; CR 638@FM 1777; Milton Street in Josephine; CRs 484, 504, 637, 668, 825, and 1216, and SH 1216. Barricades were installed at all of these locations. In addition, the bridge support of SH 5 at the East Fork of the Trinity River in McKinney was being washed out and the bridge had to closed for a few months. The flooding was the result of several hours of rainfall on ground that was already well saturated.
Numerous city streets were underwater in Pineland, Texas.
Numerous roads in eastern Navarro County were closed due to high water. TxDOT had to close several of the roads.
Heavy rain caused flooding in Bull Creek Park.
Heavy rain caused Berry Creek to flood upstream of I35 near Georgetown.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which resulted in flooding and the closure of a low water crossing on Camp Craft Road and the 6700 block of Lakewood Drive near Bullcreek Park. At 0526 a low water crossing was closed on Posten Lane in the 9700 block.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which resulted in one foot of water over the roadway at the intersection of County Road 307 and Ranch Road 3404.
Austin city officials reported that portions of Spicewood Springs Road remained closed due to flash flooding.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Crockett Street in Hallettsville.
Heavy rain caused water to flow across the intersection of Highways 21 and 77.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Lockhill Road at White Bonnet Road.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed West San Antonio Street at Loop 337.
Heavy rain caused water to flow over the road on County Road 226.
County Road 185, 4 miles southeast of Stephenville, was impassable.
Several inches of water were flowing over Mountain Creek Parkway because ditches along the road were overflowing.
Highwater was reported over Highway 188 near Interstate, in addition to several County Roads near in the area.
Water covering multiple roads throughout the city.
The Sheriff's Office reported that numerous county roads across the county were closed due to high water.
Residual flooding of numerous roads in eastern Navarro County continued into the overnight hours. Several of these roads remained closed.
Heavy rainfall on saturated ground led to closures of flood prone roads with several cars reported stranded.
Heavy rainfall flooded 30 homes in the Chateau Woods subdivision in the southern part of the county.
Heavy rainfall produced flash flooding in and around the community of Navasota.
Highway 67 in Keene had water over the road.
Highway 190 in the northern part of the county was closed due to high water.
County Road 256, 2 miles southwest of Stephenville, was impassable.
Heavy rain caused flooding on County Road 320 near Lexington.
Deep water was reported in spots along US Hwy. 80 between Marshall and Waskom, Texas.
Local law enforcement officials reported that many roads in the Jarrell area remained flooded from earlier heavy rain.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Morningside Drive at Solms Road.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed County Road 226.
Heavy rain caused flooding which left vehicles stalled in high water on roadways.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Spicewood Springs Road between Loop 360 and Old Lampasas Trail.
Heavy rain caused Brushy Creek to flow over the roadway of County Road 174 between San Bass Road and Great Oaks Drive. There was at least one vehicle stranded.
Heavy rain caused several inches of water to flow over the roadway southeast of Florence.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding that closed Babcock Road from Camp Bullis Road to Chase Hill Boulevard in San Antonio.
Heavy rain caused water to cover a portion of Highway 55 south of Camp Wood.
Two County Roads were underwater and closed around Lindale, Texas.
Grande Blvd. was closed at the intersection of Hollytree due to excessive heavy rainfall.
Heavy rain caused flooding in Florence.
Roads were flooded in and around Missouri City due to heavy rainfall. The intersections of Highway 6 and Ft. Bend Parkway and Highway 6 and Olympian Parkway were both closed due to high water.
Doniphan Road between El Paso and Canutillo was flooded.
Numerous roads in and around Friendswood were impassable due to high water caused by heavy rainfall. Several high water rescues were required due to the flooding.
Heavy rainfall due to slow moving thunderstorms produced brief road closures along Interstate 10, with four feet of water reported over the road at the intersection of Highway 61 and the interstate.
Heavy rainfall caused one to five feet of water over local roads between Bryan and Benchley.
Heavy rain caused water to flow over the roadway which closed County Road 1492 at River Road.
Heavy rain caused the closure of Jung Road at Stahl Road in San Antonio.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Highway 57 from I35 West to Highway 140.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed numerous roads in and around Jarrell including I35 in both directions.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 140 from Frio Town to Pearsall to the Atascosa County line.
Heavy rain caused a creek to rise four feet in less than 30 minutes and necessitated a high water rescue from a house.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 1582 from Highway 85 south to the county line.
Heavy rain caused Berry Creek to rise rapidly into flood at 15 feet.
River Road near the Smith/Upshur County line was closed due to 2 feet of water over the road.
Due to heavy rain, Terlingua Creek rapidly filled in the Big Bend National Park.  Water up to 2 1/2 feet in depth covered roadways in the park.  The roads were barricaded by park officials.
Numerous county roads were flooded throughout the county.  The I-30 service road in Mount Vernon was flooded and briefly closed as well.
Several roads across the county were flooded and closed.
A couple of county roads were flooded and closed briefly in and around Daingerfield, Texas.
Kingfisher Road was closed due to high water in the community.
Numerous county roads were flooded and closed across the county.
Flooding was reported in the downtown Timpson, Texas community.

Heavy rainfall led to several city streets in and around Rockport being flooded during the evening and overnight hours.  Several vehicles were stranded in high water.  Eight homes were flooded, with one home up to a foot deep near the intersection of Linden and Lady Claire.
Nearly 2 inches of rain fell within 45 minutes in northeast El Paso, which resulted in rock slides and street closures.
Several roads were closed throughout the county due to excessive heavy rainfall.
Heavy rainfall led to the closure of FM2868.
Several county roads were closed due to excessive heavy rainfall.
TXDOT reported FM 1745 was flooded near the Tyler/Polk County line west of Chester.
Port Arthur News reported several streets throughout the city were flooded including Ninth Street.
KFDM-TV and the public reported widespread street flooding in downtown Beaumont and Port Arthur.
Upwards of 25 roads were closed across the county due to flooding.
Several Wood County roads were under water east of Mineola.
Macedonia Road between Hwy. 67 and Redwater Road was covered with four feet of water.
Water was running across Hwy. 82 near MLK.

KBMT-TV and KFDM-TV reported major flash flooding across the city of Beaumont.  3 cars were flooded with water up to the car door windows on the East Tex Freeway at Lucas St. 15 people were rescued from cars stranded in flood waters throughout the city.
The Arkadelphia Community was cut off due to flooding on CR 1102 and Rock Creek Road.
Upwards of 63 roads were closed at one time across Titus County and 3 high water rescues were required.
Numerous roads across Camp County remain flooded and impassable due to excessive heavy rainfall.
Numerous roads across Upshur County continue to be closed and flooded due to excessive heavy rainfall.
Cox Road at Birmingham...Five Notch Road just south of I-20...Buck Sherrod Road just south of the creek and FM 968 at Potters Creek were all closed due to high water.
The South Service Road...FM 9 south at Dixie Lake Lane...and the Jonesville Cutoff at the bridge were all closed due to high water.
High water was reported across Hwy. 11 and Hwy. 49.
High water was reported across Hwy. 67 in town.
Road closed at Dickerson and Carr Road due to high water over the road.  High water rescue performed at Carr Road and Charco Road intersection.
One lane of FM 356 closed due to high water.
Two neighborhoods in the Wake Village community were isolated from incoming or outgoing traffic as water was 3 to 4 feet deep on roads around the area.
Water was covering Hwy. 259 south and west and Central MLK.
Numerous roads across the county were under water.
Several roads across the northern half of the county were under water.
Several cars were stalled out due to high water.

Periods of heavy rainfall during the late afternoon and evening hours resulted in flash flooding in Hopkins County. The following roads were impassable at some point during the evening hours: CR 1197 near FM 2297 and CR 1174, FM 69 north of Interstate 30, FM 1870 near the bridges, FM 2560, CR 1444, CR 1152 near FM 1567, FM 71 west, CR 2316 near FM 69 south, and several of the main streets in Sulphur Springs. It was also reported that some vehicles got trapped in water on SH 11, CR 2316, and SH 154.
FM 71 near the Delta/Hopkins County line and FM 69 near the Mahoney slab remained impassable due to heavy rainfall from the night before.

Five to seven inches of rain fell over a five hour period during the afternoon hours across northern Jefferson County. Widespread flooding of roadways was reported by the public and law enforcement in and around Beaumont.  The public reported about a foot of water on Major Drive at Willow Creek Drive in southwest Beaumont, with water covering the yards of area residences.  An NWS employee observed flooding on the frontage roads along Interstate 10 at the Highway 69 interchange, and law enforcement reported several of the underpasses in the city were also flooded.
An amateur radio operator observed 3 to 6 inches of flowing water near the intersection of I-20 and TX 158.  There was also other significant flooding near the same area.
The broadcast media reported high water rescues ongoing in the Ridgecrest Circle area and also around the Western Street and Catalpa Lane area.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported six inches of fast flowing water in the area around Osage Street and Interstate 40.

Numerous roads across the southern half of the county were heavily damaged by flooding. Moderate to severe road damage was caused in the area from Shive to Evant to Ohio. Road material was washed off the road, and ditches, culverts, and tin horns were washed out. Highway 84 near Evant was closed for approximately 1.5 hours due to high water and a swift water rescue was required. Highway 281 also had water crossing the road in a few places. CRs 519, 524, and 530 sustained heavy damage and remained closed for some time.
A vehicle was washed off Country Club Road in Mansfield. Twenty-two employees at the country club had to be rescued due to rapidly rising water and the water was waist deep at the time of the rescue.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported 4 feet of water over FM 2230 eleven miles northwest of Big Spring. The highway was closed due to the flooding.

A law enforcement official reported a stalled car in an underpass in Schulenburg with the water rising rapidly. The car was on Highway 77 and the car stalled while going underneath the railroad underpass. An elderly couple was in the car. The woman was rescued, the elderly man drowned.
Heavy rainfall from a slow moving tornadic thunderstorm closed portions of Old San Antonio Road between FM 1452 and Normangee.

A large, slow moving thunderstorm produced widespread heavy rainfall across western portions of Harris County during the early morning hours. Many roads including portions of US 59, Interstate 10 West, Beltway 8 West, and the 610 Loop were impassable for most of the morning rush hour, with numerous cars becoming stranded by high water. One fatality occurred when a vehicle was swept into the drainage system near the Katy Freeway (Interstate 10 W) and Beltway 8.||In addition to the major disruption to the morning commute, over 2,100 homes received some amount of water intrusion from this event. This ranks as the fourth largest number of homes flooded in a single event for Harris County.

Slow moving thunderstorms across the southern portion of Harris County produced widespread flooding and road closures. The area traversed by this system had received heavy rainfall 6 days prior to the event, and the ground was still saturated. The heaviest rainfall fell along a line from Friendswood to Baytown, with totals of 7 to 8 inches during a 6 hour period. Many secondary roads along Interstate 45 became impassable for most of the evening. Forty to fifty homes recieved water damage from this event, although this is only an estimated count as all of the homes flooded on the 24th were also flooded during the earlier event on April 18th.
Heavy rainfall from a slow moving thunderstorm produced street flooding which closed several county roads in the vicinity of Clover Field.

Widespread heavy rainfall across the county resulted in road closures and reported rainfall totals of 10 to 12 inches.  Some roads between Nada and Weimar, including FM 155 and County Roads 378, 373, 369 and 372 were flooded.

KFDM-TV and the public reported widespread flash flooding across central and eastern Jefferson County. Several major roadways were underwater in the Fannett and Labelle areas. Numerous roadways and underpasses were flooded in Beaumont, including the intersection of Madison Road and Irving Street. Cars were stalled and submerged in floodwaters on Jimmy Johnson Boulevard between Highway 347 and 9th Avenue in Port Arthur.
Flooding was reported along most of Fairgrounds Road by a trained spotter.  The flowing water height was estimated to be 3 to 6 inches high.
Local law enforcement observed flooding near the intersection of 10th Street and FM 1936.  There was also flooding near the intersection of Dunn Street and FM 1936.
Flooding was observed in Seminole near the local Pizza Hut.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated Farm to Market Road 1028 was closed due to flooding.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated that numerous low water crossings along Farm to Market Road 504 to Doole were flooded.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated that Farm to Market Road 714 over Brady Creek was closed due to flooding.
Texas Department of Transportation reports Ranch Market Road 1989 was closed along Granger Draw due to flooding and high water. Over one and a half feet of water was over the road.
Texas Department of Transportation reported that Ranch Road 385 was closed due to flooding from US Highway 377 to US Highway 290. Numerous low water crossings were flooded.
Texas Department of Transportation indicates that Ranch Road 2597 was closed due to flooding at the intersection of Ranch Road 864.

Thunderstorms began to impact portions of Swisher County just before 13:00 CST on the 16th. These storms quickly became severe and displayed occasional supercellular characteristics as they effectively trained over the Interstate 27 corridor. ||A combination of heavy rainfall and accumulating hail resulted in a prolonged closure of Interstate 27 during the afternoon and overnight hours of the 16th and into the morning of the 17th. The most significant impacts occurred between Kress and Tulia. Up to 50 vehicles became stranded on the interstate as high water and hail covered the driving surface. Some motorists were rescued from their stalled automobiles with the use of boats and fire engines. Up to 5.27 inches of rainfall was measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Tulia, and 5.90 inches was measured by the Tulia National Weather Service cooperative observer. Ponded water receded sufficiently from the highway by 07:00 CST on the 17th, and the interstate was re-opened. No serious injuries were reported, but combined damages from hail and floods were estimated near $1 million.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated that Ranch Road 2596 was closed due to flooding in Sutton County at the First Draw which is located just past the intersection with Ranch Road 864.

Torrential rains fed by continuing outflows from storms along the Sierra Madre Oriental blitzed the west half of Zapata County during hte mid evening.  The Zapata County Sheriffs Office reported minor flooding along Federal Highway 83 in the San Ygnacio area north of the City of Zapata toward the Webb County line.  The flooding was reported between Corralitos and the La Perla Ranch, Lake #4, area. ||The Manager of the Zapata County Airport recorded 3.75 inches of rain, in addition to the fairly long duration of quarter size hail. Radar rainfall estimates were over 7 inches, but likely contaminated by the prodigious hail. Still, it is conceivable that more than 4 inches fell in a few spots, leading to enough water flowing across roads to consider the event a Flash Flood.

The Lynn County Emergency Manager reported that repeated waves of thunderstorms throughout the late afternoon and evening hours had produced heavy rainfall and resulted in flash flooding over portions of Lynn County. Reports indicated that extensive areas of flowing flood waters inundated portions of U.S. Highway 87 near Tahoka. Flood waters additionally flowed over Farm to Market Roads 211 and 1730 near New Home. No damage or injuries were reported.
The Moulton police chief reported street flooding in the city caused by 7 inches of rain.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated water was over low spots and low water crossings along Ranch Road 1674 from I-10 to Ranch Road 864.
San Angelo Dispatch reported street flooding at numerous intersections and barricades set up at low water crossings across the city.
A COOP observer reported Hwy 90 East out of Flatonia was closed due to high water.
Streets were beginning to flood in Nocona.

Water was reported over the roads in several locations across the northern portions of the county. Road and bridge damage was being observed. At 330 pm, a fatal accident occurred on HWY 377 north of Whitesboro.

Widespread flooding continued through the night across the county with several roads and bridges under water and several areas inaccessible. High water rescues and evacuations continued in Gainesville and parts of Interstate 35 South were still closed due to water over the road. Rainfall totals were as high as 11 inches. Approximately 35 homes and 15 businesses were damaged by flooding in Gainesville.  Homes and businesses along Pecan Creek in Gainesville suffered major damage. The water was 1-2 feet deep around the creek. A total of 10 swift water rescues were needed during the event. The Moss Lake area also received significant damage to boats, docks, and boathouses.
High water rescues and evacuations continued in Gainesville. Parts of Interstate 35 South remained closed due to water over the road. Widespread flooding continued around the county.
Ross Avenue at HWY 14 in Mexia is closed due to high water.
Flooding was occurring along HWY 6 south of Hearne.

Interstate 35 at mile marker 493, about 3.5 miles south of Gainesville, was closed due to water over the road. Widespread flooding continued elsewhere in the county with several roads and bridges flooded. In Gainesville, Pecan Creek and Wheeler Creek overflowed their banks and flooded the surrounding areas resulting in evacuations and rescues along both creeks.
Highway 69 and FM 981 between Trenton and Leonard was closed due to water over the road.
Widespread secondary roads and bridges were closed due to flooding in the northwestern parts of the county.

Water was over the roads around Nocona and several roads across the northern portions of the county were closed due to flooding. A few families were being evacuated in St. Jo. Vehicle rescues were also requested on Bulcher Highway. The water was curb deep in Bowie.
High water was reported over the road at the intersection of US 59 and FM 62.
FM 942 was reported closed at Hickman Creek due to high water.
Roads were reported flooded along FM 350 near Bear Creek.
Prolonged heavy rainfall during the day left numerous roads and bridges in the Franklin area closed.
Numerous county roads and bridges were damaged across the county. CR 2230 along Richland Chambers Reservoir between Ladd's Harbor and Arrowhead subdivisions collapsed.
Widespread flooding continued across the county. Parts of HWY 56 and HWY 11 were closed.
Widepsread flooding continued through the night across the county with several roads and bridges under water and several areas inaccessible.
Heritage Row at Live Oak Street was closed due to several inches of water over the road from heavy rain. Some drainage culverts were crushed by the weight of the water.
Several areas of flooding in and around Mexia were reported due to 5-6 inches of rain that fell over the area in a short time. The water was a few feet deep on East Hopkins Street.
Texas Department of Transportation indicated that debris and rock was over Farm to Market Road 2169 due to flooding.
County Dispatch reported that Junction schools were closed early today due to heavy rain and the potential of flooded roadways and low water crossings.
Texas Department of Transportation reported water over roadway from Melvin to Brady along Farm to Market Road 2028.

Heavy rainfall from thunderstorms moving across the county produced road closeures and widespread flooding of homes, with high water rescues being required in Dickinson. A rain gauge at FM 528 and Clear Creek in League City recorded a 1 hour rainfall total of 6.02 inches. League City reported 300 homes sustaining flood damage from this event.

Water was covering several roads in Gainesville and was up to the bumper of pick-up trucks in some locations. Also, part of HWY 82 was closed between Muenster and Lindsey for nearly 2 hours where the water was reported to be a foot deep.
Nash Creek Road and a portion of Hwy 90 were closed due to water on the roads east of Seguin. There was 6.34 inches of rain in less than three hours.
Highway 87 south of Cuero and some streets in town were closed due to water covering the roads.
Pecan and Ash Streets in Johnson City were closed due to flooding.
Highway 123 was flooded in Geronimo.

Several roads in Kosse are blocked with 3-5 of water over the road. Numerous county roads were under water county-wide from heavy rain during the day. Several homes around Lake Mexia and other lakes were flooded and so were schools in Groesbeck. An estimated 12 bridges and 60 roads were damaged or destroyed.
Water was over the road at FM 1366 and HWY 84W.

High water rescues were conducted on FM 246 near Wortham. Numerous County Roads were under water and damaged from prolonged rainfall for much of the day. Nearly every road between Fairfield and Mexia and Fairfield and Wortham was under water. Numerous bridges were washed out or heavily damaged around the county. The Tawakoni Bridge on Interstate 45 was damaged. The Wortham City Hall was damaged by water in the building. The lake near Wortham overflowed its dam and flooded nearby roads with up to three feet of water. Many motorists were stranded in rural parts of the county.
Water was reported over the road near Hubbard, and the sheriff's office also reported county roads near Hillsboro had water over them.
Numerous roads across the northern half of the county were closed due to water over the road. The water was several inches to a foot deep in some areas.
The HWY 190 access road between W.S Young Road and Trimmier Road in Killeen was closed due to high water.
Honey Creek and Plum Creek rose out of their banks.
Highways 80, 97, and 87 were closed for a short time due to water covering the roads in Nixon.
FM2440 was closed due to water covering the road northwest of Giddings.
Water was reported over the roads in several locations across the northern portions of the county.
The sheriff office reported several streets closed in Cuero due to flooding.
There were reports of several low waters crossings being flooded along Highway 473.

Widepsread flooding continued through the night across the county with several roads and bridges under water and several areas inaccessible. Estimated rainfall totals across the northern portions of the county were as high as 12 inches of rainfall.
The heavy rain caused flash flooding in Brownwood as many roadways were covered by water.  Shelters were open for persons in flooded homes.

The National Park Dispatch Center reported flowing water over SH 120 just north of the Rio Grande Village.  Although multiple vehicles hydroplaned near this location, no accidents or injuries were reported.

The local law enforcement reported roads were impassible at 1530 CST due to high water and a motorist was stranded at Nelson and 1st Street.  The motorist was not injured.  In addition, the public reported standing water depths of 1 foot and multiple softball fields covered with water in Fort Stockton at 1536 CST.
Several county roads and areas remained under water through the night. Several roads and areas were flooded by Woodbury Creek and Brushy Creek which overflowed their banks.
Several sections of road near the intersection of Highway 205 and Highway 80 in Terrell were under water.
High water and flooding was reported on parts of FM 36, multiple service roads of I-30 and on Northshore Road in Quinlan.
A bridge on CR 283 1 mile northwest of Kaufman was underwater.

Numerous roads were closed or covered in water across Hopkins County. These roads and areas included: FM 71 near the Delta/Hopkins county line, CR 2316, CR 2321, CR 4708, CR 3518, CR 4763, CR 2322, CR 4764, CR 2310, FM 2560, FM 71 at CR 3567, FM 69 north at CR 3918, FM 1567 west, CR 3380 at FM 900, and SH 11 west just past CR 4738. A car was reported stuck in flood waters on CR 3523 north of FM 69 in Dike and a vehicle was washed off CR 2315, but no injuries were reported with either incident. In addition, several yards in Sulphur Spring were underwater due to heavy rain that overwhelmed the drainage system.
Several single-family residences were flooded in Oak Point.
Several county roads were underwater.
FM 350 closed due to high water west of Moscow.
A car was stalled in high water on Cooper Lane in the extreme northern portion of Texarkana, Texas.
High water reported on Tristate Road in Redwater, Texas.  The road had to be closed.
FM 1487 near the Cuthand community was closed from flash flooding.

Flooding was reported at Lamberth Road and Travis Street in Sherman. The underpass at HWY 75 and Lamar Street in Sherman was also flooded. Poor drainage and water running off a hill behind the Villas of Parkhaven complex on FM 1417 resulted in the flooding of 29 apartments. In at least one apartment, the water was ankle deep.
CR 992 northeast of Dekalb was flooded and closed.
FM 909 east of town was flooded and closed.
FM 1699 was closed from excessive heavy rainfall near the community of White Rock.
FM 44 was closed 1 mile west of the community of Lydia due to excessive heavy rainfall.
CR 3117 was flooded and closed.
FM 1159 AT CR 3240 was closed from excessive heavy rainfall.
CR 3117 was closed near the Hopewell community.

The Hickory Creek Mobile Home community was flooded by Bryant Branch Creek that runs through the community. The water depth ranged from knee deep to 5 feet deep in some locations and entered several homes. One couple had to evacuate their home after it was deemed unsafe to live in when it started shifting from the flood waters.
A high water rescue was conducted at LBJ Freeway and Park Central Lane.
Numerous city and county roads in and around New Boston, Texas were flooded from excessive heavy rainfall.  Two homes were flooded by three to four feet of water on Lacy Street in Hooks, Texas.
FM 1385 east of Aubrey was closed due to water over the road.
FM 407 between Argyle and Interstate 35W was closed due to water over the road.
Numerous roads in northeast Dallas were flooded. Also, Walnut Hill Lane at Goodnight Lane was flooded.
The Sheriff's Office reported a truck stuck in high water on HWY 66 in Royse City. The water depth was unknown.
Floodwaters entered homes in Trophy Club.
Street flooding was reported in McKinney.
The Rockdale PD reported that several streets in the city had to be closed due to water covering the streets.
At Silverwood Lane and Regent Drive in Plano, a few cars were flooded out when they attempted to cross the bridge that was covered by high water. No injuries were reported.
The water was reported to be 8 inches deep across roads that run along Hickory Creek in Balch Springs.
Tyler County Sheriff Office reported several roads covered by high water across the county.
Local law enforcement reported roadway partially washed out at intersection of Daily Street and Chris Street just west of FM 252 in southwest Jasper.
The Sheriff's Office reported that several county roads remained under water.
Two feet of water was reported over the road near Loop 820 and Lancaster Avenue on the east side of Fort Worth.
Water was reported over the road at Interstate 20 and Highway 67.
The access road along Interstate 35E in the Corinth and Lake Dallas area had water over the road.
Law enforcement reported water covering Highway 1013 west of Mt. Union.

Numerous city streets were flooded and closed.  Floodwaters from the city's water system backed up which resulted in the local Scout Hutt at Tapp Park in New Boston being innundated by three feet of water.

One water rescue was performed during the morning hours of the 3rd and several county roads were covered in water. Of note, CR 1325 near Woodbury Creek was underwater and CR 1275 at Brushy Creek was underwater as both creeks overflowed their banks. Woodbury Creek also flooded farms and ranches along its banks.
The Sheriff's Office reported that several county roads remained under water.
The Sheriff's Office reported flooding along the I-30 service road at FM 2642 near Royse City.

Ongoing flooding continued into the night from heavy rainfall over the county during the evening hours. Hickory Creek Mobile Community continued to be affected by several feet of water from flooding on Bryant Branch Creek.
Water was over the road at SH 78 and CR 578 north of Blue Ridge.
The sheriff's office reported the service road between the prison and river bridge completely inundated.
Flash flooding occurred at several locations in Brady. Barricades were set up by law enforcement.
Flooding was reported on 12th Street in Brownwood. Also, the water depth of four to five feet was reported across the underpass on Vine Street.
Flooding was reported near the intersection of US Highways 67 and 377 in Early.
Major roads were reported flooded.
The Texas Departmet of Transportation reported water over US Highway 380 from Rule to the Throckmorton County line.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported water over Highway 6 from U.S. Highway 380 in Rule, to 5 miles south.
Jones County Sheriff's Office reported water over Farm to Market Road 600 between US Highway 180 and Avoca.
The drainage ditch at Shawnee Park was flooded and the water flowed onto Elm Street. Several roads in the city were left impassable due to heavy rain from an MCS.
Some homes and businesses were flooded in Comanche. Indian Creek overflowed its banks around South Houston Street covering the road with a few feet of water.
The water was reported to be 18 inches deep on the 4800 block of Gaston Ave in Dallas. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Dallas County.
The water was reported to be 3 feet deep near Fair Park in Dallas. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Dallas County.
A car was stranded in 2 feet of water at Harry Hines Blvd and Northwest Highway. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Dallas County.
The water was 2 feet deep at Singleton Blvd and Loop 12 on the west side of Dallas. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Dallas County.
Flooding along Big Bear Creek in Keller flooded the park and kept Bear Creek Parkway closed for part of the morning until the waters finally receded during the afternoon hours.
A creek flowing under Hurstview Drive in south Hurst overflowed its banks and flooded nearby homes. The water was reported to be a foot deep in some homes. The bridge over the creek was closed.
Some service roads along I-35 in Denton were impassable and were being closed.
Three feet of water was reported over the road at I-20 and Bryant Irvin Road.

Significant flash flooding occurred in Highland Park from training echoes over Dallas County. Turtle Creek overflowed its banks and flooded roadways near its shores. A highwater rescue was required where Fitzhugh/Wycliff crosses the creek. The water was chest deep at the time of the rescue. Another water rescue was needed on Westside Drive and at the intersection of Armstrong Avenue and Lakeside Drive. Also, about 6 homes were flooded with water and the basement of the HPDPS was flooded.

Two lightning strikes hit the Dallas pumping station causing the failure of one of the pumps that is responsible for parts of west Dallas. This failure exacerbated flooding that was already ongoing in Dallas. Some evacuations were performed in neighborhoods around Hampton Road and Canada Drive.

An estimated seven inches of rain in about 10 hours resulted in flooding in Forney. Street flooding closed down neighborhood streets and the water was up to the foundation of some homes in areas where the terrain was slightly lower. In parts of Downtown Forney, the water was up to the bumper of cars. The Curves on East Main Street was flooded and Mustang Creek rose out of its banks on one side. High water also closed down the intersections of Bowie Street and Pinson Road and Heritage Hill Drive at FM 470.

Flooding was observed in North Dallas. The flooding was the result of training cells over Dallas County. The emergency manager also reported that by 7:30 am, Dallas Fire and Rescue had conducted 48 water rescues around the city and the police had worked 200 traffic accidents due to weather.

Eight homes and one business was flooded in Mesquite. In addition, numerous roads were flooded and closed. At times, seventeen streets in the city had be closed and five of those were closed for several hours. Highway 80 at Town East Blvd had be closed and I-635 just south of Gross Road was reduced to one lane on the southbound side. A high water rescue was performed at Highway 80 and Town East Blvd at about 9:30 am. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Dallas County.
Roads throughout the city of Lampasas were being barricaded.

Vehicles were stalled on Georgia Street due to flooding and the road was completely covered. The water was reportedly over the sidewalks and up to buildings. The forty-second block of Crockett Street was reportedly under water and water was up to car doors at Washington Street and 27th Street. Also...vehicles were reported to be stalled at 6th Avenue and Bowie Street and northbound Georgia Street was not passable due to high water. The Potter County and Amarillo Emergency Manager reported stalled vehicles at every intersection from Georgia Street and Interstate 40 to Georgia Street and Hawthorne Drive. A river of water a few feet deep was flowing down Interstate 27 at the low areas between Washington Street and the 34th Street bridges. Also...rapidly flowing water about three feet deep was flowing along Georgia Street from 10th Street north through McMasters Street. Major flooding was reported in the San Jacinto Park area. There was also a report of the road caving in at Interstate 40 and Washington Street due to the flooding. Water was reported to be across the entire roadway on Georgia Street and was impassable. The road reportedly buckled at Southwest 3rd Avenue and Hayden Street.
Water was reported over roads near the junction of HWY 360 and HWY 121 in Grapevine. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Tarrant County.
Homes were evacuated near Sylvan Avenue and McBroom Street. The flooding was the result of training echoes over Dallas County.

Training echoes for several hours dropped several inches of rain that caused Big Bear Creek to flow out of its banks near Bear Creek Park in Keller. The park was flooded and Bear Creek Parkway had to be closed between Cindy Court and Anita Avenue due to water over the road.

Training echoes for several hours dropped several inches of rain that caused Little Fossil Creek to flow out of its banks on the east side of Saginaw. East McLeroy Street was closed through Thursday morning due to water over the road.

Training echoes for several hours dropped several inches of rain that caused Big Fossil Creek to flow out of its banks on the east side of Saginaw. Some lanes of FM 156/Blue Mound Road at East Bailey-Boswell Road were flooded and barricaded. In some locations, the water was about a foot deep.
Several roads remain underwater and closed in Dekalb, Simms and Moss SPrings, Texas.
Street flooding was reported in the west side of town.
High water was reported across Tri State Road.
Stream flooding was reported east of New Boston that led to some road closures.
Hwy. 4215 southwest of Annona, Texas was closed from extensive flash flooding.
High water resulted in the closure of FM 911.
Meadowbrook Lane in Texarkana, Texas was flooded and closed.
Heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of Elm Street along the Swampoodle Creek.
FM 911 near and north of Avery remains closed from flash flooding.
Tri-State road was washed out in the community of Red Water, Texas.
Hwy. 82 east from New Boston to Texarkana, Texas had to be closed due to excessive heavy rainfall and flash flooding.  Several other roads were closed throughout Bowie County as well.
College Drive underpass was flooded.  Another driver was stranded in flood waters at the 7th street underpass.
A thunderstorm produced heavy rain which flooded the low water crossing at Lakewood Drive and Bull Creek in northwest Austin.
The bridge at 12th and Red River Streets in Austin was washed out.
Extensive flooding across the entire county.  County roads underwater and closed include 4109, 4125, 4126, 4108, 1306, 4008, 1101 and 2253.
Heavy rainfall resulted in swollen creeks in and around Texarkana, Texas which backed up onto several rural roadways.  Some of these included the Aiken Creek, Anderson Creek and the Barkman Creek.
Some roads were impassable due to high water.  The duration of this event was estimated due to limited reports.
Numerous streets were flooded in the city of Sulphur Springs. The water was knee to waist deep and several water rescues were performed for trapped motorists.
There were several impassible points along the Ross Maxwell Scenic Road due to high water.
Multiple vehicles were submerged at the intersection of 23rd Street and Andrews Highway in Odessa.  In addition, 12 to 16 inches of flowing water covered the same roadway.

Heavy rainfall persisted across the county as several thunderstorms produced rainfall totals of 8 to 10 inches across the county. Numerous roads were closed in areas of the county, including Jersey Village, Houston Heights, La Porte, Pasadena, Webster, and near the Houston Hobby airport. More than 350 homes were flooded due to the heavy rains and flooding along bayous. In some areas residential streets were reported to have more than one foot of standing water. The highest one hour rainfall total was 6.90 inches recorded at Bay Area Blvd and Clear Creek. This exceeds the highest one hour rainfall rate measured during Tropical Storm Allison in June 2001, which was 6.30 inches.||In the northern part of the county five children were killed after the car they were riding in inadvertently drove into a drainage ditch that was filled with nine feet of water from the heavy rainfall. Two adults and one child were able to escape the floodwaters, but the five younger children, all under 7 years old, were not able to escape.
Flooding was reported in Canutillo and Anthony.
Ponding of water on Interstate 20 and its service roads between FM 113 and HWY 281 was reported.
Residual flooding from heavy rain during the early morning hours left several road underwater in and around Mineral Wells; especially out by the airport.
Ponding of water on Interstate 20 and its service roads between FM 113 and HWY 281 was reported.

Widespread street and creek flooding was reported around Irving. The river walk at Centennial Park in Irving was flooded, and several other parks were flooded and closed. A few motorists had to be rescued from their cars and in at least one case the water was 3-4 feet deep. Some major highways had to be closed down.

Significant flash flooding occurred in University Park from training echoes over Dallas County. Twenty emergency calls of vehicles stalled in water were reported to the police department and fire department. Barricades were needed in 18 locations to close down streets inundated with high water.
Cars were stranded in high water at Elam Road and St. Augustine Road in southeast Dallas.
A man had to be rescued from his flooded car on Riverside Parkway in Grand Prairie. The water was up to the headlights of the sedan.
Eight inches of flowing water was observed near the intersection of Scarborough and A Street.
Water was reported over the road at the intersection of FM 1999 and CR 9.

Numerous roads and highways were underwater in Atlanta, Texas.  Several roads were closed.  Water was also reported in a few homes in town with evacuations needed.  Several high water vehicle rescues were also reported in town.  Several roads were also washed out including FM 1841.
Report of water completely covering the Josey County Road two miles southwest of Avinger, Texas.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in high water across several roads in and near town.
A daycare facility on West Houston Street was flooded.

A television photojournalist was shooting video of the storm when a sudden strong current of water displaced his vehicle and moved it down a city street. Water depth was unknown and no injuries were reported.
Two feet of water was covering several roadways with many other low lying areas covered in water.
Several city streets and underpasses under water in the city of Marshall, Texas.
Knight Avenue and Whipperwill Drive were closed from high water.

Local emergency manager reported a total of 11 high water rescues from stalled vehicles in flooded roadways around and close to the city.
