Four children were rescued from a flooded home on Thomas Street and another 5 homes in various portions of the city were evacuated due to flooding.  Two other flood related vehicle rescues were also made in Queen City with several homes evacuated.  Two residents on CR 1896 were driving on the road in a truck when they spotted a woman hanging onto a fence post in rushing flood waters with a disabled vehicle.  The occupants of the truck attempted to drive the truck close enough to rescue the woman but their vehicle was also disabled by the high water.  Another resident of the county road brought a boat with him and all victims were rescued.
Highway 114 in Olney had to be closed and an apartment complex on Bluebonnet Drive had to be evacuated.
Two feet of water over FM 1794 about one quarter mile east of U.S. 59 and at least 1.5 foot of water over CR. 263 about a half mile east of U.S. 59.

There were numerous reports of flooding from multiple sources, but most were confirmed by the media.  At 515 AM CST, the Midland Police Department reported a few stalled vehicles across the city limits.  Three minutes later, a high water rescue was reported at the intersection of Lee and Maple.  At 635 AM CST, the media reported flash flooding along the Scharbauer Draw in residential areas.  The police department then reported two more cars were submerged in the city of Midland, at 717 AM CST.  One foot of flowing water was present near the intersection of Golf Course and Garfield.  Finally, at 1001 AM CST, the media still continued to report areas of high water across Midland.
Page Creek was out of its banks with over a foot of water in adjacent fields.  A measured 4.10 inches of rainfall fell in the 24 hour period ending at 10 am cst.
Numerous roads were under water near Deberry, Texas.
Three cars were trapped in high water at teh intersection of Douglas Avenue and Lemmon Avenue. The water was reported to be 9 inches deep.
Residual flooding from heavy rain early in the morning left County Road 506 impassable until 9 am.
Two cars were stuck in high water at Hurst Blvd and Norwood Road.
Most roads out to the Mineral Wells Airport were underwater. The water was reported to be 6 inches deep at the intersection of FM 1821 and FM 1195.
Flash flooding was reported at the intersection of FM 1788 and Business 20.  A few vehicles were stalled in the high water.
Law enforcement reported multiple high water rescues do to flash flooding near the intersections of 2nd Street and West County Road, and Wendover and Penbooke Roads at 1148 CST.
The North Service Road was closed at mile marker 165 on Interstate 30 due to high water.

Widespread flash flooding was reported with over 50 roads across the county closed at one point.  Water ranged from one to three feet deep across most roads.  Some of these roads were washed out including Walker's Mill Road, the intersection of Cox and Birmingham roads as well as Stagecoach Road.  South Washington Avenue also reported some damage.
Three inches of rainfall fell in 20 minutes and a total of 4.70 inches fell in 65 minutes near the town of Avinger, Texas.  Several roads and secondary roads were underwater southwest of town.

There were multiple reports of flash flooding, mainly across western Midland County.  Flash flooding was first reported on Loop 250 and the adjacent access roads between Tremont and Holiday Hill Roads at 1138 PM CST, where there was 6 inches of flowing water present.  The next location of flooding was reported at the intersection of Andrews Highway and Midland Drive at 1141 PM CST.  Cars were also stranded at the intersection of Andrews Highway and Idlewild Road at 1146 PM CST.  Finally, substantial flooding was reported by TEXDOT at 1152 PM CST and likely continued for another 30 minutes before the storm weakened.

The first flash flood report received for this event was from the Odessa Police Department.  At 710 AM CST, several roads were covered in water throughout the city limits.  The media reported the water depth was estimated to be 15 to 20 inches deep near the intersection of 36th and Dixie.  Finally, at 901 AM CST, another media crew reported many areas across Odessa were flooded with high water.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of Hwy. 59 to all traffic from Tenaha to Timpson, Texas.  Traffic was diverted to Hwy. 87 but it became closed from high water as well.
Numerous County roads still underwater throughout the county.  U.S. 69 was flooded south of Lufkin, Texas as well.
Highway 31 near Elysian Fields was covered in high water.
Numerous roads were flooded and closed throughout the entire county.  Some homes were also flooded near Hwy. 59 south near Diboll, Texas.

The public reported Heavy rainfall in a thunderstorm which produced flooding on Business Highway 83 between Airport Drive and Texas. Some homes in the area were reported to have water up to the door steps. Major flooding was reported in nearby streets. Six inches of rain was estimated to have fallen during the thunderstorm. The Hidalgo County Emergency Manager reported thirteen intersections were closed due to the flooding and several cars were totaled due to the flood waters.

Significant flooding was observed across the far southern and far western portions of Tarrant County. Road closures were widespread in Arlington, Crowley, and Mansfield. Cars were stuck in water and high water rescues were required.

Significant flooding was reported across Ellis County from heavy rainfall that fell in just a few hours. It was reported that over 10 of rain fell in parts of the northern portions of the county. Water was reported over the road at Interstate 35E, mile marker 395. Water was over the road on Highway 77 near Italy and high water rescues were reported in the Ferris area. A local newspaper listed several roads that were closed around the county, including part of the I-35E service road, the service roads along I-45 (in the Palmer area), and numerous County Roads and Farm-to-Market roads around the county. Another local newspaper also reported that the water was 3 feet deep in Bristol on FM 660.
Park Central Drive at I-635 in north Dallas was closed due to high water.
Campbell/Blackburn Road in Garland was closed between North Garland Ave and East Brand Road due to high water.

Flash flooding affected far east El Paso. Reports from TxDOT included water covering State Highway 375 near Del Valle High School and wzter covering Montana Street east of Highway 375. Also, an arroyo overflow closed part of I-10 at Eastlake Boulevard.
Highway 114 near the Texas Motor Speedway was closed for several hours due to high water over the road.
Several roads remained under water and closed through the afternoon hours from earlier heavy rainfall.
TxDOT had to close down HWY 271 just west of Pattonville for several hours due to water over the road.

Excessive heavy rainfall fell across the county...resulting in several roadways under water.  Water was also reported to be entering homes in Gilmer, Texas and a shed was washed from a yard and ended up in the roadway.  A motorists had to be rescued from her vehicle when it stalled out on Bob-O-Link Road.

Several local business in town experienced flood damage from the excessive heavy rainfall that fell during the day.  Several city streets were closed as well.  The Bakery Restaurant along with the Jefferson Jimplecute and numerous other buildings in town suffered water damage when city pumps couldn't handle the excessive heavy rainfall.  The worst flooding occurred along Austin, Polk, Walnut and Soda Streets but there was some water damage to Parker and Parker CPAs and the Otstott and Jaminson law firms on Lafayette Street.

Significant flash flooding occurred in southern Bell County when 9-15 of rain fell in less than 10 hours. The town of Salado was hit the hardest during the early afternoon hours. Salado Creek that runs through town overflowed its banks and forced the evacuations of approximately 12 families. The rapid rise in the creek also heavily damaged the Main Street Bridge, ripping the asphalt from the bridge and forcing its closure through October 14th. In other areas of Salado, the water was reported to be nearly 10 feet over some bridges and some homes were flooded with up to two feet of water. In addition, Interstate 35 near the Bell/Willimason county line had to be closed for a few hours and other parts of the interstate were down to one lane due to water on the road. The access roads of Interstate 35 between Salado and the Bell/Williamson county line were also closed due to water over the roads. Many of these road closures began during the early afternoon hours. In the town of Bartlett, 5 of water was reported to be flooding streets, and 5 of water was also reported over FM 487, east of Bartlett. Additional roads in the southern portions of the county were flooded and closed as well.
The exit ramp from Interstate 35 onto Illinois Avenue was closed due to high water. Seven cars went around the barricades and were stranded in the high water.
Numerous county roads were underwater throughout the county.  Several homes were flooded throughout the county as well, mostly in rural portions of the county.
Flooding was reported at the intersection of FM 919 and FM 2692. In addition, persistent street flooding was reported in Gordon.
Water was reported over certain portions of U.S. 59 Loop in Lufkin, Texas.

Residual flooding continued across Ellis County into the next day. Additional periods of rainfall caused additional problems across the county. In particular, the service roads along Interstate 45 in Palmer remained under water, the southbound exit of Interstate 45 at mile maker 258 was under water, parts of FM 660 in Bristol remained under 3' of water, and several roads across the county remained closed.
A high water rescue was conducted near the intersection of FM852 and County Road 4490 near Winnsboro, Texas after the vehicle was washed off the road.  No injuries were reported.

A 44 year old white female was walking down CR 4583 when she fell and was swept off the road by swift flood waters.  County Emergency officials tried to rescue her but she was unable to hold onto a lift rope and she drowned.  Time of death was approximated around 330 pm cdt.
Many roads were reported to be underwater and closed in Carthage, Texas.
Numerous roads were flooded across the county.
Numerous roads were flooded in the southern and eastern portions of the county.

Significant flash flooding occurred across mainly the southern half of Dallas County from continuous rainfall that lasted nearly 12 hours. The Dallas EOC reported several streets southeast of downtown Dallas had to be closed. Also, the area north of Interstate 30 and south of the Trinity River in west Dallas was significantly flooded when the water pump system failed due to the heavy rainfall. Several intersections along Carrier Parkway and other major roads in Grand Prairie were flooded. Numerous other roadways in southwest Dallas County were flooded. High water rescues were performed in the southern portions of Dallas County, Interstate 45 at Simpson Stuart was closed, and the exit ramp from Interstate 35 to Illinois Avenue was closed.

Several flooded areas were reported across the county but the city of Burleson was impacted the most. Numerous roads were closed in Burleson and cars were stranded in water in the city. A few residents had to be evacuated on Bowden Circle between 4-5 am CST. In Joshua, five water rescues in automobiles were needed on CRs 913, 914, 1021, and 705 and Indian Hills.  Several streets in the city of Joshua were also closed for several hours. The fire department in Joshua reported the floodwaters began to recede in Joshua around 645 am CST. Other road closures were reported across the county.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in high water across FM 31 southeast of Marshall, Texas.
Several roads closed in Friendswood due to high water including 528 near near Interstate 45, the 17200 block of Blackhawk Road AT 528 and the 500 block of FM 518.
Heather Drive, Whitehead Drive, and Park Street in Granbury had to be closed due to high water.

A couple had to be rescued after driving into high water at the Spirit of the West Resort. Water from the lake at the resort was overflowing its banks due to heavy rainfall of 6-8 inches and flooding the surrounding roadways. The water was reported to be up to the headlights of the car. No one was injured, and the water began receding shortly after the rescue and was cleared by the next morning.

A car was swept off the road at a low water crossing on Salesville Road that was covered with about 2.5 feet of water. The woman driver was rescued from the middle of the raging creek by a local resident.  The road was barricaded after the incident. Local residents reported they had only seen the creek as high one other time.
A portion of FM 79 near Lake Cook was closed due to high water.
Flooding of roadways in Hunt County continued. Several roads in Greenville remained flooded and sections of HWY 380, FM 3211, FM 1565, and FM 36 had to be barricaded.
Water flooded several homes in the Liberty Eyleau community.  In addition, nearly 14 city streets were flooded in the community.
Flood waters from a swollen creek were entering a home on South Alabama Drive in Celina. Also in Celina, flooding was reported at Ash Street and South Ohio Drive.
A high water rescue was reported near Lake Pat Cleburne.
A high water rescue was ongoing on HWY 82, 2 miles west of Honey Grove.
A few roads south and west of McKinney were closed due to high water.
Water was reported over a few roadways near Aubrey and at the intersection of HWY 377 and FM 3524/Sherman Drive north of Aubrey.

Eight inches of water was reported over HWY 175, 1 mile north of Kaufman. Near Terrell, the water was a foot deep at HWY 34 and FM 2578. In Terrell, significant street flooding occurred with 3-4 feet of water reported on Catherine Street and Alamo Street, and High Street and Delthine. High water rescues were reported on Catherine Street. In the mid afternoon hours, it was reported that at least a dozen county roads had to be closed; including 4007, 4008, 4009, and 4011. The baseball field in Mabank and Optimist Park in Seven Points was under water.
FM 1565 near the intersection of SH 276 was under water and other county roads were also impassable during the heavy rain period.

Widespread flooding was reported around the county; especially north and west of Hillsboro where 10 county roads had to be closed. Near Whitney, CRs 1240, 1248, and 1258 were closed due to high water. FM 309 west of Woodbury was closed after Cottonwood Creek overflowed its banks. Whitney Creek also overflowed its banks, resulting in the evacuation of 30 residents in an apartment complex nearby. Another home along the creek had water in the house up to the top of the baseboards.
Mound Prairie Creek at SH 155 was out of its banks and flooding nearby pastures.
A man had to be rescued from a low water crossing on Riverside Trail that was still covered in water several hours after the rainfall had ended. The water was up to the bumper of his stranded truck.
Mother Neff State Park was closed for several days due to flooding of the park and its access roads.
Ongoing flooding of roads, creeks, and ditches continued across the county. Some roads remained closed through the late afternoon hours.

Ongoing flooding continued across the county from earlier heavy rainfall. The flooding damaged several roads and washed out culverts and headwalls of bridges. Several of the roads were going to need to be torn up and redone according to local officials.

Numerous county roads and low water crossings were flooded. Several barricades were used to close roads. Several gravel roads in the eastern parts of the county were washed away. It was also reported that parts of SHs 56 and 22 had to be closed down. A recently rebuilt bridge on CR 3125 over Neils Creek was flooded out. The bridge had just been replaced last year.
Significant flooding problems continued across the county with several roads and low water crossings impassable. A few parks in the city of Gatesville were closed due to flooding.

Two flooded bridges along the access road of Interstate 35 in Salado were reopened during the afternoon hours, but the South Ridge bridge and Chisholm Trail bridges in Mill Creek remained closed until the following morning when the water finally drained. The closure of these two bridges cut off residents' access through the subdivision.

Five bridges in Salado were closed for a few hours due to high water that covered each bridge with up to 3 feet of water. The South Ridge and Chisholm Trail bridges in Mill Creek, the Smith Bluff bridge east of Mill Creek, and two access road bridges along Interstate 35 were all closed down.
Some roads in Gun Barrel City were closed; including Blacklash Road, Harbor Point, Flag Lake Road, and Pritchard @ Jess Hinton Road.

Several roads around the county remained closed. Damage was sustained on several roads where the gravel was washed away or other erosion occurred. The water didn't drain off some roads that lie near creeks until later in the week.
High water was reported across Hwy. 59 in town.  In addition, one foot of water flooded the Westside Baptist Church in Atlanta, Texas.

Flooding continued along many creeks, rivers, and streams in the county; especially across the northern half of the county. In particular, heavy flooding was noted along the Mound Prairie Creek from near Elmtown to SH 155, and roads were impassable near the Trinity River in the eastern portions of the county.
Persistent rainfall resulted in the flooding of fields across the county. Some lesser traveled roads had water flowing over them, but no roads were closed.
Persistent rainfall pushed Bois d'Arc Creek out of banks by at least half a mile on each side. This flooded nearby pastures on each side of the creek.

Numerous city streets in Sulphur Springs were inundated and a few were barricaded. Highway 19 just north of Sulphur Springs was under water, and FM 1870 southeast of Sulphur Springs had high water over the road. FM 69 north of Interstate 30 had to be closed down because the water was a foot deep over a 100 feet section of the road. CR 4766 south of FM 71 was impassable but possibly because it lies near a swollen section of the South Sulphur River.
Vehicles were unable to pass on FM 269 at CR 3310 due to high water.

Numerous roads around the county were closed due to high water. It was reported that over 60 roads in the county had to be closed at some point during the day, and the majority of the closed roads were across the eastern half of the county. The water in some places was 2 feet deep over the road. The right lanes of northbound Interstate 35 south of Waxahachie were closed due to pavement damage from the heavy rainfall.
Numerous roads around the county were closed due to high water. Also, high water rescues were needed in Whitesboro on HWY 377.
Four feet of water was reported on Icehouse Road near Sabathaney in northeastern Parker County.

At first, a few rural roads in the county were closed due to high water; however as the rain continued, heavy flooding of creeks and farmland occurred causing problems on additional roads in the county.
Ongoing flooding continued across the county and in Terrell due to heavy rainfall earlier in the day. Several roads remained closed.
High water was reported in Grand Saline and high water rescues were ongoing.
High water was reported in Van and high water rescues were ongoing.

A few secondary roads in the county were flooded due to persistent rainfall over several hours. Buffalo Creek in the northern portion of the county overflowed its banks and flooded some county roads near the creek for a few days.
Several secondary roads north of Palestine were flooded due to persistent rainfall over several hours.
Several streets in Lampasas were closed due to high water.
Residual flooding of roads near Aubrey continued due to heavy rainfall earlier in the evening.

Several secondary roads were flooded across Navarro County from persistent rainfall over the county. It was also reported that creeks, streams, and ditches were overflowing their banks causing some flooding.
High water was reported on County Roads 1806, 2120 at 2102, and 1129 at 1110. The flooding was the result of persistent rainfall over the county for several hours.

Numerous low water crossings, FM roads, and county roads were impassable and barricaded. Flooding conditions were especially bad in Coryell City. Other reports included FM 1829 at Mound was closed and Hwy 236 at Mother Neff State Park was closed.

Creeks in Decordova were 3-5 feet out of their banks and flooding surrounding areas. At least 4 county roads were closed due to high water and several more low water crossing locations were barricaded. Just after midnight, a man had to be rescued from his truck after getting stuck at a low water crossing on Stroud Creek Avenue near Thorp Spring. The water was 2 feet deep in the low water crossing. The truck was swept into the raging Stroud Creek just moments after the man was rescued. The man was injured during the rescue.

Nearly two inches of rain fell at the Borger ASOS station located two miles north of Borger Texas between 1630 CST and 1800 CST. Local officials closed the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1551 and Texas State Highway 136 due to flooding. The accident occurred at about 1730 CST on Texas State Highway 136 north of Borger. One vehicle hydroplaned and collided with the other vehicle resulting in the deaths of two people.
Residual flooding continued across Kaufman County through the following day. Areas around a lake near Warsaw remained flooded and CRs 4011 and 1390 also remained closed.
Several roads were closed in the Styx area and in Arnold Hills in Seven Points. Also, CRs 2100 and 2138 south were closed.  Some of these roads were washed out.
Water entered three homes and the City Hall in Trenton.

The following roads in Hunt County were closed due to flash flooding: FM 2655 at the Middle Sulphur River, FM 272 two miles west of Celeste, FM 3211 between the 618 and 620 mile markers, FM 118 at the Sulphur River, and FM 1565 between SH 276 and the Hunt/Kaufman County Line.
High water was reported on County Road 752 near Lake Limestone.
High water was reported on County Road 456 west of the Navasota River. Other flooding was also reported along the Navasota River and some roads were covered in water.

In north Fort Worth, NE 28th Street at Decatur Avenue and Northside Drive at Cold Springs Road had to be closed due to cars stuck in both intersections. Water rescues were required on NE 28th Street.  The Fort Worth Police Department responded to approximately 33 high water rescue calls during the rain event. The city of Fort Worth also experienced sewer overflows when rainfall entered the city's sewer pipe lines and flooded the system.
Multiple roads in Watagua were closed due to high water.

Marshall Leigh Road at John Sanders Road in Karnack, Texas was closed due to high water.  Additional roads flooded and closed throughout the county include FM 134 between Jonesville and US Hwy. 80, the South Service Road at the 619 mile marker, Airlite Road two miles south of State Highway 154, FM 31 north of interstate Hwy. 20, Cargill Road 2 miles east of State Hwy. 59 and Magnolia Road one mile south of Interstate 20.
Upper Bay Road was closed due to flooding around the 18700.
A Lipan school bus got stuck in 3 feet of water at a low water crossing. The exact location of the incident is unknown.  No one was injured.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 2676 along with numerous low water crossings along State Highway 173 and County Road 462.
Portions of highwy 77 and 77A from Cuero to Yoakum were closed due to flooding.
Law Enforcement reported U.S. Highway 183 was closed from 9am until 11 am due to water over the road.
The county reported numerous roads on the northeast side closed including Weidner road at Schertz road.
Farm to market road 535 was closed due to high water between Rosanky and Smithville.
Austin Highway at Ira Lee Road was closed due to high water. There were numerous roads closed across northeast San Antonio at this time.
The state highway 111 east of Hochheim was closed due to flooding.
Highway 80 at FM 1117 was closed due to high water and flooding.
Bulverde Road at Classen Road was closed due to flooding.
The Guadalupe county sheriffs office reports over 30 road closures across the county due to water over the roadways.

Heavy rain caused flooding which closed several roads in San Antonio including Babcock Road at Hollyhock Road, Classen Road at Stahl Road, Encino Park Road at Southwell Road, Huebner Road at Southwell Road, and Lookout Road at Old O'Connor Road.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed numerous roads in and around Kingsland including FM 1431, FM 2545, County Road 309, and County Road 307.
Portions of Farm to Market road 1863 were closed due to flooding.
State highway 95 from Moulton to Yoakum was closed due to flooding.
The county roads department reported many roads closed around New Berlin due to high water.
County Road 465 near Santa Clara was closed due to flooding.  Other county roads were closed in the county including county roads 775, 539, and 467.
Law enforcement reported portions of FM 1447 were underwater due to flooding.
Emergency management reported a water rescue was ongoing on FM 535 between Smithville and Rosanky.
Emergency management reported several roads with high water including portions of FM 535, 812, and FM 20.  Some of these roads were closed due to the flooding.

Heavy rain caused numerous road closures in and around New Braunfels including Landa Street from Mission Drive to Walnut Avenue and South Business I35 from Seguin Avenue to Old McQueeney Road. Bulverde Road at the Cibolo Creek crossing at the Comal/Bexar County line was also closed in this time frame.
A large marina with about 40 boats attached broke loose in Lake Travis just above the confluence with the Pedernales River and was doing damage as it floated down  stream.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed Cave Lane and Danville Avenue in San Antonio.
Portion of Hwy. 49 was closed due to excessive heavy rainfall near Smithland, Texas.
The railroad overpass was closed at Hwy. 67 and at Hwy. 82 east and Broad Street.  Numerous secondary roads were also closed.
Several businesses were flooded on Michiel Street between Titus Street and US 271 in the city of Gilmer, Texas.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 1174 along with numerous low water crossings.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed 11th Street in Carrizo Springs.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed County Road 962 near Cypress Mill.
Heavy rain caused flooding which required a few evacuations of residents along Sandy Creek in Kingsland.
Heavy rain caused flooding of several roads in Crystal City with 8 inches of water covering roadways.
Numerous streets were flooded in the city of Paris. One person was rescued when a wrecker removed a stranded vehicle from high waters.
High water was reported on Interstate 30.

Repeated thunderstorm development and associated training across the far northern portions of Galveston County around the League City area produce flash flooding. Numerous roads were under water and several automobiles were flooded and abandoned.
High water rescues were performed with cars stalled along Cypresswood Drive from Highway 249 to Kuykendahl Road.

Ongoing flooding continued in southern Bell County and additional rainfall during this period kept much of the area flooded. The town of Salado remained flooded and several roads in the southern portions of the county remain closed due to high water.

Significant flooding continued across the southern and southwestern portions of Dallas County. Several roads remained closed. Also, the area north of Interstate 30 and south of the Trinity River in west Dallas remained flooded.

The Laredo Fire Department reported ten intersections closed in the city due to flash flooding, with several stranded motorists and high water rescues.  In addition, several residential homes scattered throughout the city were flooded.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall across the Weslaco and Mercedes areas September 22. The Emergency Manager for Weslaco reported the area near Texas and Business highway 83 had three feet of water due to the heavy rains which occurred during the afternoon.  He also reported four feet of water along the south side of Business Highway 83 from Oregon west to Westgate Drive. Other areas to the north of Business Highway 83 had widespread flooding with minor damages to some homes.

Localized flash flooding was reported in Temple. The intersection of First Street and south Loop 363 had to be closed and so did the eastbound access road of Loop 363 in front of Kings' Daughters Hospital.

Widespread flooding was reported in Rockdale. Numerous streets were closed and Highway 79 west of Rockdale was closed due to high water. High water was also reported in parts of Milano and Cameron. FM 1915 at Big Elm Creek and FM 486 at the Little River had to be closed. Other county roads that were closed at some point during this time were CRs 119, 120, 147, 203, 230, 335, 402, 405, 408, 412, and 414.

FM 1915 north of Buckholts from HWY 190 to FM 485 was closed because Bear Creek overflowed its banks and water was covering the roadway. Also, FM 487 at Donahue Creek and FM 486 at Little River south of Pettibone were closed due to water over the road.
Several roads in the county were closed due to high water.
Vehicles were stalled on Saturn Lane.

Residual flooding continued across the county. The waters washed away the gravel on some roads and these roads had to remain closed for several days until they could be fixed. This included CR 3150 off the lime plant road, CR 3310 between Valley Mills and Clifton, and CR 3512 near Cayote.
Overflowing creeks and ponds flooded nearby farmland in parts of the county.
Watercrest Road at Cody Poe Road and Little Nolan Road at Cunningham Road in Killeen had to be closed due to high water.

Locations and roadways near creeks and large bodies of water were flooded.  Locations along the Bosque River in the northwestern portions of the county experienced flooding problems due to the swollen river. The Eichelberger Crossing bridge over the Bosque River had to be closed. Some parks around Lake Waco were also closed due to overflow from the lake.
Farm to Market Road 3128 closed due to high water.
FM 2262 and FM 357 closed due to water over the roadways.

CR 4011 and 1390 were closed off due to high water. Also, a small lake near Warsaw overflowed its banks flooding the surrounding roads, neighborhoods and pastures. This resulted in the closing of FM 148.
Water was over the road on parts of FM 46 south, FM 50, and HWY 6 south of Hearne. TxDOT was installing barricades.
High water in apartments.
Water was reported in homes in the Bear Creek Village subdivision.
Numerous roads and intersections blocked due to high water, including the intersection of FM 1488 and FM 2978, the FM 1488 at Interstate 45, and Interstate 45 at Shepherd Hill.
TxDOT was forced to close portions of a few roadways for a few days due to high water: FM 1915 and Big Elm Creek and at the Little River, FM 437 at Donahue Creek, and FM 486 at the Little River.
Roads were closed around Axtell due to water over the roads.
Mother Neff State Park was closed for four days to flooding. Its access roads (SH 236 and CR 338) were also flooded.
CRs 142, 185, 247, 260, and 303 were closed due to high water.
An earthen dam failed on Victory Lake near the intersection of Hwy .37 and CR 2330.  Three homes had to be evacuated due to the flood waters.
A man had to be rescued from his car off NE 1030 near Rice after it got stuck in a low water crossing. The water was reported to be knee deep or approximately 1.5 feet deep.
Multiple roads in Greenville were flooded. On Stonewall Street, the water was reported to be 2-3 feet deep.
TXDot closed FM 1565 between SH 276 and the Kaufman County line and FM 36 between FM 1564 and SH 276.

A car got stuck in a low water crossing at Wildflower Country Club in Temple, and the driver had to be rescued. The water was up to the bumper of the sedan. Also in Temple, several manholes in the Bird Creek area were overflowing from the excessive amount of rain.
Residual flooding of County Roads and numerous roads in the city of Rockdale continued until the late evening hours. Many roads remains closed throughout the day.
Roads were closed in the Spring Lake area due to water over the roads.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported dirt, debris and water over Ranch Road 618.
Sheriffs office reported County Road 4250 had to be closed due to flooding.

A woman was killed while trying to cross a low water crossing.  Karen Eichelberger, age 47, was driving home after working in Austin this Wednesday night.  She tried to cross the flooded low water crossing on Deer Springs Drive in her neighborhood when her 1994 Jeep was apparently forced off the road and into the creek.  Her body was found one half mile downstream from where the Jeep was located.
A vehicle was reported submerged within the city limits in Andrews.  Roads on the northwest and northeast side of the city also had 1 foot of flowing water over them.
The Azle Police Department closed the intersection of HWY 199 and Boyd Rd/FM 730 due to high water. High water rescues were also taking place at this intersection.
FM 1713 near Whitney was closed due to high water.
Some roads in Harker Heights were barricaded due to high water.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 108 due to high water across the road.
There were 15 campers rescued from rising water in the Pecos River Gorge.
Water was over the road between Joshua and Cleburne.
County Road 455 was closed due to high water.

Slow moving thunderstorms dropped heavy rain in eastern El Paso County which resulted and flooding across mainly east El Paso and Socorro. Four houses were flooded and 13 evacuated, most of them in Socorro. In addition, there were 9 water rescues across the area.
Several roads across the northern portions of Lampasas County remained under water from heavy rainfall that occurred earlier in the day.
Heavy rainfall caused flooding along Walnut Creek Drive; likely the result of the nearby creek overflowing its banks.

Flooding continued across the county with several roads impassable. Near Burleson, flooding of creeks and farmland continued. High water rescues were also reported in Lillian; including one at the intersection of CR 528 and CR 526.
Several streets flooded in LaPorte. Portions of Farrington and Broadway not  passable.
Heavy rainfall resulted in high water on County Road 506. The road was left impassable until 9 am.
High water was reported across FM 1277 just west of town.
Street flooding was reported in Crystal City.
High water from an isolated slow moving thunderstorm closed both access roads and several mainlanes of Interstate 45 North at Spring-Stuebner Road.
A local gas station reported flooding across McCamey, TX.  The water was high enough to move into both the middle school and elementary school.
Highway 238 was closed due to high water over a bridge crossing. Flooding of this road, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.
Between 2 and 4 inches of rain from Tropical Depression Two produced widespread flooding of secondary County and Farm to Market roads throughout San Patricio County.
A car was apparently swept off the road during the middle of the night and later recovered in Cibolo Creek.  The man driving the car was found dead inside the vehicle.

Water was reported over the road on FM 796, between FM 888 and SH 359. Water was reported over the road on FM 1349, from U.S. 59 to FM 797. FM 796 at CR 533 was closed due to flooding. Flooding of these roads, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.
Water was reported over FM 1930, between U.S. 281 and FM 1352. Flooding of this road, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.
SH 188 was closed from Interstate 37 to FM 796 due to low water crossing flooded. Flooding of this roads, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.

Widespread lowland flooding of fields, creeks and rural country and farm to market roads was observed across Nueces County. SH 286 was closed between FM 2444 and FM 70 due to flooding, particularly between CR 12 and CR14. Flooding occurred at FM 2292 and Leopard Street. Flooding occurred on SH 44, from Business 44 to FM 1889. Water was reported over SH 361 at various locations inside the Port Aransas city limits. Water was over SH 357, just west of the La Jolla Creek bridge. Flooding was reported on FM 763, between FM 665 and FM 0043. Water was reported over FM 2826, between CR 85 and CR 87. Water was reported over FM 2292, between McGloin St. and FM 665. Several roads in the city of Bishop were reported flooded. North and southbound feeder roads on U.S. 77 were closed, between CR 44 and Terry Shemise Blvd, due to flooding. FM 70 was closed at FM 624 due to flooding. Flooding of these roads, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.

Water was reported over the southbound lane of Business 35L near Stapp St. Water was reported over FM 1781, near FM 1069. Water was reported over FM 1069 at various locations between 1069 and SH 188. Flooding of these roads, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.
Hwy. 69 north was closed just north of Loop 323 and it remained closed to all north-bound and south -bound traffic.

The following city streets were closed from excessive heavy rainfall.  East Gentry Parkway and Duncan Street, Bellwood Street, East Erwin Street, Old Gladewater, Loop 323 and Texas College Road, West Erwin Street, Shaw and Chilton, Bonner Street underpass, Broadway and Spring Street, Douglas at Front, Idle at Fleishel, Noble, Houston, Hurt, Walton at Reinheart and Bonner at Locust street.
A bridge was washed out near the East Mountain community.
Numerous roads were flooded and closed throughout the county.
County Road 4807 was closed due to flooding.

Several roads throughout the county were closed and flooded including 155 at Noonday, a culvert was washed out on FM 2661, FM 2330, Smith County Road 1295 as well as numerous County Roads including 1113, 1141, 1130, 1143, 1134, 1295, 1131, 1105, and the intersection of 1227 and 1141.

Excessive heavy rainfall helped to erode an earthen dam for the 45 acre Lost Pines Lake.  One to two feet of water was spilling over the dam along CR. 1134.  CR 1130 off of Lake Placid Road was underwater with the water being so swift, emergency crews were having difficulty getting to the scene.
Numerous roads remain flooded and closed throughout Smith County.
Several streets in downtown Tyler experienced flooding resulting in road closures.
Water was 3 foot deep running across the junction of FM. 344 and FM. 155.
A woman rescued herself and her baby when she drove her vehicle into a flooded intersection at Chilton Avenue and Shaw Street.

Between 1 and 3 inches fell within one hour, causing wide-spread flash flooding of city streets in Kingsville.  King Avenue and 14th streets were completely flooded.  Several manhole covers came off causing sewage to flow into city streets.  Flash flooding along Tranquitas Creek made 14th and 17th streets impassable.

Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell within 2 hours over the city of Laredo, producing flash flooding.  Several city streets were flooded.  Closures occurred at Springfield and Hillside, as well as Mann Road at Interstate 35 where a vehicle became stranded.
KINT Television reported the intersection at Gateway West and Airway was flooded and a motorist needed to be rescued. An apartment was also flooded in the San Mateo Apartments on Viscount Boulevard.
Hwy. 135 near the intersection of Hwy. 271 in the southwest portion of Gladewater, Texas was flooded.  Many of the side streets off of Hwy. 135 and 271 were flooded and closed as well.
Lafamo Road between Whatley Road and Tenneryville Road was closed due to high water.
Cars were stalled and flooded at the intersection of Robertson and Sunnybrook Drive in Tyler, Texas.
Numerous roads were flooded and closed throughout the county.  Water entered a number of homes throughout the county as well.  Several bridges were washed out.
U.S. Hwy. 67 was under one foot of water in front of the radio station west of Mount Pleasant, Texas.
Excessive heavy rainfall opened up a sinkhole along County Road 1130 that was nearly 20 foot deep.  A vehicle was seen lodged halfway inside the sinkhole.  Thee was in injury reported at the scene.
Hwy. 80 at Cotton Street was closed due to high water.
The Naples Police Department was flooded.  Numerous roads were closed across the northern portion of the county.
There were a total of 17 swift water rescues across Smith County including one on Hwy. 155 where a motorists tried to drive across the flooded roadway.
A woman was rescued from floodwaters after her vehicle stalled on Glenwood Road southeast of Gilmer, Texas.  Numerous roads remained flooded and closed throughout the afternoon.

Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell with 2 hours producing flash flooding in Premont. Flowing water with depths of 6 to 18 inches was reported on many streets. Cars were stalled at U.S. 281 and 3rd Street.
County Road 4910 near the Mixon community was closed due to high water.
Numerous roads were closed in Smith County.  Since 745 am, at least 10 high water rescues were reported throughout the county.
Spur 364 near the loop in Tyler, Texas was underwater.
County Road 4807 was closed due to flooding.
Rushing flood waters damaged yards, homes and roadways in and around the Azalea District in Tyler, Texas.
Water flooded a home on Pioneer Road or on Smith County Road 1156.  The water was nearly 2 feet high in the home.
Hwy. 69 north was closed just north of Loop 323 and it remained closed to all north-bound and south-bound traffic through early evening.
Several roads were under high water in the town of Mount Vernon, Texas.  Other county roads were flooded and closed as well.

High and fast flowing waters continued through the North Floodway in extreme southeastern Willacy County well into August, as water continued to flow through the Anzalduas (Hidalgo County) Diversion Dam into the Lower Rio Grande Flood Control Project (floodways/levee system).||These floodways, protected by a robust system of levees and gates, protected communities outside of the levees by containing up to 50%, or 4 to 8 to feet, of fast flowing water, within them.  ||The North Floodway finally drained to mud toward the end of the month.  The end date of the high water is a best estimate.  In Willacy County, there were no reports of structural damage.  However, FM 507 and FM 1420, as well as several paved and unpaved county roads, were closed at low water crossings inside the levee.  Earlier in July, a leaky levee valve required pumping water away from homes just east of FM 1420 immediately north of the Levee Road near Santa Monica. ||Crops may have been destroyed by the flood along North Floodway, but damage in the Willacy County portion was unknown as of this writing.  Infrastructure damage to roads and low water bridges may have exceeded [$x] thousand in southeastern Willacy County.  Note: The dollar damage for this portion of the flood is included with the July report.

River flooding continued into the first third of August across the initial section of the Lower Rio Grande Valley Flood Control Project, which includes improved levees between Penitas and the Anzalduas Diversion Dam southwest of Granjeno. While the levees protected most property behind them, a number of structures built inside the levees suffered significant and costly water damage, from Penitas to south of Granjeno.||The structures included the popular river front Chimney Park RV Resort, which had more than 3 feet of water cover half of the land and property; Pepe's on the River Bar and Grill and the Riverside Club, favorite haunts for Winter Texans and local residents alike which provide river views but unfortunately were covered by feet of mud after the flood waters subsided in August.  Some crop may have been destroyed by the flood, but damage was unknown as of this writing in this area.  Property damage may have exceeded [$5] million in these areas alone.  Note:  Damage estimates for this portion of the flood area are listed in the July report.

High and fast flowing waters continued through the North Floodway in extreme northwest Cameron County well into August, as water continued to flow through the Anzalduas (Hidalgo County) Diversion Dam into the Lower Rio Grande Flood Control Project (floodways/levee system).||These floodways, protected by a robust system of levees and gates, protected communities outside of the levees by containing up to 50%, or 4 to 8 to feet, of fast flowing water, within them.  In Cameron County, there were no reports of structural damage as the North Floodway tracks in largely uninhabited country.  However, several paved and unpaved roads were flooded inside the levees, including the Federal Highway 77 (Expressway) frontage road (the Expressway was well above the water level), County Road 506, and FM 1425 (along the Cameron/Hidalgo County line).||The North Floodway finally drained to mud toward the end of the month.  The end date of the high water is a best estimate. ||Crops may have been destroyed by the flood along North Floodways, but damage in northwest Cameron County was unknown as of this writing.  Infrastructure damage to roads and low water bridges may have exceeded [$x] thousand in northwestern Cameron County.  Note:  The dollar damage estimate is listed with the July report.

Though the heavy rains had long since passed, and most days were dry from late July into much of August, release rates from dams and reservoirs across northeast Mexico tributaries flowing into the Rio Grande, as well as along the Rio Grande itself, continued at high levels into early August.||All of this water would continue impact hundreds of structures during the event.  The city of La Grulla remained under a voluntary evacuation into early August as waters began to recede slowly. As a precautionary measure in the city of Roma, three small subdivisions located in the low lying areas and along the bank just south of the Port of Entry were placed under mandatory evacuation. These included De La Cruz sub-division about (20 to 25 homes), Campo Verde (4 homes), and Garza sub-division (1 home). The flooding in Starr County had impacted at least 178 homes/businesses, including 65 in La Grulla and 39 in Roma.  166 families required temporary housing.  Preliminary damages to highways and bridges in Starr County was at $19 million; preliminary public and private property estimates were listed at an additional $18 million.  Agricultural damage was also notable in flooded areas.  Note: Since the bulk of the flood related damages occurred in July, dollar estimates are listed with the July report. [Data will be available later in September].

River flooding continued into the first third of August based on upstream gaging information in Starr County. Affected communities included Cuevitas, Havana, and the south portions of La Joya and Penitas - locations not protected by the Lower Rio Grande Valley Flood Control Project levee system. The city of Los Ebanos, surrounded on three sides by the river, was most impacted by the flood, which was well over a mile wide for several weeks.  Major flooding continued into the first days of August - most likely August 4th.||Voluntary evacuations continued in the area between Cuevitas and Penitas into early August; conditions improved by the 10th as the river returned to its banks.  At that point, the cleanup of mud caked mud filled structures and roadways began - these efforts would continue into September.||In all, hundreds of structures, as well as paved and unpaved roads, were damaged significantly by the long duration flood. Most of these were in Los Ebanos, but others were along or south of Military Highway between Cuevitas and the south portion of Penitas. Five homes were evacuated near Military Road in Havana where the river flooded them.  Damage to property was estimated to be $[xx] million, with additional [unknown] damage to crops in southwestern Hidalgo County estimated at $ [yy] thousand/million.  Note:  Damage estimates are included with the July report, based on the direct causative impacts from the deepest, widest, and fastest flows.
The local law enforcement reported 3.5 to 4 feet of standing water along US 385, 24 miles south of Fort Stockton.  Several cars were stranded due to the high water.
Law enforcement closed a bridge due to high water in Rooney Park.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and closed Perrin Beitel Road at Vicar Drive.
A flood wave resulting from heavy rain on the 16th and 17th impacted Petronilla Creek.  FM 2826 was closed between FM 666 and U.S. 77 due to flooding along the creek.
Between 4 and 6 inches of rain fell producing flash flooding near CR 308 and CR 306, east of Tilden.  Water was reported flowing over the road near this intersection.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded and closed McGregor Lane.
CoCoRaHS observer reported 2.73 inches of rain fell in only 45 minutes.  Water was reported flowing over the road at FM 666 and FM 3088.

Pendleton Park and City Park in Harlingen was under water. One lane of North Farm to Market Loop 499 was closed. Local newspapers reported water surging through city streets between 6 and 7 PM. Power was knocked out at Valley International Airport from 7 until around 830 PM from unknown causes related to the storm.  A daily record of 2.77 inches of rain fell in a very short time at Valley International Airport; radar estimates suggested 3 to 4 inches fell in areas which flooded.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded and closed several low water crossings.

The Chief of Police in the City of Zapata reported one and one half feet of water was flowing on Alamo St. and State Highway 16. The arroyo at Highway 16 and Carla Street overflowed its banks, with one and one half feet of water flowing over the road there as well. Heavy creek and arroyo flooding was also reported at the Manuel Medina Addition colonia, south of Zapata County Airport.
FM 1930 flooded in 3 places, with up to 1 foot of water flowing over the road.

Several spots along HWY 16, between Freer and Hebbronville, were flooded, including 3 feet of flowing water over HWY 16 roughly 18 miles south of Freer.  Highway 16 was closed for much of the night.  In addition, flooding was reported along FM 2295, between Benavides and HWY 16, and it was also closed.
FM 1596 closed between CR 311 and 332 due to flash flooding of Gamble Gully Creek.
Heavy rain produced flash flooding of several County and Farm to Market Roads near Lagarto.  Six inches of flowing water was reported covering CR 175, FM 534, and FM 3162.

Excess runoff from heavy rainfall the day before led to flooding of Macho Creek near Realitos.  Also, the Agua Pocquita Creek flooded, forcing the closure of FM 2295, between Benavides and Highway 16.  One resident had to be rescued by helicopter from a racnh home on FM 2295.  Many residents were evacuated from there homes in and around Realitos.  Several rural homes were reported flooded.  Damage estimated are very rough.
Rainfall total of 1.32 inches reported at the University of Texas-El Paso Centennial Museum in an hour and a half. Flash flooding was reported on the campus by a university professor.
One foot of moving water was observed at the intersection of Trans Mountain and Rushing Roads in Northeast El Paso.

Victoria Fire Department responded to stalled vehicles in high water across the city, including a high water rescue of a driver trapped on Lova Drive.  Three cars were stalled in high water on Ben Jordan Street, and the road between Houston Highway and Airline was closed due to flooding.  An additional three vehicles were stalled in high water at North Main Street and Loop 463.

Widespread urban and poor drainage flooding affected an area from Mercedes and Weslaco northwest to Edinburg, likely including known flood problem areas in Elsa, Edcouch, La Villa, and other places where drainage remained an issue nearly two years after Dolly. The flooding began toward sunset after more persistent heavy rains arrived in the area, and continued into the very early morning hours of July 1st (see June report for start times).  Much of the flash flooding, where water reached 3 feet or higher or threatened structures, occurred in these typically poor drainage locations in all areas.  ||Total rainfall for the entire event ranged from 8 to near 10 inches in the areas that tended to flood, with an estimated 4 to 7 inches occurring during and just prior to the significant flood impacts.  Damage from freshwater flooding directly due to Alex was unknown as of this writing. The primary estimate is shown in the June report.

Widespread urban flooding affected an area from west of Brownsville through Brownsville, Olmito, Los Fresnos, and near Bayview during the afternoon and into the very early morning hours of July 1st (see June report for starting time of event).  Much of the flash flooding, where water reached 3 feet or higher or threatened structures, occurred in typically poor drainage locations in all areas.  ||Total rainfall for the entire event ranged from 8 to near 10 inches in the areas that tended to flood, with an estimated 5 to 7 inches occurring during and just prior to the significant flood impacts.  Damage from freshwater flooding directly due to Alex was unknown as of this writing. For the July data, only a very small value is included, as the primary flood impacting rains fell on June 30th.
U.S. 281 was closed from FM 624 to 1 mile north of that location due to water flowing over the roadway.
Heavy rainfall led to FM 534 being flooded in several spots with several inches of moving water, near the Arrowhead community.

Between 4 and 7 inches of rain fell producing widespread flash flooding in the Skidmore and Tynan areas.  Flowing water was over the road at the intersection of Hwy 181 and Hwy 359 in Skidmore.  Water was also over the road at Hwy 359, between Skidmore and Tynan.  Water was flowing over Hwy 181, between Skidmore and Papalote, where some motorists were stranded with water up to the doors on vehicles.  FM 796 was closed from FM 359 in Tynan to US 59 due to high water.  One high water rescue was performed on FM 796.  Water was also reported flowing over the road on Hudson Marshall Rd., 2 miles north of Skidmore.
Several inches of flowing water was reported at a low water crossing on Briggs Blvd.  Minor flooding of roadways was reported elsewhere through the city.
Flowing water once again covering the road at Hwy 72 near the prison.
Water was reported flowing of CR 44, just west of Robstown.  The flowing water was up to a foot deep in some areas.
Flowing water was reported across FM 188 and FM 630, near the CR 35 intersections.

A flood wave from previous rainfall on the 16th and 17th, continued down Banquette Creek.  A driver tried to cross the flooded roadway at the creek near CR 38 and CR 83 and lost control of the vehicle.  All four passengers were able to abandon the vehicle to safety.
A park ranger reported a 3 foot boulder was blocking SH 54 due to high flowing water.  Low water crossings were also impassable.
Flowing water was reported over Hwy 72 at Park Road 8, south of Calliham, and also along Hwy 72 near the prison entrance.
Heavy rainfall produced several feet of water over the Mann Road and San Dario Avenue intersection, forcing its closure.
Hudspeth County Herald reported one to two inches of rain fell quickly in Dell City causing the city's roads to become flooded.
FM 1069 from State Highway 188 to Business 35 is closed due to high water.
Street flooding in Beeville with some roads closed including Adams Street and Tyler Street. Average reports of 4 to 6 inches of water in some places.

A trained spotter reported that several vehicles had stalled on the north side of Canyon with water up to the doors. The trained spotter also reported that there was two to three feet of water over some roads. No injuries were reported.
High water was reported over Hwy. 69 near the Huntington, Texas community.
The swollen Petronila Creek generated 4 feet of water over County Road 18 between CR 73 and 73B.
Roads flooded and impassible around the Rockport High School area. Some vehicles needed assistance getting out of the flooded roadways.
Water over the road on State Highway 44 near San Diego.
Frontage road along Highway 44 about 3 miles west of the Corpus Christi International Airport impassable due to high water. Some of the homes on the north side of the highway were flooded.
Road closed due to high water on FM 665 from FM 2292 to FM 763. The frontage road on US Highway 77 closed between County Roads 44 and 48.
FM 1360 closed southeast of Woodsboro due to flooding.
High water closed FM 629 from FM 136 to FM 3037 southeast of Woodsboro.
FM 796 closed due to high water from FM 888 to State Highway 359.
FM 1717 east of Highway 77 closed along the intersection with Escondido Creek.
Great Lakes Drive in the Lakes subdivision residential area on the south side of Corpus Christi completely covered with water.
Water over the roadways of FM 774 and Highway 35 along Artesian Creek.

The broadcast media and the Amarillo Emergency Operations Center reported that Interstate 27 was closed from Georgia Street to Hillside Road due to numerous stranded motorists in high water. Also, numerous high water rescues were performed all across central and southern Amarillo. No injuries were reported, however numerous vehicles were damaged due to the flash flooding.
KBMT-TV reported S MLK Jr. Parkway was closed around Lamar University due to underpass flooding.
Numerous streets were flooded in the city of Breckenridge after 3 to 4 inches of rain fell in 2 to 3 hours.
Area roads around St. Mary's Street, Vietnam Street and St. Joseph's street were impassable due to flooding.
Roads were barricaded around Sulphur Creek due to a rapid rise in water.
Numerous roads throughout the county remained closed due to flooding well after the heavy rain had ended.
Numerous roads in the northern and eastern parts of the county remained closed due to flooding well after the heavy rain had ended.
Several county roads throughout the county were covered with water. County Road 243 was closed east of the city of Kaufman.
Several roads throughout the county were covered with water or closed. This included Farm-to-Market roads 36, 118, 2655, and 3211.

Numerous county roads and city streets were closed due to high water. A culvert on Plum Creek, north of the town of Purmela, was washed out. Most low water crossings in the county were also closed due to the flooding.
A motorist got her vehicle stuck in high water on CR 4754 and the vehicle had to be removed by a wrecker.

Between 5 and 8 inches of rain from Hurricane Alex left several flooded County and Farm to Market roadways across San Patricio county for a few days after the event.  An elderly couple's vehicle stalled in flood waters near CR 696 & CR 1441.  The couple abandoned their vehicle, and swept into floodwaters and drowned.

Due to persistent rainfall of 1-2 over the county, some low lying areas flooded nearby roads. Most of the closed roads were reported in Precinct 2 which covers the southeast quadrant of the county. Closed roads included: CR 2310 at CR 3343, parts of CR 2336, CR 2408, and the south side service road of Interstate 30 at mile marker 134.  CR 2408 was washed out and would likely be closed for longer. Most of these roads remained closed through the morning hours of February 5th.

East and westbound lanes of SH 359 was reported with standing water over the roadway from Skidmore to Tynan. Standing water was reported over the north and southbound lanes of U.S. 181 from Skidmore to San Patricio. FM 1349 was closed from FM 797 to U.S. 59 due to water over both the north and southbound lanes. Flooding of these roads, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.
Flooding from the very heavy rain was reported in Hamby.

Flood waters swept a truck off FM 1340 resulting in a fatality.  A local resident of Hunt was headed home from a local school board meeting when he tried to cross a low water crossing. By the time rescuers responded he was apparently swept downstream and drowned.  His body was discovered several days later about a mile downstream at another low water crossing.

Flooding of the Lower Rio Grande Valley Flood Control Project floodway/levee system (spillway), which includes the Banker Floodway (from near Granjeno to just south of Pharr), the Main Floodway (from just south of Pharr to the split at the Arroyo Colorado just southwest of Mercedes, the Arroyo Colorado itself, and the North Floodway, (which extends from near Mercedes to near La Villa before curving east to northwest Cameron County), continued through a good portion of August, as water continued to be diverted through Anzalduas for several days beyond the time that water was receding upstream of the dam.  Continuing water diversion helps reduce the potential for backwater flooding along the improved levee section (Penitas to Anzalduas) as well as unprotected shorelines west of Penitas.  At the same time, the diversion maintained several feet of water in the floodways for days to come which receded more slowly.  The floodway emptied out for the most part by August 15th, but local high water hazards continued through at least the 18th.   ||These floodways, protected by a robust system of levees and gates, protected communities outside of the levees by containing up to 50%, or 4 to 8 to feet of fast flowing water, within them into the first third of August.  Unfortunately, a number of residences, dozens of paved and unpaved roads with low water bridges, and some agriculture are located within  the floodways; significant damage was noted in several locations.  Pumping and plugging operations near Weslaco and La Villa successfully kept high water out of poor drainage locations where the potential for freshwater flooding due to heavy rains would have been exacerbated with periodic thunderstorms, which did not materialize in August.  Closed roads included  FM 493 and FM 1015, each moderately traveled; at least five homes were flooded along the Main Floodway south of Pharr along I Road; 15 to 20 homes were asked to voluntarily evacuate, and at least two other residences were flooded south of Weslaco near FM 88. Floodwaters also submerged portions of the Llano Grande golf course in Mercedes. ||Voluntary evacuations were finally lifted along I Road (Capote Farms subdivision) on August 18th at 6 PM CST, where the 15 to 20 homes mentioned above were located.  Wet, muddy conditions continued in these areas until the last week of August; damage assessments began on roadways and bridges impacted in the floodway after the waters finally receded.  In all, the floodways contained water for more than 6 weeks.||High flowing water along the river covered a large portion of the Lower Rio Grande Valley National Wildlife Refuge (Santa Ana) south and southeast of Pharr, including a number of unpaved roads.  Damage to the roads was unknown at this time; the flooding occurred downstream of the Anzalduas Diversion Dam; river gages downstream at San Benito and Brownsville remained in action stage.  Floodwaters did not reach public or private structures, nor roadways, between the Refuge and the Main Floodway.  The water finally receded back to muddy pockets sometime between August 27th and 28th.||There was one reported fatality in early August; a man drowned after reportedly driving his vehicle accidentally into the fast flowing waters of the floodway late on August 1st or early on August 2nd. His body was found along the south side of the Main Floodway, near S. Jackson and W. Juan Balli Road just west of Pharr.  ||Several crops may have been destroyed by the flood along the Main and North Floodways, but damage was unknown as of this writing in this area.  Property and infrastructure damage may have exceeded [$10] million in these areas.  Note:  Dollar damage estimated for the flooding are provided in the July report.

Low water crossings were flooded with water over the roadway along FM 1360. FM 629 was closed from FM 3037 and FM 136 due to water over the road. Flooding of these roads, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.

Water was reported standing over the roadway one mile north of the U.S. 281 and FM 624 intersection. Flooding of this road, creeks, and lowland fields were observed several hours after the heavy rainfall had ended.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced heavy rain and flooding which closed Hwy 470 between Tarpley and Hwy 187.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced heavy rain and flooding which closed Hwy 187 south of Vanderpool.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced heavy rain and flooding which closed FM 1340 along the upper Guadalupe River west of Hunt.
Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flooding closing some rural roads around Pearsall.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused flooding north and east of Luling. On FM 1322, Plum Creek Bridge and the intersection with McNeil Road were closed and County Road 129 was completely flooded.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded intersections in Del Rio with several motorists stranded in their cars.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused flooding and closed the intersection of County Roads 158 and 159.
Heavy rainfall near the San Antonio International Airport caused street flooding on Country Club Lane.
Water was at least 8 inches deep and flowing over curbs at the Longview Mall in north Longview, Texas.

At 1520 pm CST, the Howard County Emergency Manager reported flash flooding in and around Big Spring, TX.  Fifty-five gallon drums were floating down roadways and several motorists were stranded in vehicles submerged under water.
More than 6 inches of flowing water was present across several low water crossings along Route 16 from Castolon to Santa Elena Canyon.  There was no significant damage reported.
Six to eight inches of flowing water covered the intersection of Interstate 20 and County Road 1140.  There were no reports of damage.

Torrential rainfall of 4-8 inches fell led to widespread flash flooding in northern and northwest Jim Wells county.  In particular, A flood wave developed on the Agua Dulce Creek, west of Orange Grove, and traveled downstream through Jim Wells County and into Nueces county.  Several County Roads became impassable along the creek.  One vehicle was swept into the creek near CR 239 and CR 308, with all three passengers rescued by a Coast Guard helicopter.  Another resident who was trapped in their home was rescued by a Coast Guard helicopter.  The flood wave destroyed one mobile home in Jim Wells county.  In addition flooding of roadways occurred in Orange Grove, and several homes were reported to have water in them.  FM 624 was closed in Orange Grove due to 1 foot of flowing water over the road.  Also water was reported over CR 307, northwest of Orange Grove, making it impassable.||WATER COVERING COUNTY ROAD 307 NORTHWEST OF ORANGE GROVE. THE ROAD IS BECOMING IMPASSIBLE.

The county sheriff reported that 23 barricades were set up on various roads around the county due to flooding from persistent steady rainfall across the county. At one intesection in Acton the water was 8-10 inches deep. Rainfall totals averaged 3-3.5 across the county but were reported as high as 5 inches in the northern portions of the county. Most of the water had receded within a few hours. Some damage to the road surface on Paluxy Highway near Neri Road occurred.

Heavy rain caused flooding which closed several roads in Atascosa county. FM 2146 was closed between FM 476 and Highway 173. FM 1470 was closed near Galvan Creek. FM 1333 was closed where it crossed the Atascosa River. FM 536 was closed between US 281 and IH 37. FM 140 was closed between US 281A and Texas Highway 16.
City officials reported flooding along with some road closures around Throckmorton.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced heavy rain and flooding which washed a vehicle off Hwy 39 southwest of Hunt. A family was rescued from their van which was washed off the road.
Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded intersections in Del Rio stranding several cars.

Rainfall totals over 6 over the weekend resulted in Lake Graham overflowing its banks and flooding the nearby land. Also, flooding along the Brazos River backed up into area creeks and streams resulting in widespread flooding around the county. A high water rescue of three teenagers was performed on April 18th around 4 pm CDT when rising flood waters pushed their car off Power Plant Road in Graham. Another vehicle nearly got stuck in this same area. Rising waters also flooded Graham Bible Church where several inches of water was found inside the building, and the water in the parking lot was almost waist deep. Fireman's Park in Graham was under water. Several major roadways were closed on the 18th due to high water: HWY 380 West at Elm Creek, HWY 61 near Spivey Hill, HWY 16 north at the Archer Co line, and HWY 578. All roads were re-opened by the morning of the 19th.
Water was flowing over Smith Road at least 6 inches deep and rising.

Thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall trained for much of the night across northern McMullen county, dumping up to 10-15 inches of rainfall and producing widespread flash flooding.  Highways 16, 72, and 99 were all closed near Tilden due to flooded roads.  A portion of FM 3445 was washed out and a vehicle swept into the high water.  A successful high water rescue was performed.
Heavy rainfall caused flooding at the intersection of Loop 1604 and Stone Oak Parkway.
Heavy rainfall caused local street flooding in the Stone Oak section of San Antonio.
Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flooding which closed FM 1407 and FM 1557 in Carrizo Springs.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced heavy rain and flooding which closed FM 471, County Road 482, and County Road 584 in and near La Coste.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused flooding stranding cars along Ingram and Marbach Roads.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed FM 536 from Highway 281 to IH37.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed the intersection of County Roads 2615 and 371.
Heavy rain caused flooding which closed part of Texas Highway 581.

Slow moving thunderstorms through much of the night produced widespread flash flooding in and around Three Rivers.  Between 8 and 12 inches of rain fell.  Many city streets were flooded in Three Rivers, with as much as 2-3 feet of water stranding motorists.  Eight homes were flooded on Hwy 72 in town.  East and west bound lanes of Hwy 72 at I-37 were flooded and impassable.  Schools were closed in Three Rivers for the day.

Heavy rainfall produced flash flooding of roadways in and around Beeville.  FM 799 just east of La Para Rd. had 1-2 feet of flowing water over the road.  U.S. 181 Business north of Beeville also had flowing water over the road.  Many low-lying city streets were closed in Beeville due to flooding.
A canal was over its banks at the Mineral Wells Golf Course and there was 3 to 4 inches of water on the roadways that surrounded the canal.
A high water rescue was reported by the broadcast media near the intersection of FM1936 and I-20.
Local law enforcement reported cars were stalled at the intersection of 42nd and Dixie in Odessa, TX.  The water was up to car door handles.
Local law enforcement reported high water at the intersection of Andrews Highway and Illinois St.  Large construction barrels were seen floating down the road.

Street flooding in the city of Victoria was widespread, as approximately 8 inches fell over parts of Victoria over 24hrs, including approximately 4.5 inches within a 2 hour span.  This led to widespread flooding over approximately 25-35% of the citys streets, and an unknown but significant number of county roads.  All told, approximately 160+ residences were flooded (almost all to a minimal degree).  Additionally, a number of dwellings and vehicles suffered minor damage from falling trees or limbs.  However, due to the rapidity in which most of the flood waters receded, Victoria was spared catastrophic loss to residential and business infrastructure.  There was damage sustained to governmental infrastructure: Damage was done to the Victoria County Sheriffs Office Communications Center when rainwater inundated a portion of the first floor.  Damage was sustained to multiple City and County vehicles.  A water-main was damaged and required expedient repair.  A storm-water/drainage outfall was damaged by floodwater and will require repair.

Water was over roadways at several intersections in southern Montague County. This was all due to Old Bowie Lake running over the spill way and Briar and Brushy Creeks running over their banks as heavy rain fell over the region. Some of the intersections included West RC Road and Highway 81, Farm-to-Market Road 1125 and Turkey Creek Road, and Jordan Lane and Farm-to-Market Road 3043.
A few roads were briefly closed in the city of Bowie due to high water. One car was stranded at the Mill Street underpass.
Significant flash flooding occurred throughout the county and several roads had to be closed. Parts of Highway 59 had over 8 inches of water covering the roadway.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded several roads and required high water rescues in and around Del Rio.

The broadcast media reported flash flooding in parts of Amarillo Texas along with numerous road closures. Interstate 40 in the eastbound and westbound lanes were reported closed at Washington Street due to a flooded underpass. Interstate 40 and Ross Street and also Interstate 40 and Coulter Street were impassable due to the flash flooding. Interstate 27 and Hillside Road along with Interstate 27 and Bell Street were reported closed. Interstate 40 was reported closed to westbound traffic due to underpass flooding at the intersection of Interstate 40 and Ross Street. High water rescues had to be performed at several intersections within Amarillo Texas including at Bell Street and Fulton Drive and also at Mesa Circle and Western Street. Two cars were reported to be overturned at 34th Avenue and Interstate 27. No injuries were reported.
Several high water rescues were conducted at intersections in south Arlington due to heavy rainfall.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded and closed FM1283 and Park Road 37 due to high water.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded and closed FM2676. A high water rescue was required.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which closed US Highway 90 between Hondo and Dunlay due to water expected to cover the road from Hondo Creek.

High water was reported over the roadway at the intersection of Highway 34 and FM 3900 in Ladonia. Highway 34 was also impassable in a few areas between the cities of Ladonia and Wolfe City. High water was also reported on city streets in the town of Leonard.
Several streets in the city of Corsicana were impassable due to high water.
Streets were flooded and impassable due to high water along Highway 84 in the city of Mexia.
Water rose over several residential streets and threatened homes in the city of Olney.

Several roads across the city of Olney had to be closed due to high water including Highway 79 and Highway 114. There was one report of a car stalled due to high water. Evacuations were also conducted along Bluebonnet Dr. and a few apartments experienced minor flooding.
Several roads around the city of Mineral Wells were closed due to high water.
Weatherford St. in the town of Chico was closed due to high water.
Water flowed over Farm-to-Market Road 718 due to heavy rain.
High water was reported over Highway 79 between the cities of Leonard and Bailey.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which flooded and closed several low water crossings in Castroville.
Several streets experienced minor flooding in the city of Bonham.
A storm chaser reporter water over Hawk Avenue near FM 765.

At 13:46 pm CST, local law enforcement reported that a car had been swept into the Scharbauer Draw near Jackson Street and Scharbauer Drive.  When emergency officials arrived on the scene, they were unable to locate the car.  Later that evening, a wrecker service was removing the reemerged car from the water when they found the body of a female driver inside.  Numerous cars were submerged throughout Midland, and several high water rescues were executed.  The police received over 92 submerged vehicle reports, although some may have been repeats.  The monetary damage for this event was estimated based on the number of vehicles observed under water.
A bridge was damaged and impassable along Country Road 216.

The Mason County Sheriff Office reported extensive street flooding in an near the town of Mason.  A couple of high water rescues were also reported.  Highway 386 north of Mason was closed.  Flash flooding was also reported in Wolf Creek and many other small streams across northern Mason County.
The local law enforcement officials reported water to be five to six feet deep with several roads closed four miles northwest of Spearman Texas. No damage or injuries were reported.
Local law enforcement officials reported numerous motorists were stranded on highways around the town of Gruver Texas. No damage or injuries were reported.
Two to 3 feet of water was over the intersection of Farm-to-Market Road 218 and Ranch Road 573 north of the city of Mullin.

Interstate 45 feeder roads were impassable due to high water over the roadway. One fatality occurred when a vehicle drove off the feeder road and into a retention pond. This occurred on the 6900 block of Interstate 45 between West Little York and West Parker Road.
US Highway 90 Alternate was closed due to flooding at the State Highway 36 intersection near Rosenberg.
Water was reported flowing into the City Hall in Premont.  Portions of FM 716 and CR 428, just west of Premont, were impassable due to high water.  Several city streets in Premont were also flooded.

Flooding from heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of numerous roadways in the Lubbock area.  Portions of south Indiana Avenue were washed away by the flood waters.  A number of roadways were flooded in the Ransom Canyon and Buffalo Springs Lake areas of eastern Lubbock County, where some residences were also isolated by rising flood waters.  No injuries were reported.
Low lying areas in and around Plainview were flooded by heavy rains.  Flood waters threated the Ace Hardware store and several other structures, however, only minor damages were reported.

Flooding from heavy rainfall rendered a number of roadways impassable in portions of central and northern Floyd County.  Texas Highway 207 and Farm to Market Road 97 north of Floydada were closed.
