One report of 2.73 inches in 3 hours was received from Port Arthur and KBPT received 3.86 inches of rain on the 9th.

A series of thunderstorm lines moved across the southern Texas Panhandle from the evening hours of the 27th through the early morning hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms were able to tap into a highly moist atmosphere to produce periods of heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding across portions of Wheeler County. The Wheeler County Sheriff's Office reported that an estimated 6 inches of water was flowing over State Highway 152 at Mobeetie (Wheeler County). This portion of the Highway was barricaded by TXDOT until the flash flooding subsided prior to 5 AM CST on the 28th. No reports of stranded motorist or swift water rescues were reported in association to this flash flooding.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Twelve inches of water was reported on Wadley Avenue between Ward and North Midkiff.  The cost of damage is assumed to be zero since there was no damage reported.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Vehicles were reported to be stranded along Wadley Avenue between Midland Drive and Midkiff.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Flash flooding was reported at Austin and Bedford Streets in Midland.  The cost of damage is assumed to be zero since no damage was reported.

Heavy rain moved across Brewster County and produced flash flooding about eight miles southeast of Alpine.  Low water crossings were reported to be flooded.  The cost of damage is assumed to be zero since no damage was reported.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in two cars being stranded at the intersection of High Street and Common Street.  The intersection of Nelson and Green Streets was also closed due to high water.

A series of thunderstorm lines moved across the southern Texas Panhandle from the evening hours of the 27th through the early morning hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms were able to tap into a highly moist atmosphere to produce periods of heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding across portions of Wheeler County. The Wheeler County Sheriff's Office reported flash flooding on U.S. Highway 83 north of the town of Wheeler (Wheeler County). Also the KVII Schoolnet site at Begert Ranch (Wheeler County) recorded a storm total accumulation of 3.92 inches. Flash flooding persisted for an hour after precipitation had ended across the county before diminishing a little before 5 AM CST. No stranded motorists or swift water rescues were reported in association to this flash flooding.

Thunderstorms moved over Howard County and produced flash flooding in Big Spring.  The 1300 block of Sixth Street, portions of Third Street, and the intersection of Alamesa and Parkway were all flooded.  A taxi cab was reported to be pushed off the road in Big Spring.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
A trained spotter reported massive flooding across rural Hudspeth County. Area roadways had water at jeep hood level. Rainfall amounts of between 2 to 4 inches were reported from CoCoRaHS observers.
Significant flooding issues were reported across Far Northeast El Paso. Total rainfall amounts were between 3 to 4.5 inches in 6 to 8 hours.

Heavy rain from training thunderstorms fell across Jasper County and neighboring Tyler County for multiple hours. This produce flooding across the region as near 6 inches of rain fell. The high rainfall rates caused flooding around the city of Jasper closing streets, flooding of at least one car, and flooding a couple of houses.

Almost 4 inches of rain fell in the Horizon City, Tornillo and Socorro areas overnight and into the morning of September 12th. Water levels in Tornillo were up to the hoods of some cars. Homes and neighborhoods in Socorro flooded with at least 15 families needing to be evacuated. In San Elizario TX serious flooding damaged the historic Old  County Jail and La Portales Museum along with some homes.

A line of near stationary thunderstorms developed over northern Lipscomb County during the evening hours of the 19th. These thunderstorms formed in a highly moist atmosphere which allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding on County Road 9 between Booker and Darrouzett. The USGS rain gauge near Lipscomb reported a storm total accumulation of 3.10 inches. No swift water rescues or stranded vehicles were reported in association to this flash flooding.
Public reported county roads north of Agua Dulce near Rancho Banquete were flooded.

Heavy rain across the Beaumont area produced flooding along Eastex Freeway from near the Highway 287/69/Interstate 10 spilt to Highway 105 in Beaumont. Flooding caused the exit ramps and frontage roads to be impassable to some cars with lower sitting vehicles flooding.
Heavy rain from training thunderstorms produced the flooding and closure of numerous county roads along Big Cow Creek between Newton and Call.
Bee County Sheriff's Office reported water over the road on Farm to Market Road 673 near Orangedale.

A line of near stationary thunderstorms developed over Potter County during the evening hours of the 19th. These thunderstorms formed in a highly moist atmosphere which allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding which caused a car to hydroplane and wreck at Interstate 40 and Western Street (Potter County). The Amarillo Globe Newspaper reported that a foot of water had accumulated in the parking lot of Rudy's Barbecue.  Emergency personnel also reported to wrecks on Interstate 40 between Avondale Street and Georgia Street. Flash flooding was able to recede after 8 PM CST as thunderstorms moved south of the city.

A thunderstorm moved over Ector County and produced flash flooding.  Six inches of flowing water was reported at Dixie and 42nd Street as well as Dixie and 44th Street in Odessa. The cost of damage is unknown and is assumed to be zero since no reports were received.

A line of near stationary thunderstorms developed over Potter County during the evening hours of the 19th. These thunderstorms formed in a highly moist atmosphere which allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding on 9th Street and Bell Street which caused a car to stall. The occupant was able to escape the flood waters unassisted. A trained storm spotter 8 miles north-northwest of Amarillo (Potter County) recorded a 1.10 inches of storm total accumulation. Flash flooding was able to recede after 8 PM CST as thunderstorms moved south of the city.
Hamilton County Sheriff's office reported several low water crossings were barricaded in and around the city of Hamilton.
Heavy rain moved across Dawson County and produced flash flooding four miles west of Lamesa.  Highway 180 west of Lamesa was partially washed out.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Rainfall amounts around 3 inches produced flooding of roads in Kingsville. Several intersections were under water.

Corpus Christi Police Department reported flooding from Annaville to Calallen. Roads were flooded near the intersection of Rand Morgan Road and Leopard Street and at the intersection U. S. Highway 77 and Interstate 37.

Heavy rain moved across Culberson County and produced flash flooding in the Guadalupe Mountains.  Guadalupe Mountains National Park was closed due to flash flooding from over nine inches of rain within a 24 hour period reported at some locations.  Law enforcement officials reported mud and rock slides on portions of U.S. Highway 180/62.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

A line of near stationary thunderstorms developed over Potter County during the evening hours of the 19th. These thunderstorms formed in a highly moist atmosphere which allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rain. This heavy rain led to 2 feet of water at the intersection of Bowie Street and the railroad tracks near Martin Luther King Jr. Park. The KVII Studios repored a storm total accumulation of 1.00 inch. No swift water rescues or stranded vehicles were reported in association to this flash flooding. Flash flooding was able to recede after 8 PM CST as thunderstorms moved south of the city.

A line of thunderstorms developed over Donley County during the evening hours of the 13th. These thunderstorms moved slowly and produced heavy rain over the city of Clarendon (Donley County). This heavy rain led to flash flooding on U.S. Highway 287 from the north side of Clarendon to the U.S. Highway 287 and State Highway 70 turn off, water completely covered Koogle Street at U.S. Highway 287, and water completely covered 3rd Street at the intersection with Koogle Street. An off duty NWS Employee reported a storm total of 2.25 inches of rain once the rain had subsided by 7 PM CST. No swift water rescues or stranded motorist were reported in association to this flash flooding.

Heavy rain occurred over western Houston that lead to flash flooding. There were numerous stalled cars in high water near the Highway 290 and 610 loop intersection and also along Chimney Rock road just south of Highway 59. Harris County Flood Control District rain guages measured between 4 to 5 inches over those areas.

Numerous roads were flooded and closed throughout the county.  FM 3053 was flooded with 3-5 feet of water across it.  Industrial Drive near Hwy. 79 was flooded with 4 feet of water.  Flooding was also resulted in a sinkhole on CR 379D south of Henderson.
Aransas County Sheriff's Office reported water was up to 1.5 feet near Market Street and Highway 35 Bypass.
FM. 855 between Hwy. 175 and FM. 3198 was closed due to flash flooding.
A car was stalled in high water on FM. 2868 near the Flint community.

A series of thunderstorm lines moved across the southern Texas Panhandle from the evening hours of the 27th through the early morning hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms were able to tap into a highly moist atmosphere to produce periods of heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding across portions of Donley County. The Donley County Sheriff's Office reported a vehicle became stranded in high water near the city park due to the bridge the vehicle was traveling on flooding. Flash flooding was also reported on U.S. Highway 287 from Koogle Street southward to the State Highway 70 intersection. The KVII Schoolnet site at Clarendon High School reported a storm total accumulation of 3.09 inches and the site are Matthews Ranch reported a storm total accumulation of 3.55 inches. Flash flooding persisted for several hours after precipitation had ended across the county before diminishing after 4 AM CST.
CR. 460 was flooded and closed with 2 feet of water over the roadway.
FM. 95 between Hwy. 103 East and Hwy. 21 East was closed due to flooding.
Several roads were closed due to high water across the county.
Heavy rain caused road flooding around the city of Houston.
FM. 1277 about a half mile south of Spur 85 was closed due to flooding.  FM. 3230 two miles north of San Augustine was also flooded.

A series of thunderstorm lines moved across the southern Texas Panhandle from the evening hours of the 27th through the early morning hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms were able to tap into a highly moist atmosphere to produce periods of heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding across portions of Wheeler County. The Wheeler County Sheriff's Office reported a stranded motorist on County Road 8 near Interstate 40 due to flash flooding. The occupant was assisted by law enforcement officials to escape the flood waters. Flash flooding persisted for a few hours after precipitation had ended across the county before diminishing a little before 5 AM CST.

Heavy rain moved over Martin County and produced flash flooding eight miles northeast of Tarzan.  Two feet of water was reported over a low water crossing.  The cost of damage is assumed to be zero since no damage was reported.
Portions of Hwy. 96 and FM. 138 in Center, Texas were blocked and closed due to high water.
Portions of Hwy. 84 west of Joaquin, Texas was covered with water and closed.

A line of near stationary thunderstorms developed over Potter County during the evening hours of the 19th. These thunderstorms formed in a highly moist atmosphere which allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding which caused a car to stall at the intersection of Interstate 40 and Ross Street (Potter County). The Amarillo Globe Newspaper reported the car was pushed out of knee deep flood waters by the driver while other vehicles attempted to cross the intersection. Flash flooding was able to recede after 8 PM CST as thunderstorms moved south of the city.
Flooding occurred on Weber Road from Saratoga Boulevard to past Apollo Road with water nearly a foot deep. The southbound lanes became impassable for small vehicles.
Flooding of streets occurred in many areas across the city of Corpus Christi. Flood waters reached a business on South Alameda.
Several roads closed due to flooding.

Heavy rain moved across Ector County and produced flash flooding in southeast Odessa.  Cars were stranded at I-20 and Meadows Street.  The water was estimated to be twelve inches deep.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
All low water crossings over frontage road which parallels Interstate 10 between Transmountain Road and Vinton were running full with water. Arroyo in Vinton was running full as well.

Heavy rain moved across Ector County and produced flash flooding from Pleasant Farms to Highway 385.  There was an estimated six inches of water over the curbs.  The cost of damage is assumed to be zero since no damage was reported.
Road closures along portions of Texas Highway 97 and Farm to Market Road 624 in Cotulla with 2 feet of water moving over the roads.
The Duval County Sheriff's Office reported flooding on a bridge along Texas Highway 16 about 10 miles north of Freer.
Heavy rainfall produced flooding in Cotulla and across La Salle County. Rising creeks and water over the roads caused road closure across many Farm to Market roads including FM 468 and FM 469.
Interstate 35 near mile marker 37 was closed due to flooding and multiple car accidents.
Heavy rainfall produced flooding on several roads and streets within the city of Laredo|including Jacaman Road, Bartlett Avenue, and McPherson Road.
U. S. Highway 59 and Texas Highway 44 west of Freer closed due to flooding.
Laredo Police Department reported several roads across central and northern portions of Laredo were barricaded due to flooding.
Farm and ranch equipment were inundated by major flooding along the Nueces River. Some oil field equipment were flooded also.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding by Midland International Airport.  There was six inches of water running over the northern service road off of Business Highway 20.  The cost of damage is assumed to be zero since there was no damage reported.
Several high water rescues occurred in La Salle County with water as high as|4 feet deep in some areas.
A stranded motorist was rescued at mile marker 37 on Interstate 35 south of Encinal.
Major flooding along the Nueces River occurred near Cotulla. Some farm and ranch equipment were flooded. Cattle were cut off by the flood waters also.
County Road 365 in River Creek Acres flooded and closed due to major flooding on the Nueces River.
Airport Park and boat ramp flooded and closed due to major flooding on the Nueces River.
County Road 336 was flooded and closed at Keller Road due to major flooding on the Nueces River. Approximately 20 mobile homes were evacuated. Flood waters surrounded 2 permenant home structures.
Antelope Road was flooded and closed due to major flooding along the Nueces River. Approximately a dozen homes along Cub Lane were cut off and not accessible.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several low water crossings in and around Marble Falls.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing FM1431 and several low water crossings in southern Burnet County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that lead to flash flooding closing low water crossings along Old Spicewood Springs Rd, McNeil Dr. and O'Neal Ln. in northern Austin.

A transient was swept away in a drainage ditch under Interstate 35 along Little Walnut Creek.  Widespread flash flooding was not observed, but locally heavy rainfall occured in the area and lead to stronger flow in the creek.  The transient was rescued out of the water but was unconscious.  He was pronounced dead a short time later.

Heavy rain moved across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa.  A vehicle was reported to be stranded in high water at the intersection of Yukon Street and Grandview Avenue in Odessa.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Water over the curbs was reported at Wadley and Midkiff Streets in Midland.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Flash flooding was reported at Scharbauer Draw, and four roads were closed around the draw due to the flooding.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Flooding was reported at Scharbauer Draw, so roads along the draw were blocked off since they were beginning to flood.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding on Bandera Road south of FM 1560.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing FM 1506 between Culebra and Bandera Rds.
Heavy rainfall produced flooding in southern Refugio County with water over the roadways around the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 1360 and 3037 in the Bonnieview area.
Interstate 37 was closed due to high water near the community of Oakville.

A supercell thunderstorm brought copious amounts of large hail and heavy rain to the city of Amarillo (Potter County). The large hail clogged drainage systems which caused localized flash flooding near the intersection of North Eastern Street and northeast 24th Ave. A motorist became stranded in the flood waters and the Amarillo Police Department were called out to perform a high water rescue. The motorist was uninjured and the flood waters quickly receded once the thunderstorm had moved out of the area.

A supercell thunderstorm brought copious amounts of large hail and heavy rain to Amarillo. The hail clogged drainage systems which caused localized flash flooding near the intersection of North Grand Street and East Hastings Ave. A motorist became stranded in the flood waters, and the Amarillo Police Department was called to perform a high water rescue. The motorist was uninjured and the flood waters quickly receded once the supercell moved out of the area.

Heavy rainfall between 7 to 9 inches occurred over northern Bee County causing significant flooding along Medio Creek. Flood waters from Medio Creek caused road closures along U. S. Highway 181 at the intersections with Farm to Market Road 623 in Pettus and with Farm to Market Road 798 in Tulsita. Flood waters reached a depth of 1 to 2 feet in homes and businesses in the city of Pettus, including the Dairy Queen and U. S. Post Office. Damage estimates from the flooding were at half of a million dollars.
Interstate 37 was closed due to 4 feet of water over the road near mile marker 74.

A foot of water covered the intersection of Deacon Drive and Rio Grande Street in College Station. Flash flooding was also reported on Old San Antonio Road as a creek was overrunning its banks. Minor street flooding was reported at the intersection of George Bush Drive and University Oaks Drive.
Roads were closed due to high water near the intersection of Guadalupe Road and York Road in southern Victoria County.
Flooding forced evacuations of homes near Tipps Park just west of Three Rivers near Texas Highway 72.

Laredo Fire Department reported sporadic flooding of roadways throughout the city of Laredo.  Flooding affected intersections on the north side of town at McPherson Avenue and International Boulevard as well as McPherson Avenue and Del Mar Boulevard, on the southeast side of Laredo near Los Presidentes Avenue and Loop 20, and Scott and Coke Streets in the downtown area.

Flooding on the northwest side of Laredo led to a water rescue of one person near the intersection of Mines Road and Rancho Viejo Drive. High water flooded a home on Lady Di Loop in north Laredo. Flooding was reported on McPherson Avenue and International Boulevard. Streets were flooded in south Laredo also.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Ranch Road 336 between Hwy 83 and FM 3235.

There were numerous reports of flooding around the greater Houston metropolitan area. There was curb high street flooding at the intersection of Gessner and Hammerly Streets. There was also high water causing flooding at the West Sam Houston Tollway southbound at U.S. Highway 59 southwest. Frontage road flooding was reported at the 610 West Loop northbound at U.S. Highway 59 southwest. There was a road closure at the U.S. 59 southwest freeway at Shepherd Drive due to high water. Road flooding was also reported in Humble, state highway 288 southbound at the 610 south loop, southwest U.S. 59 northbound at the 610 west loop, and at the south Beltway 8 eastbound at U.S. 90 alternate south.
Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall caused saturated ground that gave way to flash flooding. Streets and cars were flooded in the north end of Beaumont.
Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall caused saturated ground that gave way to flash flooding. A neighborhood flooded in Lumberton with 2 homes taking on water.
Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall caused saturated ground that gave way to flash flooding. Several roads were flooded and closed around Bridge City and Vidor.
A motorist was stranded near Las Tiendas Road in rising water up to the roof top of the vehicle near a normally dry creek in western Webb County.
Roads were flooded in Rotan with a depth of 1 to 2 feet of water.
Southwest Boulevard was flooded near Loop 306. The flood gauge showed a depth of 1.5 feet.
A high water rescue occurred at South Taylor Street and Concho Street.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Hacienda Rd. and Hwy 90.
Webb County Sheriff's Office reported water was over the road in several areas in the community of El Cenizo.
Menard Sheriff's Office reported a bridge along US Highway 83 was impassable due to high water north of Menard, and a second bridge was impassable along US 190 west of Menard.
Ranch Road 2291 was closed at Bear Creek due to flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Ranch Roads 336 and 337 and FM 1120 near Leaky.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing a few highways in and around San Antonio including Sleepy Hollow and Sunburst Ln.
Flooding was reported on corner of Hwy 21 and FM 39 in North Zulch.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several roads across the western Austin metro area including Joe Tanner Rd., Old Bee Caves Rd., and River Hills Rd.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing numerous roads around the San Antonio metro area including Holbrook Dr., Old O'Connor Rd., and Dreamland Dr.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several roads in and around Floresville.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several roads in and around Seguin.
Goliad County Sheriff's Office reported Farm to Market Roads 883 and 2442 were covered with water northwest of Berclair.

Flood waters along Medio Creek were slow to recede during the afternoon with water around a foot deep in Pettus. U. S. Highway 181 was closed in Pettus and Tulsita due to the high waters along Medio Creek through the afternoon into the early evening hours.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Rainfall totals reported by CoCoRAHS observers were up to 8.93 inches. This rain flooded several roads in western and central Comal County. There was also one water rescue.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Hwy 72 west of Kenedy and Hwy 181 at the Bee County line.
An 18 year old male was killed when he unsuccessfully tried to cross a rain swollen Cibolo Creek around 4 pm.  His body was recovered that evening near the area where he went missing.

A supercell thunderstorm brought copious amounts of large hail and heavy rain to Amarillo. The hail clogged drainage systems which caused localized flash flooding. One motorist was caught in flood waters at the underpass near Bowie Street and 6th Ave. The driver reported that water was rapidly rising into the interior of the vehicle, but was able to escape the flood waters unassisted. Once the water receded, a tow truck was able to remove the vehicle from underneath the overpass.

After a supercell produced copious amounts of large hail and heavy rain, a trained spotter near the intersection of Interstate 40 and Ross Road reported two cars stranded under the underpass. No injuries or swift water rescues were associated with this report.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in and around San Antonio and Bexar County. There was record rainfall in the San Antonio area with the San Antonio International Airport recording 9.87 inches of rain (2nd highest 24 hr total on record) and CoCoRAHS observers reporting over 11 inches.  Most of the rain fell in about six hours with four inches in one hour between 6 and 7 AM. A USGS stream and rain gauge on Olmos Creek and Dresden Drive reported 2.58 inches in 15 min between 615 and 630 am.  The gauge reported 6.13 inches in one hour, 9.46 inches in 2 hours, and totaled 15.31 inches in 5 hours.  A 24hr total at this gauge was 17 inches of rain.  This led to massive flooding in the Olmos Basin/Creek just inside Loop 410 near the Quarry.  Most of the flooding across the city was in north central and northwest San Antonio along and just side Loop 410. This rain came a day after another heavy rain event with parts of the city receiving over two inches. This all led to major flooding with Olmos Creek, the Medina River, Leon Creek, the San Antonio River, and Salado Creek all reaching major flood stage. There were many roads closed including Hwy 281 at Olmos Creek which remained closed for several days. At 10 AM, there was a foot of water over Ingram and Callaghan Rds. San Antonio creeks and streams saw big rises in their levels which led to additional flooding down steam in the south portion of Bexar County.  Areas that were hit the hardest included the Espada Road area near the San Antonio River and Loop 410 intersection.  A mobile home park on Plumnear Road off Leon Creek on the southwest side of the city was flooded out.  Several hundred rescues and calls for rescue occurred during the morning of the 25th.  Two fatalities occurred inside Bexar County. A woman was killed when her car was swept away in flood waters along Leon Creek at the 5800 Block of U.S Highway 90.  Another woman was killed in her car when her car was swept away in the 400 Block of Rhapsody Drive about 730 am.  In all the City of San Antonio and Bexar County Emergency Management agencies found over 350 impacted residences with 15 of those being destroyed and 27 suffering major damage.  The other residences suffered minor damages.  Most of the destroyed residences were in the Espada area along the San Antonio River in southeast Bexar County.

After a supercell produced copious amounts of large hail and heavy rain the 2800 block of Duniven Street in Amarillo (Potter County) was affected by a localized flash flood. A vehicle became stranded in the flood waters and the Amarillo Police Department performed a high water rescue. No injuries were reported with this rescue and the flood waters receded quickly.
The Eastland County Sheriff's Department reported the South Fork of the Leon River was out of its banks. The bridge over County Road 169 was underwater.
The Eastland County Sheriff's Department reported the South Fork of the Leon River was out of its banks. County bridges along the Big Sandy Creek were underwater.
Flooding occurred at Plantation Drive and Country Club Drive. A vehicle was stranded in high water.

Heavy rain caused flooding of low lying areas across the central and northern portions of the city. A motorist was stranded in high water near North Bartlett and North Malinche Avenues. Some of the exits and on-ramps on Interstate 35 were flooded.|Flooding occurred near Jacaman Road and McPherson Road and near Shiloh Drive and McPherson Road.
County Road 474 gave way with a car stuck nose first in the water.
The intersection of Hwy. 59 and Hwy. 80 in Marshall, Texas was underwater.
High water entered a home in Ore City, Texas.

Numerous roads were closed in Tyler due to flash flooding.  This included Douglass Street between Houston and Front Street, Sunnybrook and Kennedy, Erwin and Saunders, Townsend and Oakwood, Bonner and Locust as well as the 2800 block of Calloway.
Texas Street was closed due to flooding.  The intersection of Moreland and Fairview Street was also closed due to flooding.

A portion of Scenic Drive in front of the Penwood Apartments collapsed due to flash flooding.  The underpass at High Street and Cotton Street was closed due to high water.  The underpass at Green and Nelson Streets were also closed due to high water. A bridge was also washed out in the 2200 block of Lafamo.  Another road was washed out at Lincoln and Avenue B.

In the 36 hours ending at 7 AM on June 15 as much as 16.65 inches of rain fell around Eagle Pass. The first report of flash flooding was at 10:30 AM on June 14 when Highway 277 from Eagle Pass to Quemado was closed and water was reported to be entering some homes in Eagle Pass. A short time later El Indo Hwy was closed at Memo Robinson Dr. As heavy rain continued overnight, there were multiple swift water rescues in Eagle Pass. At 5:08 AM on June 15 the Deer Run, Elm Creek, and La Herrdura subdivisions were evacuated by law enforcement officials.  In all 564 homes were impacted across the city of Eagle Pass and Maverick County, including 140 homes that were destroyed, the majority of which where in Maverick County just outside of the Eagle Pass city limits.  In addition, 143 homes had major damage and 180 homes had minor damage.
A trained spotter reported minor flooding of Highway 87 frontage road at 114th Street.

Zapata County emergency manager and fire department reported floodwaters of 1 to 2 feet deep on Highway 83 in the vicinity of Falcon in the far southern portion of Zapata County. The emergency manager also reported that the Texas Department of Transportation had placed warning signs along portions of Highway 83, but closed no roads.
Starr County Sheriffs Department reported floodwater covering the southbound lane of Highway 83 in the vicinity of Salineno.

Torrential rainfall created widespread street flooding throughout the city of Plainview with some vehicles reported to be stalled in high water. The rains also caused damage to some buildings, particularly the roof of the city library where an estimated $1200 worth of books were damaged after water leaked through the roof along the north wall. The city jail also experienced flooding from a faulty roof resulting in an unknown amount of water damage to ceiling tiles.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Carson County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain produced flash flooding in spots on County Road 294 between County Roads 13 and 21. No injuries or swift water rescues were reported with this flooding.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Armstrong County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain produced flash flooding in the city of Claude (Armstrong County). Flood waters completely covered Highway 207 near the Hotel Road exit. No injuries or swift water rescues were reported in association with this flooding.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Armstrong County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain caused flash flooding in Claude (Carson County). Water covered intersections of Andrus Street and 5th as well as Goodnight Street and 2nd Street. No swift water rescues or injuries were reported in association with this flooding.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Donley County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain caused flash flooding on Farm-to-Market Road 3257 up to three feet deep. This road was closed due to this flooding. No swift water rescues or injuries were reported in association with this flooding.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Carson County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain caused flash flooding on County Road 293 between County Roads J and H. This portion of County Road 293 was closed due to the flood waters. No injuries or swift water rescues were reported in association with this flooding.

Training thunderstorms brough heavy rain to Donley County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain produced flash flooding in the town of Clarendon (Donley County) which swept a police vehicle from the road at the intersection of Koogle Street and Highway 287. The officer was pulling out of a parking lot and was unable to see a ditch which was filled with water. As the vehicle tires began to dip into the ditch, the officer attempted to prevent the vehicle from going into the ditch but the fast moving flood water swept the vehicle into the ditch. The officer was able to escape the vehilce uninjuried and unassisted. Once the water receded, the vehicle was removed from the ditch.

Local law enforcement officials reported that heavy rainfall from continued thunderstorm activity forced the closure of the Highway 83 underpass on the south side of Childress. The highway reopened a couple of hours later following the end of the intense rainfall. No injuries or damage were reported.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Carson County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain caused flash flooding which stranded a motorist 3 miles north of Panhandle on Farm-to-Market Road 207 three miles north of Panhandle (Carson County). The flood water was reported to be 3 to 4 feet deep where the vehicle came to a rest. No injuries to the motorist were reported.
Trained storm spotters and law enforcement officials reported major flash flooding in the City of Abilene along with high water rescues.  A few vehicles were fully submerged.

Torrential rainfall inundated several roads in northern Cottle County for at least two hours. The worst flooding was observed in and around Cee Vee where law enforcement reported all roads as impassable. Road flooding elsewhere was less severe, but still an inconvenience to motorists particularly along Highway 83 and Farm-to-Market Road 104. No known damage occurred to the road surfaces.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Carson County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain caused flash flooding which swept a vehicle off of County Road 293 between County Roads J and H. A high water rescue was performed and the occupants in the vehicle were rescued uninjured.

Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Donley County during the morning hours of the 19th. This heavy rain produced flash flooding which swept one car off of Highway 287 northwest of Clarendon (Donley County). No injuries were relayed with this report.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing many roads in Marble Falls including Highway 281. CoCoRAHS observers reported 2.48 to 3.22 inches of rain in the area and most of the rain fell in two to three hours.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing numerous roads in and around Smithville. The Lower Colorado River Authority rain gauge at Smithville recorded 3.50 inches of rain in the three hours ending at 15:57 CST.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing multiple roads in Bastrop. The Lower Colorado River Authority rain gauge at Smithville recorded 3.50 inches of rain in the three hours ending at 15:57 CST.
A bridge along FM 1041 was washed out 4 miles West-Southwest of Burkville from rainfall run-off.

Widespread flash flooding was reported by several sources in northern Hall County. The Hall County Sheriff's Office and public reported widespread flash flooding in north-central Hall County from torrential rain. A resident in Lakeview measured 2.7 inches of rain in just 45 minutes, and a total rainfall of 3.5 inches was measured in Memphis. Rapid runoff resulted in flooding of Highway 256 from Lesley east to Lakeview, and to 5.5 miles southwest of Memphis. This highway was reported as being impassable in Lesley. The cluster of storms responsible for this flooding earlier produced five-minute rainfall rates measured as high as 0.72 inches by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet located two miles southwest of Clarendon. Damage to roads, property, or some area crops are unknown.
Breckenridge PD reported streets were closed in the city of Breckenridge due to high water.

Torrential rainfall rates produced 1.92 inches of rain in nearly 30 minutes at Caprock Canyons State Park. Additional rainfall from training thunderstorms this morning resulted in a storm total rainfall of 4.02 inches at the park. Similar to a flash flood in the park in September of 2012, the bridge crossing the South Prong of the Little Red River was inundated by floodwaters laden with debris and subsequently lost large sections of asphalt road. Elsewhere in Briscoe County, a rock slide occurred along Highway 256 east of Silverton and Farm-to-Market Road 599 in Gasoline was under water.
Goliad Sheriff's Office reported water over the road at several intersections within the city of Goliad.

Two vehicles became stranded in 2 feet of water near Iturbide and Santa Isabel Streets in west Laredo. Another vehicle was stranded in high water near U. S. Highway 59 and Loop 20 in east Laredo. Another vehicle needed assistance near Texas A&M International University on the northeast side of Laredo.

Heavy rain caused the flooding of numerous roads, that became impassable, across southwestern Harris County into eastern Fort Bend County. Harris County Flood Control District instruments recorded near one inch five minute rainfall rates over Brays Bayou at South Main/Reliant Park. One hour totals exceeded four inches at Reliant Park.||Heavy rain caused the flooding of numerous roads, that became impassable, across southwestern Harris County into eastern Fort Bend County. Harris County Flood Control District instruments recorded near one inch five minute rainfall rates over Brays Bayou at South Main/Reliant Park. One hour totals exceeded four inches at Reliant Park. ||There were 98 homes and 2 businesses that were flooded. The majority of the flooded homes were in the Westbury area. Widespread significant street flooding occurred along US Highway 59, the south 610 loop, and State Highway 288. The main lanes of SH 288 were closed for several hours due to high water and over 80 vehicles were stranded on the US Highway 59 service roads between Beltway 8 and Highway 90. There was high water as deep as up to the door handles of cars on Monroe Road near Hobby Airport. Hundreds of stranded motorists required high water rescues.

Comanche County Sheriff's Office reported flooded roads due to heavy rainfall. The roads closures were on Texas Highway 36 approximately 6 miles southeast of the city of Comanche, along with Farm to Market Road 1702 South, and Farm to Market Road 1476 North.
Anderson County Emergency Management reported several roads underwater and impassible due to locally heavy rainfall.
Law enforcement reported flooding along Main Street in Turkey. Sections of rural roads outside the city also had various degrees of flooding. No known flood damage was reported in Turkey.

Law enforcement reported that all roads in northern Motley County had some degree of flooding. Torrential rainfall created several mud and debris flows that in some cases deposited in excess of one foot of mud along sections of roads. No known damage occurred to any of the road surfaces.
A trained spotter reported minor street flooding at the intersection of 4th Street and Slide Road.
Thunderstorms moved over Scurry County and produced flash flooding in Snyder.  Two high water rescues were performed by the Scurry County Fire Department. The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Thunderstorms moved over Borden County and produced flash flooding in Gail.  Nearby creeks were flooding into local roads.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Thunderstorms moved over Scurry County and produced flash flooding two miles south of Snyder on Highway 350.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
A section of Highway 380 just west of Tahoka was covered by about 2 to 3 feet of water rendering two cars disabled. Minor flooding of streets was reported in Tahoka.
Thunderstorms moved over Borden County and produced flash flooding in Gail.  Creeks were reported to be flooding into local roads.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.

Heavy rain caused the flooding of numerous roads, that became impassable, across southwestern Harris County into eastern Fort Bend County. Harris County Flood Control District instruments recorded near one inch five minute rainfall rates over Brays Bayou at South Main/Reliant Park. One hour totals exceeded four inches at Reliant Park.||Heavy rain caused the flooding of numerous roads, that became impassable, across southwestern Harris County into eastern Fort Bend County. Harris County Flood Control District instruments recorded near one inch five minute rainfall rates over Brays Bayou at South Main/Reliant Park. One hour totals exceeded four inches at Reliant Park. ||There were 98 homes and 2 businesses that were flooded. The majority of the flooded homes were in the Westbury area. Widespread significant street flooding occurred along US Highway 59, the south 610 loop, and State Highway 288. The main lanes of SH 288 were closed for several hours due to high water and over 80 vehicles were stranded on the US Highway 59 service roads between Beltway 8 and Highway 90. There was high water as deep as up to the door handles of cars on Monroe Road near Hobby Airport. Hundreds of stranded motorists required high water rescues.
Local television station reported Morgan and Baldwin Streets near 19th Street and Crosstown Expressway were flooded.

Slow moving thunderstorms dropped over three inches of rain over the Raymondville area in the matter of a few hours, with a nearby COOP site reporting 3.2 inches. This rainfall caused water to rise rapidly in downton Raymondville. The Willacy County emergency manager reported several inches of water entering the Raymondville City Hall building.

After a wet start to the year more rain fell on the 9th. Slow moving thunderstorms moved into far Southeast Texas and South Louisiana. Heavy rain fell across Orange County with reports of water 4 inches deep in a home in Bridge City and cars stalled along a flooded Round Bunch Road.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Dimmit County. Nearly all major roads in the county were closed due to high water including Highway 83 between Carrizo Springs and Asherton, FM1433, FM1407, FM1556, and FM468.  A CoCoRaHS observer 3.0 miles NNE of Carrizo Springs reported a rainfall total of 17.67 inches of rain during this event.  Several other rainfall totals of 11 to 13 inches were reported in the Carrizo Springs and Crystal City area.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Dimmit County. Highway 85 was closed between Carrizo Springs and Dilley and a few stranded motorists needed assistance.
The public reported standing water of unknown depth covering all of Highway 86 in and around Turkey.

There was two feet of water over the roadway at low water crossing on Alfred Petsch Rd near the Pedernales River. The road was closed due to high water at the low water crossing at Pfiester Rd near the Pedernales River.
Heavy rain and flash flooding led to the closure of Wedel Cemetery Road. The road was damaged by the flood waters.
There was flooding reported along Barton Creek and water rescues along Bee Cave Road.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending one foot of water over South Hausman Rd. at a low water crossing near Helotes. The 24 hour rainfall in the area ranged from 3.02 to 4.08 inches.

Scattered thunderstorms merged over the city of Clarendon (Donley County) during the evening hours of the 16th. These thunderstorms had access to a highly moist atmosphere which allowed them to produce periods of heavy rain. The heavy rain led to flash flooding across the city. The intersections of Koogle Street and Hawley Street with U.S. Highway 287 were reported to have 2 to 3 feet of water covering the intersections. Flash flooding was also reported on portions of U.S. Highway 287 with up to 8 inches of standing water. A vehicle became stranded on U.S. Highway 287, but all of the occupants were able to escape the vehicle unassisted. As time progressed the flash flooding on U.S. Highway 287 widened to encompase one block to either side of the highway. Farm-to-Market Road 2161 was closed at the Highway 287 intersection. This flash flooding later diminished once precipiation moved out of the county.
Local law enforcement reported water approaching and entering homes in Rio Grande City.
One to two feet of water was flowing over the intersection of FM 436 and Old TX 95 in Little River. Heavy thunderstorms produced nearly 8 of rain in just a few hours resulting in flash flooding.

Heavy thunderstorms produced flash flooding in southern Falls County. FM 1373 was underwater between FM 413 and HWY 6. High water was reported on HWY 6 where it crosses Little Brazos River. Water was also reported on FM 2413 and FM 46. Nearly 8-10 of rain fell over the area in just a few hours.

After a night of heavy rain, runoff into the San Marcos River sent a flood wave downstream. Below San Marcos there was flooding at the Pecan Park Campground. Farther downstream the river sent water over FM1979 closing the road, and there was a swift water rescue at FM 1977 near Staples.  There were 21 homes destroyed across Caldwell County, 20 of which were mobile homes.  Most of the homes that were damaged and destroyed were uninsured.
Flooding continued across parts of Falls County after nearly 8-10 of rain fell over the area. Most of the rain fell over the southern half of the county. The water took several hours to recede.
The Sheriff's Office reported Juno Highway or Ranch Road 189, located about 14 miles south of Sonora, was closed because of flooding.
The Sheriff's Office reported Bond Road or Ranch Road 1691, about 4 miles southeast of Sonora, was closed due to flooding.
Local law enforcement reported water approaching and entering homes in Rio Grande City.
Highway 53 near Rosebud was under water.

A line of near stationary thunderstorms developed over southern Oldham County during the evening hours of the 19th. These thunderstorms formed in a highly moist atmosphere which allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding of the Interstate 40 side road with a foot of fast flowing water. Swiftly running water 3 inches deep was also reported at the intersection of 5th Street and Walnut Avenue in town. No swift water rescues or stranded vehicles were reported in association to this flash flooding.
The Tom Green County Sheriff's Office reported a vehicle was stalled on a flooded road on Lagoon Lane near the town of Knickerbocker.
The Sutton County Sheriff's Office reported Caverns Road or Ranch Road 1989, located 10 miles west northwest of Sonora, was closed due to flooding.
There were road clousures due to flooding in and around the Camilla area.
Four roads in Coryell County were barricaded overnight due to heavy rainfall from thunderstorms.
Flooding was reported by a trained spotter along State Highway 137 at the Howard Draw.  Water was estimated at two feet deep.
FM 915 was closed because of flooding about 13 miles south southeast of Mertzon.
McIntosh Road located in southeast Schleicher County was closed due to flooding.
U.S. Highway 277 located just south of Sonora was closed because of high water.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding at FM 685 and FM1825.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Wimberley. Observers reported 12.45 to 14.01 inches of rain in the 24 hours ending at 7AM. This flooded a workshop with one half inch of water. A citizen estimated the river level near the confluence of the Blanco River and Cypress Creek was higher than that of the 1998 flood.
The Texas Department of Transportation closed Ranch Road 385 in Eastern Kimble County because of flooding.
The Texas Department of Transportation closed Ranch Road 2291 about 4 miles south of Menard.
The City of San Angelo reported flooding at the 1200 Block of Tres Rios Street.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding at the intersection of FM 20 and FM 621. Time is approximate.

There were flooded roads across eastern parts of Washington County. There was a 24 hour 11 inch rainfall total reported at a COCORAHS site 10 miles north northwest of Hempstead ending at 7 AM the morning of the 29th.
There was water over Highway 59 between Moscow and Seven Oaks.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding on Old Chappell Hill Road just west of the town of Chappell Hill.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Some cars were reported to be flooded and there was flooding reported in some homes.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate since the number of cars and homes affected is unknown and the extent of the damage is unknown.

Across Round Rock and the northern sections of Williamson County, heavy rain fell much of the night with areas reporting up to 10 inches of rain.  At the peak of the flooding there were 23 areas closed due to high water. Several homes along Brushy Creek were evacuated.  Houses were damaged over the eastern portions along the Highway 79 corridor including Forest Creek, Hutto, and the County Road 123 area.  Voluntary evacuations were called for in eastern Round Rock and Hutto.  88 homes were evacuated.  Several swift water rescues were performed including 8 vehicle rescues.  Overall 19 homes were affected by flooding rains in Williamson County with overall damages hit 1.1 million dollars in uninsured losses to public infrastructure.

A truck drove around a barricade at Brushy Creek on Polonia Road.  The truck became submerged and the driver was able to escape unharmed.  The passenger was not able to escape and got swept downstream. The body of the female passenger, age 57, was found more than a week later.

Flooding continued across mainly the southern half of Limestone County after 4-11 of rain fell over the area. The water took several hours to recede. Several roads remained closed and some roads were damaged by the flood waters.

Caldwell County reported several flooded roads during the morning hours including FM 1979 at the San Marcos River, Old Colony Line Road, and FM 86.  A flash flood fatality occurred near Track Road and FM 20 East when a 51 year old teacher at Smithville Junior High was driving to work and his car was swept off the road.  His body was recovered later that day.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Pflugerville. Four feet of water swept cars off Grand Avenue Parkway which necessitated two swift water rescues. A CoCoRaHS observer in the area reported 5.72 inches of rain in the 24 hours ending at 7AM.
There were numerous roads closed and water rescues in and around Pflugerville.  There were rainfall reports of over 8 inches of rain during the late evening hours up through 1am.

Flooding was observed on many city streets in the central portion of Corpus Christi. Two to three feet of water was reported over the roadway at McArdle Road near La Palmera Mall, leading to stalled vehicles. Water was over the road at several intersections from Port Avenue and Crosstown Expressway to Alameda and Robert Streets.
Several low water crossings were flooded across Comal county due to heavy rain.
Several roads were closed in Hondo due to flooding.
A foot of water was flowing over a roadway near Interstate 35 and State Highway 84 in Bellmead.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding in Wellborn at the intersection of Greens Prairie Road and Royder Road.
Flooding continued across Anderson County after 4-8 of rain fell over the area. The water took several hours to recede. Several roads remained closed and some roads were damaged by the flood waters.

Significant flooding was reported along Highway 164 and the road was impassable. Several other major roads across the southern half of the county were closed due to flash flooding. Rainfall totals of 5-11 of rain fell across the southern half of the county in just a few hours.

Several cars were stalled in high water on Trinity Blvd in Hurst, behind the Bell Helicopter facility. In addition, several cars were also stalled in high water in the construction area near Northeast Mall.
Seven inches of water was reported over Interstate 35W at North Loop 820.

Four people had to be rescued in southeast Arlington when Bowman Branch Creek overflowed its banks and trapped their cars. The incidents happened near the intersection of Webb Ferrell Road and Hanrahan Ave. One car was swept off the road, and its two occupants were rescued from the nearby trees. The other car stalled in the high water and the two occupants were rescued from the roof of the car. The creek rose after 4-5 inches of rain fell in a 12 hour period with most of the rain falling during the few hours before the cars were trapped. The water was 4-5 feet deep where the cars were stalled.

Heavy rains caused flash flooding in and around the Sealy area.  Several roads throughout the area were impassable, including the intersection of Highway 36 and Highway 90.  There was some water damage to the Sealy Intermediate and Sealy Junior High schools.
Flooded roads were reported across western Polk County in and around the Livingston area.

Heavy rain caused road closures due to flooding in and around the towns of League City, Hitchcock, Dickinson, La Marque, and San Leon, as well as high water around Tiki Island, and the Bolivar Peninsula.

The Comal County Engineer's Office website reported that portions of Smithson Valley Road had nearly 3 feet of water over it in spots.  Low water crossings were flooded across other portions of Comal and Hays Counties.

Heavy rains in excess of 14 inches upstream of Austin in the Onion Creek Watershed near Wimberley caused a flash flood that hit portions of South Austin in the early morning hours.  Water started to rise and flood portions of the Onion Creek area near Interstate 35 by 4-5am on the morning of the 31st and water continued to rise into the early morning hours.  USGS gauges were overtopped near Twin Creek Road and this record flood water continued to move along Onion creek, passing under I-35 and inundating several neighborhoods between I-35 and US Highway 183.  A reverse 911 was utilized by the City of Austin to help evacuate residents but flood waters rose so quickly that most residents sheltered in place and were rescued by truck and helicopter later that morning.  Those that tried to escape the flood waters via their vehicles got caught in the rising waters and this led to several fatalities.  A mother and infant son died when their SUV vehicle was swept off the Onion Creek bridge on Bluff Springs Road in the predawn hours around 430 am. Another resident in a neighborhood along Onion Creek was also found drowned as his vehicle got swept off the road and was recovered near Pleasant Valley Drive and William Cannon.  Almost 2 weeks later the body of a homeless man was found in Williamson Creek near South First Street and Heartwood.  He was presumed a flood fatality from this event.  Manual readings were performed by USGS at the Onion Creek/Highway 183 gauge site ATIT2.  The creek crested just over 40 feet at 930 am the morning of October 31st.  This was a new record height for this location and translated to about 135,000 cubic feet per second. In total across Travis County and the City of Austin, over 700 homes were damaged by the flooding, of which over 100 were destroyed.  Most of the affected homes did not have insurance and were within the 100 year flood plain of Onion Creek.  Flood recovery lasted for several weeks including debris removal. Damage estimates are still being calculated as of this writing but damages across Travis County and the City of Austin look like they will exceed 100 million dollars.

Numerous roads were closed across the county due to very heavy rainfall resulting in flash flooding. 4-12 of rain fell across the county in just a few hours. Water entered one house on Highway 84 in Teague. 4 houses on the northeast side of Teague were evacuated as Turtle Creek quickly rose.

Several county roads across the northern part of the county were impassable due to flash flooding. Heavy thunderstorms produced 3-7 of rain across the northern half of the county resulting in flash flooding. FM 2269 at Elm Creek was impassable for a few days. FM 485 at Elm Creek was closed for several weeks due to damage caused by flooding from the swollen creek. At least 3 people were rescued out of Elm Creek near FM 485. In addition, parts of FM 487 and 437 near Davilla were flooded. Damage was reported on FM 437. CR 116 was also closed because the asphalt was washed away.

Significant flooding continued across eastern Bell County after nearly 8 of rain fell over the area. The water took several hours to recede. Several roads remained closed and some roads were damaged by the flood waters.

Flooding continued across Freestone County after 4-12 of rain fell over the area. The water took several hours to recede. Several roads remained closed and some roads were damaged by the flood waters.

Flooding continued across northern Milam County after 3-7 of rain fell over the area. The water took several hours to recede. Several roads remained closed and some roads were damaged by the flood waters.
Just over 1.25 of rain fell in Mexia in a 2-3 hour period. This resulted in some street flooding in the city, and a portion of Hwy 84 had to be closed for less than an hour.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Hays County. Numerous roads were closed due to flooding around Wimberley, Driftwood, Dripping Springs, Kyle, and Buda.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Crystal City. There was a high water rescue on JFK Dr. and several other roads were closed including Starr St.

Water was reported up to the hood of cars approximately 2 miles west of Rockdale on US 79. Multiple streets in Rockdale were flooded, and the local newspaper reported extensive flooding at the intersections of US 79 and Childress, Meadow, and Calhoun streets. The worst flooding was at US 79 and Meadow Rd where four inches of water entered a restaurant and moved a large outside cooler about 40 yards. A trash dumpster near the restaurant was also moved. FM 908 & 487 were briefly closed during the event. In addition, a portion of Cypress Trail Loop on the western side of Rockdale was washed out.
Several creeks remained swollen out of their banks and several roads remained impassable in and around Rockdale after nearly 8 inches of rain fell over the town in a few short hours.

Numerous roads were closed due to flash flooding that resulted from heavy thunderstorms that produced 4-8 of rain across the county in less than 8 hours. Portions of Highway 79 in Palestine were closed. Part of Highway 79 between Palestine and Tucker were also closed. Numerous other roads in Palestine were impassable including Reagan, Azell, Bassett, North Sycamore Rd near Ezell and Green Street. CR 2201 at Salt Works Rd, and CR 2715 and 2301 were also closed. One home on CR 2301 was flooded with 6 of water when Lake Creek overflowed its banks. FM 312 in Frankston was washed out. FM 321 at HWY 287 in Tennessee Colony was impassable. FM 321 between Tennessee Colony and Neches was closed in some places. FM 320 was closed near Harmony. A woman was trapped in her vehicle on FM 645 in Tucker due to high water, and FM 645 north of Tucker was also partially closed. Also, parts of FM 315, US 79 from Westwood to FM 645, FM 645 to FM 320, CR 2054, FM 321 to CR 2706, CRs 2223, 2401, 2504, 2303, & 2311 were closed or damaged. In many locations, it took the water several days to recede or the roads were closed for at least a week due to damage to the roads and/or culverts.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in the Rollingwood and Sunset Valley sections of Austin. Rainfall totals were as much as 11.33 inches in Travis County near Barton Creek and Loop 360 in west Austin. There were several high water rescues in both Rollingwood and Sunset Valley. Major flooding was reported along Williamson Creek near Heartwood Drive in south Austin.  One fatality was discovered along Williamson Creek near Heartwood drive. The fatality was a homeless man.  Several homes along Heartwood drive sustained considerable flood damage and damage was reported along Lady Bird Lake and Barton Springs Pool.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Caldwell County. Numerous roads around the county were closed due to water covering them. Rainfall totals in the county were as much as 4.02 inches.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Uvalde County. FM1051 was closed due to flooding after as much as 3.47 inches of rain fell.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Pflugerville. Several roads and low water crossings were not passable due to rising water.
Heavy rain from slow moving thunderstorms caused street flooding around Newton forcing Law Enforcement to close some roads in and around the city.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Big Wells and Carrizo Springs. Parts of Highway 85 were covered with water and closed due to needed repair. Some homes in Carrizo Springs were flooded up to the window sills. A co-op observer in Carrizo Springs reported 10.65 inches and a co-op observer in Big Wells reported 9.50 inches.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Eagle Pass. Several homes were evacuated, manhole covers were blown out, roads were damaged by flood water, and several roads were closed due to flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in the Austin area. Low water crossings were flooded closing Bee Caves Rd., Joe Tanner Ln., Wasson Rd., and David Moore Dr.

Heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in the Holland area. Six inches of water was over Highway 95 between Holland and Bartlett. Water rescues were performed along Sunshine Rd and Strasburger Rd, and the two roads were barricaded due to the high water. One man was also rescued on Donahoe Rd to the southeast of Holland. The area received nearly 8 of rain in less than 12 hours.
The Zavala County Emergency Manager reported street flooding in Crystal City.  A shelter was opened for displaced residents.
Flooding was reported along FM 864, a few miles south of Highway 190 along the San Saba River.  The road was also closed.

Heavy rains caused flooding around Waco. Several cars were stalled in high water. One of the most flooded areas was the I-35 overpass at University Parks Drive. The heavy rain also resulted in road damage at 4th Street and Jefferson Avenue, and part of the intersection had to be closed.

Heavy rain in training thunderstorms fell across Tyler County and neighboring Jasper County for multiple hours. Near 6 inches fell during the event. High rainfall rates produced quickly rising water that flooded some streets around Woodville and briefly flooded the lower portion of one home with an inch and a half of water. Minor flooding was also reported at Wolf Creek at Highway 96.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Comal County. People were evacuated along River Road in New Braunfels, and near Spring Branch, Elm Creek was running 40 to 50 feet wide where it is normally about four feet. The 24 hour rainfall in the River Rd. area ranged from 3.81 to 6.58 inches while in the Spring Branch area there was between 10.40 and 11.75 inches.  A man fell into the Guadalupe River near the horseshoe just down from Canyon Dam.  The man was trying to retrieve some equipment while the river was quickly rising.  The 26 year old drown and his body was recovered a few days later.  Portions of River Road just west of New Braunfels became flooded between 1 and 2 am in the morning.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Wimberley, San Marcos, Buda, and Kyle.  Public reports of 14 inches of rain fell near Wimberley and this rainfall made its way into the Blanco River Watershed and the Onion Creek Watershed.  Rainfall totals near Bude and Kyle were upwards of 8-10 inches. The Blanco River flooded and major flooding occurred downstream to San Marcos.  The Blanco River crested at 26.74 feet in Wimberley. The Blanco River USGS gauge at Kyle crested at 35.92 feet.  Flooding then occurred in the San Marcos River as the flood wave crossed I-35 and flooded areas near Martindale in Caldwell County.  Reports indicate that the Blanco River was near or slightly higher than the 1998 flood of record.  Sections of San Marcos flooded near the Blanco River including areas of Texas State University and areas along River Road where several evacuations of residences occurred.  The Blanco River was 100 feet out of its banks.  In many areas along the Blanco River, debris was found 15 to 20 feet up.  Several roads needed repair and several homes were flooded out.  Across Hays County, 47 homes sustained minor damage, 24 sustained major damage, and one home was destroyed.  Four businesses sustained major damage including the Buda Fire Department station and Buda Elementary.
The City of Brownwood barricaded the flooded Vine Street underpass.  Other streets were closed because of flooding.
Very heavy rain of 5 to 6 inches fell over a short time and flooded many roads in the town of Wall.
There was water over Highway 539 near Sutherland Springs Cemetery.
Several roads were closed from South Austin Park to Battle Bend Park to Woods of Legend Oaks Park.
Several low lying streets across the city were flooded, including Railway at Delarosa.

Street flooding was reported on the west side of Trans-Mountain Road with debris. Autos were having a difficult time driving through with a rock slide blocking westbound portions of the road at the mountain top. Several homes and streets in the Vinton and Westway area were flooded with several inches of water.  There were reports of cars overturned in arroyos near Executive Drive.  Rainfall amounts of over 3 inches were reported on the west side of El Paso through the morning into the early afternoon. An electrical explosion and building fire in Downtown El Paso were also blamed on the heavy rain. Interstate 10 near the Piedras exit had to be closed due to water crossing the interstate.

Heavy rainfall began to impact the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site northeast of Post shortly after 0130 CST, with rainfall rates approaching four inches per hour. Officially, 3.73 inches fell mainly between 0200 to 0300 CST, with reports of flash flooding received from local law enforcement officials between 0300 and 0400 CST. Portions of Highway 84 between Southland and Post were flooded, leading to eighteen-wheelers having difficulty driving through the water and smaller vehicles being stranded in high water. No significant damage or injuries were reported.

A series of thunderstorm lines moved across the southern Texas Panhandle from the evening hours of the 27th through the early morning hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms were able to tap into a highly moist atmosphere to produce periods of heavy rain. This heavy rain led to flash flooding across portions of Gray County. The Gray County Sheriff's Office reported TXDOT was working on closing portions of State Highway 273 near Lefors due to flash flooding on the highway. The KVII Schoolnet site at McLean High School (Gray County) reported a storm total accumulation of 4.58 inches. This flash flooding persisted for an hour after precipitation had ended across the county before diminishing a little after 3 AM CST. No reports of stranded vehicles or swift water rescues were reported in association to this flash flooding.
Road closed at HWY 163 AND 90W with 1 to 2ft of water over roadway.

A supercell thunderstorm produced a period of intense rainfall over Hutchinson County. This heavy rain led to a foot of flowing water over intersection of U.S. Highway 136 and Farm-to-Market Road 1559. This flash flooding receded after the supercell which produced the heavy rain moved south of the area.

A supercell thunderstorm produced a period of intense rainfall over Randall County.  This heavy rain led a car becoming stalled in floodwaters at the intersection of Grand Street and 34th Ave. The driver was able to escape the vehicle unassisted and the vehicle was recovered once the floodwaters receded.
Several homes in Canutillo took on water with sandbags being handed out by the fire department.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding requiring a vehicle water rescue.

Up to 3.35 inches of rain fell in the Upper Valley within an hour and a half which caused Mesa Street to become nearly impassable with eight inches of water flowing across it in a couple of locations. Water was reported to be flowing into some businesses on Mesa as well.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Flooding was reported across Illinois Street from Andrews Highway to Big Spring Street in Midland.  There was no damage reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain in Kinney County with CoCoRAHS observers reporting 8.25 inches in Spofford and up to 8.05 inches in Brackettville. This rain led to flash flooding in Brackettville, Spofford, and Alamo Village. Many roads were reported closed including FM1572, FM1693, FM1908, and RM674. Barricades were placed on Fulton and Beaumont Sts. in Brackettville. Las Moras Creek overflowed in the Fort Clark Springs community.

Between 4.23 to 4.96 inches of rainfall fell in less than 90 minutes across western Brownsville, leading to flash flooding across that portion of the city. The Brownsville Emergency Operations Center reported several businesses with some water in them, numerous thoroughfares with several inches to nearly 2 feet of water on them acorss the area limiting travel. During the peak of the rains, 42 streets had flooding that reduced travel to one lane or less. Some resacas were also reported to have reached bankful or flooded low lying grassy areas.

Significant flooding was reported in Mexia after nearly 4 inches of rain fell in a short period. The 700 block of Palestine Street was impassable with water running into nearby homes and manholes blowing their covers. A new culvert at Bonham St and Hopkins Street was pushed out of the ground creating problems for drivers at that intersection.
Bastrop County Emergency Management reported that there was flooding on sections of Highway 812 between State Highway 21 and Elroy Road.
Heavy rain fell across Loving County and produced flash flooding near Mentone.  There was water flowing eight inches over State Highway 302.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Andrews County and produced flash flooding southeast of Andrews.  There was water over Farm to Market road 1788 and traffic was diverted off this road.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding.  Water up to six feet deep was covering low water crossings along Scharbauer Road in Midland.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Culberson County and produced flooding.  Farm to Market Road 1108 remained closed in northern Culberson County due to high water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rains from the previous week of rainfall kept elevated flows along the Pecos River from Red Bluff southward to the city of Pecos.  Roads remained closed with water flowing over the roads in the areas near the Pecos River.

Local Emergency Manager continued to report several roads closed along the Pecos River in Reeves County including Highway 302 between Mentone and Highway 285.  Roads were closed due to elevated flows along the Pecos River cause by significant rainfall around the area.
Heavy rain fell across Howard County and produced flash flooding in Vincent.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding.  The fire chief in Gail reported most farm to market roads across Borden County were flooded.  He recommended not to travel in the county on that day.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding in Gail.  Water was reported to have risen to residents' houses and some roads were impassable in Gail.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and produced flooding.  Business 20 was closed near the city of Pecos between Collie Road and Farm to Market Road 516.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Local Emergency Manager continued to report road closures from elevated flows along the Pecos River from Red Bluff Reservoir to the city of Pecos.  One of the roads being US 302 between Mentone and US 285.  Elevated flows were caused by significant rainfall around the area.

Heavy rain fell across Howard County and produced flash flooding near Vincent.  A pickup truck washed off the road at the intersection of Farm to Market road 1205 and Farm to Market road 846.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding near Gail.  Six to eight inches of water was reported to be running over Highway 180.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

KFOX reported flooding in the Socorro area near Thunder and Rio Vista Drive. Streets near the intersection had to be blocked off. Some people had to wait for the water to recede to get to their homes.

Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding southeast of Gail.  There was an ongoing high water rescue at Lake JB Thomas by the Scurry Volunteer Fire Department.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rainfall up to 5 inches caused flooding of streets in the community of Odem. Water depth reached up to a foot in places.
Tenth Street between Nettie Avenue and Avenue A in Kingsville was closed due to low water crossings being flooded.
High water made roads impassable on Morgan Street between Alameda Street and 15th Street in Corpus Christi.

Rainfall amounts between 5 and 7 inches occurred over western Kleberg County. This produced major flooding in the city of Kingsville. Water was 1 to 1 and 1/2 feet deep in some areas of Kingsville. Several cars were stranded in high water.

Heavy rain fell across Martin County and produced flash flooding.  A truck driver reported that water was so high on State Highway 137 just north of Farm to Market Road 846 in Martin County that he was barely able to make it through the water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding.  Most of the farm to market roads across eastern Borden County had flooding.  Farm to Market roads 1610, 1205 and 669 were closed due to flooding.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Dawson County and produced flash flooding in Lamesa.  There was two and a half to three feet of water over a road next to a park.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate since no damage was reported.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  At least a foot of water was over the road at the intersection of Garfield Street and West Louisiana Avenue in Midland.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Loving County and produced flash flooding.  An oil tanker was reported to be stranded on Farm to Market Road 300.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding around Lake JB Thomas.  People were reported to be trapped at Lake JB Thomas due to roads around the lake being flooded.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produce heavy rain in a short period of time that resulted in water 8 to 10 inches deep across Armstrong near 28th Street on the north side of San Angelo.

Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding.  Farm to Market Road 669 was closed due to high water.  Portions of the road were swept away.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Gaines County and produced flash flooding.  Six to eight inches of water was reported to be flowing over Farm to Market Road 303 and County Road 104 east of Seminole.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in and around Austin. Some apartments were flooded on Westheimer as was a house in the 4900 block of N. Imperial Dr. In addition there were numerous streets closed due to flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused street flooding in the Stone Oak area of San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. The Austin police and fire departments responded to a vehicle stuck in high water at Mellow Meadow Dr. and Lake Creek Pkwy.

A CoCoRaHS observer reported 2.10 inches of rain in about an hour 7 miles north-northwest of Quitman Canyon. The heavy rain washed out a two inch steel pipe that had been in place since the 1940's and caused severe flooding in the canyon.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and produced flooding along the Pecos River.  There were mandatory evacuations in the city of Pecos due to this flooding.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and produced flooding along the Pecos River. Flooding continued along the Pecos River from Orla to the city of Pecos over several days.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing CR 347 north of CR 346 at Opossum Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing a few roads in Uvalde.
Reports of extensive street flooding with water well over the curbs at intersection of Rojas and Joe Battle.
An Anderson County Commissioner reported a bridge washed out on Anderson County Road 2933 just southwest of Palestine.
