Flood waters made Interstate 37 impassable near Corn Products Road.
Flood waters made the westbound lanes of Interstate 37 impassable near Clarkwood Road.
Heavy rain caused flooding near the high school in Ingleside. The water depth was less than half of a foot.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Pleasant Valley Rd. between Thornwood Dr. and Vine Hill Dr. and a low water crossing on Wasson Rd. in Austin.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding requiring swift water rescue of three people trapped in a vehicle on Old San Antonio Rd. and closing a low water crossing on Old Bee Caves Rd. at Joe Tanner Ln in Austin.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding of two rooms in a house in Converse and sending six inches of water over I-10 near Woman Hollering Creek. The home owner in Converse said it was the worst flooding they had seen in years.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing a low water crossing on Joe Tanner Ln. in Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing River Rd. at Loop 337 and Gruene Rd. at Business 35 in New Braunfels.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding sending six inches of water over FM2503 at Brushy Creek leaving ten motorists stranded in the water.
Public reported flooding occurred near American Bank Center where Bike Fest was being held. Flood waters were deep enough to cause some damage to motorcycles outside.
Public reported flood waters were deep enough to prevent fire trucks from reaching the downtown area at Crosstown Expressway and Leopard Street.
Some roads within a mile radius of Staples Street and Saratoga Street were impassable with water depth up to a foot and a half.
Leopard Street underpass at North Padre Island Drive was flooded and impassable.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. The emergency manager reported that most low water crossings around San Marcos were closed due to flooding.
Several roads were closed across the south and north sides of San Antonio including the lower level of Interstate 35.
KFDM TV in Beaumont relayed several reports of street flooding of secondary roads around Vidor from slow moving heavy thunderstorms.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in Karnes County. The roads were closed at the intersection of FM 99 and US 181 on the west side of Karnes City, and farther northeast FM 792 at TX 80 was closed near the San Antonio River.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in and around Austin. Low water crossings were flooded closing the intersection of 15th and Red River Sts. near Waller Creek and 3523 McNeil Dr. Maha Creek flooded the intersection of FM 1327 and Evelyn Rd.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Bell Springs Rd. at Barton Creek was closed with 0.75 feet of water over the road.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing County Road 1353 south of Karnes City.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Eight roads in New Braunfels were closed due to flooding.
Water was over the intersections of Hwy. 21 and CR. 127 as well as Hwy. 147.

A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms moved into the southwestern Texas Panhandle during the late morning hours of the 24th. This cluster of storms produced very heavy rain with reports of up to 4.50 inches of rain being produced in 2 hours. This heavy rain led to the development of flash flooding on Farm to Market road 809 west of the town of Umbarger (Randall County) between Highway 60 and Pondaseta Road. Once rain ended by 8:30 AM CST, flash flooding quickly came to an end.

A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms moved into the southwestern Texas Panhandle during the late morning hours of the 24th. This cluster of storms produced very heavy rain with reports of up to 4.50 inches of rain being produced in 2 hours. This heavy rain led to the development of flash flooding on Farm to Market road 1062 north of the town of Hereford (Deaf Smith County). Once rain ended by 8:30 AM CST, flash flooding quickly came to an end.
The intersection of Gessner Road and Interstate 10 was closed due to high water.
The northbound lanes of Interstate 45 north of the city of Houston were flooded with the adjacent feeder roads under water.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding near Midland International Airport.  Cars were reported to be stalled on Business 20 under the Farm to Market road 1788 bridge.  Two to three feet of water was covering the road.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Street flooding was reported on Ward Street south of Neely.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Pecos County and produced flash flooding near Bakersfield.  Several spots on Farm to Market Road 1901 between Bakersfield and McCamey were reported to be flooded with over six inches of water.  Since no damage was reported, the cost of damage is a rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa.  There was flooding reported on 52nd Street from John Ben Shepperd Parkway to Grandview in Odessa.  The road was flooded curb to curb.  There were no reports of damage so the cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  There were multiple high water rescues in Midland.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding near Greenwood.  There was one and a half feet of water over the intersection of Highway 307 and Farm to Market Road 1090.  Cars were stalled as a result of this flooding.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Howard County and produced flash flooding near Big Spring.  There was two feet of rapidly moving water over Center Point Road northeast of Big Spring.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate since no damage was reported.

Heavy rain moved across Scurry County and produced flash flooding in Snyder.  Low-lying areas were flooded with six to eight inches of water covering the roads.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain moved across Brewster County and produced flash flooding near Alpine.  A pasture was flooded.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Flooding was reported on Farm to Market Road 133 west of Artesia Wells.
Water covered the road on Farm to Market Road 469 south of Los Angeles.

KIII-TV sent pictures of flooding of streets in the southeast portion of the community of Bishop. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches within an hour caused water to pond in low lying areas. Pictures indicated up to a foot of water standing in the streets.

A cluster of intense rain producing thunderstorms moved over the city of Amarillo (Potter County) for an extended period of time. This intense rain led to the development of flash flooding at the railroad crossings of 3rd Ave and 10th Ave. The flood barricades at both locations were closed to prevent motorist from driving into the flooded underpass. These flood water persisted for several hours before receding by 3 AM CST.

A cluster of intense rain producing thunderstorms moved over the city of Amarillo (Potter County) for an extended period of time. This intense rain led to the development of flash flooding at the underpass of Interstate 40 and Washington Street. The water was estimated to be around 3 feet deep. These flood waters persisted for several hours before receding by 3 AM CST.
A vehicle was underwater on Hwy. 69 in Huntington, Texas in front of the Texas State Bank.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in Southwood Drive in Lufkin, Texas being flooded.  Rainfall on the south side of town totaled in excess of 6 inches.
County Road 1992 was flooded and closed from excessive heavy rainfall.

A cluster of intense rain producing thunderstorms moved over the city of Amarillo (Potter County) for an extended period of time. This intense rain led to the development of flash flooding at the Hunsley Hills area. The flash flooding carried a large dumpster floating down the road and an unoccupied car was stranded in the water. This flood water persisted for several hours before receding by 3 AM CST.

Heavy rain began during the 17th across southern portions of Hardin County with 1 to 4 inches falling before sunrise on the 18th. An additional 1 to 3 fell during the 18th. This produced street flooding around the City of Lumberton.
Heavy rains caused flash flooding in and around the Bryan/College Station area, especially near Bryan High School and on Spring Loop.

Heavy rain moved across Pecos County and produced flash flooding about 15 miles south of Fort Stockton.  There was water one foot deep crossing U.S. Highway 385.  No damage was reported, so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Public reported county roads covered with a foot of water in places to the northeast of Refugio.
Texas Department of Public Safety reported flooding of Highway 83 in the vicinity of Tejones Creek, around 6 miles to the north of Toll Road 255..

Heavy rain moved across Pecos County and produced flash flooding about 19 miles south of Fort Stockton.  There was water one foot deep crossing U.S. Highway 385.  No damage was reported, so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

A series of heavy rain producing thunderstorms moved over the same area during the evening hours of the 21st. This training of storms and heavy rain led to flash flooding on State Road 207 south of the town of Claude (Armstrong County). This flash flooding was sufficient to completely cover the roadway. Thunderstorms diminished shortly before 8 PM CST and the flash flooding quickly dispersed. No injuries or fatalities were relayed in relation to this flash flooding.

Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa.  The local media reported a parking lot on 16th Street near a drainage basin had six plus inches of standing water.  There was no damage reported so the cost of damage is a rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Gaines County and produced flash flooding south of Seminole.  One to one and a half feet of water was reported to be running over Highway 385.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Water rose to the doors of Fannin Elementary School.  Portions of Wadley Avenue were flooded curb to curb and at one to one and a half feet deep.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate since no damage was reported.
Water was flowing over the Interstate 45 access road in Palmer.
High water rescues were being conducted in Arlington near North Cooper Street and West Randol Mill Road.
Several homes along the creek in Trophy Club had 4-6 of water inside of them.
Heavy rainfall caused road closures in the 9500 block of Saginaw Blvd.
Johnson Creek in Arlington overflowed its banks due to several inches of rain. The creek flooded part of Six Flags Over Texas.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. In Pleasanton there were six to eight vehicles stranded with water up to the headlights and several roads, including Highway 281, closed with water two and a half feet deep in some places.

Heavy rain moved across Andrews County and produced flash flooding just southeast of Frankel City.  There was water over the intersection of State Highway 176 and County Road NW 5001.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time causing high water and flooding on Bonds Ranch Road to the west of Highway 287. Several vehicles were trapped in the high water.
Heavy rain moved across Andrews County and produced flash flooding in the city of Andrews.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Andrews County and produced flash flooding near Andrews.  The Texas Department of Transportation reported that an eight mile stretch of State Highway 176 from County Road SW 2001 to State Highway 181 was closed due to flooding.  Traffic was being detoured around the flooded stretch of road.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Andrews County and produced flash flooding in Andrews.  The county judge reported numerous flooded roads in the city of Andrews.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Flat Creek near the intersection of Hewitt Drive and Mars Drive, behind Midway High School, flooded over the roadway. The creek also overflowed near the intersection of Panther Way and Panther Run. It was reported that the creek overflowed by at least half a mile, was up to 2 feet over at least one road, and the water was swiftly flowing over the road; like a river. Several cars were stuck in the water. An 18-year-old male died when his car was swept off the road in the dark and swept down the creek. The car was found about 2 miles down the creek, and his body was found the next day near the creek. Part of the asphalt of Panther Way was destroyed in chunks and had to be replaced.
Waco police department was closing I-35 South at New Road due to flooding.

Castleman Creek in Hewitt overflowed its banks due to heavy rainfall and flooded Hewitt Park. It was reported that the water was as high as the 4-foot-tall disc golf baskets in some areas. The flood waters flooded the park restrooms. A 40-foot-long section of Earle Street near the creek had to be replaced after the flood waters ripped up the road and moved it about 100 feet.
Waco police department was closing I-35 North near Robinson due to flooding.
Interstate 35 south of Moonlight Drive in the Lorena area was closed due to high water. Some cars were partially submerged on the interstate.
Byron Nelson Blvd at Oak Street and under Highway 377 in Roanoke was closed due to high water. James Street between Crosby St. and Walnut St. was also closed.

Residual flooding across the northwest parts of Tarrant County continued for several hours after the heavy rain ended. Some of the most significant flooding was along Highway 287 in the Saginaw and Haslet areas. Roads remained closed.

Residual flooding across the southwest parts of Denton County continued for several hours after the heavy rain ended. Some of the most significant flooding was in the Roanoke and Trophy Club areas. Roads remained closed.

Heavy rainfall resulted in the flooding of several streets and areas in Corsicana. The most significant flooding was around Community Park which was under close to a foot of water. Nearby Oaklawn Drive was affected by an overflowing creek and had to be closed. Flooding was also reported on Northwood Blvd and on North Business 45 just north of East 1st Avenue.
Heavy rain moved across Scurry County and produced flash flooding in Snyder.  Roads in Snyder were barricaded due to the high water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rains caused area roads to flood in and around the College Station area, including portions of SH 6 and Tauber Road. Some water rescues were reported along with water in some cars and homes.
High water on roads SW of Huntsville. Public report of 7.99 inches of rain was received.
County Road 1116, located southwest of Cleburne, was being closed due to high water. Over 4 inches of rain was estimated in the area.
Water was reported over CR 1121 just to the east of FM 2331. Over 3 inches of rain was estimated in the area.

Timber Wild Drive in Brock was being barricaded due to an estimated 10 of water over the road. Ox Mill Creek Road was also being barricaded. Water was also reported over Old Dennis Road and Daniel Road. A vehicle became trapped in high water on Old Brock Road.
FM 1189 in the 6610 block was barricaded due to very heavy rainfall across the area. Over 5 of rain fell in the area.

Significant flash flooding occurred in and around Granbury when 5-8 of rain fell over the area. Up to 3 feet of water was reported over some roads in Granbury. Many water rescues were reported; especially in areas northeast of Granbury. The Quail Run and Sunchase Meadows subdivisions (northeast of Granbury in unincorporated Hood County) were the hardest hit. The Quail Run area is near Rucker's Creek which overflowed sending several feet of water into the subdivision. One home was reported to have shifted off its foundation. Three mobile homes were destroyed and two had minor damage. In the Sunchase Meadows subdivision, 18 people had to be rescued from their homes. Four homes were destroyed and three had major damage in Sunchase Meadows. The DeCordova area was also impacted by flash flooding with road problems.
SH 174 north of Morgan was closed due to high water over the road. At least a few other smaller roads in the area were also covered in water. An estimated 5+ inches of rain fell over the area.
Nearly 2 feet of water was reported over China Creek Drive near the Waco Airport. The airport recorded 3.94 of rain in one hour at the time of the report.
Several homes in the Western Lakes Estates were flooded after over 5-6 of rain fell in the area. Several feet of water was reported over the roadway that connects the two lakes in the neighborhood.

A CoCoRaHS observer reported 2.10 inches of rain in about an hour 7 miles north-northwest of Quitman Canyon. The heavy rain washed out a two inch steel pipe that had been in place since the 1940's and caused severe flooding in the canyon.

Several homes in Horseshoe Bend were flooded after over 6 of rain fell in the area. The road to the boat ramp at Horseshoe Bend was washed out. Silverado Drive near Highway 51 was also shut down due to 3-4 feet of water over the roadway.
Culverts at the Bear Creek crossing in White Bluff Resort near Huron collapsed due to heavy rainfall near 4 inches.

Several hours of moderate to heavy rainfall caused a few flooding problems in Crawford. Highway 185 near 4th Street had to be closed for much of the day, and the picnic area at Tonkawa Park near the creek was under water. Part of 4th Street near the community center also had to be closed for a few hours.

Heavy rain fell across Jeff Davis County and produced flash flooding in Fort Davis.  Three roads were reported to be closed in Fort Davis.  Four feet of water was reported over low water crossings in Fort Davis.  The extent of damage is unknown so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and produced flash flooding near Balmorhea.  Portions of State Highway 17 near Balmorhea were closed due to flooding.  The amount of damage is unknown so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain moved across Culberson County and produced flash flooding along Farm to Market Road 652 near US 180/62.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Jeff Davis County and produced flash flooding at the Buffalo Trail Scout Ranch.  A major flash flood came down from Goat Cave Creek and it was described as larger than anything experienced in the last 30 years.  The flash flood damaged the pool shower house, pushed rocks and boulders into the pool, and washed out the pool slab.  Large trees between the Old Folks Home and the pool were washed out, and there was water damage to the Ranger's house, Buffalo Hall, and the Dining Hall.  Two jeeps, Kawasaki Mules, and four ATV's were submerged.  The shop area was flooded leaving large amounts of silt and rocks.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several highways in Kinney County.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding in and around Quemado. Houses were flooded in Quemado and FM 1908 east of the town was closed due to flooding.  In the Quemado area, 1 house had major damage while 35 others reported minor damage. Similar numbers were reported around the Elm Creek area. The State of Texas reported that over 60 tons of debris was removed out of the Quemado and Elm Creek subdivisions.  Some roads remained closed for days while repairs were made.  Total estimates of loss are over 1 million dollars with regards to home and road repair, along with debris removal efforts.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Some people in Brackettville and Fort Clark were evacuated from their homes due to flooding. A CoCoRAHS observer five miles west of Brackettville reported 11.86 inches of rain.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. In Del Rio, the intersection of Industrial Blvd. and Ciengas Rd. was closed as was the intersection of Farley and Las Vacas Sts. The Del Rio International Airport reported 4.67 inches of rain during this event.
Numerous reports via Twitter and media showed Interstate 10 near Raynolds and the Spaghetti Bowl flooded with traffic at a standstill. A trained spotter reported 1.75 inches of rain near this area.

Significant urban flash flood occurred as 2-3 inches of rain in less than 2 hours fell over the western half of Tarrant County. Social media reports showed significant flooding near Hulen and Bryce Streets in Fort Worth. Some roads in downtown Fort Worth were impassable and blocked by the fire department. In the West 7th district, the water was reported to be several feet deep. Many vehicles were flooded or trapped in flood waters. More than 40 high water rescues were conducted in Fort Worth.
A few roads in Bellmead were under water due to heavy rainfall over a 1-2 hour period.
A few roads in Robinson were under water due to heavy rainfall over a 1-2 hour period.
Law enforcement reported flooding across the City of San Saba, including Mill Pond Park and Live Oak Street.
Live Oak County Sheriff's Office reported street flooding in the cities of Three Rivers and George West. Some roads were briefly closed due to the flooding.
The broadcast media reported closed roads in the City of Abilene, including Mockingbird underpass, South 27th from Treadway to Jackson Street, and South 32nd from Treadway to Jackson Street.
Corpus Christi Emergency Manager reported streets were flooded on the south side of Corpus Christi in the area around Rodd Field Road and South Padre Island Drive.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding.  About one foot of water was running over the intersection of Big Spring and Business 20 in Midland.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Culberson County and produced flash flooding in the Guadalupe Mountains.  This flash flooding resulted in mud and rocks falling onto Highway 62/180 through Guadalupe Pass.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Borden County and produced flash flooding on Farm to Market Road 1054.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rains across Reeves County produced flash flooding 9 miles south of Toyah on FM 2903 with water over the road along Nine Mile Draw.  Damage estimates are very rough.

One foot of water was reported over the Interstate 35 access road in Sanger, south of FM 455. Interstate 35 in and just north of Sanger also had to be closed two times due to high water. Up to 4 of rain was reported in Sanger in just a few hours.
The east side of Quail Run Circle was washed out by heavy rainfall. 2-4 inches of rain fell in the area in just a few hours.

Heavy rains occurred along the Pecos River which flowed towards the city of Pecos causing nearby draws to flow out of their banks.  This contributed to water ponding over the roads and low lying areas about one to three miles north of Pecos on FM 1216.  This section of the road was closed due to the flooding.  Damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and produced flooding along the Pecos River.  Local emergency management officials were continuing to report flooding along the Pecos River from Orla to the city of Pecos.  Mandatory evacuations were issued from the Pecos River to U.S. Highway 285.  Emergency management in Loving County reported minor flooding on the western side of Mentone.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain caused several streets to flood in and around the Spring Branch area.
Law enforcement reported several cars stalled in the City of Abilene due to high water from flash flooding.
Law enforcement reported a stalled car due to high water at the intersection of County Road 142 and County Road 134.

Significant flooding was reported in Gunter and flood waters reached the edges of a few homes and businesses in the city. Parts of Highway 289 were closed due to high water.  Several residents were trapped in their homes until the waters receded. 3-5 of rain fell in the area in just a few hours.
Flooding along Highway 5 near Rosamond Pkwy in Anna closed the road.
Residual flooding of creeks, streams, and roads continued across the southern portions of Cooke County after 3-5 of rain fell in the area.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over Donley County during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms produced intense rainfall which led to the development of flash flooding in rural areas northwest of the town of Clarendon (Donley County). A local law enforcement officer reported that a foot of flowing water was covering a low water crossing 3 miles northwest of Clarendon (Donley County). This flooding diminished quickly once precipitation moved east of the area.
Heavy rain fell across Martin County and produced flash flooding near Tarzan.  State Highway 176 was reported to be under water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain moved across Reeves County and produced flash flooding in Orla.  Roads in Orla were damaged from the flowing water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa.  Several roads in southern portions of Odessa had two to three feet of water over them.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Vance Jackson at Orsinger.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding between Groveton and Apple Springs.  Sections of FM 94 were under water, and some flooding was reported in and around the Apple Springs area.
Heavy rain fell across Winkler County and produced flash flooding south of Kermit.  There was water running across Highway 18.  No damage was reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Intense rainfall from a line of thunderstorms which moved through Randall County during the early afternoon hours of the 24th led to the development of Flash Flooding in Palo Duro Canyon State Park. Park officials reported the water crossing number 2 had between 8-10 inches of water flowing over the road, and water crossing numbers 3 and 5 had 5 inches of water flowing over those crossings. Once storms moved south of Randall County, this flash flooding was able to recede.

Heavy rain fell across Winkler County and produced flash flooding in several locations in the county.  Water was reported to be covering State Highways 115, 18, and 302.  Water was also covering Farm to Market roads 1232 and 874.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Several roads across the northeastern half of Denton County were flooded by high waters due to 3-6 of rain that fell in that area in just a few hours. Denton County Road and Bridge East reported Mustang Trail in Sanger, Coffey Road in Aubrey, Shearer Road in Pilot Point and the county roads of North Legacy, Fairfield, and Mobberly near Celina and Prosper remained closed until crews could check on them later that morning.
Eight inches of water was reported over Highway 287 about halfway between Decatur and Alvord.
Heavy rain fell across Ward County and produced flash flooding in Pyote.  Water was several feet deep over Farm to Market road 2355 in Pyote.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Andrews County and produced flash flooding.  There was water over portions of Farm to Market Road 1788 between one and ten miles south of State Highway 176.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Very heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding across the southern portions of Cooke County. Up to 10 inches of rain fell in the area. The town of Valley View was significantly affected by the flooding. Interstate 35 was shut down from the Denton County line north to mile marker 491. The water was 5-6 feet deep on the frontage road in some locations. One gas station along I-35 in Valley View had standing water in the convenience store. The interstate reopened between 8-9 am CDT. Numerous cars, trucks, and semis were stranded in the area; including along Interstate 35. The emergency manager estimated 20-30 vehicles were pulled from high water. Numerous high water rescues were conducted.

Emergency management, local law enforcement, and members of the public reported flash flooding across portions of Brownsville, especially the western and downtown areas. There were several reports of 3 feet or more of water into properties.
Law enforcement reported knee deep water on roadways in Menard.
Coleman County Sheriff's office reported street flooding across the Coleman area, including some underpasses.

Heavy rain fell across Loving County and produced flash flooding in Mentone and along the Pecos River.  State Highway 302 was reported to be closed in Loving County.  The Pecos River was reported to be flooded 16 inches deep over State Highway 302 a half a mile on either side of the river near Mentone.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain moved across Loving County and produced flash flooding in Mentone.  Eight to ten men were stranded on oil field equipment due to high water in town.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. A low water crossing on Ranch Rd. 783 had approximately 1.5 feet of water over the roadway between Doss and Harper.

Very heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding across the northern half of Denton County. Up to 11 inches of rain fell in the area. A rain gage near the Denton/Cooke County line reported 10.78 of total rain. The town of Sanger was significantly affected by the flooding. Interstate 35 was shut down from Sanger north to the Cooke County line. Several other roads around Sanger were closed due to high water. Numerous cars, trucks, and semis were stranded in the area; including along Interstate 35. Numerous high water rescues were conducted.
The Coleman County Sheriff's office reported city wide street flooding, including minor debris resulting in the closure of some roadways.

Local post office and school officials reported flash flooding along sections of Farm to Market Road 193 and U.S. Highway 82 in and around Dickens on the 18th. Several inches of water rapidly rushed across these roadways following one to two inches of rain falling in a short period. While water flowed across these roadways for several hours, they did remain passable for most vehicle types.

Curb to curb street flooding was reported in Muleshoe at the intersection of U.S. Highway 84 and West 12th Street on the 18th. The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site just southwest of town measured over three inches of rain during this period.
Law enforcement officials observed flooding along approximately a one mile stretch of Farm to Market Road 3333 northeast of Farwell, forcing them to close the road for a short period.

Widespread rainfall amounts of two to three inches occurred during the morning hours, causing flooding along portions of U.S. Highway 84 near Amherst according to law enforcement. Several road closures due to high water were also reported.

Local Emergency Management Officials reported that state highway 302 between US Highway 285 and Mentone was closed due to water over the road.  Heavy rains from previous days lead to elevated flows along the Pecos that came over the banks and into adjacent low lying areas.

Local Law Enforcement reported street flooding in and just north of the city of Seminole from thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall.  Grounds in the area were already well saturated from previous days rain.
In Krum, 5 people had to be rescued from their homes as high water prevented them from leaving.
High water was reported on FM 3264 along the Wise/Montague county line.

The Texas Department of Transportation reported Farm to Market Road 1424 north of Hale Center was inundated with several other roads, including access roads to Interstate 27 southwest of Plainview. Rainfall amounts of two to four inches were common with locally higher amounts reported.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding.  Low water crossings at South Midland Drive and the north Highway 80 service road were flooded by two feet of swift flowing water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Local emergency management officials reported street flooding and over spilling playa lakes as additional rainfall amounts of up to one inch fell on top of that from the 20th.

Local law enforcement officials observed flooding of Farm to Market Road 1054 east of Tahoka along U.S. Highway 380. This was due to additional light to moderate rainfall which added to saturated soils, from heavy rains on the 20th.

A swath of intense rainfall moved south directly over Interstate 27 from Abernathy, through downtown Lubbock, and south to Woodrow. Although total rainfall was around two inches in most locations, the majority of this fell in less than one hour resulting in prolific flooding near downtown Lubbock. A stretch of the Marsha Sharp Freeway near University Avenue was inundated with up to four feet of standing water resulting in multiple stranded vehicles. Many other vehicles were disabled by floodwaters along the northwest Loop 289 near Highway 84.  Several vehicle accidents were also reported due to near zero visibility and hydroplaning. The majority of monetary losses were attributed to vehicles being totaled from flood damage.
The right lane of I35E in Lewisville was closed due to water on the roadway.
Some intersections in Gainesville have 2+ feet of water over them and are being closed. An estimated 2-3 inches of rain fell in just a few hours in the area.
East Eldorado Pkwy was closed from Hart Road to Preston of the Lakes Blvd in Little Elm due to flooding. Rainfall reports totaled 3-4 of rain in just a few hours in that area.

Heavy rain caused flooding to enter homes in the Aldine Bender area. There were several flooded roadways in and around the northern Houston area, generally located inside the Sam Houston Beltway. Some notable one hour rainfall rates were 4.16 inches at Greens Bayou and Highway 59 and 3.96 inches at Jefferson and Highway 59.

Heavy rain fell across Andrews County and produced flash flooding southeast of Andrews.  Portions of Farm to Market Road 1788 were closed due to two and a half feet of water over the road about eleven miles south of State Highway 176.  A vehicle accident was reported at this location.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding near Greenwood.  Farm to Market Road 307 between County Road 1120 and County Road 1110 was closed due to flooding from the heavy rainfall.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa.  There were two water rescues.  One of these rescues was at West County Road and Kermit Highway.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Flash flooding on multiple roadways across north-central Bexar county was reported by the Highway Department. Road closures were reported at Cave Lane, Oak Glen Drive, Vance Jackson, McCullough Avenue, Rio Seco Drive, Sleepy Hollow Drive, and Bulverde Road. Other roadways were reported to have water on the roadway across the northern part of the city of San Antonio.
Water flowing over Washington Avenue and Memorial Heights Blvd closed Washington Avenue.
Broadcast media reported flash flooding in rural Hidalgo County. Flood waters damaged property and several feet of standing water remained.

Very heavy rain occurred over northeast and central El Paso with over 5 inches of rain reported in about 4 hours. Several water rescues were reported including at the intersection of Alcan and Fairbanks. Another water rescue was attempted at Vulcan and Diana but resulted in a fatality of a 64 year old woman. ||Interstate 10 West at the Cotton exit ramp was closed, Dyer Street between Diana and Manila was closed as well as Scenic Drive due to flooding.

Interstate 10 remained closed through approximately 930am mst. Additional roads were closed around central and northeastern El Paso County including Railroad and Diana along with Joe Herrera Drive. Total rainfall from the storm in northeast El Paso was 6.50 inches at the El Paso Museum of Archeology.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. ATXFloods reported multiple roads closed in the City of Austin. Rainfall totals of four to five inches were reported in the area.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding sending one foot of water over Highway 55 at Maverick Crossing.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. ATXFloods reported over 50 low water crossings were closed across the southern half of Austin and other parts of Travis County.

Interstate 10 remained closed until approximately 1am mst. Through the duration of the event, the El Paso Fire Department responded to 135 incidents which included stalled cars, over 50 water rescues, electric hazards and flooding at houses. ||Rainfall totals from the evening of the 17th to the early morning of the 18th included 3.11 inches within an hour in the Eastwood(Album) Park area on the east side.

Continued heavy rainfall resulted in Flash Flooding on multiple roadways in north-central and central Bexar county including the city of San Antonio. These reports continue a flash flooding event from a previous warning. Road closure reports included East Houston Street, Brook Hollow Road, George Road, Dreamland Drive, Southwell Road, Stahl Road, Encino Park Road, and Evers Road. All road closures were due to high water on the roadways. These closures encompass mostly north central San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several county roads east of Highway 130 near Highways 29 and 79.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding requiring the evacuation of several condominiums on Stoney Creek Cove in Lakeway. Highlands Blvd. was also closed due to the flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding with a foot and a half of water over RM-693 at Elm Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding sending a foot and a half of water over FM-1323 at Spring Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing County Road 105 and County Road 110 at Highway 79.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing several city streets in Austin near Escarpment Blvd. and Highway 290 and the 9100 block of Highway 71.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding sending four feet of water over County Road 301, Cypress Mill Rd. There was still water over the road at 8:30 PM.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding sending water over Ranch Road 648 at Squaw Creek in northern Gillespie County.

Rio Grande City Police Department reported major street flooding across the city. Starr County Sheriff's Office reported that the normally dry Arroyo Los Olmos exceeded bank full by 2 to 3 feet and that several feet of flowing water had flooded the Las Lomas neighborhood. Several cars were partially submerged and at least one house had extensive inundation.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding sending water over RM-1888 at Hunter's Creek Crossing southeast of Luckenbach.

Hidalgo County EM reported widespread flash flooding along the frontage roads of Highway 83/I-2 and closed roads across Mercedes, Alamo, Pharr, San Juan, and McAllen. There were several reports of stalled and half way submerged cars across the area.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding requiring a swift water rescue at Fritz Hughes Park. A Travis County Sheriffs Deputy was reported missing around 1 AM after she called in by radio that her patrol car was being swept away by fast moving water. The 35 year old Deputy had been on patrol checking a low water crossing near the 3400 block of Fritz Hughes Park Road near Lake Austin. Her car was recovered on Thursday and her body was finally found Friday afternoon. Lower Colorado River Authority Rain gauge network reported rains in the area that totaled nearly 4 inches in 30 minutes.

Numerous reports of flooding on Interstate 10 which was at a standstill near Piedras due to large amounts of water crossing the highway.  ||A car was also swept away by flood waters on Elm Street in central El Paso.  The driver was rescued by the El Paso Fire Department. Around 9pm, another vehicle was swept off the road by strong currents and into a reservoir at Fierro and Bywood Drives. Three people were rescued by the fire department on the top of the vehicle with one man having sustained an ankle injury.
Flooding was reported on Corporate and Executive and Fountain Lake and Exchange Drives.
The local radio station reported water covering the roadways near Mullberry (FM roads, as well as Hwys 78 and 56).

Interstate 10 near Piedras continued to be closed through this time period. Several portions of Gateway Drive both east and west were closed due to mud and rock slides caused by the heavy rain. Numerous water rescues were reported with the worst location in east El Paso near the intersection of Fierro and Bywood where 2 people were pulled to safety. ||Cars were stalled at North Mesa Street near the University of El Paso. Other areas where cars were stalled included the intersections of Cotton and Missouri as well as Gold Avenue and Elm Street. ||Several other major intersections in El Paso were closed by 1030pm including Montwood and Wedgewood, McRae and Gateway East, Montana and Piedras, Yarbrough and Montwood, and Hawkins and North Loop. ||Trans Mountain Road was closed due to flooding, heavy rain and poor visibility.

Numerous locations from the Cypress area to the Sugar Land area to the Houston area were flooded, including the corner of Westheimer Road and Fountain View Drive, George Bush State Park in the Cinco Ranch area, the Cypress area, the left exit lane of 610 South Loop West, parts of Eldridge Parkway, portions of Hidalgo Street near the Galleria area, parts of the Fairwood subdivision, the intersection of Bering Drive and Richmond Avenue, the Interstate 610 East Loop and Clinton Drive, Old Katy Road near the Hillshire Village area, and the 13600 block of FM 1092 near Stafford. The heavy rainfall did cause an old oak tree to collapse in Hunters Creek Village.

Flooding was reported from just east of the Katy area to the Bellaire area. Flooded areas included Saums Road near the the intersection of both Barker Cypress Road and Greenhouse Road,  the intersection of Fondren Road and Bissonnet Street, the Cullen Park area, the Avenue D area between First Street and Sixth Street, the intersection of Gerrner Road and U.S. Highway 59, and Richmond Avenue in the Galleria area.
Flooded roads were reported near the intersection of FM 2025 and FM 2666, FM 2025 and FM 945, Oak Forest Boulevard, and southbound lanes of US Highway 59 between Shepherd and Old Truck Stop.
Various streets are flooded in and around the Cleveland area.
Several League City area roads were flooded with water as deep as 5 to 8 inches.
Flooding caused road closures near River Oaks Drive and around Capstone Circle.
The Lufkin Police Department reported a road closure on Frank Street from excessive heavy rainfall.
Water was across several roadways in the city of Nacogdoches, Texas.
Numerous county roads in the northern section of the county were closed due to flooding.
Seventh Street near the Railroad Bridge was flooded and closed in Texarkana.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. FM187 was closed due to a flooded low water crossing.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Whartons Dock Rd.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Flood waters, filled with debris, closed numerous roads in Medina.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Old Mill Creed Rd. at the Sabinal River crossing.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding along Huebner Creek in San Antonio. Several low water crossings were closed due water over the road.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. The underpass at Loop 410 and Highway 151 was flooded requiring high water rescues.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Evers Rd. was closed near Raymond Rimkus Park due to water over the road.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Sections of Highways 72 and 81 were under water.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing many low water crossings in eastern Hays County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing many low water crossings in eastern Comal County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing many low water crossings in eastern Travis County.

A 3 year old girl downed after being swept into a small flooded creek.  The girl went missing around 5 pm and her body was recovered shortly before midnight approximately 50-75 yards downstream.  A 5 year old was successfully rescued and recovered from his near drowning.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing FM 1021 in Eagle Pass and US Highway 277 near Elm Creek.
High water was reported on Hwy. 82 between Kings Highway and the Wal-Mart in Nash, Texas.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  There was a high water rescue at Midland Drive and Industrial Avenue.  Water was up to the dashboard of the car.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

A cluster of thunderstorms brought an extended period of heavy rain to the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter County). This heavy rain led to the development of flash flooding. A NWS employee reported stalled cars due to high water on Coulter Road (Randall County). Thunderstorms moved east of the city which allowed the flood waters to recede by 8 PM CST. No reports of injuries were relayed with this report.

A cluster of thunderstorms brought an extended period of heavy rain to the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter County). This heavy rain led to the development of flash flooding. A NWS employee reported cars stalled along the entrance ramp to Interstate 40 and Lakeside Road (Potter County). Thunderstorms moved east of the city which allowed the flood waters to recede by 8 PM CST. No reports of injuries were relayed with this report.

A cluster of thunderstorms brought an extended period of heavy rain to the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter County). This heavy rain led to the development of flash flooding. A member of the public reported water up the bumpers of cars at the Ross/Osage Road exit of Interstate 40 (Potter County). Thunderstorms moved east of the city which allowed the flood waters to recede by 8 PM CST. No reports of injuries were relayed with this report.

Numerous roadways and subdivisions were flooded from near the community of Nursery to the northern portions of the city of Victoria. Water was as deep as a foot to a foot and a half in these areas. A few of the roads were closed between Victoria and Nursery for a couple of hours. Several cars were stranded in high water in Victoria.
The Dimmitt Sheriff's Office reported extensive flooding of streets and roads in and around Dimmitt.

A series of heavy rain producing thunderstorms moved over the same area during the evening hours of the 21st. This training of storms and heavy rain led to flash flooding on US Highway 287 east of the town of Claude (Armstrong County). This flash flooding was sufficient to completely submerge vehicle tires. Local law enforcement had to divert traffic from the highway. Thunderstorms diminished shortly before 8 PM CST and the flash flooding quickly dispersed. No injuries or fatalities were relayed in relation to this flash flooding.

Local law enforcement officials and trained spotters reported submerged roadways between Plains and Denver City, including Highway 214. A storm spotter measured 4.30 inches of rainfall in just a few hours near Plains.

Three people were rescued from a drainage canal near Valero gas station at Loop 375 and Gateway North. One lady was rescued from under 3 feet of hail and treated for hypothermia, but later died. Additional flooding was reported near Kenworthy and Salem Dr. with cars stalled out.
Numerous reports were received of six to eight inches of water on the road on the intersection of Hummingbird Lane and Cardinal Drive in the city of Denton.
Amateur radio spotters reported Paloma Creek was out of its banks and flooded houses.

The convergence of two outflow boundaries over the city of Amarillo (Potter and Randall County) produced thunderstorms capable of producing very intense rainfall. These storms also moved very slowly to the south after developing which allowed for a longer residency time over the city. The intense rainfall caused flash flooding to occur across the southwest side of town. Flood waters were reported to be as deep as a foot and one half foot deep from the Bell Street exit of Interstate 40 (Potter County) to the intersection of 45th Street and Western Street (Randall County). This flash flooding persist for a few hours before precipitation ended then quickly receded. Storm total rainfall in these areas ranged from 1 inch to 1.5 inches.
Law enforcement reported State Highway 163 was flooded about 4 to 6 miles south of Sterling City.
Water was reported over FM 934 near Blum.
Several roads in Maypearl were impassable due to rushing flood waters.
Two feet of water was over a road near Whitney. No other specific details were provided.
Up to a foot of water was reported over Panther Way near Midway High School.

Heavy rain caused street flooding in Waco. Several roads were covered in water, but New Road at Waco Drive was the most problematic location. The Waco PD reported several emergency calls for drivers stranded in high water.

High rainfall rates with training thunderstorm cells produced street flooding in an around the town of Columbus. There were reports of flooding on numerous county roadways including Schobel Road, FM 2434, and Schulenburg Lane. Power lines were also reported down over Interstate 10 near Columbus.
There was water inundating the roadways around the Grand Parkway and Westpark tollway intersection.
There were numerous flooded roadways with water over adjacent sidewalks.
An amateur radio operator reported 1 to 2 feet of water in several locations along FM 584 and west of U.S. Highway 277.
Law enforcement reported curb to curb flooding in Muleshoe. An eastbound lane of Highway 84 also had one lane under water two miles southeast of the city.
Heavy rain caused flash flooding that allowed overflowing water to inundate Telge Road in Tomball.

Heavy rainfall resulted in the flooding of several roads around Dallas. In particular, several roads in the Preston Hollow and Oak Cliff areas were flooded. Flooding was also reported along Loop 12 on the west side of town.
Water was reported over Highway 16 to the southwest of Goldthwaite.
Water was reported over Highway 84 near Mullin.
Water was running over Highway 75 north of Buffalo due to an overflowing creek. Up to 3 of rain fell in the area in just a few hours.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the early morning hours of the 6th. These storms produced intense downpours which led to localized flash flooding across the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter Counties). A NWS employee reported flash flooding making the intersection of Hollywood Street and Coulter Street impassable. Two vehicles became stranded in the flood waters but no high water rescues were reported. This flooding persisted until the rain came to an end around 3 AM CST.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the early morning hours of the 6th. These storms produced intense downpours which led to localized flash flooding across the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter Counties). The Emergency Manager reported a swift water rescue of the driver of a vehicle that drove into flood waters downtown. The vehicle was not able to be recovered until the flood waters receded. This flooding persisted until the rain came to an end around 3 AM CST.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the early morning hours of the 6th. These storms produced intense downpours which led to localized flash flooding across the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter Counties). The Emergency Manager reported the access roads at the intersection of Interstate 40 and Ross-Osage were flooded. This flooding persisted until the rain came to an end around 3 AM CST.
Flash flood waters entered a home near the intersection of FM 2840 and Hwy 174 in Meridian. A third of the home was damaged. Rainfall totals with the storm was 2.5-3 in the area.
Several main roads across the northern half of the county had 3-4 of water flowing over them.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the early morning hours of the 6th. These storms produced intense downpours which led to localized flash flooding across the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter Counties). The Emergency Manager reported water over the curbs and flood waters up to the doors on cars near the intersection of Interstate 40 and 45th Ave. This flooding persisted until the rain came to an end around 3 AM CST.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the early morning hours of the 6th. These storms produced intense downpours which led to localized flash flooding across the city of Amarillo (Randall and Potter Counties). The Emergency Manager reported the southbound lanes at the intersection of Sleepy Hollow and Coulter. Multiple vehicles stalled in these flood waters. This flooding persisted until the rain came to an end around 3 AM CST.
A trained spotter reported water covering several sections of County Road 303 south of Pep.
The public reported Jackson Street was becoming impassable.
City street flooding and road closures were reported in San Saba.
Six to eight inches of water was reported over Highway 67 approximately 5 miles southwest of Stephenville.

Very heavy rainfall fell across the county resulting in significant flooding. Rainfall totals from 4-5.5 were reported across the county with radar estimates of higher amounts in the northwestern portions of the county. Significant flooding was reported in the city of Commerce. Many streets in the city were flooded and described as flowing rivers. Two cars were trapped on flooded roads and the drivers had to be rescued. Flood waters entered homes in Quinlan and Tawakoni. The roof of the cafeteria at Ford High School in Quinlan ruptured during the lunch hour sending ceiling tiles falling and water into the lunchroom. No one was injured. Several roads across the county were closed due to high water.

The convergence of two outflow boundaries over the city of Amarillo (Potter and Randall County) produced thunderstorms capable of producing very intense rainfall. These storms also moved very slowly to the south after developing which allowed for a longer residency time over the city. The intense rainfall caused flash flooding to occur across the southwest side of town. Flood waters were deep enough to come half way up the wheels of cars at the intersection of 45th Ave. and Bell Street (Randall County). This flash flooding persist for a few hours before precipitation ended then quickly receded. Storm total rainfall in these areas ranged from 1 inch to 1.5 inches.
Vega Verde road was flooded for several hours with portions of the road underwater.

Coop Observer reported roads flooded around Langtry.  Portions of the Judge Roy Bean Visitor Center sustained heavy water damage from a leaking roof after getting nearly 12 inches of rain in only a few hours.
A NWS Cooperative observer reported streets in Hart were covered by several inches of water.  NWS radar indicated nearly four inches of rain fell between Hart and Nazareth.
Many streets in Muleshoe were reported to be covered in water.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing I-35 at Toepperwein Rd. and the ramp from eastbound I-410 to southbound I-35.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Verbena Rd. at Southwell Rd.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Lockhill Rd. at White Bonnet St.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding filling Dry Short Prong Creek with several inches of fast flowing water. There was also one foot of water covering the main entrance to Prade Ranch and two to four feet of water flowing over two other low water crossings nearby.
A NWS employee reported flooding of some streets in Shallowater.

Heavy rain began during the 17th across Orange and Jefferson Counties with 1 to 5 inches fall before sunrise of the 18th, however during the 18th an additional 4 to 8 inches of rain fell. This large amount of rainfall lead to numerous streets and roadways being flooded including the feeder roads along Interstate 10 between Beaumont and Orange, the Eastex Freeway, MLK Blvd, SH 346, SH 347, and the streets around Lamar Beaumont.

Heavy rain began during the 17th across Orange and Jefferson Counties with 1 to 5 inches fall before sunrise of the 18th, however during the 18th an additional 4 to 8 inches of rain fell. This large amount of rainfall lead to numerous streets and roadways being flooded including the feeder roads along Interstate 10 between Beaumont and Orange.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Old O'Connor Rd at Lookout Rd.

Law enforcement officials reported standing water over Highways 60 and 86 in the vicinity of Bovina causing multiple vehicles to hydroplane off the road. One car was stranded in high water as rainfall amounts of 4 to 6 inches fell across much of town, with locally higher amounts.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing the lower level of I-35 at San Pedro Ave.

A line of thunderstorms moved across Randall County during the late evening hours of the 8th. The line produced intense rainfall which caused localized flash flooding. This flash flooding caused 18 to 24 inches of water to cover the road at the Hunsley Hills Barricade (Randall County). This flash flooding continued until the rain moved east of Randall County by midnight on the 9th.

Fire department officials observed flooding near and around Anton, including Farm to Market Road 1294 to 168 as 3 to 5 inches of rain fell over the area. Areas east of Levelland to Opdyke West also reported minor flooding on area roadways, including Highway 114.

A cluster of thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Collingsworth County during the late night hours of the 7th and early morning hours of the 8th. This heavy rain led to the development of flash flooding across the city of Dodson (Collingsworth County). A law enforcement officer reported a vehicle stalled in flood waters in town. This flash flooding persisted until storms exited the southeastern Texas Panhandle at 3:30 Am CST.

Torrential rains resulted in widespread flooding of playa lakes, streets and roads throughout far southwest Lubbock County, or generally from Wolfforth and points south.  Roads such as Brownfield Highway and County Roads 179 and 41 had several sections that at times became impassable by car.  One sedan was disabled by floodwaters near Farm-to-Market Road 1585 and Brownfield Highway shortly after midnight CST.  A daycare school in Wolfforth reported water of two feet deep throughout the building which would necessitate a complete remodeling of the walls and carpeting.  The floodwaters gradually receded from area roads by early Sunday morning, although some tertiary roads remained overwhelmed by playa lakes for several days to follow.  Damage to recently planted cotton and grain crops was particularly severe as tens of thousands of acres were washed away from the heavy rains and flooding.  Area farmers will likely replant with sorghum as the cotton planting deadline had passed.  Estimated crop damage and losses due to flooding will likely reach $100M.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of Hwy. 80 between Ward and Rockwall Streets from flash flooding.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in several street closures in the south portion of Tyler, Texas.
Widespread street flooding reported at New Copeland Road on the south side of Tyler.
Widespread street flooding reported at Shiloh Road in south Tyler.
High water entering the Hill Creek Baptist Church just south of Loop 49 on the east side of Hwy. 110.
High water was covering U.S. Hwy. 64 just east of Chapel Hill.
Severe street flooding was reported on Eastman Road, Scenic Drive and Pine Street in Longview, Texas.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of Hwy. 80 from Greggton to HG Mosley streets in Longview, Texas.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of the Circle in Kilgore, Texas.
Heavy rainfall resulted in several feet of water in Jackson Park.
Excessive heavy rainfall resulted in the closure of Wilkins Road near Rocky Creek.

The Brownfield Sheriff's office reported water over roadways throughout town, as well as along portions of Highways 137 and 380 south and east of town on the 20th. Widespread rainfall amounts of two to four inches were observed with locally higher amounts. Several cars stalled out due to the high water.
Eight county roads were closed due to high water. FM Road 1155 was closed due to flooding between FM Road 2193 and Chappell Hill.

Flash flooding occurred in and around the Bryan and College Station areas. Water reached up to cars near the intersection of East Villa Maria Road and Rustling Oaks Drive, and there was high water near the intersection of South College Avenue and Davis Street.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and produced flash flooding in the northern part of the county.  Farm to Market roads 652 and 2119 as well as U.S. Highway 285 were flooded.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Ward County and produced flash flooding in Monahans.  Two to three feet of water was reported over some of the roads on the south side of Monahans.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding.  Water was reported to be one foot deep on Farm to Market Road 307 between Farm to Market Road 1379 and County Road 1086.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Andrews County and produced flash flooding.  There was flooding reported at the intersection of SE Road 8000 and U.S. Highway 385.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Flash flooding was reported by various sources of flash flooding along the frontage roads in Weslaco along Highway 83/I-2 and road closures in Weslaco. Several feet of water was noted, as well as water to the top of tire wells.

Fort Worth PD reported water covering the service roads along I-30. Additionally, the Star Telegram (local newspaper) reported flooded roads at Hulen St. and I-30, Camp Bowie Blvd. and Bryant Irvin Rd., and U.S. 287 and Rosedale St. until 7 p.m. local time.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. ATXFloods reported approximately 50 low water crossings closed around Austin and other parts of Travis County. Rainfall totals exceeding six inches were reported in the area.
Public reported water was over the roads in the northern portions of the community of Rio Bravo. The roads were impassable in the area.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in Midland.  Six inches of water was reported to be over the road at the intersection of Andrews Highway and Golf Course Road.  There was no damage reported so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Spotter reported very heavy rain in the downtown area near Concrete Street. Water was up to 1 foot in depth at Interstate 37 and downtown with cars stalled.

Reports state two female horseback riders (one 24 years old the other 6 years old) traveling along the banks went missing prior to noon on Monday June 23rd. By 7 PM that day, search and rescue crews located the still saddled horse the females were last seen riding downstream of the US 60 bridge spanning the Canadian River. Roughly 15 minutes later the remains of the 6 year old were recovered. The remains of the 24 year old female were recovered 5 days later 2 miles downstream from the US 60 bridge. Preliminary autopsy results showed the cause of death to be drowning.
Several flooded roads and streets were reported in Corsicana; including 7th Avenue between 28th and 31st street.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing Leslie Rd. at Braun Rd.
A National Weather Service employee reported 2.5 feet of water flowing across Southwest Boulevard, near Loop 306. This resulted in the road being closed.
Heavy rain at Sam Houston State University collapsed a recreational building wall and allowed water to flow into the lower levels of the structure. Numerous parking lots were flooded.
Flooding of roadways continued for a few hours after several inches of rain fell across the county. Several of these closed roads were likely near low-lying areas and creeks and streams.

Flooding was occurring across low-lying areas in the county, and along creeks and streams after several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time. Many roads along the swollen creeks and streams were closed due to flooding. The local TxDOT office reported FM 80 near Streetman between Interstate 45 and FM 833 was closed and remained closed until the 14th.

Flooding was occurring across low-lying areas in the county, and along creeks and streams after several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time. Many county roads were closed due to the flooding and many of the closed roads were along creeks and streams. Some of the closed county roads included CRs 468, 463, 321, & 2715.
Flooding of roadways continued for a few hours after several inches of rain fell across the county. Several of these closed roads were likely near low-lying areas and creeks and streams.
High water was reported over Highway 7, east of Texas Highway 39 near Concord. The flooding possibly was due to Spring Creek flowing out of its banks and over the highway.

The combination of moderate to heavy rainfall, melting of snow and ice, and ice blocking the drainage of water contributed to flash flooding in Odessa.  There were multiple high water rescues as a result of these conditions.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

High water was reported at US 79 and Texas Highway 75 in Buffalo. Water was also reported over Texas Highway 164 at Interstate 45 north of Buffalo. Additional flooding was also reported in the town of Buffalo; in particular the parking lot of the Community National Bank was covered in water with the water extending up to the doors of the building.
Heavy rain trained across southern and central sections of Newton County for several hours on already saturated soil. This produced roadways that were flooded out and closed for many hours.

Heavy rain during the 17th produced flash flooding in south and central sections on Newton County. Multiple roads remained closed from Bon Wier to the southwest into the 18th as flood waters slowly drained.

The heavy rain and flash flood event from the 17th lingered into the early morning of the 18th. Flood waters remained across southern sections of Jasper County through the morning of the 18th with many roadways remaining closed as the water slowly drained.
Numerous roads were closed and impassable due to flood waters especially in and around Navasota.

Flash flooding occurred across the central and eastern part of the county. There were vehicles flooded with numerous impassable roadways in and around the Sugar Land and Rosenberg areas. There was one drowning fatality.
Flooded roadways were reported near Blum in northwestern Hill County after 2 to 3 inches or rain fell.
Homes on the west side of Highway 287, across from Lake Padera, were flooded.
Heavy rain fell in Gaines County and produced flash flooding in Seagraves.  Roads were reported to be closed.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Numerous roads were flooded throughout the county.
Still several Farm to Market roads closed due to water. Water still covers portions of some highway service roads as well.
Jack County Sheriff's Department reported flooding along Hwy 281 near the Jack/Archer County Line.

Significant flooding of parts of Dallas County continued after nearly 3-8 inches of rain fell across the county. Some of the hardest hit areas were along Duck Creek in Garland which overflowed it banks affecting properties along the creek, and Loop 12 at Interstate 30. Loop 12 between Irving Blvd and I-30 was closed for nearly 4 days until the water could be removed from the low-lying area.
The Jack County sheriffs office reported that several roads were closed due to high water in and around Jacksboro. The road closures began just after 5 AM CDT, and lasted until approximately 7:30 AM.
A low water crossing on Highway 377 was flooded due to heavy rain.
Multiple low water crossings were reported flooded along Highway 16 east and west of the city of Medina.

Heavy rain produced flash flooding in and around the city of Houston that caused numerous creek and bayou overflows.  Multiple water rescues were conducted.  Numerous roads were impassable due to flooding that was as high as six feet deep.  Hundreds of vehicles were stranded in the flood water.  Flood waters inundated at least 2,585 homes and 73 commercial buildings. Many bayous, including Brays, Keegans, Buffalo (610 Loop to Downtown Houston), White Oak, Armand, and Halls were out of banks. Additional flooding occurred along Brickhouse Gully, South Mayde Creek, San Jacinto River, Clear Creek, Rummel Creek, Willow Water Hole, Cypress Creek, Little Cypress Creek, Willow Creek and Spring Creek.  There were six directly related drowning fatalities.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing FM 1623 along the Blanco River. A 42 year old man died in his vehicle along the Blanco River near downtown Blanco.  Flooding along the Blanco River in the town of Blanco was substantial.  Water came up to the bottom of the Highway 281 bridge in Blanco.  Water overtopped the Loop 163 bridge east of Blanco.  The Blanco River overtopped County Road 165 and destroyed that bridge.  Portions of the Blanco State Park were heavily damaged with cabins flooded.  There were a total of 22 homes either destroyed or heavily damaged.  Monetary losses were unavailable at the time of this writing but estimated to be more than several million dollars with losses to homes/structures and road infrastructure.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding. Rainfall totals of 10 to 13 inches were reported upstream in southern Blanco County and all of this water entered the Blanco River and Little Blanco River. The Fischer Store Rd. bridge over the Blanco River was destroyed by flood waters west of Wimberley. The Blanco River, down stream from the bridge, at Wimberley reached a record crest. The gauge failed at 40 feet and the USGS later estimated the crest at 44.9 feet with 175,000 cfs. This height was more than 10 feet over the previous record height of 33.3 feet from 1929. Homes along the banks of the Blanco River from the City of Blanco, through Wimberley, and down to San Marcos experienced an historic flood.  Many homes were totally destroyed and swept down stream.  Many homes were struck by large debris, including full size cypress trees which typically lined the banks of the river.  A house in the 100 block of Deer Crossing Ln. in Wimberley was washed away in the flood with nine people inside. There was one lone survivor while eight others died. Six bodies were recovered and the two small children remain missing.  Several of the bodies were recovered near San Marcos Texas nearly 30 miles downstream. Another fatality occurred when a man was washed away with his vehicle. He was 29 years old and was found on May 26 near FM 2325.  A 74 year old male also drown after he was swept off his roof of his house along River Road near Wimberley. The river experienced rises that exceeded 20 feet in one hour.  Estimates of insured losses are around 100 million dollars.  Overall in Hays County including Wimberley and San Marcos, 321 homes were destroyed, with hundreds more heavily damaged.
Numerous roads were closed and impassable in Bryan. High water rescues needed.
Numerous roads were closed and impassable north of Huntsville.
Heavy rain from a line of thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall in Seminole and flooded Hwy 214 just north of Seminole leaving some patrons under a foot of water.
A public report indicated that 2 feet of water covered FM 4 at Barton Chapel Rd in Jacksboro, TX.
Montague County Sheriff's Department reported that a few of the roads across western portions of the county were closed by TXDOT due to high water.
Emergency management reported that several water crossings were closed near Morgan, and CR 1743 in Laguna Park was also closed due to flooding.
Flooded roadways were reported north of Morgan in northern Bosque County after 2 to 3 inches or rain fell.
Emergency management reported that many roads were closed across the county due to high water.
Broadcast media reported that Abrams Road and a nearby shopping center in Arlington, TX were flooded.
Arlington PD reported that many vehicles were stranded in high water and some water rescues were occurring.
A trained spotter reported flooding across roads near Sherman Airport.

Extensive flooding continued in Johnson County after over 3 hours of heavy rain fell across mainly the southern half of the county. The area around Rio Vista was one of the hardest areas impacted after a tornadic supercell stalled over that part of the county for over 3 hours. Several swift water rescues were still ongoing hours after the rainfall ended. Low lying areas and roads were flooded for over a day after the heavy rain event. One deputy was treated for minor injuries when his patrol car became trapped in high water.
The South Sulphur River bridge at FM118 collapsed.
Some roads in south Olney were closed due to high water.
Numerous roads were closed in and around Crockett.
Amateur radio reported that high water rescues were occurring on Poplar St in Bonham, TX.
A social media report stated that flooding was occurring on Highway 75 near exit 51 in Van Alstyne, TX.
Reports came in of multiple streets being under at least a foot of fast-rising water in the Arlington Heights neighborhood.
One house was reported to have minor flooding on property, and Pecan Creek had overflowed 1 to 1.5 feet of water over several roadways.
There were flooded and impassable roadways, with a few flooded vehicles, around town. A local rain gauge at Spindletop Bayou near Winnie reported 6.89 inches of rainfall.
Roads were flooded between the Navasota and Shiro areas, including the intersection of FM 302 and FM 362, FM 234, and parts of Highway 6 south of Navasota.
Street flooding was reported in and around the Brenham area.
Street flooding was reported in and around Columbus, including Fannin Street that was closed due to high water.
Young County Sheriff's Department reported water over Hwy 380 west of Newcastle, TX.
The Denton County Sheriff's Department reported that 2 to 3 feet of water on the highway forced the temporary closure of Interstate 35 just north of Denton, TX.
The Alvord Fire Department reported that CR 2690 in Alvord, TX is being closed due to high water.
A social media report indicated high water across a driveway in Boyd, TX.
Amateur radio reported that several intersections in the town of Whitewright, TX  were flooded.
Amateur radio reported that 6 to 8 inches of water covered U.S. Highway 82 in central Fannin County.
Amateur radio reported that CR 36650 and FM 197 were both closed due to high water. Other county roads across the northern portions of the county also had to be barricaded.

A 36 year old man died when his vehicle was swept away by flood waters three-quarters of a mile south of Spring Creek Road, north of Valley View, TX. A little while later, Interstate 35 north of Valley View had to be closed due to high water. Several vehicles had stalled in the high water on the interstate.
Amateur radio reported that high water rescues were taking place in southwest portions of Denison, TX.
Emergency management reported that multiple high water rescues were ongoing.
Johnson County Emergency Management indicated that road closures included FM 916, FM 157, CR 505, CR 1205 and CR 1019 due to high water.
Many county roads remained closed due to flooding. The Sheriff's Office already reported a few structures were inundated.
Several roads remained closed due to flooding.
Streets were flooded from Crockett to Weldon, including FM 2110, portions of Highway 21 west, CR 3385 near Austonio, and portions of FM 3580.
Parts of FM 230 were flooded and closed.

Thunderstorms with heavy rain moved across Borden County in the morning hours and produced flash flooding.  The fire department reported more than six inches of water over FM 1785 about 15 miles south southeast of Gail.
Emergency management reported that the northbound ramp to Interstate 35 at FM 1858 was closed due to high water.
Several areas in mainly the southern half of Ennis County remained flooded. Law enforcement reported that residual flooding was still occurring on FM 985 at McCrady Rd.
Emergency management reported street flooding in Dawson, TX.
A public report stated that numerous cars were stalled along Business Highway 45 in Corsicana, TX.
Emergency management reported major flash flooding throughout the county. Most roads were under water.
A thunderstorm produced 6-12 inches of water over portions of Highway 84 in northwestern Scurry County about 2 miles southeast of the Scurry and Garza County line.
A thunderstorm that produced heavy rainfall caused FM 1269 from Fluvanna to the Garza County line and FM 612 from Fluvanna to 5 miles east of Fluvanna to be impassable due to high water.
A public report stated that water was up to the headlights of cars near the intersection of Hwy 360 and Mayfield Rd.
The Grand Prairie Fire Department reported that approximately 2.5 feet of water covered the area near the intersection of Hwy 360 and Claremont Dr.
