Due to record pool levels in Barker Reservoir, homes in Cinco Ranch flooded. Big Creek flooding in Needville caused the flooding of homes on Ansel Road.
County roads 283, 284, 401, and 127 north of the town of Edna were inundated with flood waters.

Numerous roads closed due to flooding including but not limited to FM109, FM 331, FM 2429, FM 1093 and SH 36. Moderate, yet record, flooding along the Brazos at San|Felipe caused several homes to flood along FM 1458. Inundation ranged from 4 to 7 feet of water. Minimal impacts were observed at Mill creek near Bellville. No impacts were observed from the minor flooding at the Brazos river near Hempstead.

Slow moving Tropical Storm Harvey produced very heavy rainfall and flooding over portions of San Jacinto County. Major lowland flooding occurred near the Trinity River and areas below Lake Livingston. There was a report of high water closing Marie Street in Shepherd with numerous reports of other flooded roadways around the county. Many roads and homes along the southern end of Lake Livingston were inundated. FM 3278 was inaccessible due to the inundation of flood waters. Major lowland flooding occurred on the Trinity River near Goodrich. Hundreds to thousands of homes received various levels of damage from flooding; from minor to being completely destroyed.There were 3 fatalities, all direct.

Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Harvey caused major flooding around the county. At one time, 140 roads were closed the most ever recorded. The emergency manager estimated that 75% of the county's roads were damaged by flooding. The cost of the damage to roads and dams was estimated at $10 million. There were 18 homes destroyed and another 198 damaged by flood water with a total cost of $2.85 million.

The largest impact across Lee County with Harvey was the rainfall where as much as 20 inches fell near Giddings.  The southern half of the county experienced the worst flooding with 25 homes being impacted, many of those having experienced major damage.  The tropical storm force winds did bring some trees down across the county.  Damage from the flooding is estimated to be near 250K dollars.
Flooding occurred over Texas Roads 61 and 65 just east of Anahuac.
Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Harvey produced flash flooding leading to a swift water rescue in Smithville.

There were numerous water rescues within Houston and the surrounding suburbs. Flash flood waters, from sheet flooding and bayous/creeks coming out of banks, completely inundated hundreds to thousands of homes and businesses. Roads and highways in and around Houston were flooded and therefore closed for long time periods.||Catastrophic flooding occurred on nearly every one of the 22 watersheds in Harris County. 10 out of the 19 bayous in the county reached record crests and flooding. There was widespread flooding along Buffalo Bayou and upstream and downstream of both Addicks and Barkers Reservoirs due to record level pool elevations. There was major flooding of hundreds of homes within numerous neighboring subdivisions along the San Jacinto River and the East Fork of the San Jacinto River. Lake Conroe's releases and backwater flow from Lake Houston also contributed to the widespread flooding across the northern and northeastern sectors of the county.

Multiple lanes of Highway 290 at the FM 2920 intersection near the town of Waller were closed due to flooding.||In the southern part of the county, sections of FM 3318 near the Brazos River flooded and became inaccessible. There was significant countywide home flooding along the various creeks/bayous and their tributaries.

FM 1960 at Interstate 45 and surrounding roadways within local neighborhoods were inundated with flood waters and impassable.||Catastrophic flooding occurred on nearly every one of the 22 watersheds in Harris County. 10 out of the 19 bayous in the county reached record crests and flooding. There was widespread flooding along Buffalo Bayou and upstream and downstream of both Addicks and Barkers Reservoirs due to record level pool elevations. There was major flooding of hundreds of homes within numerous neighboring subdivisions along the San Jacinto River and the East Fork of the San Jacinto River. There were numerous water rescues within Houston and the surrounding suburbs. Flood waters completely inundated thousands of homes and businesses. Catastrophic flooding occurred on nearly every one of the 22 watersheds in Harris County. 10 out of the 19 bayous in the county reached record crests and flooding. Roads and highways in and around Houston inundated and closed due to flash flooding. ||Some of the reported flooded roads in Pasadena were Vista Street, Shafer Street, Fairmont Drive and Strawberry Road.
Flooding being reported in or within homes in Missouri City with water rescues being conducted off of the Westpark Tollway in the Jeanetta Sharpstown area.
Sections of Interstate 10 west of Winnie were inundated and closed due to high flood waters.
Flash flooding from Huntsville to New Waverly. Road closures include Bowers, Bearkat, Cotton and Podraza Roads.  Also FM 1374.
Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Harvey produced flash flooding closing numerous roads in the county including sections of Hwy 71.
Flash flooding closed sections of FM 949 just off of Interstate 10.

There were numerous water rescues within the county; from Pearland down to the Angleton-Lake Jackson area. Flash flood waters, from sheet flooding and bayous/creeks coming out of banks, completely inundated hundreds to thousands of homes and businesses. Roads and highways in and along the Highway 288 corridor were flooded and therefore closed for long time periods.||Major record flooding of the Brazos, San Bernard and Oyster Creek caused the flooding of hundreds to thousands of vicinity homes, vehicles and businesses.  Numerous Roads and homes were inundated with flood waters on east side of Oyster Creek including the  Columbia Lakes, Mallard Lakes, Great Lakes, Riverside Estates and Bar X subdivisions as well as homes along CR 39. Other county roads that became impassable due to high flood waters include, but are not limited to, FM 1462, Highways 35 and 90, FM 950, CR 25, 380A, CR 42 and FM 521. The Phillips refinery outside of the town of Sweeny took on water from the west near Little Linville Bayou. Hanson Riverside County Park along the San Bernard River southwest of West Columbia was inundated and water over-topped the Phillips Terminal.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding around Stevens High School on the far west side of San Antonio.
Law enforcement reported water over Old Sour Lake Road.

Record river stages were observed along Pine Island Bayou and the lower Neches during Harvey. This kept lower sections of Jefferson County flooded into early September which included some river side refineries. The high stream flow in the Neches at Beaumont caused an under water natural gas pipeline to rupture. The river also caused a lot of erosion.

Widespread and long duration rainfall produced a storm total rainfall over 40 inches across a large portion of the county. The highest rainfall totals in Jefferson County were 60.58 inches 1.5 mile southwest of Nederland and 60.54 inches 1.3 mile north of Groves. This resulted in over 64,000 homes being flooded. The hardest hit areas were Port Arthur, Groves, Bevil Oaks, Hamphire, Fannet, China, and northeast Beaumont.  Several refineries in the county also received floodwaters and were offline for an extended period. City and county infrastructure was also damaged with water pumps and treatment plants being inundated. Record crests were observed along Pine Island and the lower Neches. 5 deaths were reported by flooding.
River levels hit record levels along the lower Neches and the Sabine hit the 2nd highest stage at Orange. This kept water in sections of Orange County into early September.

Widespread 20 to 40 inches fell across the county which resulted in near 10,000 homes being flooded. Worst hit areas were around Lumberton, Silsbee, Sour Lake, and Kountze. Record flooding occurred on Pine Island Bayou and Village Creek. The second highest crest of the Neches occurred at Evadale. The US Highway 96 bridge near Silsbee collapsed due to the current.

Widespread 30 to 50 inches of rainfall fell across Orange County during Harvey. This resulted in 27,742 homes being flooded. The hardest hit areas were Orange, Vidor, Orangefield, Pine Forest, West Orange, Rose City, Mauriceville, Rose City, and Lake View. Record crests occurred on the lower Neches and Cow Bayou. The Sabine River was at its highest level since Hurricane Ike in 2008. Water covered and closed portions of Interstate 10 in the county. Only 1 home was reported not flooded in Rose City and the community's drinking water was interrupted for near a month. 10 people perished during the event with 2 of them being from electrocution in a flooded home.

Harvey produced 20 to 30 inches of rain which flooded 1,730 homes. Major flooding occurred  in Warren, Fred, and along the Neches River where it had the 4th highest crest at Town Bluff. 1 death was a result of the flooding.

Harvey produced 20 to 40 inches of rain across a large portion of Jasper County. This resulted in over 4,000 homes being flooded. Worst hit areas were Kirbyville, Buna, and Weiss Bluff. The Neches River had its second highest crest at Evadale.

Harvey produced 20 to 40 inches of rain across a large portion of the Newton County. This resulted in near 2,000 homes being flooded. Hardest hit areas were Trout Creek, Call, and along Big Cow Creek and the Sabine River. The Sabine River reached its 3rd, 4th, and 5th highest crests at Deweyville, Bon Weir, and Burkville respectively.
Heavy rain caused water to flow across FM 1003 in several locations closing the roadway for a period.
A report was received of near 12 inches of flowing water across Highway 509 northwest of Kirbyville after heavy rain.
Five inches of rain during the morning of the 10th flooded some roadways north of Silsbee including Craven Camp Road and Turtle Drive.
Fannin County Sheriff's Department reported that FM 100 at Bois D'Arc Creek was closed due to flooding from the past few days of rain.
Emergency management reported multiple water rescues near the intersection of Jeanette Way and North Denton Dr in the city of Carrollton, TX.
Carrollton Police Department reported that Luna Rd south of Belt Line Rd was closed due to flooding.
High water on FM 1254 northeast of Mineola.
A vehicle was washed off of County Road 4115 off of FM 990 southeast of Dekalb.
Highway 37 closed between Bogota and Hagansport due to flooding.
FM 1818 was closed due to a washout on the southbound side between FM 844 and US Highway 69 South. Report from TXDOT Twitter page.
Water covered numerous roadways across much of Red River County.
Many low lying, poor drainage areas were flooded across Franklin County.
High water over multiple roads between Hemphill and Jasper.
FM 1487 closed from the Maple community to County Road 412 due to flooding.
FM 83 was closed between Highway 96 and FM 1 in Pineland.

Widespread heavy rainfall of eight to ten inches across the Sabine River basin of Northeast Texas during the final week of February resulted in rapid rises on the Sabine River south of Mineola, with the river cresting at 18.69 feet during the evening hours on February 27th. This resulted in moderate backwater flooding along the river, inundating some barns and secondary roads including FM 1804 in Southern Wood and Northern Smith Counties.
Extensive flooding reported over central parts of the county, especially near Buffalo Creek.
Several roadways across the city of Corpus Christi were flooded due to heavy rainfall.

Pictures on social media indicated standing water and stalled cars along Jimmy Johnson Blvd shortly after 6 AM. Heavy rain continued with one rain gauge reporting 10.18 inches in Groves and another reporting 7.68 inches in Hampshire. Many streets were flooded during the event with numerous homes becoming flooded in Port Acres where some were being remodeled from flooding due to Harvey.

High water flowing over FM 1804 along the Wood/Smith County line due to backwater flooding on the Sabine River from periods of moderate to heavy rainfall across the Sabine River Basin. Road is closed.
Texas Department of Highways reported high water covering three lanes of loop 12 near the intersection of Highway 183.
A trained spotter reported high water in east Sachse and south Wylie.

Highway 37 was closed at the Sulphur River bridge along the Franklin/Red River County line due to a prolonged period of moderate to heavy rainfall across the basin which led to rapid rises on the Sulphur River and extensive backwater flooding.

Widespread heavy rainfall of ten to in excess of twelve inches across the Sulphur River basin of Northeast Texas during the final week of February resulted in rapid rises on the Sulphur River north of Talco, with the river cresting at 26.81 feet during the early evening hours on February 22nd. This resulted in major backwater flooding along the river, with numerous secondary roads (and State Highway 37) flooded across Southern Red River and Northern Franklin Counties.

Widespread heavy rainfall of ten to in excess of twelve inches across the Sulphur River basin of Northeast Texas during the final week of February resulted in rapid rises on the Sulphur River north of Talco, with the river cresting at 26.81 feet during the early evening hours on February 22nd. This resulted in major backwater flooding along the river, with numerous secondary roads (including State Highway 37) flooded across Southern Red River and Northern Franklin Counties.

High water flowing over FM 1804 along the Wood/Smith County line due to backwater flooding on the Sabine River from periods of moderate to heavy rainfall across the Sabine River Basin. Road is closed.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. BEXARFLOOD.ORG reported 25 roads closed on the north side of San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending water over the roadway at the intersection of S. LBJ Dr. and the I-35 Frontage Road, on Guadalupe St., and on Sessom Dr. in San Marcos.
A thunderstorm produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring a water rescue near the intersection of Westcreek Oaks Dr. and Military Dr. W. on the far west side San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring a water rescue near the intersection of Chula Vista Dr. and San Pedro Ave. just of east of Hwy 281 in Hollywood Park.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring a water rescue at Loop 1604 and Green Mountain Rd. on the far northeast side of San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding with residents evacuated from an apartment complex on Nacogdoches Rd. in far northwest San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring a water rescue at I-35 and N. Weidner Rd. in northeast San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring a water rescue at the intersection of Hwy 281 and Loop 1604 on the far north side of San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring a water rescue at I-35 and Thousand Oaks in northeastern San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing the lower level of I-35 between Alamo St. and Guadalupe St. in downtown San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to street flooding in the Hyde Park neighborhood of Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Lakeline Blvd. between Little Elm Tr. and Old Mill Rd. in Cedar Park.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous low water crossings in Williamson County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous roads in Kyle.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous low water crossings in Austin and Travis County.
Farm to Market Road 410 near and south of County Road 1119 was closed due to flooding.
Farm to Market Road 909 north of County Road 1487 was closed due to flooding.
High water was reported on Tom Holland Road near FM 1475.

Moderate flooding continued along the Sabine River south of Mineola as a result of heavy rains that fell across the Sabine basin during the final week of February, with additional rains on March 1st contributing to a secondary crest of 18.83 feet during the late evening hours of March 2nd.  Thus, moderate backwater flooding continued along the river, inundating some barns and secondary roads including FM 1804 in Southern Wood and Northern Smith Counties until the river receded below moderate flood stage by the second week of March.

Moderate flooding continued along the Sabine River south of Mineola as a result of heavy rains that fell across the Sabine basin during the final week of February, with additional rains on March 1st contributing to a secondary crest of 18.83 feet during the late evening hours of March 2nd.  Thus, moderate backwater flooding continued along the river, inundating some barns and secondary roads including FM 1804 in Southern Wood and Northern Smith Counties until the river receded below moderate flood stage by the second week of March.
Heavy Rain produced street flooding in Woodville, Town Bluff, and Newton.
Street flooding resulted from several inches of heavy rain. Some roads became impassable for a period.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous roads and requiring high water rescues across Bexar County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous roads across Medina County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous roads in Williamson County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous low water crossings in the San Marcos and Kyle areas.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous roads in Caldwell County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple low water crossings west of Seguin especially along Alligator Creek.
Approximately twenty-five roads were flooded across the county.
FM 247 near Nelson Creek was impassable.

Major flooding continued along the Nueces River due to releases from Lake Corpus Christi. Major lowland flooding occurred from Blutzer to near Calallen. Widespread residential flooding occurred for days. This included homes in the Sandy Hollow, Los Escondidos, and Rio Encinos subdivisions.
Major flooding continued along the Nueces River due to releases from Lake Corpus Christi.
Emergency management reported a water rescue ongoing near the city of Venus, TX.
Emergency management reported a vehicle swept off Dagnan Road by flash flood waters.
Grayson County Sheriff's Department reported flooding across 8 major FM roads and 30 county roads, with 2 people being rescued from a stranded vehicle near the city of Bonham, TX.
Emergency management reported that several intersections were blocked due to high water, and one house was flooded near the 100 block of Stuart Street.
A social media report indicated several feet of water near the intersection of Sheffield Dr and Astoria Dr in the city of Arlington, TX.
Broadcast media reported motorists being stranded near the intersection of Highway 103 and Park Spring Blvd.
Fire and rescue reported a car being swept away, resulting in a drowning, on South Cravens Rd between Baylor Street and Good Shepherd Way.

Broadcast media reported a car being swept off of the road by flood waters near the intersection of the Loop 820 access road and Wilbarger Street, resulting in the drownings of a young woman and her daughter.
Emergency management reported that several roads in northwest Cooke County have over 6 inches of water running over them.
Emergency management reported stranded cars on Old Alton Road and water rescues on Cooper Canyon Road near the city of Argyle, TX.
Emergency management reported the closure of Jackson Road at Hickory Creek due to flash flooding.
Emergency management reported that Hickory Road at FM 1173, northwest of the city of Krum, TX,  was closed due to high water.
Broadcast media reported that U.S. Highway 75 in Plano was shut down due to high water, with several vehicles stranded.
Emergency management reported Flash Flooding ongoing on several roads in Southlake, TX, including a water rescue at Canyon Park and Dove Road.

Emergency management reported flash flooding ongoing on Bridlewood Blvd. Also, stranded vehicles were reported near the intersection of FM 407 and Chin Chapel Rd, as well as Lusk Lane at Shiloh Rd in the city of Flower Mound TX.
Emergency management reported multiple road closures in the city of Richardson, TX due to flash flooding.
A social media report indicated that Interstate 35E was shut down near the intersection of State School Rd due to high water.
Emergency management reported 2 housed being flooded in the city of Argyle, TX.
A social media report indicated that Southlake Fire and Rescue was on the scene of a water rescue at the 3900 block of North White Chapel Blvd.
Emergency management reported that high water was surrounding homes near Rippy Rd and Bayberry Street in the city of Flower Mound, TX.
A social media report indicated that a swift water rescue was ongoing in the Doug Russell Park area near the intersection of Cooper St and Mitchell St in the city of Arlington, TX.
A social media report indicated that Loop 820 at Forest Hill Dr was shut down due to high water.
A social media report indicated that Loop 820 at Berry St in the city of Fort Worth, TX was closed in both directions due to high water.
Broadcast media reported that a man drowned after being swept away by high water on the west side of the University of Texas Arlington campus.
There was flooding along the Gulf Freeway-Interstate 45 that closed sections of the freeway between the FM 518 and Highway 96 exits.
There was a road closure near the intersection of Highway 59 and the 540 Loop in Beasley.
TxDOT reported via Twitter that vehicles were stranded in high water at the Frank Street Underpass as well as in between Timberland Drive and Denman Avenue in Lufkin.

Heavy rain fell across Pecos County and produced flash flooding 29 miles west of Fort Stockton. There was a high water rescue on the service road along I-10 at mile marker 229. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Pecos County and produced flash flooding eight miles southeast of Fort Stockton. At least one foot of water was running over US Highway 285. No damage was reported.
Heavy rain fell across Pecos County and produced flash flooding near Coyanosa. Water up to two feet deep was reported east of FM 1776 on and along FM 1450. No damage was reported.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding across the City of Midland. Flooding was reported over roads and up into sidewalks and front yards at the intersection of Midkiff Road and Neely Avenue and across towards Garfield Street. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

An NWS cooperative weather observer reported extensive flooding on his property with water threatening to enter his residence. The cooperative weather observer recorded 4.48 inches of rainfall with radar estimates between four and five inches. Radar rainfall estimates were between five and six inches only a few miles east of the observer's location.
Heavy rain produced flash flooding in Odessa. Curb to curb flooding was reported along US Highway 385 just north of 31st Street and surrounding areas.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. Multiple vehicles were stranded at various intersections along Wadley Avenue. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Significant flooding in and around Panhandle. Broadway from 1st to Elsie is impassible.  207 from 5th to the high school is impassible.  One to two feet of water over the roadways.

Heavy rain fell across Pecos County and produced flash flooding near Imperial. Water runoff from heavy rains had forced the closure of FM 1053 south of Imperial between FM 11 and FM 1450. It was reported that the road will be closed until damage assessments and repairs can be made. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. High water was reported over Highway 191 at Loop 250. No damages were reported.
Heavy rain fell across Midland and Ector Counties and produced flash flooding. FM 588/Faudree Road was reported to be under water with flooding over the curbs. No damage was reported.

Nearly four inches of rain fell in one hour in east Harlingen, causing varying amounts of flooding through the city.  2 to an estimated 3 feet of water piled up along some roads, including enough to flood an indoor garage at Harlingen/Valley International Airport.  Damage amounts were unknown as most of the flooding was high water on roads, though some vehicles were inundated.
Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding. Service roads were impassable at I-20 and Loop 338 E. There were stranded vehicles. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Martin County and produced flash flooding near Lenorah. Water was running over Highway 137, five miles north of Highway 176. No damage was reported.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. There were numerous road closures and stalled vehicles reported throughout the City of Midland. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa. Numerous road closures and stalled vehicles were reported across various portions of the City of Odessa. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding. This flooding caused road closures of the I-20 service road near Cotton Flat, the Lamesa Road overpass and north service road eastbound lane, and FM 307 at I-20 due to road damage. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Reagan County and produced flash flooding north of Big Lake. There was significant flooding on State Highway 137 north of Big Lake. Vehicles were stalled and water was running in the bar ditches and pastures. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Emergency management reported five cars stranded in high water near the intersection of Windhaven Parkway and Old Denton Road.
A trained spotter reported high water near the intersection of Meandering Way and Spring Valley Road, causing a closure of the road.
A trained spotter reported water up to car doors on Interstate 35 East at Dallas North Tollway.
A social media report indicated stranded vehicles on Green Oaks Blvd near River Legacy Park.
The Abilene police department reported 10 high water rescues that continued until midnight. Several low water crossings were also closed and watered entered one home.
Heavy rain allowed for water to fill over the roadways.
Vehicle stalled in flood water in knox city.
Flooding was reported between McRae and Wedgewood starting around 720pm.  A water rescue was necessary on Bywood Drive between Eads and Fierro near Eastwood Middle School.
Heavy rain fell across Winkler County and produced flash flooding in Kermit. There was water up to the car doors on roads in Kermit.
Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa. Water almost made it into the homes on Center Avenue in Odessa. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
One foot of water flowing over some city streets. Report by city official.
A social media report indicated flooded vehicles stranded near the intersection of Anderson Avenue and Loop 12 in the city of Dallas, TX.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several low water crossings in northwestern Bexar County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several roads in and around Leon Valley.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple low water crossings along FM 1340 west of Hunt along the North Fork of the Guadalupe River.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 337 near Camp Wood Creek between Camp Wood and Leakey.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 41 from RM 336 to Hwy 83.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 55 between Rocksprings and Barksdale.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 377 south of Rocksprings to Hwy 277.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RM 335 from Hwy 41 to the Real County Line along Hackberry Creek.
Intermittent flash flooding was reported around the University of Houston - Clear Lake campus.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Bandera Creek Rd. was washed out at West Verde Creek in the Hill Country State Natural Area.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Hondo Creek flooded FM 462 north of Hondo. FM 463 was also flooded at Twin Hollow Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Lehman Rd. south was flooded at Masonwood Dr. in Kyle.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The Blanco River flooded Wayside Dr. southwest of Wimberley.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The low water crossing near Helotes Creek at FM 1560 and Parrigin Rd. in Helotes was flooded up to the three foot marker.

More than sixty people had to be rescued from the Casa Rio Del Colores wedding venue as a large wedding party got trapped from quickly rising waters along the South Fork of the San Gabriel River just south of Liberty Hill.  Multiple cars were flooded and inundated.
Williamson County officials reported multiple flooded roads across the eastern sections of Williamson County especially around and just south of Taylor.
Williamson County officials reported multiple roads closed due to flooding across the eastern half of the county.
Six inches of water were over roadways to the southeast of Liberty around the Pignut Gully, Shiloh Creek and FM 770 areas.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Privilege Creek flooded Privilege Creek Rd. sending nine inches of water over the road northwest of Pipe Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Parts of Hwy 16 and Hwy 173 were closed near Bandera due to water over the road.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several roads in and around Coupland.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several roads in and around Taylor.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several low water crossings on CR 330 were flooded along the South Fork of the San Gabriel River southwest of Bertram.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Park Rd. 37 was closed due to high water in a few locations northeast of Lakehills.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads in the northwestern part of Bexar County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several county roads in the southern half of the county.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several low water crossings across the north central and northwestern part of the county.

There were several RVs that were flooded along the Medina River in the Medina River RV Park as the water rose after a night and morning of heavy rain upstream.  Over 20 people were rescued from their RVs as they became trapped when the river rose above banks and flooded the RV park.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding of the Nueces River. The river flooded Hwy 55 near Montell.

Web cameras showed portions of Highway 288 South going under water. Two lanes on I-10 at the 610 Loop were flooded on the west side of Houston. Reports of high water and impassable roadways around NRG Stadium. An underpass at Washington Avenue and Katy Freeway was impassable due to flood waters with significant flooding reported at Highway 290 and Hollister Street.  There was several inches of water in a church near Melrose Park, and there was water in three homes in Spring.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Multiple low water crossings on River Rd. were flooded by the Frio River near Concan.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads around Uvalde including Hwy 55.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing 43 roads across the city of San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending Rocky Creek over Old Castroville Rd. near the northern end of Medina Lake.
High water was reported across Highway 69 south between Huntington and Zavalla.
An amateur radio operator reported flash flooding at the intersection of College Hills Road and Trinity Avenue.
The Abilene Police Department reported street flooding in the area around the Mall of Abilene and south to the Buttonwillow area.
Homes flooded in low-lying portion of Buena Vista neighborhood including Courchesne Rd. Drainage may have been compromised by nearby construction.
Flooding reported off of I-10 on Gateway West and Geronimo in central El Paso.
NW Borger had approximately 6 inches of running water in flood prone roadways around 730 PM.  The water quickly drained off and closed roads were reopened by 750 PM.
Street flooding near and around the intersection of 45th and Western.
Street flooding at the intersection of 34th and Western.
Street flooding reported near 45th and Washington St.
Rushing water caused a rock wall to collapse just east of Suncrest Drive, north of Wallenberg Drive. Swift water then rushed down south Mesa Hills Dr nearby.

Slow moving thunderstorm clusters dumped torrential rains over and near Rio Grande City during the early to mid evening of May 4th, with storm totals likely between 4 and 5 inches across the area.  A combination of reports from law enforcement, emergency management, and social media indicated dangerous flooding in parts of the city, with several water rescues and minor flooding reaching into several homes on the east side of town.  Social media photos and discussion reported a yard with 1 to 2 feet of water flowing through it at around 8 PM CST; water rescues from stranded vehicles were reported along US 83 on the east side of town at around 8:55 PM CST, and another vehicle was reported stranded in floodwaters at the intersection of Flores and Monroe Street, also on the east side of town.  The NWS cooperative observer reported 4.28 inches with the event, most falling within two to three hours.
A storm chaser reported water flowing across Farm to Market Road 658 south of US Highway 287.
Water standing over roadways and streets.  Bar ditches overflowing. Intersections flooded with water 6 to 8 inches deep.
Water has filled the bar ditches and is flowing over the road about 1 to 2 inches.
Flowing water was reported over several sections of FM Road 834 northwest of Spur.  The road was temporarily closed overnight until flooding receded.
Highway 70 between Jayton and Spur was impassable due to mud and debris flows from floodwaters.

Torrential rain resulted in flowing water across US Highway 82 in far western Crosby County and disrupted travel for nearly one hour.  Radar indicated a maximum of four inches of rain fell in nearby eastern Crosby County, but no reports of flooding were available in this area.
An amateur radio operator reported that water was over the road at 29th Street near Kirby Park.

An amateur radio operator reported two feet of water over the road on Jackson Street near Angelo State University. Roads were blocked due to high water on Knickerbocker Road near Jackson Street. In addition, six inches of water was reported over the road at College Hills and Millsbrook.
The San Angelo Police Department reported swift water rescues across the city of San Angelo.
Several roads in the Magnolia and Stagecoach areas became impassable due to high water. Several water rescues were made from stalled vehicles.
Heavy rainfall producing localized street flooding.
Street flooding reported.
An amateur radio operator reported a flooded low water crossing on Southwest Boulevard by Loop 306.

Many rural roads in southeast Terry County were flooded following two to six inches of rain that fell in the span of two hours.  Thick mud deposits were commonplace and required removal in the following days.
Water was over the road at Highway 281 and Jentsch Rd.
Minor street flooding in Pampa.
Flooding reported by an amateur radio operator at a low water crossing at Sunset Drive near the Red Arroyo.
An amateur radio operator reported street flooding along Forest Park Avenue.  About 1.8 inches of rainfall was measured at The Bluffs.
Eight inches of water reported over FM 263 and FM 1594.
Four to six inches of water over roadway.
Streets flooded and vehicles stranded in high water.

Heavy rains of 8 to more than 14 inches (estimated) across northern Brooks, northeastern Jim Hogg, eastern Duval, and much of Jim Wells County allowed substantial water flows into the riverine system of creeks, including Los Olmos, Palo Blanco, and Cibolo. Each creek flowed outside of its banks during and well after the heaviest rains fell, for much of June 19th and June 20th before waters receded below bank full. At Los Olmos Creek along the Brooks/Jim Wells County line, the gage reached flood stage (11 feet) around 4 PM CST on the 19th, and continued to moderate levels (12 feet) shortly after 6 PM. The creek would remain in moderate flood for a few hours, before dipping below 12 feet at around 9 PM CST.  Slower recession brought the stage below 11 feet by early evening on the 20th. ||The peak stage at 12.32 feet ended up being the third highest on record, with only values associated with locally heavy rainfall in late August 1967 and the remnants of Hurricane Fern in September 1971 at higher levels. ||Impacts included lowland flooding between 300 and 700 feet into the flood plain, as well as high enough flow to close several farm to market roads on the east side of Falfurrias. Flooding of the Cibolo/Palo Blanco system aggravated high water from the rainfall alone that created initial flash flooding in the area earlier on June 19th.

Heavy rainfall measured and estimated between 4 and 7 inches in a general 3 to 4 hour period produced flash flooding, mainly in the east half of McAllen stretching east to the Donna area, mostly during the pre-dawn hours through a bit after daybreak on June 20th.  Between 2 and 4 feet of inundation was reported by law enforcement where the heaviest rains fell and combined with known poor drainage.  The frontage road between McAllen and Donna was closed in most spots during and just after the peak of the rainfall and during the early morning commute.  Several hundred homes and hundreds of vehicles received some level of flooding.

Numerous roads were closed in Beaumont, Groves, and Port Arthur due to flooding including underpasses which had up to 5 feet of water. Photos also indicated water levels approached some structures. Rainfall reports from DD6 recorded 4 to 8 inches, however radar estimates indicated some areas in the city my have received around 9 inches during the morning.

One day after 3 to more than 5 inches fell between Brownsville and Los Fresnos during the afternoon and early evening hours, a repeat event occurred, fed by deep tropical moisture and multiple boundaries left behind from devastating morning flooding across western Cameron and eastern Hidalgo County.  A persistent line of torrential rainfall dominated through the early evening commute, with another 3 to 6 inches having fallen for a two-day total of 6 to 11+ inches.  The second day rainfall produced more widespread flooding across locations in and east of Brownsville and Los Fresnos, with farm and subdivisions under 2 to 3+ feet of water when all was said and done. ||The additional flooding on saturated soils (pump priming from June 19) likely produced more damage this second go-round, including more erosion to drainage canals/ditches and mainly rural roads.  Doubling of the damage left a total of around $20 million.

The Roma Fire Department reported that Arroyo Roma exceeded its banks, flooding parts of town with 1 to 3 feet of standing and flowing water during the pre-dawn hours of June 21st, 2018.  The flooding was associated with the initiation of a thunderstorm system that would later cause significant flooding in western Hidalgo County, including the McAllen/Mission metropolitan region during the daylight hours later that morning. Measured and estimated rainfall was between 3 and 7 inches across southern and central Starr County.  Estimated public damage, along with a standard doubling, left nearly $3 million in property and other damage (estimated).

An additional 1 to 2.5 inches of rain fell over already flooded neighborhoods in the McAllen/Mission area early on June 22, exacerbating already dangerous conditions from prior flooding on June 20th and 21st.  Neighborhoods in the south and west side of McAllen that had a foot or more of water depth temporarily saw levels rise higher during the peak of the heavy rainfall, which fell for an hour or two during the pre-dawn hours.  Additional damage was unknown from the prior estimates.

A band of thunderstorms, moving slowly from west to east, intersected the sea breeze and stalled between Brownsville and Los Fresnos, dumping 3 to 5 or more inches of rainfall in a 2 to 3 hour period, causing significant street flooding and some road closures. Flood prone roads, including Morrison Blvd. in north Brownsville was closed due to 3 feet of water; Dennet road nearby was also covered in 2 to 3 feet of water. Other roads between North Brownsville and Los Fresnos were flooded with an unknown amount of water depth.  Several to dozens of vehicles were flooded, with damage unknown as of this writing.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Based on radar estimates, 8-11 inches of rain fell in a three hour period across northwestern Uvalde County. Many low water crossings flooded across this area, and Highway 55 was closed from Uvalde to Camp Wood. A flood wave traveled down the Nueces River and through the Chalk Bluff camp ground. Several people from the camp ground became stranded in trees and on roof tops of vehicles, and some were reported swept downstream. Twenty-seven people were successfully rescued from the flood waters by boats and helicopter. One person was treated for a head injury and two children were treated for hypothermia.  Estimated monetary loss of one hundred thousand dollars based on flooded cars and trailers that were lost downstream.

Heavy rainfall measured and estimated between 7 and 18 inches in a 3 to 5 hour period produced locally devastating flooding in Weslaco and Mercedes, just north of the expressway.  Measured rainfall at the Weslaco Cooperative station was 15.57 inches for the event, with 11.36 of it falling in a three hour period generally between 3 AM CST and 6 AM CST.  Radar estimates suggested higher amounts at the Las Brisas and other neighborhoods in northeast Weslaco, where nearly all homes had 18 inches of water depth or higher inside.  ||The rain flooded (at least 18 inches) 2500 homes in Weslaco, with an unknown number (but likely in the 1,000 range) in next-door Mercedes.  Video, photograph, and first response/law enforcement evidence showed widespread 2 to 4 feet of water depth, with a few poorly draining areas in east Weslaco and Mercedes of at least 5 feet of water depth.  An unknown number of vehicles were flooded throughout the area, and the Interstate 2 frontage road was closed through most of the morning.  Eighty-six of the eighty-nine school buses in the Weslaco Independent School District sustained significant flood damage. ||Publicly reported damage was estimated to be at least $12.5 million; standard doubling estimated the damage at $25 million though in reality, values could be much higher due to poor measurement due to the volume of uninsured properties that were impacted.  The rainfall in the east/north side of Weslaco was the highest on record (since 1910) for a single event, besting the Labor Day 1933 Hurricane (15 inches).

The same clusters of thunderstorms that dropped between 12 and an estimated 18 inches in the Weslaco/Mercedes area early on June 20th dropped an estimated 5 to 10 inches on central through northeastern Willacy County (primary population areas), including a number of farm fields (agricultural damage unknown).  Final damage totals from initial emergency management surveys of public damage were nearly three-quarter of a million dollars, with standard doubling estimating the value at just over $1.5 million.

Major street flooding in Stinnett. One foot of fast flowing water over some roads in town with water well up into residents yards. Rainfall of 1.53 in 40 minutes at nearby West Texas Mesonet site. Emergency manager reported water flowing into home with garage and utility rooms completely flooded.
Emergency management reported ongoing flash flooding with 2 stranded vehicles near the intersection of Josey Lane and Windhaven Parkway in The Colony.
Fire and Rescue reported flash flooding near the intersection of Sandy Lake Road and President George Bush Turnpike in the city of Carrollton, TX.
A social media report indicated vehicles stranded in high water on Las Colinas Blvd in the city of Las Colinas, TX.
A social media report indicated multiple vehicles stranded near the intersection of Highway 183 and Belt Line Road in the city of Irving, TX.
A social media report indicated 8 vehicles stranded on Walnut Hill Lane west of Interstate 35 in the city of Dallas, with fire and rescue assisting people from their cars.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were high water rescues and evacuations on Glass Canyon along Mud Creek just north of San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Cars were stranded in high water at I410 and NW Military Dr. in northern San Antonio. There were also dozens of other roads closed across the city.

Measured and estimated rainfall of between 7 and more than 12 inches in north central Brooks County from the pre-dawn hours through around noon on June 19th created high standing water in and around Falfurrias. More than a dozen roads in town were flooded, some with 2 to 3 feet of water depth, and a number of properties saw floodwater inside of them. Farther north, along US 281 but mainly in Jim Wells County, two to three feet of flowing water closed the highway for a time during the morning and early afternoon. Highest rainfall totals for the event included 12.1 inches at the NWS cooperative observing station 4 miles west of Falfurrias and 8 inches near the center of town.  Much of the flooding was the result of a combination of creeks, including Palo Blanco and Cibolo, overspilling their banks in nearby Jim Wells and Duval County, along with sheet flow from the same areas.  An unknown number of water rescues were conducted during the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
Road was impassible and closed due to 2 feet of rapidly running water across 1526 at a creek crossing.
Thunderstorms produced an estimated eight inches of rain that caused flash flooding. Water covered the road at Bitters Rd. and Hwy 281 in northern San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending two feet of water over a low water crossing on Cibolo Creek in Bulverde.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Multiple roads and low water crossing were flooded across north central San Antonio between I-410 and Loop 1604.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several roads around Sabinal were closed due to flooding along the Sabinal River including RM 187 and TX 127.
Cars flooded out due to running water over roadways in N Perryton. Three-quarters of a mile of us highway 83 covered with flowing water, and water making contact with Wright elementary school.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads in north central San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced eight to 10 inches of rain across the northern part of San Antonio that led to flash flooding. The San Antonio Fire Department reported 63 high water rescues across the city. Multiple roads and low water crossings and several area creeks were flooded.

State and local emergency management officials, as well as ground truth rainfall totals, reported widespread flooding in south-central Hidalgo County, focused on the Mission/Alton/West McAllen area as a firehose of thunderstorms persisted for more than five hours through the morning commute until around noon before finally dissipating. Estimated and measured rainfall for the event ranged from 6 to 11 inches, with periods of 2 to 3 inches per hour embedded during the heart of the morning commute.  Numerous roads, thousands of homes and vehicles (specific number unknown) were under a range of water depth, ranging from 18 inches to 3 to 4 feet in either poorly draining neighborhoods from the west half of McAllen through Mission.||A peak total rainfall of 18.31 inches fell in Mission for the combined events of June 20-22.  Estimated damage, using a combination of county-reported damage and standard doubling, was an estimated $22 million for this particular event.  Actual values may be much higher as data continues to come in throughout 2019.

Flooding was reported on the College of the Mainland campus. A few flooded residences had a half of a foot of water in them along Meadowlark Lane in western Texas City and western La Marque. There were numerous street flooding reports.
Some roads along Dickinson Bayou were flooded including Hughes Road.
Heavy rain flooded county and ranch roads about 2 miles southwest of Silver located in northwest Coke County.  A rainfall report of five inches was reported from a local resident.
Heavy rain fell across Scurry County and produced flash flooding in Snyder. The Snyder Fire Department confirmed that low water crossings were flooded and barricaded.
Large sections of Farm-to-Market Road 1057 were flowing with one to two feet of mud and water as documented by a video stringer with KVII-TV.
Heavy rain fell across Gaines County and produced flash flooding in Seagraves. Cars were flooded out at the intersection of US 385 and TX 83. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. Front Street was flooding between Marienfeld and Garfield streets in Midland. No damage was reported.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. Lots of streets in Midland were reported to be flooded with numerous stalled vehicles. Some of the flooded streets included Wadley, Garfield, and by the Midland Park Mall. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa. Motorists were stranded in Odessa. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding near FM 1051 and US Hwy 83 along the Nueces River near Concan.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding along Hwy 55 at the Nueces River and Indian Creek. Hwy 55 was closed between Uvalde and Camp Wood.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several roads in southern San Antonio. Road closures were reported on the bexarflood.org website.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing the low water crossing at Jungman Rd. and the Medina River outside of Lacoste.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing US Hwy 277 at Hamilton Ln. in Val Verde Park.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding with water rescues on Hwy 90 at Braddie Dr. in Del Rio.
High water levels on Lattas Creek caused flooding of Farm to Market Road 665 near Alice.
Flooding along Chocolate Swale and Sous Creek caused water to cover the roadways along Farm to Market Roads 629 and 1360 near Bonnie View and Farm to Market Road 1360 near Woodsboro.
Significant flooding of roadways occurred along Everhart Road near South Padre Island Drive.
Many roads around Woodsboro were flooded. Highway 77 between Woodsboro and Refugio had water over the roadway. Farm to Market Road 1360 was flooded between Woodsboro and Bonnie View.
Portions of Highway 183 north of Refugio had water over the roadway.
Manhole covers along several Alice streets came off due to excessive flooding. Numerous roads and intersections were closed in Alice. Portions of Business 281 were not passable.
TXDOT closed Farm to Market Road 1538 northwest of La Gloria due to water flooding the road.
Yorktown and Saratoga Boulevards between Staples Street and Cimarron Boulevard in south Corpus Christi became impassable with water over a foot in depth in places.
Staples Street was flooded between Holly Road and Williams Drive in Corpus Christi. Flooding also occurred near Morgan Avenue and Crosstown Expressway.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing roads in and around Round Mountain.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding washing away a vehicle near Cypress Creek. No injuries were reported.

Heavy rain to the northwest of Beeville in the watershed of Poesta Creek led to flooding in Beeville. Low lying areas along Poesta Creek were flooded with road closure barricades set up. Farm to Market Roads 673 and 351 were flooded. A few water rescues were conducted for people driving around barricades.
A vehicle was flooded and stranded at the intersection of FM 910 and College Ave. in Clarksville.
Water flooded the road on Farm to Market Road 1329 near Rios.
Many roads from around Alfred to near Orange Grove were closed due to flooding.
Significant street and road flooding occurred around Orange Grove.

Several high water rescues occurred in Corpus Christi near Interstate 37 and Corn Products Road. Occupants were standing on the roofs of vehicles. Water rescues were also done near Antelope Street and near Brownlee Boulevard.
Observer recorded 11 inches of rain. The heavy rainfall produced significant flooding of roads to the southwest of Premont.

Minor flooding of roadways continued over portions of Corpus Christi due to slow drainage of heavy rain. Flooding was reported on Leopard Street between Palm Drive and Port Avenue. Flooding occurred along Crosstown Expressway from Leopard to Agnes Streets. Flooding was reported at the intersection of South Padre Island Drive and Everhart Road.
Officials closed many roads in Premont due to flooding.

Cars stalled in high water across Port Aransas with several water rescues performed. Avenue A and Alister Street was under 3 feet of water. Snapchat Live map showed significant street flooding. Water reached several homes in Port Aransas.
Thunderstorms with heavy rain moved across Scurry County and produced flash flooding. One rancher lost 17 head of cattle in the flash flood. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain from thunderstorms fell across northeast Mitchell County and produced flash flooding. A pickup truck was found washed off the I-20 feeder road at North Fork Champion Creek. The water line on the bridge suggested the water was near 10 feet deep over the feeder road at one point. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Flooding closed Highway 188 between Interstate 37 to Highway 77 in Sinton.
Flooding caused multiple road closures near Odem. Farm to Market Road 234 was closed near intersections with County Roads 2015 and 2047.
Vehicles were stranded in water on Interstate 37 near Navigation Boulevard.
County roads were flooded and closed around Orange Grove.
Corpus Christi Police Department reported several roadways were flooded across the city.
Roads from Market Street to Key Allegro were closed due to water over the road in Rockport.
Water was over the road near Chocolate Swale and Farm to Market Road 136 southeast of Woodsboro.
Heavy rain fell in Mitchell County and produced street flooding in Colorado City.
Flooding occurred under the overpass of the Nueces River near Labonte Park.
Flood waters along San Fernando Creek covered County Road 101 near Farm to Market Road 70.
Underpasses flooded along MLK Blvd with at least one car stalled during the heavy rain event where near 8 inches fell.
Images posted to social media indicated water entered several structures in Bridge City and many streets were flooded south sections of Orange County.
Numerous streets were flooded in Port Arthur, Groves, and Central Gardens with several cars reported flooded.
Flooding of roads occurred in Aransas Pass with some of the roads impassable. One business and one home were infiltrated by water.
Road closure due to flooding occurred on County Road 406 near La Gloria.
Parts of South Padre Island Drive and Crosstown Expressway were closed due to high water across the roadway.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that caused flash flooding closing numerous county roads with water and debris.
There were 11 water rescues from vehicles stranded within the flood waters.
Various rural roads were closed due to flooding. These roads included SH 90 and FM 1452.
SH 90 was closed due to flooding near Bedias Creek and the Madison-Grimes County line.
Three water rescues were conducted from vehicles stranded within the flood waters.
There were flooded roadways that included Round Prairie Road and FM 2989.
There were flooded roadways in and around the town of Kurten that included FM 2038 and Democrat Road.
There were flooded roadways that were impassable near Burns Road and SH 21.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending water over the bridge on Creamer Creek Rd. southwest of LaGrange.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to minor flooding closing FM 154 northeast of Muldoon.
Emergency management reported various street closures due to flooding across northwestern Tarrant County.
Prosper Fire and Rescue reported several roads temporarily closed due to flooding.

Widespread heavy rainfall of eight to ten inches across the Sabine River basin of Northeast Texas during the final week of February resulted in rapid rises on the Sabine River south of Mineola, with the river cresting at 18.69 feet during the evening hours on February 27th. This resulted in moderate backwater flooding along the river, inundating some barns and secondary roads including FM 1804 in Southern Wood and Northern Smith Counties.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing E State Hwy 29 at CR 337 due to water over the roadways. Water spilled out of a drainage ditch near the intersection.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing the Walsh Dr. crossing at Brushy Creek near Brushy Creek Rd.
TXDOT reported flooded roads near downtown Orange after 3 to 6 inches of rain occurred.
Highway 390 east of Gay Hill was impassable due to high water.
A section of FM Road 1585 was closed following floodwaters up to 2.5 feet from a swollen playa lake.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding trapping two vehicles in high water in the 6000 block of Spicewood Springs Rd. along Bull Creek. Multiple people were rescued from the vehicles.

Numerous roadways and intersection were flooded around Houston. Some of the flooded locations included the intersections of Alabonson Road and West Little York Drive, Eastex Freeway and Little York along with Jensen Drive and Buck Street at the Interstate 10 and Interstate 69 junction.
Flooding was reported at the intersections of Highway 59 and Beltway 8 and at Memorial Drive and Shepard Drive.
There was high flood water that caused the intersection of the Gulf Freeway and Highway 96 to become impassable.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending Morrison Creek over SE River Rd. outside Martindale. Two people were killed when their vehicle was swept into the flood waters.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding covering Knobbs Rd. with 1.5 feet of water northeast of McDade.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding when Cottonwood Creek left its banks and covered Old Kimbro Rd. east of Manor. Two people were rescued from the top of their car when it stalled in the flood waters.
County Road 472 across Prairie Creek in Lindale was closed due to flooding well after the rains had ended.
FM 2868 over Saline Creek between Noonday and Flint was flooded and closed well after the heavier rains had ended.
Pliler Precise Road along Roy Creek and Elm Branch Creek in north Longview was flooded and closed well after the heavier rains had ended.
The Highway 135 overpass in Kilgore was closed due to flooding.
Willow Springs Road between Moccasin Trail and Woodway Street along Bighead Creek was closed due to high water well after the heavier rains had ended.
Numerous roads across many of the smaller creeks and streams were flooded across Angelina County well after the heavier rains had ended, including FM 706, FM 324, FM 2109, and FM 1818.

High water was reported on numerous streets in Lufkin mostly after the heavier rains had ended, including Southwood Drive near Hoshall, the Frank Avenue underpass at Angelina Street, the Loop 287 underpasses at South First Street, and the underpass on Tulane Drive at U.S. Highway 59.

Numerous county roads were flooded and closed near the smaller creeks and streams in Nacogdoches County well after the heavier rains had ended, including County Roads 210, 228, 230, 234, 271, 274, 280, 302, 411, 421, 526, 620, 628, 765, 780, 836, 850, 868, and 879.
Farm to Market Roads 1944 and 2046 northeast of Odem were closed due to flooding.
Water was 1 to 2 feet deep across portions of Gregory.
Videos showed significant street flooding in Robstown.
Water was over Farm to Market Road 70 between Farm to Market Road 1833 and Northwest Boulevard.
Farm to Market Roads 2678, 1360, and 3037 around and east of Bonnie View had water across them but were passable.
Water was over the road at Buford Street and 3rd Street intersection in Corpus Christi.
Minor street flooding occurred across northern portions of Corpus Christi from Morgan Street to near the intersection of Port Avenue and Crosstown Expressway.
Water rescues were performed in northwest Laredo due to flooding near Mines Road|and Las Cruces Drive intersection.
High water was reported along Lamar Beach Road to 12th Street and along Palmetto Street from Hagy Drive to 8th Street in Lamar. High profile vehicles were able to move through the water.
Multiple streets were affected by minor flooding in Corpus Christi to south of town. Water affected Weber Road, Highway 286 south to Farm to Market Road 70 and County Roads 28 and 57.
Public reported minor flooding on Avenue J in Robstown from Picker Lane to past Bosquez Street near Robstown High School.
Heavy rain caused flooding on Highway 361 near the Packery Channel bridge.
Multiple videos showed street flooding near Premont via the Snapchat map. The flooding affected 25 homes in the Premont area.

The Nueces River near Tilden reached major flood stage on the 21st. This caused major lowland flooding of livestock, roads, irrigation pumps and tank batteries. Fencing was damaged along with a few hunting cabins.

Heavy rains flooded Oso Creek on the 16th with the creek going above major flood stage. Major flooding reached the approaches to the Farm to Market 763 bridge. Numerous outbuildings and barns were surrounded and approached apartment buildings below Farm to Market 763.
FM 1818 at Buttermilk Road was covered in high water.
The southbound lanes of Highway 59 near Diboll were flooded.
FM 1818 at FM 58 was covered in high water.

The intersection of FM 58 near FM 1818 was flooded and closed.
Bartmess Drive was flooded and closed.
County Road 302 was flooded and closed.
Scott Street was covered in high water, with water encroaching on homes.

FM 23 was closed due to flooding from FM 1857 south to FM 2322.
FM 1857 was closed due to flooding from FM 23 to FM 2322.

Roads were closed due to flooding between Odem and Taft. Farm to Market Road 1944 between U. S. Highway 77 and Sodville Road, Sodville Road between County Road 82 and Villareal Street, and Davis Road between Mexico Street and Railroad Avenue were closed.

Several pictures and videos showed flooding of streets and parking lots near Robstown.
Nueces County Road 28 bridge was closed between County Roads 57 and 61 due to water over the road and bridge.
Heavy rains caused flooding along Beach Access Road 1 in Port Aransas.
Videos showed street flooding near Robstown High School.
Water was over the roadways at Crosstown Expressway and Interstate 37 south to around Brownlee and Morgan Streets.
Water entered the bottom floor of several apartment buildings around Oso Bay. The turnaround near Oso Bay became impassable due to flooding.

Heavy rain fell across Glasscock County and produced flash flooding about 22 miles east southeast of Midland. There was a public report of six inches of water running over State Highway 137, about one mile north of State Highway 158.

Widespread heavy rainfall of two to four inches fell across the Upper Sabine River Basin of Northeast Texas on December 26th-27th, atop already saturated grounds where rainfall amounts of five to seven inches fell during the month of December. The associated runoff resulted in the Sabine River near Mineola to rise above its 14 foot flood stage by 730 am on the 27th, where it neared the 18 foot moderate flood stage around 9 am on the 30th. This resulted in FM 1804 from the Smith/Wood County line north to Highway 80 to be closed due to flooding. ||In addition, Lake Fork Creek just southwest of Quitman also rose above its 16 foot flood stage around 10 pm on the 27th, and neared the 18 foot moderate flood stage around 2 pm on the 28th, before falling back to near flood stage by midnight on the 31st. This resulted in FM 1254 being closed due to flooding at the Lake Fork Creek bridge between  Loop 564 near Mineola and FM 778 southeast of Quitman.

Widespread heavy rainfall of two to four inches fell across the Upper Sabine River Basin of Northeast Texas on December 26th-27th, atop already saturated grounds where rainfall amounts of five to seven inches fell during the month of December. The associated runoff resulted in the Sabine River near Mineola to rise above its 14 foot flood stage by 730 am on the 27th, where it neared the 18 foot moderate flood stage around 9 am on the 30th. This resulted in FM 1804 from Highway 69 just north of Lindale to the Wood County line to be closed due to flooding.
Photos and videos showed significant street flooding in Portland. Water covered the parking lot of a gas station.
Clarkwood Road at Highway 44 was covered by flood waters.
Farm to Market Roads 631, 1944, and 2046 were closed due to flooding between Taft and Odem.
Matlock Street in Flour Bluff was impassable due to flooding.
Roads were impassable due to flash flooding near the waterfront at Ingleside on the Bay.
Flash flooding occurred on Memorial Parkway and Lang Road in Portland.
Parts of Farm to Market Road 629 near Bonnie View was closed due to flash flooding along Chocolate Swale.
Farm to Market Road 2511 4 miles north of Bayside was closed due to flash flooding.
Highway 63 was flooded near Bob Boulware Road.
Homer Alto Road was flooded at a small creek near Acorn Drive, well after the rains had ended.
Highway 69 North near Massingill's Meat Market was flooded.
Crawford Creek flooded FM 2021 near Highway 103 West.
Numerous county roads were flooded near the smaller creeks and streams across Cherokee County, which occurred as runoff continued well after the rains had ended.

Widespread rainfall amounts of two to four inches fell across the Neches River Basin of East Texas on December 26th-27th, atop already saturated grounds where six to ten inches of rain had fallen throughout the month of December. As a result, the Neches River southwest of Alto near Highway 21 rose above the 16 foot flood stage at 7 am on December 27th, reached the 18 foot moderate flood stage at 1115 pm on the 27th, and crested at 18.45 feet at 445 am on the 28th. The Neches River remained near 18 feet for the remainder of December, with a new and higher crest occurring after the first of the new year in 2019 due to additional rains that had fallen. ||This flooding resulted in moderate to severe flooding of the heavily wooded floodplain, with boat ramps and picnic areas completely inundated.

Multiple cells and clusters of thunderstorms during the pre-dawn hours into the morning commute on June 20th dropped measured and estimated rainfall between 5 and more than 8 inches in western Cameron County, which caused widespread flooding between La Feria, Harlingen, San Benito, and other locations. The flooding produced locally 2 to 4 feet of water depth, with Santa Rosa through La Feria particularly hard hit. Interstate 2 frontage road was closed from Harlingen to McAllen due to the intense rainfall, which fell at an estimated rate of 2 to 3 inches per hour in a few spots for 2 to 3 hours - and on top of prior rainfall earlier in the week.||Detailed damage for this particular event was not known, though total damage through multiple agencies along with standard doubling for uninsured properties, as well as significant damage to drainage canals, suggested event totals in Cameron County were over $60 million.  For this particular event, which included some of the highest rainfall rates, damage was estimated at around $35 million.  There were an unknown number of properties and vehicles damaged in this particular flood, though the numbers are likely above 1,000 for each case.  ||Full details will be available within 12 to 18 months of the event.
Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding near the City of Midland. There was flooding around Highway 158 near I-20. No damage was reported.
Heavy rain fell across Mitchell County and produced flash flooding near Westbrook. There was flooding along FM 670. Several city streets within Westbrook were also covered with water.

Heavy rain fell across Howard County and produced flash flooding south of Big Spring. There was flooding along Ranch Road 33 near US 87 at the Howard-Glasscock line. A car was stranded in flood waters.
Heavy rain fell across Howard County and produced flash flooding south of Big Spring. Ranch Road 33 was closed off of Highway 87 due to flooding.
Heavy rain fell across Glasscock County and produced flash flooding about 26 miles east southeast of Midland. The public reported one foot of water running over Private Road 4281.

Heavy rain fell across Glasscock County and produced flash flooding west of Garden City. There was road flooding just to the north of Highway 158 on Highway 137. Numerous water crossings were coming up over the road. This forced the closure of the road.

Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flooding on Highway 158. There was a high water rescue on Highway 158 near the Midland/Glasscock County line. Highway 158 was closed just northwest of State Highway 137 due to flooding. The rushing water removed much of the pavement along this road and SH 137. A guard rail also got damaged along SH 158.

Heavy rain fell across Gaines County and produced flash flooding near Seagraves. The Seagraves Fire Department performed high water rescues at the intersection of State Highway 83 and US Highway 62, one mile north of Seagraves. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain fell across Winkler County and produced flash flooding in Wink. The intersection of State Highway 115 and Wildcat Drive was closed due to flooding. The timing of flooding was estimated.
Heavy rain fell across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. Farm to Market Road 307 was closed at I-20 in Midland.
