It dropped below flood stage early on the 10th. A truck was washed away on RR 187 at a low water crossing that remained flooded south of Sabinal at 1:50 am Oct 12. A man in his 20s was killed and his body was found approximately one mile from the river crossing.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RR 335 along the Nueces River north of Barksdale.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 55 along the Nueces River north of Camp Wood.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads around the county including CR 404.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding washing out CR 414 at Pecan Creek east of Valley Spring.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RM 648 and RM 783 around Doss.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 55 south of Camp Wood and RM 337 east of town.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RM 2342 along the Colorado River south of Lake Buchanan.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RM 1631 and RM 1323 east of Willow City.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads in and around Llano.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads across western Kerr County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 29 along San Fernando Creek along with many other roads across the western half of the county.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RM 2147 at Flatrock Creek outside of Marble Falls.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads around the county including CR 405.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing multiple roads around the county including CR 408.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 2093 along the Pedernales River.

After 5-10 inches of rain fell in the Llano River basin flood waters moved into the Colorado River basin along with heavy rain in the basin. Lake Travis rose into its flood pool (681 feet MSL) on the 16th and eventually rose to 704.3 feet MSL on the 19th. This flood water overwhelmed Austin's water treatment facilities and the city issued a boil water notice on the 22nd. The city and Travis and Williamson Counties distributed bottled water to residents. The Lower Colorado River Authority conducted flood operations opening as many as eight floodgates on Mansfield Dam to reduce the level of the lake. By the 28th the level was sufficiently low to allow the water treatment facilities to operate normally and the boil water notice was lifted.  In and around the Lake Travis area there were reportedly nearly 100 homes that experienced Major damage, 76 with Minor damage, and over 200 homes that were Affected.   Damage estimates and insured losses are not complete as of this writing but will likely top 10 million dollars.  The monetary loss to businesses in Austin with regards to the boil water notice are unknown.

Heavy rain overnight produced flash flooding that washed away the FM 2900 bridge across the Llano River in Kingsland. A body was recovered near Kingsland and it was determined that this fatality came from a flood in the city of Junction the previous week.  Damage to the bridge is estimated at 20 million dollars.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 41 across the northern part of the county.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing CR 116/FM 3509 east of Inks Lake State Park.

Heavy rain mainly west of Burnet County and lakes LBJ and Marble Falls, caused rapid rises on the Colorado River.  Several hundred thousand CFS of flood water entered Lake LBJ near Kingsland (where the Llano River enters the lake), with flood waters flowing down the Colorado River into Lake Marble Falls.  Lake LBJ and Marble Falls rose rapidly, flooding homes and some businesses.  While the lake only rose a few feet at Wirtz Dam, farther upstream on Lake LBJ near Kingsland, Granite Shoals, Highland Haven, and Cottonwood shores, rapid rises on the Lake caused many homes to flood.  Lake LBJ started to rise in the predawn hours and continued high through the day.  Downstream of Wirtz dam is Lake Marble Falls which saw a 15 feet rise in less than 12 hours.  Evacuation notices were sent out near the Lake on the morning of Oct 16.  For the above mentioned communities, estimates of damage include 17 homes destroyed, 168 with Major damage, 64 homes with Minor Damage, and 31 homes that were affected.  As of this writing, early and ongoing flood insurance payouts totaled over 11 million dollars so far along with roughly 7 million spend on debris removal and 2 million dollars worth of damage to the Marble Falls water treatment plant.  Additional flood repairs to homes should easily surpass an additional 10-15 million dollars when you total the several hundred homes impacted.  It is estimated that total losses in Burnet County and Lakes LBJ and Marble Falls could surpass 30 million dollars.

Heavy rain across Llano County and points west produced a large flash flood on the Llano River.  The flash flood emptied into Lake LBJ at Kingland, causing water to back up in the lake and flood areas as early as 7 am north of Kingland.  Many homes along the canals had 4-6 feet of water in them.  Many homes along Lake LBJ in Kingsland flooded, as well as areas down the lake at Sunrise Beach and Horseshoe Bay.  Lake LBJ started to rise in the predawn hours and continued high through the day.  In Llano County, preliminary damage assessments show estimates of 38 homes destroyed, 494 with Major damage, 140 with minor damage, and 49 that were affected.  A few businesses also took on water.  The FM 2900 highway bridge was destroyed with a total replacement cost estimated to be 20 million dollars.  As of this writing, over 8 million has been paid out to Flood insurance claims with much more to likely come.  Infrastructure loses including debris removal should surpass 12 million dollars.  Home damage could easily be estimated at an additional 15 to 20 million dollars.  As of this writing will place a damage estimate of 50 million although numbers could exceed this.
Friars Creek in the South Temple Community Park was reported to be out of its banks.

Heavy rain caused an extensive rise in area creeks and rivers, pushing the Llano River to near 40 feet at the USGS river gauge in Llano.  This is the 2nd highest ever recorded height on the river in the city of Llano.  Flow peaked out about 285,000 CFS around 730 AM that morning nearly coming up to the level of the Highway 16 (Ford St.) bridge in town.  Several homes were flooded along the river with damage to the area parks as well.  A 58 year old woman lost her life in her vehicle as she was trying to get to work in town near West Sandstone and Flag Street.  Time when she entered the water is unknown but is estimated around 5 AM that morning.  Phone and internet service went down as the high water flow washed away phone lines underneath the Llano River Bridge.  Damage in the city of Llano will likely surpass 1 million dollars.
High water rescue took place  on FM 1224 near Lake Pat Cleburne.
Lane closures at MM230 on Interstate 35 due to flooding.
Urban flash flooding occurred in northwest Dallas with multiple water rescues near NW Highway and Harry Hines, as well as Mockingbird and Maple.
Multiple road closures across Arlington, including 2100 Park Spring BLVD, California & Cannon DR and Fort Edge Dr.
Emergency manager reported sandbagging to prevent home damage along FM 1954 between highway 79 and Holliday.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Camp Wood near the Nueces River. An observer reported 4.81 inches of rain in Camp Wood.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 83 north from Garvin Store. An observer reported 6.00 inches of rain at Prade Ranch.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 55 near Pulliam Creek between Rocksprings and Barksdale.
Multiple intersections with water flowing over them. There was at least one high water rescue.

Heavy rainfall between 4 to 6 inches occurred on October 7th across the Upper Nueces River watershed. The flow from this heavy rainfall caused the Nueces River at Cotulla to reach major flood stage on the 15th and continued through the 19th across La Salle County.

Heavy rainfall between 5 to 8 inches occurred on October 15th across the Upper Nueces River watershed. The flow from this heavy rainfall caused the Nueces River at Cotulla to reach major flood stage on the 20th and continued through the 25th across La Salle County. Major and massive lowland flooding occurred. Many roads near the river were flooded, including Farm to Market Road 3408 from Interstate 35, Valley Wells Road, and the frontage road near mile marker 67. Flooding also occurred on Dobie Road including in and around Farm to Market Road 624. FM 624 flooded south of Highway 97 toward Fowlerton.

Flood wave reached McMullen County on the 20th from the heavy rainfall that occurred over the upper Nueces River watershed. Major flooding continued until the end of the month. Major flooding from west of Tilden to south of Calliham occurred. Roads and bridges near the river were flooded.
Major flooding occurred from west of Three Rivers to near George West. Flow backed up into several minor creeks.
Underpass of I-40 at Bell Street is flooded and closed.

The Texas department of transportation reported that eastbound Interstate 40 frontage road is closed at Helium Road due to flood damage to the roadway. The Soncy Road exit from eastbound Interstate 40 is also closed.
Releases from Wesley Seale Dam pushed the Nueces River into major flood stream downstream from the dam, affecting Nueces County. West bank residents below Bluntzer were cut off by the flood waters.
Releases from Wesley Seale Dam pushed the Nueces River into major flood stream downstream from the dam, affecting Jim Wells County.
Releases from Wesley Seale Dam pushed the Nueces River into major flood stream downstream from the dam, affecting San Patricio County.

Major flooding continued along the Nueces River from Three Rivers to southeast of George West for the first couple of days in November. Flow backed up minor creeks to the slabs of lowest homes in the River Creek Acres subdivision, five miles southeast of George West.
FM 855 was flooded and closed just north of the Cuney community.
FM 2274 just south of Highway 79 was flooded and closed.

FM 177 near the intersection of 2493 just west of Mixon was flooded and closed. A vehicle trying to drive through the floodwaters here was washed off the road. The driver was able to escape and was not injured.

The intersection of County Road 173 and FM 1249 was flooded and closed. A high water rescue was needed for a vehicle driving through the floodwaters.
The intersection of County Road 173 and County Road 199D was flooded and closed. A vehicle became submerged trying to drive through the floodwaters here, and required a high water rescue.

A picture was posted to Facebook of Socagee Creek inundating the bridge and surrounding areas on FM 451 near Old Town Road in the Elysian Fields community. FM 451 was closed between Old Town Road and Waskom-Elysian Fields Road.
FM 9 was closed between FM 451 and Waskom-Elysian Fields Road due to flooding.

Water was reported over FM 617 about 4 miles east of Rochester.
Water was reported over the road at U.S. Highway 380 about 5 miles west northwest of Haskell.  The water was about two feet deep in some locations.
Highway 1170 about 2 miles west of Blackwell was closed due to flooding.  Water was also over the road east of Blackwell and also along Texas Highway 153 near Country Road 263.

Numerous road were closed throughout central Schleicher County due to flash flooding.
A vehicle was stranded in high water off of County Road 316 with one individual forced onto a rooftop.  A water rescue was underway with a helicopter enroute.
Law Enforcement reported flooding across Interstate 10 at Mile Marker 392.  Interstate 10 was closed west of Sonora.  US Highway 277 north of Sonora was also closed due to flooding.
Flooding was reported FM 2596 about 8 miles southeast of Eldorado.
Flooding was reported on FM 915 just north of Eldorado.
Water entered the Haskell Elementary School and one residential home.

Very heavy rain of eight plus inches fell north of Sonora in the vicinity of thirteen uncontrolled dams north of Sonora. Sites 1-8 are on the Dry Devils River and Sites 9-13 are on Lowrey Draw.  As these dams filled, flood waters overflowed the spillways into the draws.  This was the first time (as far as anyone knows) the emergency spillways were activated for some of these dams.  There were no breaches, these structures worked as they were meant to function.  Normally these structures would help mitigate flooding in Sonora, but previous rains had already filled up many of the sites. ||One of the deputies saw a wall of water come down the Dry Devil's Draw just north of Sonora at about 1 PM CDT near U.S. 277.  This wall of water flooded many homes located near the Dry Devil's Draw in Sonora shortly after 1 PM CDT.  Flood waters even  flowed over the US 277 bridge on the south side of Sonora.  The depth of this wall of water is estimated at around 25 feet.  The flood waters cut off the city of Sonora from neighboring first responders in all directions who wanted to help.  Emergency management reported about 250 homes were either damaged or destroyed.
Texas Division of Emergency Management reported closure of US Highway 83 between Anson and Hamlin because of water over the road.
A low water crossing between Dove Creek Lane West and Dove Creek Lane East was closed because of flooding.
Facebook Post from the public showed Highway 92 in Tuxedo flooded.

Texas Division of Emergency Management reported the following roads closed due to flooding in Haskell County:  FM 2407 between US 380 and CR 110; FM 2163 between|CR 110 and FM 617; and FM 617 between Weinert and FM 2163.
Texas Department of Transportation reported RM 853 east of Mertzon closed at RM 564 due to high water over the draw.
The fire department reported 12  homes under water at Lake Stamford.
TxDOT reported FM 2092 and FM 1773 closed due to flooding.
TxDOT reported RR 2596, FM 2129, and County Roads 220, 245, 300, 312, 316, 329, and 350 in Schleicher County closed due to flooding.
TxDOT reported FM 3399 closed at the spillway of Oak Creek Reservoir due to flooding.
Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Brown County since September and this new flooding damaged some roads and bridges in the county.
A car with three people was washed off the road on FM 1856 near Lake Sweetwater. The three people were rescued by fire fighters after being stranded for hours.
Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Taylor County and this flooding damaged  some roads in the county.
The department of highways reported FM 2092 and FM 1773 closed due to flooding, 9 miles south of Menard.
TxDOT reported Ranch Road 864 and  Ranch Road 189 in Sutton County closed due to flooding.
Prolonged heavy rainfall continued to flood roads across Kimble County.  This flooding damaged 324 miles of roads and several bridges.

Some rural residents were trapped in their homes by a major flash flood on the S. Llano River and Cedar Creek, in some cases requiring them to be rescued. Others awoke to find water in their homes and were able to evacuate themselves.||The Above and Beyond RV Resort, located adjacent to the South Llano River, was completely flooded, washing RVs and motor vehicles down stream, trapping people who sought refuge in trees in the park, and carrying some down the river. First responders who arrived at the scene before daylight, heard people, who they were unable to see in trees and on top of RVs, calling for help.  They threw life preservers to the victims in the water. ||Miraculously, a woman who was staying at the RV park was carried about 23 river miles downstream before being rescued near Yates Crossing.  She was slightly injured. At least two others were injured.  ||Old Cedar Creek flows into the South Llano River just a few hundred yards above the park. In the early hours of Monday morning, the normally small creek came expanded to 300 yards in size and poured volumes of water into the S. Llano.  This water seemed to have arrived just prior to the wall of water from the South Llano.  Rescue workers said they could hear the sound of a roar with a wall of water coming down the river. ||Authorities have reported that 40-45 people were evacuated and 19 people were rescued by helicopter or swift water rescue boats.  There were three men and one woman who drowned.  Some of these victims did all they could to help others evacuate the RV Park.||Cost of road damage was estimated at 9 million dollars.  Damage to property was unknown.
Law enforcement reported Ranch Road 386 from Mason to Fredonia was closed due to flooding. Also, FM 1871 south of Mason was closed for several miles due to flooded low water crossings.

Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Callahan County and this flooding damaged  some roads and bridges in the county.  This damage and flooding was exasperated by all of the rainfall since September.
TxDOT reported that State Highway 16 was closed at the San Saba River bridge due to water over the bridge. The closure was from FM 500 to South Lewis Street.
TxDOT reports State Highway 137 closed between US 190 and State Highway 163 due to flooding.
TxDOT reported US 380 from State Highway 6 to FM 2407 in Haskell County closed due to flooding. The water depth was 16 inches deep and covered the road.
TxDOT reported RR 2291, RR 1773, FM 2092, and FM 1311 in Menard County closed due to flooding.  Lots of damage to area roads and county infrastructure form the prolonged flooding.
Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Mason County and this flooding resulted in damage to 257 miles of road.

Law enforcement reported several roads closed in Kimble County due to flooded low water crossings, including U.S. Highway 377 from the county line to Junction, Ranch Road 385 from London to Harper,  Ranch Road 479, and FM 2169.
The sheriff's office reported Johnson Creek flowing over FM 2169.
The sheriff's office reports Crothers Street and West White Street closed in Brady due to flooding.

Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Nolan County and this flooding damaged  some roads and bridges in the county.  This damage and flooding was exasperated by all of the rainfall since September.
The media shared a video on Facebook of urban flash flooding on Lindenwood Drive and Sul Ross Street in San Angelo.
Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Throckmorton County.  This flooding caused damage to some of the roads.
The public posted photos on Facebook of several streets flooded in Ballinger.

The Mason County Sheriff's office reported Beaver Creek flowing onto a road near U.S. Highway 87, 10 miles southeast of Mason. U.S. Highway 87 south of Mason was closed. In addition, Texas Highway 71 in northeastern Mason County was closed due to flooding.

The sheriff's office reported that Johnson Fork Creek was flowing over one of the lanes on Interstate 10, with multiple swift water rescues in progress. Interstate 10 was closed as well as FM 2169 north of Interstate 10 due to the Johnson Fork Creek flooding.  First responders launched swift water rescue boats from Interstate 10 and rescued some people from their roofs.

The Throckmorton Sheriff's office reported flooding on the south side of town. The city park is flooded, the creek is full and a business park is moving merchandise out of the building as a precaution.
TxDOT in Brownwood reports FM 1311 closed at State Highway 190 and State Highway 29 due to flooding.
Multiple streets were flooded during the storm with some impassable. At least 1 vehicle was stalled on Taft AVE.
Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Jones County and this flooding damaged  some roads in the county.  This damage and flooding was exasperated by all of the rainfall since September.

TXDOT reported FM 617 between Rochester and Weinert closed due to flooding.  Many other roads were affected across Haskell County.  Prolonged heavy rainfall flooded roads across Haskell County and this flooding damaged some roads in the county.  This damage and flooding was exasperated by all of the rainfall since September.

There were reports of water near homes with flooded cars and roadways in Santa Fe, Dickinson and League City. Some of the flooding occurred as Dickinson Bayou went out of banks at SH 3 near Hughes Road.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Multiple low water crossings were closed in northwestern Bexar County.
There were reports of flooding in and around the University of Houston-Clear Lake campus.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain with as much as 3.19 inches in just over an hour reported at a site in Helotes. This rain caused flash flooding closing 28 low water crossings in Bexar County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The right lane of I-10 near W. Woodlawn Ave. was flooded in San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There was water over the road in the vicinity of Walzem Rd. and I-35 in San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The San Antonio Fire Department made a water rescue on the city's south side.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The San Antonio Fire Department made a water rescue at Oppenheimer Ave. and W. Harding Blvd on the south side of the city.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 377 about 25 miles outside of Rocksprings.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing numerous low water crossings in and around Del Rio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing the intersection of Industrial Blvd. and Cienegas Rd. in Del Rio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 674 between Rocksprings and Kickapoo Cavern State Park.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 2523 north of FM 3008.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 55 between Uvalde and Camp Wood near the Nueces River.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 1051 at the Dry Frio River crossing.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 55 outside Uvalde.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing SE Military Dr. near the San Antonio River in southern San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Dry Hollow Rd. at the Dry Hollow Creek crossing outside of La Vernia.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The San Antonio Fire Department made a water rescue near the intersection of SW Military Dr. and S. Zarzamora St. on the south side of the city.

Heavy rain moved across Midland County and produced flash flooding in the City of Midland. Midland County Sheriff reported numerous stalled vehicles due to flooding across the City of Midland. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Water flowing over Munchrath road.
Water flowing over one lane of Highway 82.
Water running over Ford road.

Moderate flooding continued along the Sabine River in East Texas during the first half of January 2019, in response to widespread heavy rainfall that fell across the basin throughout much of December. The Sabine River near Mineola reached the 18 foot moderate flood stage at 11 am on January 3rd, and crested near 18.6 feet at 2 pm on the 5th. The Sabine River near Mineola fell back below the moderate flood stage at 5 am on January 7th, but remained in minor flood through the third week of the month.  The flooding resulted in FM 1804 from the Smith/Wood County line north to Highway 80 to be closed until mid-morning on January 14th. ||In addition, Lake Fork Creek just southwest of Quitman remained near or slightly above flood stage to start January, with another round of heavy rainfall of one to two inches contributing to a second crest to near 17.9 feet at 230 am on the 4th. This resulted in FM 1254 remaining closed due to flooding at the Lake Fork Creek bridge between Loop 564 near Mineola and FM 778 southeast of Quitman through the early morning hours on January 8th, when Lake Fork Creek finally fell back below flood stage.

Moderate flooding continued along the Sabine River in East Texas during the first half of January 2019, in response to widespread heavy rainfall that fell across the basin throughout much of December. The Sabine River near Mineola reached the 18 foot moderate flood stage at 11 am on January 3rd, and crested near 18.6 feet at 2 pm on the 5th. The Sabine River near Mineola fell back below the moderate flood stage at 5 am on January 7th, but remained in minor flood through the third week of the month. The flooding resulted in FM 1804 from Highway 69 just north of Lindale to the Wood County line to remain closed through mid-morning on January 14th.

Widespread heavy rainfall of five to ten inches across the Sabine River basin throughout December as well as the first few days of January resulted in moderate flooding to develop on the Sabine River near Gladewater during the first two weeks of January. The river rose above the 26 foot flood stage on around 9 am on December 28th, reaching the 33 foot moderate flood stage at 330 pm on January 4th, before cresting at 35.5 feet at 2 pm on the 8th. The Sabine River fell back below the moderate flood stage at 930 pm on January 13th, before finally falling below flood stage by the third week of the month. The flooding resulted in several secondary roadways near the river to become inundated, as well as extensive flooding of lowlands.

Widespread heavy rainfall of five to ten inches across the Sabine River basin throughout December as well as the first few days of January resulted in moderate flooding to develop on the Sabine River just south of Longview during the second week of January. The river rose above the 25 foot flood stage at 745 am on December 28th, reaching the 30 foot moderate flood stage at 2 am on January 8th, before cresting at 32.3 feet at 6 am on the 11th. The Sabine River fell back below the moderate flood stage at 1130 am on January 16th, before finally falling back below flood stage by the third week of the month. The flooding resulted in several secondary roadways near the river to become inundated, as well as extensive flooding of lowlands.

Moderate flooding continued along the Neches River near Alto through the first week and a half of January, with the river cresting a second time (since December) to near 19.1 feet at 9 am on January 5th. The Neches River near Alto began a slow recession to end the first full week of 2019, falling below the 18 foot moderate flood stage at 5 pm on January 10th. Minor flooding continued along the Neches River throughout the remainder of the month. ||This continued flooding resulted in moderate to severe flooding of the heavily wooded floodplain, with boat ramps and picnic areas completely inundated.
There were sections of Highway 21 and Highway 39 there were closed due to high water in and around the town of North Zulch.
Spotter reported flood waters to a depth of one foot on St. Mary's Street in Beeville.
MPing reports were received of street flooding near Whitsett. Several vehicles were stranded in the flood waters. Several streets were closed due to the flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that sent water from Cottonwood Creek over the FM 1660 bridge north of Hutto.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 1660 near the New Hope Church south of Hutto. The flooding was between Brushy Creek and Cottonwood Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing E. Rundberg Ln. under I-35 in Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing a low water crossing on Hwy 95 north of Taylor. A video showed water about halfway up the tires of a truck.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 95 and Hwy 29 |along the San Gabriel River northeast of Circleville.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that flooded the parking lot of the Mt. Sinai Baptist Church in the 850 block of Cameron Rd. in northeastern Austin. Water was up to the bumpers of cars in the lot. The church is located near Little Walnut Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 95 at Wills Creek south of Granger.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing northbound I-35 between US 183 and Rundberg Ln. in Austin.
Water was across Highway 7 west of FM 2782.

Several rounds of thunderstorms late this night deposited between three and five inches of rain in a few hours over a large swath of eastern Garza County.  Low lying sections of Highway 84 were reported by TX-DoT to have standing water of several inches deep.

Heavy rain fell across Gaines County and produced flash flooding east of Seminole. There was water up to the door on vehicles east of Seminole along Highway 180. No damage was reported with this event.
County Road 1139 was closed at the intersection of Maple Drive in the Indian Creek area due to flooding.
Farm to Market Road 14 at Interstate 20 was closed due to flooding.
Several roads were covered in high water in the Emerald Bay subdivision near Lake Palestine.
A picture was posted to social media of high water which covered many streets in Flint.
A man's car was swept off the road due to fast moving water at the 3300 block of Bell Springs road.  The man's body was recovered the following day after the water had receded.

Moderate flooding developed at Caddo Lake between Uncertain, Texas and Mooringsport, Louisiana as a result of persistent heavy rains that fell across the Caddo Lake basin throughout much of April and May. Widespread rainfall amounts of eight to ten inches fell across the basin during April, with additional widespread amounts of eight to ten inches falling during May as well. As a result, Caddo Lake rose above the 174.5 ft moderate flood stage at 12 am on May 10th, before cresting at 176.4 ft at 5 am on the 14th. Caddo Lake slowly receded back below the moderate flood stage at 4 pm on May 19th. Several secondary roadways near the lake were flooded, as were the access roadways in Uncertain, Cypress Village and Caddo Lake State Park. Most non-stilted homes along the lake were flooded as well, with backwater flooding increased through James Bayou on the north side of the lake.
A social media report indicated that Wagley Roberts Road was flooded between Bonds Ranch and Bailey Boswell Roads, approximately 2 miles north of the city of Saginaw, TX.
Fire and Rescue reported flooding in the Haslet Community Park.
A social media report indicated flooding near the intersection of Inwood Drive and Forest Park, near the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in the city of Dallas, TX.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several low water crossings in Fredericksburg.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that closed several low water crossings in the Austin area.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain west of Fredericksburg. A CoCoRAHS observer reported 2.23 inches that flooded a road along Dittmar Creek.
Thunderstorm produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 21 near Maha Creek in Cedar Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing FM 1624 near Middle Yegua Creek west-southwest of Lexington.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that lad to flash flooding closing US 290 at FM 2336 in McDade.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several roads in Gillespie County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RM 165 near Boardhouse Creek east of Blanco.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATX Floods reported a low water crossing closed at 6334 Joe Tanner Ln. and Williamson Creek in Southwestern Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATX Floods reported a low water crossing closed at 5003 Wasson Rd. at Williamson Creek in southern Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing a low water crossing on Bowie Dr. near Circle D-KC Estates.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATX Floods reported a low water crossing closed at 1301 W. Oltorf St. at West Bouldin Creek in Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATX Floods reported a low water crossing closed at the 880 block of Edgegrove Dr. at Eanes Creek in Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several low water crossings in northern Hays County were closed with feet of water over the roads.
Flooding occurred along Interstate 37 between Three Rivers and Whitsett.
Emergency management reported water over many roads north of Highway 380 and west of Highway 287.
A trained spotter reported high water over Highways 1655 and 2265 in the city of Alvord, TX, with Fire and Rescue on the scene.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing the intersection of Hwy 46 and Hwy 281 in Spring Branch.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The Little Blanco River left its banks closing Hwy 32 southeast of Blanco.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Hwy 16 was closed due to the flooding along the Pedernales River southwest of Fredericksburg.
Emergency management reported 6 emergency calls in under 10 minutes requiring Fire and Rescue, along with Fort Worth Police Department assistance for high water rescues.

Moderate flooding developed along the Sabine River south of Mineola as a result of persistent heavy rains that fell across the Sabine basin throughout much of April and May. Widespread rainfall amounts of five to ten inches fell across the basin during April, with additional widespread amounts in excess of ten inches falling during May. As a result, the Sabine River south of Mineola rose above the 18 ft moderate flood stage at 4 pm on May 8th, before cresting at 19.53 ft at 7 pm on the 10th. The Sabine River fell back below the moderate flood stage at 9 am on May 15th. Farther downstream on the Sabine River just south of Hawkins, the river rose above the 32 ft moderate flood stage at 9 pm on May 10th, and crested at 34.2 feet at 12 pm on May 12th. The Sabine River fell back below the 32 ft moderate flood stage at 11 pm on May 15th. This flooding inundated some barns and secondary roads including FM 1804 in Southern Wood and Northern Smith Counties through mid-May before receding.
Numerous streets were flooded and vehicles were stalled out in the high water across the city of Nacogdoches.
Videos on social media showed street flooding across portions of Rockport.
High water covered Highway 204 just east of Cushing. The road was closed.
Report received through social media of 8 to 12 cars stalled out in flood waters on Rodd Field Road near South Padre Island Drive.
High water covered FM 225 south of FM 343. The road was closed.
High water covered Highway 147 in San Augustine.
State Highway 146's north and south bound lanes were inundated by flood waters in west Baytown.

A high water rescue of several occupants from a vehicle was needed on Crabapple Road over Pond Creek near the intersection of Crepe Myrtle Road. The rain had ended several hours prior, but runoff continued through the evening resulting in Pond Creek to flood a portion of Crabapple Road. Poor visibilities in dense fog were also observed at the time of the incident based on observations from various automated weather stations in the area.
Highway 69 was flooded with several cars completely underwater just north of Rusk. The road was impassable and closed.
Street flooding occurred in the neighborhoods near Staples Street and Lipes Boulevard in Corpus Christi.
Flood waters flowed over roads in the Flour Bluff neighborhood. The water reached mid way up some driveways.
Reports were received of water piling up on the Texas A&M Corpus Christi campus.
High water covered Beckcom Road near Worth Street, and also along Railroad Street in Hemphill.
Various reports were received of standing water on roadways across the southeast side of Corpus Christi.
High water covered Highway 83 just east of Pineland.
South Padre Island Drive in Corpus Christi became inaccessible between Ennis Joslin Road and Staples Street. Water covered the exit ramps. A few cars were stalled out in the high water.
Heavy rain fell across Gaines County and produced flash flooding in Seagraves. There were stranded cars at the intersection of US 385/83. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Police briefly closed the Solis Road exit along westbound Interstate Highway 2 (frontage) due to minor nuisance flooding.

Spotters and local law enforcement reported sporadic street flooding in southeast and east Harlingen after torrential thunderstorm rains dumped 2 to 3 inches in about an hour. Minor street flooding was most common along Ed Carey Blvd. (FM Loop 499) and U.S. Highway 77 (business) between Hale Avenue and Sam Houston Drive. No significant property damage was reported.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Multiple low water crossings were closed southwest of Canyon Lake.
Copperas Cove Police Department reported several roads being closed due to flash flooding, including portions of FM 116 and Robertson Avenue.

Measured and estimated rainfall between 8 and 12 or more inches that fell predominantly from early evening June 24th through a bit after midnight on June 25th produced widespread flash flooding across western Willacy County.  Hardest hit locations were Sebastian, Lyford, Raymondville, and La Sara. ||In the tri-county area (western Willacy, northwestern Cameron, and southeastern Hidalgo), 1188 homes were considered destroyed or with major damage, with an additional 182 homes with minor damage. Hundreds of streets flooded, including 30 Texas-managed highways. This included the frontage roads of Interstate 2 and Interstate 69E.  ||More than 100 persons were evacuated to higher ground when dozens of homes were threatened by 2 to 4 feet of water in each county; the entire western two thirds of Raymondville was under 1 to 3 feet of water; up to 4 feet was noted in LaSara during the peak of the heavy rain just before midnight on June 24th, and poor drainage flow in canals and ditches backed up water into Sebastian well after the rain had ended.   |Individual Assistance costs for the affected area in the three counties was estimated at $27.6 million as of early August 2019; Public Assistance values were unknown but likely to add to the damage, which will be estimated at $75 million in all three counties. Daily rainfall records were set in the flood area, including 9.7 inches in Raymondville which shattered the prior daily record by nearly 8 inches on the date (prior was 1.83 inches in 1923) and set a new daily record for the month of June (prior was 6.23 in 1993), with records going back to 1910. ||Despite the flooding and damage, much which occurred in the dark, there were no know deaths of injuries directly attributed to the flood.

Slow drainage of torrential rains of 6 to 15 inches in just six hours during the evening of June 24th through just after midnight on June 25th maintained widespread flooding of 1 to as much as 3 feet of water depth across many neighborhoods and roads in the eastern portion of the Rio Grande Valley. Hundreds of roads remained closed or impassible, and hundreds to more than a thousand homes continued to have some water in them for several (mainly fair weather days) following the causative event. Water did not recede completely in some neighborhoods until up to 2 weeks following the rains, much due to the interconnected drainage system which was unable to handle the rainfall rate, which was a 1 in 500 probability event occurring in locations only built to sustain 1 in 5 or 1 in 10 probability events. ||Please note: Damage listed here is only a fraction of the total damage which is shown in the flash flood entries for these locations.

Hundreds of roads remained closed or impassible, and hundreds to more than a thousand homes continued to have some water in them for several (mainly fair weather days) following the causative event.
