Social media report received of a truck trapped in high water in the Harlingen area. Water depth was estimated to be around 3 feet.
Social media report received of several flooded streets with 2 to 3 feet of water depth near Miller Jordan Middle School in San Benito.

Widespread flash flooding across much of Bowie County and the Texas side of Texarkana resulted in the closure of numerous roads. A few water rescues were also needed from stranded vehicles. Water entered several structures throughout the county as well.
A slow moving thunderstorm produced 10 to 16 inches of rain over the Hampshire - Fannett area which flooded numerous homes, businesses, vehicles, and streets.
Numerous roads flooded and closed around and between Jasper and Browndell including state highways. Several homes were also flooded in Jasper.
Feeder roads and the FM 1093 exit along State Highway 99 were closed due to flooding.

Public report received of flood waters reaching up over the top of car wheel wells in the Weslaco area. Emergency managers also reported water depth of up to 3 feet in spots during this event, mostly in the area just south of Interstate Highway 2 between Westgate and Airport Boulevard.

Local emergency management coordinator and on-site law enforcement/fire and rescue reported water entering properties on the east side of Los Fresnos in poorly draining locations where 3 inches fell in a 2 to 3 hour period.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding across Midland County. There were several roads under water across western Midland County, including Farm to Market Road 1788. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
An underpass was flooded along Interstate 69 South near East Mount Houston Rd, resulting in at least one stalled vehicle.
Social media report received of water rising up to the doorsteps of homes in San Benito near the intersection of Oscar Williams Road and I69E.  Depth of water unknown, but likely 2 feet or less.
Law enforcement reports high water rescues ongoing in Abilene. Also, a flooded home was reported at the 1200 block of Westmoreland St.

Training thunderstorms over several hours across central Bailey County caused flash flooding mostly along Farm to Market Road 746 west of Texas Highway 214. The next morning water was still over Farm to Market Road 746.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Cars were stranded in flood waters from Olmos Creek in northern San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The San Antonio Fire Department performed a water rescue at Old O'Connor Rd. and Lookout Rd. in northeastern San Antonio.
Vehicles were flooded in Sweeny due to heavy rain.
Spotter reported water over roadways.
Social media report received of streets flooded in the San Cristobal Subdivision in Edinburg. Water depth was estimated to be 2 to 3 feet in some spots.
Minor street flooding in the city of Claude.  Some accumulating hail being reported as  well. Lasted from about 1630 CST to 1800 CST.
Significant street flooding occurred due to heavy rainfall with severe thunderstorms in the area.
Twitter picture of a car halfway under water.
Significant street flooding occurred due to heavy rainfall with severe thunderstorms in the area.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Lamesa. There was a video of at least a foot of flowing water over roads in Lamesa. The damage estimate in Lamesa due to a thunderstorm downburst plus flooding was around ten million dollars.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Lamesa. There was a video of street flooding in Lamesa submitted via social media. The damage estimate from the flooding and thunderstorm downburst in Lamesa was around ten million dollars.
Flooding reported on County Roads 468 and 463 along with several other roads.
Driver pulled over on County Road 468 to avoid high water and water rose around him within minutes, trapping him inside his vehicle. Lindale Fire Department performed a high water rescue.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Vehicles were stranded in flood water in and around Kenedy.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Bexarflood.org reported that a low water crossing on Leslie Rd. in northwestern San Antonio was closed due to flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. An mPing user reported street flooding near I-10 and Vance Jackson Rd. in northwestern San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There was water over the roads at Toutant Beauregard Rd. and Wild Sage near Pecan Creek. Rainfall in the area was over 2.5 inches in one hour.

A slow moving thunderstorm led to very heavy rainfall near Quitaque. The Briscoe County emergency manager reported that water was rapidly flowing across Highway 86 approximately 3 miles west of Quitaque due to this heavy rainfall.

A nearly stationary thunderstorm led to brief heavy rainfall with additional lighter showers training over the same location. Terry County Sheriff's Office reported standing water on the southbound lanes of U.S. Highway 62/82 approximately 4 miles south of Meadow.

Spectrum News Media reported flooding along Grand Canal Drive and Glen Oak Drive between Flour Bluff Drive and St. Peter Street in Flour Bluff. Flooding also occurred at the |intersection of Ennis Joslin Drive and South Padre Island Drive in Corpus Christi.
Frontage road on Highway 181 on the southeast side of Beeville was closed due to being covered by high water. Video also showed creek overflowing a bridge southeast of Beeville.
Texas Department of Transportation reported water over the roadway on southbound U.S. Highway 180.
Street flooding occurred in Port Aransas from heavy rain, stranding at least one vehicle.

Gateway South near Fred Wilson became impassable with a car stranded in the flood waters.  Ellerthorpe and US 54 was also closed due to flooding. The heavy rain created a  rock slide that caused McKelligon Canyon Road to be blocked with 100 people stranded at an outdoor concert in the area. A video of a home with several inches of water causing damage inside was also obtained via social media in the same general area.
High water was over the roads in several places from Rockport and Fulton to Holiday Beach.
Social media reports were received of water over several roads throughout Goose Island State Park.

Social media reports received of water covering Texas Boulevard in Alice.|Jim Wells Sheriff's office reported vehicles hydroplaning due to water covering the roads on Highways 281, 44, and 359 around Alice.
FM 774 from Texas Highway 35 to FM 2678 was closed due to high water.
Flood waters were slow to recede across most of Rockport into the evening hours. Flood waters were as deep as a foot near the Presbyterian Church and some roads remained impassable.
The Aransas River near Skidmore went into major flood during the morning of the 6th and  crested at 24.3 feet during the early morning hours of the 7th.
The Aransas River near Skidmore went into major flood again during the afternoon of the 8th and crested near 25 feet during the early morning hours of the 9th.
Copano Creek near Refugio went above major flood stage on the afternoon of the 8th and crested near 18 feet during the early morning hours of the 9th.
Oso Creek went above major flood stage early on the morning of the 8th and crested near 27.5 feet during the evening of the 8th. One lane of Weber Road was closed due to being under water.
A roughly 20 mile stretch of Highway 35 between Holiday Beach and Tivoli was closed due to high water.
FM 855 north of Highway 175 was closed due to flooding.
Cars were stranded and under water around McRae and Wedgewood in east El Paso.
Flash flooding was reported at the intersection of Anthony and Doniphan Drive which caused a car to become stuck in the water.
FM 456 at  Hwy 71 closed due to flooding.

Texas DPS reported that the Allen Branch Creek overpass at I-20 west near Lindale was eroded due to flooding, causing a large pine tree to fall on I-20 and resulting in 5 vehicles and a gooseneck trailer wrecking. Four injuries were reported, but none were life-threatening.
Flooding reported at the intersection of Green and Cotton Street.
The Navarro County OEM reported street flooding and flooding in low-lying areas in and around the Corsicana. Minor street flooding was also reported in Mildred, Angus, and Mustang.
Pictures on social media showed standing water on residential yards and driveways.
FM 2289 from TX-OSR to FM 978 was closed due to flooding. A social media picture showed water covering the roadway.
Several county roadways were closed across parts of Northern Madison County due to floodwaters.
Flooding reported at the intersection of Cotton and High Street. Several water rescues were required for stranded motorists in the flood waters.
Numerous roads were closed across Jackson County after floodwaters made travel impossible.
An NWS Employee reported 2 to 3 inches of water covering the road.
A trained spotter reported 3 inches of water covering Avenue N by Angelo State University.
An Amateur Radio operator reported water over the road on College Hills at the Red Arroyo.
The public reported flooding on Ranch Road 783 just south of US 87.
The Sweetwater Police Department reported flooding along a portion of an I-20 service road.
The Abilene Fire Department reported flooding along a portion of an I-20 access road on the northeast side of Abilene. The flooding resulted in a couple of water rescues.
Law Enforcement reported barricades placed on Sunset Drive at the Red Arroyo due to flooding at the low water crossing. Time of flooding estimated on radar.
Law Enforcement reported barricades at the intersection of Queens Court and Lindenwood Drive due to flooding.
FM 629 from FM 136 to FM 3037 was closed due to high water. FM 2511 from FM 136 to FM 1360 was closed due to high water.
Street flooding was reported in and around the city of Dalhart. Roads did remain passible.
Reported flooding of I-40 under the overpass at Bell St.
Social media reported street flooding occurred throughout the city of Rockport.
An NWS Employee reported road impassable due to flood waters and the intersection of Westover Terrace and Forest Trail.
An NWS Employee reported water across the road at Sunset Drive next to the pond. The road is blocked off with barricades to stop motorists from crossing.
Law enforcement reported stranded cars at the intersection of College Hills and Sunset.

The Department of Highways reported stranded motorists on county roads and in the town of San Saba due to flooding. Also, water was over the intersection of US 190 and Farm to Market Road 1031 in San Saba.
Multiple flooded roadways around Amarillo  including Soncy Road, Coulter Road,  Hollywood Road, Western Street, and Teckla Boulevard.
Water over HWY 385 causing nuisance  flooding was reported.
Water over HWY 385 causing nuisance  flooding was reported.

Report received via Broadcast Media of water completely covering lanes and shoulder on I-2/US-83 Eastbound near Mercedes. Lanes were closed as a result. Multiple water rescues eventually were needed. Video was also received via social media of water rising up to homes in the Mercedes area.
An NWS Employee reported water up to two feet deep resulting in stalled vehicles on the westbound Frontage Road near Rio Grande Valley Premium Outlets near Mercedes.
Multiple streets and intersections were under high water across the southern portions of Corpus Christi. Several cars became stranded in the high water.
FM 70 between Chapman Ranch and Bishop was closed due to flooding along with Weber Road to the southwest of Corpus Christi.

High water occurred at multiple intersections along Crosstown Expressway, along Highway 44 between Robstown and Corpus Christi. Leopard Street and North Padre Island Drive was closed. Several cars became stranded in the water.
Highway closures occurred due to high water along Highway 77 from Robstown to Calallen and along Interstate 37 from Calallen to Annaville.
FM 774 east of Refugio was closed due to flooding.
Interstate 37 closed due to flooding between Mathis and Edroy. Several roads closed in the communities of Mathis, Odem, and Sinton. SH 359 underpass in Mathis closed due to flooding.
FM 1069 and Highway 35 near Aransas Pass was closed due to flooding.
Multiple roads were closed due to flooding around Ingleside.
State Highway 361 on Mustang Island had water covering the road.
State Highway 35 was closed due to flooding.
Multiple roads around San Diego had water covering the roadways.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Rolling Oaks Dr. was flooded at Yorks Creek near Wimberley.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Huntress Ln. was flooded west of Scenic Loop at Leon Creek west of Leon Springs.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Toutant Beauregard Rd. was flooded at Balcones Creek south of Boerne.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Old Fredericksburg Rd. was flooded north of Lost Creek Gap near Leon Springs.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Little Arkansas Rd. was flooded at the Blanco River southeast of Wimberley.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Spring Branch Rd. at Rittimann Rd. was flooded by the Spring Branch.

An emergency manager reported flooding of city streets in Kaufman and multiple water rescues. Deep flooding was reported along North Monroe Street. Approximately one foot of water was above the curb on Washington Street between 8th Street and 12th Street. Water rescues were located along West 5th and 6th streets.
Carson County also reported that a car was  swept off the road and stranded in the ditch  on Highway 207 1 mile north of Panhandle.
Pickup truck had stalled in flood waters on  Jefferson Street.

An NWS Employee was reporting very heavy rainfall which was causing urban flooding, resulting in vehicles close enough to getting stuck. It was very difficult to see road with wipers on full speed. This was occurring along Southland Blvd from Knickerbocker Rd to Southwest Blvd.
An amateur radio operator reported that Sul Ross Rd at the Red Arroyo was impassable and emergency vehicles was blocking the entrance.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Cypress Cove Rd. was flooded by Rebecca Creek northeast of Spring Branch.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Heuermann Rd was flooded north of Babcock Rd. south of Leon Springs.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. FM 335 was flooded near the Nueces River north of Barksdale.
Video by  posted on KVII Facebook  page showing nuisance street flooding.
Received a report of around 8 inches of water ponding on road  along I-40 west bound near Helium Rd.
A yard was completely flooded near the creek at Valley De Oro.
The Los Fresnos Police Department reported more than 10 streets in the city were experiencing flooding. Floodwaters were rising over curbs and spilling into sidewalks at the time of the report.

Numerous water rescues occurred due to flooded streets with vehicles stranded. Some residents were evacuated due to water entering buildings. Water was a foot deep at the Presbyterian Church. Multiple roads were closed in Rockport and Fulton, including Market Street, Champions Drive at Royal Oaks Drive, and FM 2165 from Business 35 to Linden.
Brownsville Police reported that about 30 streets in the city were experiencing flooding. Floodwaters were deep enough to prevent cars from traveling through.

Reports received via social media of flooding along Frontage Road near the Sunrise Mall in Brownsville, with floodwaters reaching up to the headlights of cars. Additional flooding was also noted on FM 802/Ruben Torres Boulevard.
Reports received via public of resacas (oxbow lakes) near Valley International Country Club were overflowing onto parts of FM 802.
Public reports received via social media showed several streets near UTRGV Brownsville Campus were flooded, and portions of the campus were without power due to lightning strikes and/or flooding.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding near Fort Davis. Highway 118 between Fort Davis and Alpine was washed out with water over the road. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Roadway flooding occurred along the I-10 Frontage Road and in areas surrounding the Memorial City Mall. Multiple cars were stalled as a result of the floodwaters.
Reports received via social media of water rising halfway up wheels on vehicles as well as a few stalled cars in Olmito Estates.

Pictures received via social media of flooding estimated at 2 to 3 feet of water depth at Old Alice Road and Price Road in Brownsville, with water nearing gas pumps and buildings. This location is a flood-prone area which has seen several similar events since 2010.
The Cameron County Sheriff's Department reported FM 2480 between Bayview and Los Fresnos was flooded, with up to 1 foot of water covering the westbound lane.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There was water over the road on Cielo Vista Dr. south of Vista Mountain Dr. Rainfall in the area was over 2.5 inches in one hour.
Several homes near Heath Road and Dhaka View flooded. There were reports of 1 to 2 feet of water in a few of the residences.

Media video and USGS gauge LKST2 data indicated that major flooding occurred at the Leon Creek gauge at I-35.  The gauge peaked at 25.79 feet, the 4th highest crest.  The high water closed that portion of I-35 as water started to encroach the lanes at the entrances of the highway bridge.  Farther upstream where Leon Creek crosses the New Laredo Highway, a business close to the creek took on some water damage and a nearby mobile home park was evacuated as high water made the roads in the park impassable.
Video received via social media of water covering several streets and intersections in the Arroyo Colorado Estates area. Water depth was estimated at 12 to 18 inches.
Video received via social media showing several portions of Padre Island Boulevard covered with water along with numerous side streets also experiencing flooding.

An off-duty NWS employee reported  2 to 3 feet of water flooding multiple roads in north Brownsville, including Morrison at Stagecoach; a neighborhood between Alton Gloor and east Morrison Blvd.; and a section along Dennet Road east of the Woods' End neighborhood.  Several cars had water above their wheels, stalled in the floodwaters.  This area had last seen similar flooding on June 19 and 20, 2018.
Per public reports, numerous portions of a Frontage Road in Mercedes were flooded.
Public reports received of water covering North Border Avenue near Weslaco High School.
Local emergency managers reported standing water at the Intersection of Wilson Road and Frontage Road in Harlingen.

An official with the local Council of Government reported several feet of water on property next to her house, with over six inches of water inside her home north of La Joya. Total event rainfall exceeded 10 inches in this area over the course of several hours; additional flooding was also experienced in the area.
Considerable street flooding along Bell St.,  between 45th and Hillside. Several inches of  flowing water on sides of roads, with a few  inches in the middle.

Road closed from 45th to Hillside on Coulter  with 3 to 4 feet of water. Firefighters were helping motorist escape from flooding and stalled vehicles. An additional report was submitted by the public for water filling up West Hill Park with some  roads around the park  impassable.
Trained spotter had reported street/road  flooding, along with road closures and vehicles stranded.
Heavy flooding was reported under the bridge at I-40 and  Bell, with traffic at a standstill in the  west bound lane.
Flooding started around 2:30 with water  over the road at least 4 inches deep in some  areas.
Flash flooding occurred at the intersection of East Missouri Ave and Poplar St around the Chevron Gas Station. Vehicles were reported underwater.

Flash flooding occurred across central El Paso with a torrent of water flowing down the mountainside near Fort Blvd and Louisiana St.  There was also significant water flow down Nashville St where two deaths were reported as a wall collapsed in the basement of a house and trapped a 2 year old and her 65 year old grandmother. Atlas Avenue just north of Chapin High School also had the road buckle with slabs of pavement missing. A rainfall report at the Wyler Tramway reported 4.65 of rain in a couple of hours which caused the flash flooding.

Torrential rains of 1.5 to 2 inches in one hour reported, and more than 2 inches in less than 2 hours,  at Brownsville/South Padre International Airport and nearby neighborhoods in Cameron County caused flooding at the intersection of Boca Chica and Highway 48. Local Emergency Manager reported waters flowing over the curb and the intersection becoming impassable at 1:28 PM.
Water rescues were needed near Cottonwood Dr and Belt Line Dr in Dallas. The Hunt Branch of Cottonwood Creek crosses this intersection.
Water rescues were needed near Glenville Drive between East Collins Dr and Commerce Drive in Richardson.
Water rescues were needed near Fall Creek Drive and Prairie Creek Drive. Prairie Creek runs by this location.
Dallas fire responded to a swift water rescue call on Merriman Pkwy near White Rock Creek. A Flood Warning was in effect for the creek due to rapid rises from heavy rainfall.
Heavy rain was causing flooding of roads and low lying areas in parts of Plano. One impacted area was highway ramps and low lying roads at the US 75 and President George Bush Turnpike exchange.
A National Weather Service Employee reported that South Jackson is blocked off due to flooding. In addition, a video from Facebook showed a high water rescue at the same location.
The San Angelo Police Department reported several streets flooded across San Angelo along with several stranded vehicles.
The Tom Green Sheriffs Office reported flooded roads in Arden.
The Tom Green Sheriffs Office reported widespread flooding along Farm to Market Road 2288.
A social media post indicated several streets and low water crossings flooded in Mertzon.
Water over 1 feet deep reported at Trinity Drive and Frio Drive in Portland.
Ayers Street and Tarlton Street flooded due to heavy rain.
There was water in homes and street flooding was reported in Hamlin.  Also FM 1661, FM 126 and FM 57 were closed in Jones County due to flooding.

Local news reported that western portions of Wise County, including the Bridgeport and Chico areas, experienced flooding due to several inches of rain which fell in a matter of hours. The County EM confirmed flooding of Chico Park in Chico and Harwood Park in Bridgeport. Both locations are along creeks that overflowed.
Water flooded roads across Canutillo with at least one business near 1st Street damaged due to rapidly rising water. Several roads remained closed for hours to clean up debris.

Flash flooding occurred from near Loop 375 and Montana to areas about 11 miles northeast of Montana Vista.  There was a vehicle flooded at the intersection of Montana and Dominican Street. Flooding also resulted in stranded vehicles at Joe Battle and Montana. Further east, Petty Prue Street was closed due to a washout due to an arroyo filled up and caused damage to a low water crossing.

Numerous roads were impassable due to floodwaters across the Houston area, especially in and around the West University Place and Galleria areas. Many vehicles were stalled due to the rapid rise of water levels.
A water rescue was performed in the New Chapel Hill community at the intersection of County Road 289 and Highway 64 due to flash flooding.

Multiple reports of flash flooding in Canutillo due to 5 to 7 inches of rainfall in the region over the previous days.  A stalled vehicle needed to be rescued near the Family Dollar on Doniphan Drive. Texas Highway 20 was closed again due to water and debris across the road.
Numerous roads were flooded in the city of Tyler.
Calloway Road was flooded, as well as the intersection of Highway 110 and Loop 323 in Tyler.
Streets flooded in Portland.
Flooded roads reported near Odem Elementary School.
Street closure reported due to heavy rain.
The intersection of Farm-to-Market 628 and Farm-to-Market 1546 flooded as water went out of banks from the Arana Creek across Farm-to-Market 1546.
Farm-to-Market 616 flooded near the underpass of Highway 87.
Victoria emergency management reported several streets flooded in Victoria with a few cars stranded.
Heavy rain and flooding resulted in numerous road closures, stranded vehicles, and water rising into homes across multiple locations in the northern part of Calhoun County.
The intersection of 14th Street and Santa Gertrudis Avenue was flooded in Kingsville.
Baldwin and Osage Streets flooded.
Heavy rain fell across Ector County and produced flash flooding in Odessa. Odessa police were assisting motorists with multiple water rescues. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
The Fisher County Sheriff's Office reported flooding for several miles along FM 57, between Hamlin and McCaulley.
The Irion County Sheriff's Office reported numerous locations along FM 163 north of Barnhart under water with debris floating in the roadway.  Flooding was also reported on CR 401 and CR 131.
Farm-to-Market Road 630 and County Road 2015 west of Sinton was closed due to flooding.
Streets flooded in Aransas County near Bypass 35 with motorists unable to cross several roadways.
FM 666 north of Bishop was closed due to flooding.
Multiple roads flooded in and around Kingsville.
Law enforcement reported multiple roads closed at Bloomington due to flooding.
The Calallen High School parking lot flooded.
Highway 77 between Bishop and Kingsville flooded.
Several roads flooded and closed in Corpus Christi, including: Interstate 37 at Carbon Plant, State Highway 286 at Holly Road, Rodd Field Road from South Padre Island Drive to Holly Road.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Four inches of rain fell in two hours in the Austin area. A video on Twitter showed minor flooding on N. Lamar Blvd. between W. 9th St. and W. 10th St. near Shoal Creek in Austin.

Thunderstorms produced four inches of rain in two hours in Austin. This led to flooding closing several streets including potions of Houeke Ln. and Posten Ln. near Austin Bergstrom International Airport.
Thunderstorms produced four inches of rain in two hours in Austin. This led to flooding closing several streets including potions of River Hills Rd. near the Colorado River.
Thunderstorms produced four inches of rain in two hours in Austin. This led to flooding closing several streets including Camp Craft Rd. at Eanes Creek.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. A Certified Consulting Meteorologist in Del Rio reported that a van was stranded in flood water up to the bottom of its doors at Mary Lou Dr. and Kings Way.

Thunderstorms produced four inches of rain in two hours in Austin.  Videos on social media showed the University of Texas Gregory Gymnasium flooded near Waller Creek as well as portions of the state Capitol building having water damage.
Numerous road closures due to flooding were reported in Laredo, including the 2300 block of Jacaman Road, Las Cruces Drive, and areas east of Mines Road.
Roadways within the Holiday Village Subdivision along Lake Livingston were impassable due to floodwaters.

Many portions of FM 802/Ruben Torres Blvd in Brownsville remained under several feet of water through the morning hours on the 2nd due to overwhelmed drainage systems in the area. It was not until around 9:00-9:30 AM local time on October 2nd that flood waters finally began to recede to the point of roads being traversable by mid-size cars.  Other high water of 2 to 3 feet along the sides of roads in a subdivision along Dana Avenue north of Ruben Torres Blvd. continued through the afternoon of October 2nd.  Damage to vehicles and property was not known as of this writing.

A resaca continued to overflow its banks along Vermillion Avenue, from 1 to 1.5 miles north of the intersection with Boca Chica Blvd. (State Road 4), well into October 2nd with the road remaining closed. At 18 inches to two feet of water covered the center of the road, with up to four feet on the normal road edges. A CoCoRaHS observer along Vermillion Avenue reported more than 10 inches on the 1st, with most falling during this period; the two-day total was 13.53 inches. End time of the significant flooding is estimated.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. A low water crossing gauge indicated water over the roadway on CR 1492 at the Blanco River southwest of Wimberley.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Schertz. Flooding closed Lower Seguin Rd. at Weir Rd. at Cibolo Creek.
Brownsville Police Dept reported road closures due to flooding on East Washington St in downtown Brownsville.
A video was received from the public of water entering a home near the intersection of Jamie Zapata Ave and Robindale Blvd in Brownsville.
Thunderstorms produced nearly four inches of rain in under two hours that led to flash flooding. ATXFloods reported two low water crossings were flooded in southwestern Austin.
Street flooding was reported in Beaumont with some streets impassable.
Construction road ramps from Interstate 37 and Highway 286 were flooded and not passable. Law enforcement reported multiple road closures in this area around downtown Corpus Christi.
Road closure on Tarlton Street between Churchill Drive and Ayers Street occurred due to flood waters.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. A low water crossing gauge showed water over the roadway on S. Old Bastrop Hwy at Cottonwood Creek south of San Marcos.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Schertz. Flooding closed FM 1518 at Oak St. along Cibolo Creek.

Thunderstorms produced 1.81 inches of rain in just over an hour in western Bexar County where significant rain had fallen in the previous two days. This new rain flooded five low water crossings and caused urban street flooding.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATXFloods reported over 30 low water crossings flooded in the western part of Caldwell County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. FM 1107 was flooded in Pandora.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The San Marcos Police Department closed the Hwy 80 bridge over the Blanco River to rescue some people in the river.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. FM 1447 and FM 766 were closed due to flooding north of Cuero..

Band of heavy rain from Tropical Storm Nicholas moved across the Port O'Connor area during the late afternoon and evening hours on the 13th. Total rain amounts around 7 inches caused flooding of roads in the Port O'Connor area.
Picture received from the public of a vehicle partially submerged in flood waters near the intersection of FM 511 and State Hwy 48.
TXDOT reports standing water on I-69E/US-77 near and north of the business 77 split roughly 4 miles north of Raymondville.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. FM 466 was washed out at Dulling Creek near Monthalia.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Hwy 80 was flooded between Helena and Gillett.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several low water crossings were flooded with multiple high water rescues in northern and western Bexar County. Rainfall totals in Helotes were up 5.70 inches.
Picture received from the public of portions of the I-2 Frontage Road under several inches of water. Exact depth unknown at this time.
The Weslaco Chief of Police reported 2.19 of rain, with 1.5 falling in one hour. Several reports of street flooding were passed on with water starting to top curbs.
Multiple streets across Jefferson County were flooded with underpasses closed while Nicholas moved across the region.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. A couple of trailers at the RV park on the Guadalupe River under I-35 were washed into the river. No one was in the trailers.
Report received from public of several inches of water topping the curbs at the intersection of Business 77 and Harrison Road in Harlingen.
Picture received from public of Madison Ave in Harlingen under several inches of water. Exact depth unknown at this time.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several low water crossings were flooded in central Hays County. Rainfall totals near Wimberley were 8.65 inches.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Low water crossings along Swine and Ahern Creeks near Spring Branch. Rainfall totals in Spring Branch were 6.50 inches.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. An SUV was swept off Blanco Rd. near Dietz-Elkhorn Rd. west of Bulverde. Two people were rescued from the vehicle. Rainfall totals in Bulverde were 5.02 inches.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several roads were flooded in central and western parts of the Caldwell County. Rainfall totals around Lockhart were as high as 7.64 inches.
Video received from public of water reaching up to car bumpers along Washington Ave between Commerce and 1st Streets in Harlingen.
Video received from the public of water covering US-77/Sunshine Strip near the VA Health Center in Harlingen. Water was reaching up to the bumpers of some sedans.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were several high water rescues in La Grange and Hwy 77 and Hwy 71 were both closed due to flooding. Rainfall totals around La Grange were as high as 8.65 inches.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. FM 532 was closed due to flooding east of Gonzales. Up to 9.90 inches of rain fell in Gonzales.
Picture received from the public of water halfway up the wheel wells of several cars in Los Fresnos near the library.
Public report of several inches of water flooding the intersection of Boca Chica Blvd and Central Ave.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Big Bend National Park near Rio Grande Village. Several dirt roads were reported closed or impassible due to debris and mud remaining from localized flash flooding. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Severe flooding occurred on North Padre Island Drive under Leopard Street and along Interstate 37. Several vehicles were disabled or stranded due to driving through high water.

Flooding was reported near the downtown area of Corpus Christi. Flooding was reported on Crosstown Expressway from downtown to near Tarlton Street. Flooding also occurred near Interstate 37 near North Staples Street.

Flooding along Ruben Torres Blvd. during the peak of the evening commute, and the result of an estimated 3 to 4 inches of rain per hour for two hours, stranded dozens of vehicles under up to 3 feet of water. A report of 4+ feet of water was obtained from a worker at the Circle K gas/convenience store at the intersection of Ruben Torres and N. Central Avenue during the peak of the flood shortly after 9 PM on the 1st.  Other structures had some flooding, including homes just south and north of Ruben Torres.  Damage values were unknown as of this writing.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were several high water rescues around Gonzales. Up to 9.90 inches of rain fell in Gonzales.
Severe flooding was reported on Interstate 37 near McKinzie Road.
Corn Products Road was covered in flood waters.
Twitter video showed flood waters up to bumpers of cars near Louis Lynch Drive and Interstate 37.
Farm to Market Road 1944 was closed south of Sinton due to according to DriveTexas.
RV park near Gulf Street and West Avenue A had flood waters up to car bumpers. Pictures were posted on social media.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were multiple vehicle rescues across Guadalupe County, multiple roads were flooded, and many creeks were going out of their banks. Up to 7.53 inches of rain fell near Seguin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. FM 532 at the Lavaca River was flooded in Moulton. Up to 5.12 inches of rain fell in Moulton.
TX-DOT reported road closures on FM 1944 south of Sinton due to flooding. High water was also over the road on FM 1945.
Flood waters were over State Highway 188 east of Sinton.
Water covered the road on Rodd Field Road in Corpus Christi.
Water was over the frontage road of west bound South Padre Island Drive near Staples Street.
Flooding occurred in a parking lot between buildings of an apartment complex.
FM 1488 at Wyatt Chapel Rd was impassable due to floodwaters, with water heights reaching up to the guardrail on the side of the road.
Heavy rainfall resulted in the US 90 underpass at Thompson Rd becoming impassable due to floodwaters.
Peek Rd was closed between Stockdick School Rd and Beckendorf Rd due to floodwaters.
Flooded roadways were reported near the intersection of Diamondhead Blvd and Coral Bay St, leading to road closures.
High water was over the road at Buford and 3rd Streets in downtown Corpus Christi.

Several reports of significant flooding along FM 802/Ruben Torres Blvd in Brownsville. This includes multiple reports of stranded vehicles near the WalMart, as well as between Robindale Blvd and Central Ave.

Several vehicles were swept off N Graytown Road at a low water crossing.  While several persons were successfully rescued, two persons lost their lives including a 5 year old female and a 52 year old female.

A resaca overflowed its banks along Vermillion Avenue, from 1 to 1.5 miles north of the intersection with Boca Chica Blvd. (State Road 4).  At least three feet of water likely occurred toward the end of the heavy rainfall, where an estimated 3 to 4 inches fell per hour for two hours between 5 and 6 PM CST on the 1st.  A CoCoRaHS observer along Vermillion Avenue reported more than 10 inches on the 1st, with most falling during this period; the two-day total was 13.53 inches.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The Little Blanco River flooded the FM 32 bridge northeast of Twin Sisters.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. A pickup truck was carried a couple of hundred feet by rushing water on Southwell Rd near Verbena St. along Leon Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were multiple high water rescues along Santa Clara Creek near Marion.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There was a high water rescue in Flatonia.
Doniphan closed due to flooding from Canutillo north to La Tuna to pump water.
TXDOT closed railroad frontage underpass because of flooding in Sierra Blanca.

Flood gates were closed along Naaman School Road between Brand Road and Miles Road, and between Pleasant Valley Road and Castle Road. Part of the road was inundated by the rising of Spring Creek that crosses the road.
Floodgates were closed at Campbell Road at Rowlett Creek.
Minor flooding was reported in Dalworthington Gardens.
Flooding was reported along Highway 377 between Ridge Pointe Parkway and Marshall Ridge Drive. The road was closed in both directions.
North White Chapel Bridge near Kirkwood Boulevard was closed due to flooding. A video showed water beginning to overtake the road.

An Emergency Manager relayed a report from Lott PD of high water in ditches and some water over Highway 320 just outside of the Lott city limits. Water was also reported on streets within the Lott city limits.
A woman drowned after her car was surrounded by water while trying to cross Spring Creek on Holford Drive in Garland. Her car was swept downstream.
Flash flooding was reported at multiple intersections in Groesbeck. Up to two inches of rain fell in less than an hour.
Water reported over curb with a few inches of water covering all the lanes of HWY 87.

Heavy rains produce flash flooding in and around the Grapeland area. A water rescue was performed along FM 228 approximately two miles east of Grapeland after a car was swept off the road by floodwaters.
Flash flooding caused a washout in one lane of FM 2423 between County Road 1840 and US Highway 287 North.
Per reports from social media, heavy rain led to street flooding on Olga Avenue in south McAllen.
Reports received of street flooding in Weslaco, with standing water at the intersection of Westgate Drive and W Pike Boulevard.

Local emergency managers reported street flooding on the south side of McAllen, between 23rd Street and Ware Avenue southwest of McAllen/Miller International Airport, in the neighborhood east of Los Encinos Park, with water covering the entire road at their location.
Local emergency managers reported street closures along South 29th Street between Elmira and Daytona Avenues in south McAllen due to heavy rain.
Local emergency managers reported street closures south of Nolana and east of Bicentennial due to flooding in central McAllen.

Tropical like rain showers repeatedly trained over eastern Garza County on the morning of the 28th. The Lake Alan Henry Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site measured 5.18 inches of rainfall in the span of mostly three hours. The Garza County sheriff's office reported multiple areas of water running over US Highway 84 between Post and Justiceburg. Additionally, some structures became inundated near Lake Alan Henry.

Heavy rain resulted in high water over roadways, making streets impassable. At least 25 structures including many within the Bacliff Villas subdivision were inundated with floodwaters, resulting in water damage.
Reports received of minor street flooding in Donna near Salinas Road, just southwest of Donna High School.
The Starr County Sheriff's Office reported that San Juan Drive in Garceno, west of Rio Grande City, was flooded with at least 2 feet of water, causing traffic to divert away from the area.

Report received from the public, via the MPing app but confirmed with social media reports, of streets flooded with some vehicles stranded as well along Griffin Parkway north of the center of Mission.

The City of Mission's social media page shared multiple reports of street closures due to minor flooding, mainly in the southeast portion of the center of Mission near Keralum Avenue, which is east of Conway, south of 9th, and west of Bryan Road.

Widespread flash flooding was observed across the northwest side of Texarkana. Numerous roads were flooded and closed due to high water, with several vehicles stranded in high water. High water rescues were needed from some of the stranded vehicles.

Numerous areas of Western El Paso county received flash flooding with numerous roads closed.  Some of these areas included Mesa St and Montecillo Blvd, Mesa and Brentwood, Doniphan Rd through Canutillo, Camelia Dr in Westway as well as Executive and Paisano. In addition to these roads, flooding was reported across parts of Interstate 10 with 3 lanes closed near Executive Center.

The El Paso Police reported a large amount of mud and debris causing a road closure near Doniphan and Sunland Park Drive.  The area around Paisano Drive and Executive had to be closed as well due to a large amount of water flooding the intersection.  Water entered homes in parts of West El Paso as nearby drainage ponds overflowed. In addition, a 39 year old female died on the Thunderbird Trail after water rushed down the side of the mountain.  By the end of the day, some locations of the city had received over 4 inches of rain in 36 hours.

Flash flooding was reported with some cars stranded in high water around locations generally south to southwest of Waco. High water was reported at Gateway Blvd and Bagby Ave south of Waco, and flooding was also reported around Midway High School in Hewitt.
Flooding continued in the Waco and Hewitt areas for a few hours after heavy rains ended. A total of 4-5 inches of rain fell in a short amount of time.
Amateur radio reported multiple vehicles stranded in flooded roadways near Dallas Executive Airport.
A public report indicated flash flooding near Highway 180 in the city of Breckenridge, TX. An emergency manager also reported Gunsolus Creek was out of its banks.

A person was rescued from their car after it got stuck in approximately 3 feet of water on Castle Drive near the Garland/Rowlett city border. A Flood Warning was in effect for the nearby Rowlett Creek due to rapid rises from heavy rainfall.

High water was reported in the County Sheriff's Parking lot with the water depth up to the bumpers of vehicles. Water also entered the building at a depth of 1-2 inches. In addition, the public reported several instances of flooding in and around Weatherford.

Numerous roads and areas in the northeast part of the county were reported under water. In particular, a picture of water over FM 2738 was tweeted out. At least 3 water rescues were already conducted.
Luella Rd and Davenport Rd in Sherman was closed at Choctaw Creek due to flooding.
Flooding continued in the Weatherford area for a few hours after the heavy rain had stopped.
Earle Road in Hewitt was closed due to flooding.
Highway 59 just south of Carthage was covered in high water, dirt, and debris.
FM 3359 a few miles southeast of Deadwood was covered in high water and closed.
FM 31 a few miles south of Deadwood was covered in high water and closed.
FM 31 north and south of FM 2517 in the Deadwood community was covered in high rushing water.
High rushing water over FM 10 in multiple locations near County Road 119 near Gary City.

Widespread rainfall amounts of fifteen to in excess of twenty inches fell across the Neches River basin of East Texas during May, including three to in excess of eight inches that fell May 31st. As a result, a secondary crest occurred on the Neches River southwest of Alto near Highway 21, rising back above the 18 foot moderate flood stage at 1215 pm on June 1st, surpassing the 20 foot major flood stage at 315 pm on the 1st, before cresting at 20.3 feet at 8 pm that evening. A sharp recession occurred afterwards, with the river falling below 20 feet at 730 am on June 2nd, and below 18 feet at 8 am on the 4th. This flooding resulted in moderate to severe flooding of the heavily wooded floodplain, with boat ramps and picnic areas completely inundated.
A section of Highway 225 just north of County Road 4173D was flooded about 2 miles north of Laneville.
Heavy rain flooded streets in portions of Groves. Water was reported to be at least 1 foot deep over Twin City Highway near Thomas Jefferson Middle School.
Three to six inches of rain fell in Hardin and Tyler Counties during the afternoon. Flash flooding at Votaw and a few surrounding communities created unpassable roads.
Law enforcement reported 3 feet of water on the road, which resulted in two cars stalling out. Also, law enforcement reported a semi-trailer truck had water up to the radiator.
There were several water rescues in Fort Stockton. Schools and hospitals were flooded in town.
Widespread flooding was reported along Brickhouse Gully in the Oak Forest neighborhood. Roadways were made impassable by floodwaters.
Floodwaters at the intersection of Highway 146 and FM 787 made the surrounding roadways impassable.
Flooding along FM 787 around Cherry Creek resulted in impassable roads, overfull drainage ditches, and water approaching structure door thresholds.
Vehicles were flooded along impassable roadways in the vicinity of Gessner Rd and Interstate 10. Multiple high water rescues were needed in the area.
Multiple cars were stranded along Kempwood Rd, which was impassable due to floodwaters. Active water rescues were required as a result.
Approximately 6-8 homes were flooded with 4-6 inches of water along Brickhouse Gully near Bingle Rd.
Homes along Halls Bayou near Interstate 45 were inundated with floodwaters.
Centerview Road between Bronson and Pineland was closed due to high water. FM 2866 near Bear Creek was also flooded and closed due to high water.

Numerous roads in Southern San Augustine County near Lake Sam Rayburn were covered in high water. Ponds overtopped their earthen dams, and a culvert was washed out. A CoCoRaHS observer reported 6.75 inches of rain between 1030 pm on January 8th to 500 am on the 9th, with the heaviest rainfall occurring during the early morning hours. This observer recorded a 24 hour storm total of 7.25 inches.

Several storms had repeatedly trained over the Denver City region causing multiple periods of heavy rainfall over a short period of time. Law enforcement in Denver City reported flooded roads in town from this heavy rainfall.
Law enforcement reported minor street flooding due to very heavy rain near the Medina Subdivision near Zapata County High School.
Exceptionally heavy rain led to street flooding at the intersection of Highway 83 and 9th Avenue in Zapata County.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Fort Stockton. There was street/road flooding and closures. Vehicles were stranded. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Social media pictures showed several submerged cars that were being removed from flood waters from the heavy rain the night before. Flood depth of 3 to 4 feet is estimated due to how high the water was on the cars.
Water covering some roads in western Panola County near Martin Creek Lake.
FM Road 856 flooded in both east and west board lanes.
Several roads closed due to flooding in Longview.
Flooding reported FM Road 13 near Price.
Flooding reported on Highway 64 near the Gaston community.
School gymnasium flooded east of Turnertown and just north of Joinerville.
High water flooding Bison Road.
Emergency management reported major flooding on a couple of roads, with parts of Business 34 / Washington Street closed due to high water.
Amateur radio reported flooding on Forgotten Lane and Cheyenne Trail in the town of Tool, TX.

Heavy rain fell across Pecos County and produced flash flooding in Fort Stockton. There was around two feet of standing water at a low water crossing on the south end of Fort Stockton. No damage was reported.
Low lying feeder roads in constructions areas along northbound Highway 75 in Sherman were flooded. Some stalled vehicles were reported.
Low water crossings in Ladonia were flooded due to heavy rain.
State Highway 11 at Choctaw Creek, to the southeast of Sherman, was impassible due to high water over the roadways.
Calf Creek Lane near Bells was impassable due to high water, likely where it crosses Calf Creek.
High water covered Highway 7 just outside of the Center city limits.
Roads closed due to flooding with several water rescues required.
High water covered Highway 7 about 6 miles southwest of Center.

Heavy rain fell across Howard County and produced flash flooding in Big Spring. There were multiple reports of homes flooded throughout the city of Big Spring. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A public report was received of flash flooding at Mesa and Brentwood.
Emergency management reported flash flooding along Farm to Market Road 799 and County Road 329. Water flowing over the road was up to a depth of 1 foot.
Pearl Street was flooded in Nacogdoches.

Video on social media shows several feet of fast moving water near Medina Street - a flood-prone area known as Medina Addition - with two SUVs that had been swept off the road and into a ditch. Video later shows the vehicles getting dragged out of the ditch by a tow truck. Based on the during and after videos, it is estimated that 3 to 4 feet of fast flowing water was moving across the road at the height of the flash flooding. Additional video shows people having to abandon homes during the height of the flooding and the water coming up to their waists, which supports the 3 to 4 foot estimates of fast moving water. A report of 8 of rain came in from just northwest of Zapata from this storm. The local newspaper in Zapata County later reported that at least 15 homes were affected with many of them losing their furniture, clothing, and household items.
The public reported one home flooded including garage, bathroom and bedroom. Also, torrential rain was mixed with hail.
Fire and rescue reported a high water rescue near the intersection of Hillcrest Road and Huntington Road in Frisco, TX.
Fire and rescue reported a water rescue near the 5000 block of McKinney Ranch Parkway in McKinney, TX.
Emergency management reported several vehicles flooded near the intersection of Hebron Parkway at Rolling Oaks Drive in Carrollton, TX.
Fire and rescue reported a high water incident at the 4500 block of Village Fair Drive in Dallas, TX.
Fire and rescue reported a water rescue requiring a boat.
Fire and Rescue reported a high water rescue near the intersection of Park View Avenue and Gerry R. Lane.

A cyclic tornadic supercell persisted for several hours near the intersection of Bailey, Lamb, Hockley, and Cochran Counties. This thunderstorm brought copious amount of rainfall to this region leading to flash flooding over a widespread area. Most of the rainfall was observed over far southeastern Bailey County where between three and seven inches of rain fell. While conducting a tornado storm survey the next day, the NWS survey team discovered numerous roads that were impassable due to flooding.

Numerous thunderstorms repeatedly trained over portions of the extreme southeastern Texas Panhandle causing widespread flash flooding across Hall County. Several roadways were either flooded or completely washed out. Farm to Market Road 2472 near Plaska was washed out. Additionally, Farm to Market Road 1041 near Texas State Highway 256 southwest of Memphis was reportedly washed out.

As a surface boundary was moving through Lubbock County, thunderstorms developed along this boundary in the southern portion of the County. These thunderstorms caused the boundary to stall out and allow thunderstorms to train over southern Lubbock County. Rain gages near Woodrow measured as much as four inches of rain within a two hour period.

A cyclic tornadic supercell persisted for several hours near the intersection of Bailey, Lamb, Hockley, and Cochran Counties. This thunderstorm brought copious amount of rainfall to this region leading to flash flooding over a widespread area. Most of the rainfall was observed over far southeastern Bailey County where between three and seven inches of rain fell. While conducting a tornado storm survey the next day, the NWS survey team discovered numerous roads that were impassable due to flooding.

A cyclic tornadic supercell persisted for several hours near the intersection of Bailey, Lamb, Hockley, and Cochran Counties. This thunderstorm brought copious amount of rainfall to this region leading to flash flooding over a widespread area. Most of the rainfall was observed over far southeastern Bailey County where between three and seven inches of rain fell. While conducting a tornado storm survey the next day, the NWS survey team discovered numerous roads that were impassable due to flooding.

A cyclic tornadic supercell persisted for several hours near the intersection of Bailey, Lamb, Hockley, and Cochran Counties. This thunderstorm brought copious amount of rainfall to this region leading to flash flooding over a widespread area. Most of the rainfall was observed over far southeastern Bailey County where between three and seven inches of rain fell. While conducting a tornado storm survey the next day, the NWS survey team discovered numerous roads that were impassable due to flooding.

Heavy rain fell across Scurry County and resulted in flash flooding. Multiple roads were impassable due to flash flooding across southern Scurry County. There was a high water rescue. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
High water covered FM 343 in the Atoy community and FM 1911 south of Alto.

County Road 879 and AJ Nichols Road was impassible due to high water. County Road 979 just past County Road 486 was covered in swift moving water. Highway 204 near the power plant was partially covered in high water.
FM 724 west of Tyler was closed due to flooding.
Portions of Strickland Springs Road, Candyman Road, FM 9, and other county roads near Elysian Fields were flooded and closed.
Several county roads in Southern Rusk County were flooded and closed.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Austin. A trained spotter reported several parking lots covered with eight inches of water at the intersection of Hwy 290 and Airport Blvd.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Austin. ATXFloods reported the low water crossing on Wasson Rd. at Williamson Creek was closed.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding of a low water crossing on Peach Tree Ln. at Peggy Garner Park.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Brewster County. Route 16 and Old Maverick from the Maverick Entrance were closed due to the flooding. Rocks up to bowling ball sized were being removed. A couple of cars were stalled. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding near Midland. There was street/road flooding which lead to street/road closures and vehicles stranded. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in the City of Midland. Multiple cars were stalled at the intersection of Midkiff Road and West Wadley Avenue. There were police rescues. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Midland. There was street/road flooding which lead to street/road closures and vehicles stranded. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Numerous reports were received of widespread flooding along US Highway 87 from the Lubbock/Lynn County Line into Tahoka. An estimated two to four inches of rain fell within an hour causing flooding. A rain gage in Tahoka reported a rainfall total of 3.50 inches.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Odessa. There were numerous vehicles stranded or stalled in high water across Odessa. Some intersections were completely inundated with water over one foot deep. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding of a low water crossing on Krienke Ranch Rd. at Brushy Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Del Rio. A picture on social media showed the intersection of Veterans Blvd. and 10th St. flooded.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Edwards County along the Nueces River. A video on social media showed swiftly flowing water through a low water crossing on Dry Creek Rd. near Barksdale.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in rural Kinney County. A trained storm spotter reported 2 to 2.5 feet of fast-moving water through a low water crossing on FM 334 at Live Oak Creek.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding near Dunn. Farm to Market Road 1606 and Roadrunner Path were closed due to high water. The cost of damage was a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding near Ira. Block Line Road and Farm to Market Road 1606 were closed due to high water. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Jeff Davis County. There was a video of flowing water over Farm to Market Road 1832 west of State Highway 17 between Balmorhea and Fort Davis.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Scurry County. There was a report of water over the road along County Road 4156 between Highway 208 and China Grove.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Scurry County. County Road 1609 north of Ira was almost impassible due to flooding.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Scurry County. Farm to Market Road 1606 and County Road 397 were closed due to high water. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Video on Twitter showed cars driving through approximately a foot of water on N. Lamar Blvd. at W. 24th St. in Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Austin. Old San Antonio Rd. was closed at Slaughter Creek just south of the Southpark Meadows Shopping Center.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Austin. Waller Creek overflowed its banks and flooded W. 45th St. and Ave. F.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported that a portion of US Highway 84 was underwater due to heavy rainfall and a large backup in traffic occurred due to the flooded roadway.
Several roads were flooded and closed in Longview.
Several roads flooded and closed near Gladewater.
Holly Road washed out in one area due to flooding.
Flooding reported on County Road 1513 and County Road 1560.
Trained spotter posted a picture of street flooding at an intersection on West Alice Avenue in Kingsville.
Photographs on social media showed that a portion of US Highway 87 near Farm to Market Road 41 was flooded.

A photograph on social media showed a vehicle that had drifted off the road at a low water crossing in Brownfield. The Brownfield police department confirmed that there were several flooded out vehicles throughout town. Additionally, heavy rainfall led to several flooded out buildings in town.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding that closed US 55 near Montell along the Nueces River. There were pictures of water over the road on social media.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Austin. ATXFloods reported the low water crossing at W. 9th St. and Lamar Blvd. at Shoal Creek was closed.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Austin. Pictures on Twitter showed water in the halls of Murchison Middle School.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Del Rio. A car was stranded in flood water at Kings Way and Mary Lou Dr.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding that closed US 55 south of Camp Wood along the Nueces River. A trained spotter sent pictures of water over the road.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATXFloods reported the low water crossing at the Woodview Mobile Home Park on West Bouldin Creek off Oltorf St. was closed in Austin.

The Texas Department of Transportation reported that a portion of Farm to Market Road 597 was closed due to water over the roadway approximately three miles south of Pep. Radar imagery revealed that storms repeatedly trained over northeastern Hockley County for several hours. Although radar reflectivities were not incredibly high during this time, the repeated storms and very efficient rainfall production led to localized flooding.
Belton Alert Gauges reported a rise of 7 feet on Nolan Creek at Roy Reynolds Drive, about a mile and a half northeast of Killeen Skylark Airport.
Belton Alert Gauges reported a rise of 8.5 feet on South Nolan Creek at Twin Creek Road just north of Skylark Airport.
Belton Alert Gauges reported a rise of 9 feet on South Nolan Creek at Paddy Hamilton Road, about 4 miles east of Nolanville.
Three feet of running water was observed running over Webb Rd near HWY 136 where it dips down.
The intersection of Jefferson Avenue and Raguet Street in Downtown Lufkin was flooded.
Flooding forced the closure of North Phillips Spring Road, with several vehicles stranded in the high water.
A social media video indicated significant flooding near Crockett Street and West 7th Street in Fort Worth, with water depth near the tops of car tires.
A social media video indicated water knee to thigh deep in the 7th Street area of Fort Worth.
Broadcast media reported several high water rescues across Dallas.

Torrential rainfall, with local estimates of 2 or more inches per hour for two hours, produced street flooding from San Benito through La Tina Ranch, including along city and rural roads, with 1 to 2 feet of water on roads where the heaviest rainfall fell.  There were no reports of flooding of structures in these areas, and flood receded quickly after the slow moving band ended.
Video received on social media showing water running  over a rural road from ditch to ditch.
Standing water of a couple to 6 observed on  back roads in and around Parsley Rd and  Bertrand south of HWY 136.
Standing water seen on broadcast media  webcam covering theater parking lot in Palo Duro State Park.
Texas DPS reported that northbound lanes of Interstate 35W near the intersection of Highway 67 were closed due to high water.
A public report indicated several inches of rain in east Dallas with water over the curbs and covering sidewalks.
Broadcast media reported that Alcott Street in Dallas, TX was flooded and water had entered the first floor of an apartment building.
Multiple vehicles reported stranded and rescue crews dispatched between 240 PM and 4 PM due to flooding caused by thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall.

Reports started flooding in that many roads were flooded near the Interstate 30, Interstate 35E, and Interstate 45 interchanges. Vehicles were stranded, being pushed around by the flood waters, and high water rescues were required. Interstate 30 near Cesar Chavez Blvd was closed due to high water. Damage assessments after the event showed the extent of damage due to high water extended north across the city. This area took several hours to drain after the heavy rain ended. A total of up to 10 inches of rain was reported in this area.

A public report indicated that 2 feet of water had entered an apartment complex in east Dallas, knocking the front door off of its hinges. Considerable flash flooding occurred in this area after around 10 inches of rain fell in just a few hours.
Broadcast media reported that a woman was found dead after her car was swept away by flood waters of South Mesquite Creek along the service road of Loop 635.
Texas DPS reported that Interstate 635 at Scyene Road was closed down due to high water. Considerable flash flooding happened in this area after over 10 inches of rain fell in a few hours.

Broadcast media reported considerable street and home flooding in Balch Springs, with cars inundated and water rescues needed. The area in and around Balch Springs was hit the hardest of the flood event where over 15 inches of rain was measured.
Dallas Police Department reported at least 42 roads with calls reporting high water.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. ATXFloods reported the low water crossing at Edgegrove Dr. and Bee Caves Rd. near Eanes Creek in West Lake Hills was closed.
Amateur radio reported that northbound State Highway 198 was closed due to flooding, approximately 2 miles south of FM 47.
A public report indicated that Glenview Dr near Diamond Lock Apartments was closed due to high water.
A public report indicated that Big Fossil Creek flowed out of its banks across Glenview Dr in North Richland Hills. One car was swept off of the road.
A storm chaser reported many roads flooded and cars stalled northwest of Seagoville.
A public report indicated notable flash flooding along Harbor Drive in the city of Azle.
Fort Worth Fire and Rescue was working 25 high water calls at 10 AM CDT.
Low water crossings flooded along 169, FM 2761. Road closed.
Broadcast media reported that people were being rescued from their homes along Hickory Tree Road in Balch Springs. Water depth was knee to thigh deep at the time of the report.
As of 1125 AM, Fort Worth Fire and Recue had responded to 133 high water calls since 10 AM CDT.
Amateur radio reported that Cedar Creek is out of its banks and flowing over FM 4017 in Kaufman County, TX.
A public report indicated water to be about 2 feet deep neat the intersection of Belt Line and Sky Line Roads in Grand Prairie.
Law enforcement reported that Highway 377 at Marshall Ridge Drive, and Bear Creek Road at Bear Creek Park were closed down due to high water.

Considerable flooding continued across a large portion of Dallas after upwards of 15 inches of rain fell in some areas. Numerous roads, vehicles, homes, buildings and more were flooded and heavily damaged by this event.
The Trinity River in Fort Worth rose out of its bank and over Forest Park Rd from I-30 to Weatherford Road.

Notable flooding was reported around Canton. Specifically: Streets and roads were flooded along Rollins Rd and water may have entered a few homes. The EM's office on SH 64 experienced flooding around the office, and water up to 5 deep entered the office. Outside the office, pictures show the water was at least a foot deep in some areas. The location of First Trade Days was flooded with over a foot of water in some areas.
Flooding was noted on County Road 4094 where the water was widespread and several feet deep. One person had to be rescued from their home. The flood waters did enter some structures in this area.
Flooding was noted on County Road 4094 where the water was widespread and several feet deep. One person had to be rescued from their home. The flood waters did enter some structures in this area.
Part of Union Hill Rd was washed out, trapping 10 families.
Interstate 45 where it connects with Business I45 north of Palmer was closed due to water over the roadway. Traffic was blocked/stopped.
Several roads in Red Oak were closed due to high water, and a bridge was washed out on Batchler Road.
Weakly Branch Road was closed due to high water/flooding, likely from the nearby creek.
Bee Creek Road near FM 66 was closed due to high water.
Spence Road, and Gin Road near Walker Creek Road were all closed due to high water.
Numerous roads were flooded across both the Texas and Arkansas sides of Texarkana.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Eagle Pass. TxDOT reported flooding on El Indio Hwy just northwest of Memo Robinson Dr.
Broadcast meteorologist shared a public photo of street flooding in northwest Victoria.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in rural Bandera County between Tarpley and Utopia. The Bandera County Sheriff's Office reported Seco Creek had left its banks and flooded FM 470.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Real County. TxDOT closed Hwy 55 south of Camp Wood due to flooding.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Edwards County. The Edwards County Sheriff's Office reported several low water crossings on Hwy 55 near Barksdale were flooded and impassable.

Multiple reports and pictures relayed to the weather office over Facebook and Twitter, of minor flooding and ponding of water on roads and in residential yards. Rainfall reports of 1.5 to slightly over 2 of rain were received.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Del Rio. The Del Rio Police Department reported several roads flooded around the city.
Heavy rain caused Little Pine Island to go over bank full and flood streets around Pinewood Estates.
Stream gages indicated multiple bayous or ditches overflowed in China and Hampshire. Numerous roads were also flooded by several inches of rain in west Jefferson County.
High water was reported on several roads near the downtown area. Barricades were requested to close off affected roads.
Multiple streets in the South Shore Estates of Corpus Christi were flooded.

Heavy rain resulted in flooding in Big Bend National Park. All dirt roads, backcountry roadside campsites, and at least one paved road were closed throughout Big Bend National Park due to flooding. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in Terrell County. There was several feet of floodwater in Sanderson Canyon which resulted in evacuations. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in the Big Bend National Park. A section of the Lost Mine Trail collapsed which resulted in heavy damage to that section of trail. The bottom of the trail was covered in rocks and the top of the trail was too narrow to safely cross. The trail was closed as a result. Also, high water and debris crossed the pavement along the Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive. The pavement was broken off and washed away. Logs and rocks were washed onto the road which made it unsafe to travel. The damage and debris resulted in the road being closed. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in the City of Midland. There were multiple stalled vehicles reported in flash flooding at the intersections of North Loop 250 and Lancashire, North Garfield and Castleford, and Midland Drive and Wadley. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding in north Odessa. There was a road closure at the intersection of Andrews Highway and 87th Street in north Odessa due to flooding. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Thunderstorms produced moderate rain that caused minor street flooding at Hwy 281 and Thousand Oaks Dr. and a low water crossing on Copper Hill Dr. in northern San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced moderate rain that closed several low water crossings in Shavano Park.

Very heavy rainfall fell over Macho Creek in western Duval County with radar estimates showing 8 to 15 inches of rainfall. Flood waters rose on Macho Creek and moved into the community of Realitos. Two homes on south Cadena Street between Highway 359 and Adkins Street had water up to the window sills. Around 20 people were evacuated, with some of them going to a shelter in Benavides. Multiple agencies responded to the rescue effort.
Multiple streets were flooded with some cars stranded in Port Arthur, Nederland, and Groves. Water also approached some structures in Port Arthur.
Several inches of rainfall provided mostly minor flooding in Orange and Bridge City, however several streets were closed during the event.
Six to 8 inches of water was over the road on Hondo Pass near Dyer. Two lanes of Dyer southbound had standing water as well.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. An observer near Saint Hedwig reported 8.39 inches of rain in four hours. Several low water crossings in eastern Bexar County were closed due to flooding.
Brief heavy rain produced minor flooding in southern Austin. A low water crossing on Old San Antonio Rd. near I-35 filled with water.
Brief heavy rain produced minor flooding northwest of Elgin. A low water crossing in the 13300 block of County Line road filled with water.
Brief heavy rain produced minor flooding near Austin Bergstrom International Airport. Minor street flooding was reported at Carson Creek and Hoeke Ln.
Multiple public reports indicated water quickly entering homes near the intersection of Loop 820 and Trinity Blvd.
Broadcast media reported several high water rescues in the Fort Worth, Mansfield and Arlington areas.
A man drowned when his car was swept off the road in the vicinity of a low water crossing near the 7000 Block of Webb Ferrell Road in Arlington, TX.

Broadcast media reported that a woman drowned after waters rose in a ravine that she and her husband were located in near the intersection of Southwest Parkway and Bellaire Blvd in Lewisville, TX. The man broke his legs while fleeing the rising waters.
The Runnels County Sheriff office reported flooding along County Road 300.
Multiple streets were flooded in Center. Several vehicles were stalled in high water.

Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding one mile south southwest of Colorado City. There was street and road flooding which lead to street and road closures. Vehicles were stranded. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Heavy rain fell across Reeves County and resulted in flash flooding near Balmorhea. There was a high water rescue. A person in a pickup drove through a low water crossing south of Balmorhea Lake. The pickup and driver were washed 1000 feet downstream. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
State Highway 286 between Farm to Market Roads 2444 and 70 was closed due to flooding.
Farm to Market Road 70 was closed between US Highway 77 and State Highway 286 due to flooding on Petronila Creek.

Through social media, there were several pictures of flooding on the east side of San Angelo including near Fort Concho and near Goodfellow AFB. In addition. stranded cars due to flooding were reported in the city.
Water was flowing quickly near a residence.  Water was up to Highway 180 and could have been flowing over it.
The northwest loop ramp to southbound State Highway 286 was closed due to flooding.
The Nueces Bay Boulevard exit on Martin Luther King Drive was closed due to flooding.
Water was over the road on Seaside Loop and various other low lying roads north of Lamar.
Major flooding occurred in southeast La Salle County as a flood wave from San Casamiro Creek moved through. Major flooding cut off extensive portions of the flood plain.

Major flooding occurred in southern and central McMullen County as a flood wave continued to move down the Nueces River. Major flooding cut off extensive portions of the flood plain with several roads flooded.

Major flooding occurred in central Live Oak County as a flood wave continued to move down the Nueces River. Significant low land flooding occurred. Several homes were flooded in the River Creek Acres subdivision, southeast of George West. Roads and bridges near the river were flooded.
Multiple vehicles were stranded by floodwaters in the vicinity of the Interstate 45 and TX Highway 3 corridor.
Street flooding leading to impassable roadways was reported in Texas City.
Dickinson's Emergency Operations Center reported 5.25 inches of storm total rainfall, resulting in widespread flooding on multiple streets throughout the city.
San Casamiro Creek flood waters covered Highway 44. TXDOT closed the highway between Freer and Encinal.

Very heavy rainfall fell over Macho Creek in western Duval County with radar estimates showing 8 to 15 inches of rainfall. Flood waters rose on Macho Creek and moved into the community of Realitos. Two homes on south Cadena Street between Highway 359 and Adkins Street had water up to the window sills. Around 20 people were evacuated, with some of them going to a shelter in Benavides. Multiple agencies responded to the rescue effort.
Report received through Mping of yards being flooded along with waters flooding a basement near Ennis Joslin Road to the west northwest of the Naval Air Station.
Emergency manager reported street flooding in area around McKinzie Road and Leopard Street to Interstate 37 where the right two lanes were flooded.
Emergency manager reported street flooding across the city from Flour Bluff to southeast Corpus Christi to Midtown to the Bayfront area.

Harbor Bridge construction project crews temporarily closed the Port Avenue and Nueces Bay Boulevard exits to Martin Luther King Drive and the northwest loop ramp connecting to southbound Crosstown Expressway in downtown Corpus Christi.
Public reported street flooding in the southeast part of Laredo.
Farm to Market Road 624 southeast of Cotulla had flood waters covering the road.
Post on Twitter was received of flooded waters on roadways reaching car bumpers from Flour Bluff to Rodd Field Road.
