Houses were flooded near Barrios Street and near Arkansas Avenue in southeast Laredo.
Flood waters entered homes in northwest Laredo.
Rodd Field Road south of SPID became flooded and impassible with flood waters. Report by NWS employee of stalled cars with water up to the windows in spots.
Emergency manager reported street flooding at Everhart Road and McArdle Road in Corpus Christi.
Water was over the roads near Loma Alta.
Several people were rescued from flooded homes in a low lying area in southeast Laredo.

Emergency manager reported access roads on Interstate 37 were flooded near Labonte Park.
Public reported flooding of streets in northeast part of Laredo.

Report received through social media of Interstate 35 flooded south of Encinal.

Emergency management reported 2 to 3 feet of water on the underpass at Highway 164 and Rusk Street in Groesbeck, TX.
Emergency management reported flash flooding in Leona.
A public report indicated street flooding 3 miles west-northwest of Temple, TX.
A trained spotter reported street flooding about a mile east-southeast of Marlin, TX, with up to 5 inches of water on the road.
Texas Department of Transportation reported Farm to Market Road 1944 was closed due to flooding.
Texas Department of Transportation reported water over the road on Farm to Market Road 1945 west of Sinton.

Corpus Christi Emergency Manager reported the 4500 block of Baldwin Boulevard was flooded.
Corpus Christi Emergency Manager reported flooding at the intersection of South Padre Island Drive and Greenwood Drive.
Public reported video of street flooding with water up to the curbs in the west part of Portland.

The Virginia Circle area was evacuated due to flooding. An estimated four feet of water  was in the parking lot of the Oakridge  Apartments as well as some commercial buildings in the area  were flooded. An estimated 130 people and 20  pets were evacuated per Amarillo Fire Department.  Multiple high water rescues were conducted by the fire department in order to evacuate residents. Multiple cars were swept away by the flood waters, ending up in ditches and submerged in water. Areas between Georgia Street and Paramount Boulevard, and from Duniven Circle area to Duncan Street were covered by standing water. Loop 335 east and westbound service road at Western as well as I-40  service road at Western were closed due to water over the roadway.
Emergency management reported damage to a fence at Wood Family Dog Park from approximately 5 inches of rushing water. Trees were also washed away at the park.
Public reported roads flooded to the south side of Corpus Christi.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Culverts filled with water and washed road edges on CR 532 east of Moulton.
Water flooded yards due to heavy rainfall with water flowing down streets near Calallen.
High water covered Highway 96 between Center and Tenaha.
Boggy Creek exceeded bank full flooding adjacent areas near Lumberton.
Water rose above bank full on drainage ditches north of Buna flooding area roads.
Streets were flooded and cars were stalled due to heavy rain.
Flash flooding occurred on numerous roadways around Victoria. This included the Navarro Street and Laurent Street Underpasses, the Five Points area, and Crestwood Drive and Ben Jordan Street.

Law enforcement reports street flooding in Coleman.

Fire and rescue reported swift water multiple feet high and several road closures in the city of Gunter, TX.
Emergency management reported that U.S. Highway 377 near the Grayson/Denton County line was impassable due to high water over the roadway.
Emergency management reported that U.S. Highway 75 at FM 902 was impassable due to high water.

High water flooded multiple roads and vehicles across the Texas side of Texarkana.

Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that caused street flooding along Salado Creek  near Hollywood Park.
Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that flooded the area around US Hwy 183 and Duval Rd. Approximately 30 vehicles were stranded in high water and at least 21 water rescues were performed.

Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that caused flash flooding at I-410 and Evers Rd. and I-410 and Bandera Rd. The San Antonio Fire Department had to rescue people from cars stranded in the water.
Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that flooded roads in Jollyville.
High water was reported in the Dobbin area due to heavy rain around the intersection of Dobbin Rd and FM1486.
Both lanes of FM 2429 between SH 36 and GM 949 were closed due to floodwaters making the road impassable.

The worst of the flooding was near John & Olive Hinojosa Elementary School at the corner of Embassy Street and E Hinojosa Street. The flooding was caused by a thunderstorm moving slowly across southern Starr County, which produced an estimated 0.75 to 1 of rain in approximately 20 minutes. Timing based on radar estimates and the social media post.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. A car was stranded in flood water near the St. Mary's St. bridge over the San Antonio River in downtown San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Bexar Floods reported flooding on Old Corpus Christi Rd. near Salado Creek in southern San Antonio.
The intersection of US-59 and Tidwell Rd was flooded by heavy rain and made impassable.
Several areas were flooded across NE Harris County, including FM529 and Hwy 290, Roberts Cemetery Rd, Mesquite River Trl at Old Windmill Trl, and 249 at Killough St.
Water over the roadways around Canal and 66th St made streets impassable.
The Mt. Moriah Rd Bridge was closed due to high water as a result of flooding rain.
N Eldridge Pkway was made impassable due to floodwaters between FM 1960 and Falbrook.
Standing water was reported on the I-69 frontage Rd near Kingwood.

Numerous thunderstorms trained over the same area in northern Castro County early in the morning of the 27th. In addition to the training, intense rain rates led to flash flooding and many road closures. An estimated seven to nine inches of rain fell over a period of only a few hours. Farm to Market Road 1057 from Summerfield south to Farm to Market Road 2397 was closed due to flooding. Water was also covering several other roads in northern Castro County making them impassable.
A thunderstorm very slowly moved over central and southern Swisher County which brought heavy rainfall for several hours. Interstate 27 was closed due to flooding between Tulia and Kress.

A slow moving thunderstorm produced heavy rainfall over a portion of northern Cochran County which caused flash flooding. Law enforcement reported flooding on roadways at several locations in rural Cochran County.

Numerous reports were received of flooded roads in the city of Lubbock and Lubbock County. Several roads were impassable and as a result were closed due to water over the roadway. Some vehicles became stranded in high waters.
Law enforcement in Terry County reported water over the roadway on US Highway 385 between county roads 210 and 230.
A slow moving thunderstorm over southern Yoakum County created flash flooding along Texas State Highway 83 west of Denver City.
A slow moving thunderstorm moved over Motley County creating flash flooding in and around Matador. The Motley County sheriff's office reported water over the roadway on US  Highway 70/62 in Matador.

A severe thunderstorm which brought severe winds to Lubbock County also caused flash flooding around the city of Lubbock. Numerous roads in Lubbock became flooded from heavy rainfall in a short amount of time.
A severe thunderstorm very slowly moved across Hale County just to the north of Plainview causing flash flooding in and around the intersection of Farm to Market Road 788 and Interstate 27.
Laredo Police Department reported flooded streets on the north side of Laredo.
Public reported street flooding on the south side of Laredo.

Law Enforcement reported Farm to Market Road 1661 and Highway 6 flooded.

There was street and road flooding and vehicles stranded.

North Travis Street and U.S. Highway 75 quickly flooded due to prolonged heavy rain. The U.S. 75 service roads also flooded.

Brushy Creek overflowed Interstate 30 near FM 1565 and several cars were stuck in high water. The fast moving water swept one car off the road on the north service road and unfortunately the elderly man drowned.
A NWS Employee reported 1 to 2 feet of flowing water just east of the intersection of Green Meadow Drive and Oak Grove Blvd. at the low water crossing.

Four inches of rain fell in two hours leading to street flooding which caused some road closures in Booker.

Numerous reports came in for water covering roads, with fast flowing water leading to numerous roads being impassable in several areas. Drainage  ditches and playa lakes began overflowing onto  roads and encroaching on homes in the  southwest side of Amarillo.
Black Creek rapidly rose into minor flood stage after 3 to 8 inches of rainfall.
Streets flooded after several inches of rain. One car was stalled in the intersection of Amaryllis St. and Bluebonnet Dr.
Multiple streets were flooded and closed across the south side of Nacogdoches. Flooding of roads were widespread across Nacogdoches County.
The 3500 block of South Street in Nacogdoches was flooded and closed. A water rescue was needed for a stalled vehicle in the flood waters.
Highway 96 south of Tenaha was closed due to flooding. Numerous roads were also flooded and closed in Timpson.

A driver encountered approximately 6 inches  of water on the roadway, causing him to  hydroplane. The swift running water carried the driver's vehicle about 80 feet from the roadway and into 3 feet of water. This person was rescued by local officials.
Multiples roads were flooded throughout Central Rusk County with a few roads closed.

Multiple roads remain flooded and closed across the south side of Nacogdoches due to significant flooding along Bayou La Nana. Multiple other roads were also flooded and closed throughout much of Nacogdoches County.
The parking lot of Dameron Park was flooded.  Around  2 inches of rain was measured in 30 minutes by local ground observation stations.
Gordon Cummings Road was flooded due to  heavy rainfall and the overflowing of local creeks.  A water rescue did occur along this road.
Vehicles stranded near Windthorst.
Multiple roads were flooded and closed through Central and Southern Panola County.

The USGS Gauge on Bayou La Nana in Nacogdoches recorded a 14.3 foot rise and crested at 19.65 feet at 10 am, May 11th. This resulted in catastrophic flooding across the city of Central and Southern Nacogdoches, including the Stephen F. Austin State University campus.
Local media had reported that water was getting into businesses around Hereford.

Multiple vehicles with people inside, wound up in the ditch on US Highway 60. Reports of 6 inches of hail and 4 inches of water in the area. Water from Tierra Blanca Creek was reported to overtake the bottom of the Highway 60 bridge and start flowing over the highway.

Torrential rainfall rates of 3 to 5 inches  per hour resulted in major street flooding  throughout town. Vehicles were stranded with  several water rescues being conducted. Some streets had fast  flowing water over a foot deep covering the  street.
Coulter was closed at the north and south lanes at the intersection of 45th Avenue. Multiple water rescues were being conducted.
Water was reported to be across the road at the Canyon exit of I-27. A car had spun out and ended up in a ditch with deep water.

Fast moving water moved a truck bed camper at least 30 feet, and washed away several tents. As well as moved several other trailers. Flooding led to Park Road 5 being closed from the Lighthouse parking lot to the Cactus picnic area.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several cars were stranded in flood water in a low water crossing at Lookout Rd. and Old O'Conner Rd. in northeastern San Antonio. A couple of people were rescued from their cars.

The heavy rain also caused the North Fork Double Mountain fork Brazos River to rise above flood stage on the southeast side of Lubbock. Heavy rainfall in Denison caused water to flow into businesses in the downtown area. Multiple low-lying and poor drainage portions of roads were also closed in the area.

Intense rain rates occurred with thunderstorm activity over central Lubbock County affecting the city of Lubbock in addition to the severe thunderstorm winds. Numerous vehicles became stalled out on the east side of the city of Lubbock. In addition, many roads were closed across Lubbock with water over the roadway. The flooding persisted well into the afternoon of the 15th as the water moved downstream into Buffalo Springs Lake and Ransom Canyon. A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site on the campus of Texas Tech University measured 2.43 inches of rain in 20 minutes. At least one home experienced flooding at Ransom Canyon on the south side of the lake.
Extensive water in flood prone areas from near Executive and Paisano Drive to Porfirio Diaz into downtown El Paso. Several stalled vehicles and water running across highways.
Flooding of numerous streets and intersections occurred on the east and south side of the Laredo.
Public weather station recorded 3.66 inches in under an hour with a storm total near 4.5 inches. This caused flooding of roads on the south side of Laredo.
Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending three feet of water over RM 335 near and downstream of the Ben Williams crossing on the Nueces River.
Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that sent the Llano River out of its banks. The river flooded FM 3404/Slab Rd. in Kingsland.
Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing low water crossings along RM 648 near and east of Doss.
Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several low water crossings were flooded south of Kyle including on Roland Ln. and Bunton Ln.

Torrential rainfall led to near zero visibilities along US Highway 84 in northeastern Hockley County as reported by local law enforcement and from public reports. Storms slowly trained over the area from central Hockley County from north of Levelland to near Anton. Water was reportedly over the roadway along US Highway 385 between Whitharral and Levelland.
Video evidence was sent to the forecast office in Lubbock of water rushing over Santa Fe Street east of Whiteface.

Slow moving storms with intense rain rates moved over Parmer County dropping as much as one inch of rainfall in less than 20 minutes. The Friona Police Department reported that US Highway 60 in Friona was flooded. Additionally, portions of US Highway 60 outside of Friona had water over the roadway.

Thunderstorms with heavy rainfall became anchored over Lynn County during the mid-morning hours. The Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near O'Donnell measured 7.02 inches of rainfall. The intense rain rates and amount of rainfall resulted in the closure of a portion of US Highway 87 between O'Donnell and Tahoka. Numerous water rescues were completed and many vehicles became stranded in the flood waters.

The same slow moving storms that brought intense rainfall and flash flooding to Parmer County also moved over Swisher County. Similarly, the intense rainfall brought over an inch of rainfall in less than 20 minutes. The Tulia Police Department reported that several roads in town were flooded along with a few County Roads along US Highway 87.

Thunderstorms that became anchored over Lynn County bringing extensive flash flooding slowly moved into central and northern Garza County spreading intense rain rates along with it. Widespread flash flooding was reported throughout central and northern Garza County. Additionally, a tractor trailer rolled over on US Highway 84 near Farm to Market Road 399 also causing a multiple vehicle wreck.
A trained spotter reported 1.7 inches of rain in 35 minutes.

Torrential rains of nearly 4 inches in an hour (2 to 3 PM CST; 3 to 4 PM CDT) fell across west Brownsville as a strong cluster of thunderstorms eased through the city. More than 3 feet of water piled up near the B&M Bridge along Mexico Blvd. near the bridge (and in the C and D street vicinity.  Several cars were submerged up to the hoods. A CoCoRaHS observer in the Los Ebanos community, 2 miles northeast of the worst flooding, recorded 3.7 inches of rain.

Torrential rainfall in a little more than an hour dropped between 2 and 2.7 inches of rain from east of downtown Brownsville into residential and commercial areas to the north, including known flood-prone areas along SR-4 (Boca Chica Blvd.), IH-69E frontage between Boca Chica and Morrison Blvd., and eastward to Paredes Line road.  Street flooding was most common in these areas, with water levels below 2 feet.
Reports of street flooding in the city of  Perryton were received from broadcast media.  Also it was reported that around 4 rainfall received in a short period of time.

Emergency management reported multiple roadways flooded with flowing water throughout the city of Sherman.

Over one foot of rain occurred around the Kirbyville area in a short period of time. Several feet of flood water inundated numerous homes. The local fire department conducted several high water rescues.

Texas Department of Transportation reported numerous road closures due to flooding over North Beach. In addition, there were several reports of water over portions of HWY-358 and in poor drainage areas.
Texas Department of Transportation reported closure due to water over roadways on FM70 from US-77 in Bishop to Chapman Ranch.

Law enforcement reported an effort in progress helping a family out of their home which had about 2 feet of water running through it. Law enforcement also reported that E. Ranch Rd./FM 2169 is closed from Segovia to Junction.

Multiple roads in Beaumont, Nederland, and Port Neches were closed during a slow moving line of thunderstorms including Highway 380, 347, and 366 and Nall Street. Flooding of several streets were also reported in China and Hampshire. Taylor Bayou also overflowed near Hampshire.
Coleman Fire Chief reports 4 water rescues, several streets closed due to flooding, and water up to the window on a TXDOT truck.
FM 2827 flooded along Kimball Creek during a heavy thunderstorm.
Heavy rain flooded underpasses in Beaumont. Twin City Highway flooded through Central Gardens and multiple streets also flooded in Nederland.
Numerous streets were reported flooded around Jasper including FM 252 south of town and multiple county roads north of town.
Significant flooding was reported across the county roads in Jasper County east of Town Bluff.
Pin Oak Creek at South Elizabeth Avenue in Kirbyville rose above its banks flooding near by fields and roads. The stream rose 5 feet in 3 hours.
Flooding was reported in Vidor with Main Street and the I-10 underpass being closed due to high water.
Stream gauges near Silsbee and Bevil Oaks indicated water rose out out of the banks of Mill Creek and Little Pine Island Bayou.
TX 356 was impassable due to flash flooding.
Flooding resulted in multiple water rescues along FM 1696.
Russel Creek flooded FM 1745 during a heavy thunderstorm. Roads also began to flood near Colmesneil.
The stream gauge on Little Cypress Creek at County Road indicated the creek rose out of its banks.
A report was received of water over roadways in Port Neches.
Minor street flooding occurred from Beaumont through Central Gardens. Stream gages also indicated bayous and ditches in the area were overflowing.
Minor street flooding occurred north of Sour Lake. A stream gage also indicated water exceeded bank full.
Roads became flooded in Kountze and near Honey Island during heavy rain. Mill Creek also rose beyond bank full north of Silsbee.
Black Creek overflowed flooding Highway 326.
Heavy rain caused roads on the north side of Beaumont near the Parkdale Mall be be flooded.
The Woodville Fire Department reported water covering multiple streets in Woodville along with Turkey Creek flooding nearby roads. Multiple roads were also flooded near Town Bluff and Fred.
Black Creek caused FM 326 to become impassable.
Several roads were reported flooded in Lumberton and Silsbee, some with deep water. The gauge on Mill Creek also indicated the stream exceeded its banks.
Flooding was reported from Spurger to Town Bluff on FM 92 and several county roads. Flooding resulted in the temporary closing of FM 92.
Several roads were reported flooded with some closed from Spurger to Woodville to Warren.
Flooding was reported around Beaumont with portions of 380 closed from high water.
Portions of County Road 3073 were closed due to high water.
The emergency manager of Hardin County reported water over SH 327 in Silsbee. Mill Creek also exceeded bankfull.
Public reported flooding across US 83.
Heavy rain caused multiple roads to be flooded from Warren to Colmesneil.
A stream gage reported minor flooding along Black Creek. This caused minor flooding of roads north of Sour Lake.
A stream gage indicated water over Landis Drive southwest of Beaumont. Other locations also received minor flooding during the event with shallow water over roadways on the southside of Beaumont.
Law Enforcement reported flooded roads between Millersview and Lake O.H. Ivie.
Public reported on social media that 4th Street and Good Shepard Drive were covered in water and that many sections of both 3rd and Magnolia streets were also flooded.
Public reported minor to moderate flooding with the depth of the water knee deep. Also, 2.90 inches of rainfall was reported.
Texas Department of Transportation reported that FM 583 in Brown County had been closed due to flooding.
Texas Department of Transportation reported US 183 from Early to the Brown/Eastland County line had been closed due to flooding.
Vehicle stalled due to high water with water rescue team on scene.
A public report indicated 10 flooded roads throughout the city of Dallas.

The City of Fort Worth reported several flooded roads from heavy rain: west Bonds Ranch Road, Randol Mill Rd, Waggley Robertson Road, Old Granbury Road, Golden Triangle at Alta Vista, Oak Grove Rd South, and NE 28th at Decatur Ave.
Broadcast media showed video of water covering residential roads in Hillsboro and water approximately 1-2 feet deep up to home foundations. The exact location of the impacted homes is uncertain.
Broadcast media had video showing flash flooding of homes and residential property in the city of Kaufman due to a slow-draining nearby reservoir during heavy rainfall.
Fire and rescue reported at least four roads in Temple inundated. There was also a report of one vehicle water rescue.
Report from mPING: Street/road flooding; street/road closed; vehicles stranded in Holland.
Fire and rescue reported a vehicle almost entirely submerged at a low water crossing.
Emergency management reported a high water rescue completed at a low water crossing underpass in Groesbeck.
Report from mPING: Street/road flooding; street/road closed; vehicles stranded along Hwy 164 east of Groesbeck.
Emergency management reported multiple roads closed due to flooding in the city of Teague, as well as the Hwy 84 railroad underpass north of town. Many roads had at least a foot of water.
Emergency management reported that the southbound Interstate 45 service road near mile marker 193 was closed due to flooding.
On Suzy K St in Tarrant County, 8 total homes had water damage of varying degrees. One residence had to be evacuated.

Multiple roads within the county were closed due to flooding including: FM 2728 east of Oak Ridge, CR 102, TX 243, and CR 118 near Ola, FM 2860 between Oak Grove and Becker, and CR 151 southeast of Kaufman. FM 1395 had approximately 1 foot of water flowing over the bridge, and a truck was reported as swept off the road on US 175 as well.

The same roadways that flooded two days prior flooded this morning as well including: FM 2728 east of Oak Ridge, CR 102, TX 243, and CR 118 near Ola, FM 2860 between Oak Grove and Becker, and CR 151 southeast of Kaufman. Minor flooding also reported across various other county roads.

Broadcast media reported flash flooding in Everman, where homes were flooded, roads were impassable, and some vehicles were stranded. According to local officials, the hardest hit area was homes along Christie Ave which backs up to a creek. Fourteen homes on this street had water in the homes varying up to 12 inches deep. Several of these residents were evacuated during the flooding. Local officials also reported 5 vehicle rescues during the flooding.
Multiple streets flooded in Bridge City including East Young Drive and Katherine Avenue. Water also covered yards and approached homes.

Numerous thunderstorms grew upscale on the evening of the ninth due to several outflow boundaries. A very moist atmosphere allowed storms to produce heavy rainfall in addition to severe hail and winds. One of these storms moved over Lubbock County producing rain rates between three to five inches per hour. This caused many roads in and around the city of Lubbock to become impassable to due water over the roadway. There was a brief lull in activity between storms around 1800 CST through 2030 CST. An additional thunderstorm after 2030 CST again produced flash flooding due to heavy rainfall.
FM Road 2497 near Highway 94 was flooded.
Emergency management reported several roads closed and county roads with culverts washed out.
Emergency management reported road closures in the area south of Moody and a culvert collapse at Dowell Road.
Emergency management reported SH 22 was flooded east and west of Frost.
Emergency management reported flooding in Mart. Water covered the yard of a resident and approached the house.

Emergency management reported multiple instances of flash flooding along Highway 317 from Temple to the McLennan County line; including impassable roads and at least one vehicle stranded in high water.
Emergency management reported that Highway 84 between Mexia and Teague was closed due to flash flooding.
Fire and rescue reported that Bushy Creek had overflowed its banks, flooding 3 or 4 homes along FM 1240. This required the evacuation of residents in the flooded homes.
Broadcast media reported 1 lane of Highway 175 closed at Highway 34, with high water rescues ongoing.
Emergency management reported 8 inches of water into 4 homes in Kaufman.
Amateur radio reported water covering Highway 80 through Grand Saline, with some downtown businesses also flooded.
Emergency management reported that numerous roads were closed between Tennessee Colony, Montalba, Elmwood, and Frankston. Creeks were overflowing and culverts were washed out.
Emergency management reported multiple swift water rescues overnight in Temple.
Emergency management reported a flooded roadway and parking lot at Sterrett Road and Highway 77 in Waxahachie.
Broadcast media showed video of water covering neighborhood roads in Pleasant Grove.
Emergency management reported widespread flooding with multiple roads closed in Rowlett.
Frontage roads where Nolan Creek crosses under I-35 were covered with several feet of water.
Emergency management reported road closures on Highway 377 near the Marshall Ridge neighborhood 3 miles south-southwest of Roanoke, TX due to high water from heavy rain.
Emergency management reported that CR 4730 in Wise County became impassable due to high water.
A property was flooded with water up to the porch through about noon.
Flash flooding reported with stalled vehicles in Nash along North Kings Highway between Interstate 30 and Highway 82.
Flash flooding reported on Main Street in Atlanta.
Multiple roads closed across Dallas due to flooding, including Northwest Highway and Hillcrest where numerous cars stalled in floodwaters at that intersection.
Several streets in Terrell flooded with stalled cars being reported near Moore Ave and 9th St.
A vehicle was swept off the road due to flash flooding between Valley View Rd and FM 548 near Forney.
CR 1345 is impassable due to flooding.
Multiple county roads flooded.
Emergency management reported flash flooding near the intersection of Highway 75 and Travis Blvd in Sherman, TX.
Emergency Management reported the closure of Campbell Road near Water Oak Dr in Dallas due to high water.
Emergency Management reported flooding at North Catherine Street and West Alamo Dr in Terrell, TX.
Emergency management reported multiple sections of Highway 2727 flooded.

Broadcast media reported that an SUV was found submerged in high water, and appeared to have been swept off the road from rushing water while crossing W Lawther Dr between NW Hwy and Goforth Rd. This location is just north of White Rock Lake.
Emergency management reported that Washington St at Highway 175 in Kaufman was flooded.
A trained spotter reported flooding along Mountain Creek Parkway. This location is just northeast of Joe Pool Lake.
Flash flooding reported with numerous roads covered in high water in Marshall, resulting in road closures throughout parts of Harrison County.
County Road 283 flooded and closed.
County Road 2164 near Lake Cherokee flooded and closed.

Widespread heavy rainfall of three to six inches with isolated higher amounts occurred across much of the Sabine River basin of East Texas from June 2nd through June 4th, inundating the basin and especially points farther upstream and namely at Longview. As a result, the Sabine River rose rapidly into major flood stage (35 feet) late on June 10th and eventually crested near 35.9 feet on June 11th. The river remained in moderate flood stage (30 feet) through mid morning on June 19th before receding through late June.
Flash flooding reported with multiple homes impacted on Tower Drive east of Loop 323 in Tyler.
Water rescues were conducted due to flash flooding in the park.  Pictures were provided to the NWS Amarillo through social media that depicted water  over roadways with stalled cars.
Flash flooding reported around the Wulf Creek subdivision in Center.
Flash flooding reported with high water across Highway 96 and Highway 87 just north of Center.
The gage at Terry Gully and FM 1442 reached minor flood stage and continued to rise. The gully overflowed into neighboring fields and streets.
The Jasper County 911 Center reported water over the intersection of FM 2799 and County Road 166. Several vehicles attempted to drive through and stalled. TXDOT closed the road.
Portions of MLK Parkway were under water along with several side streets.
The gage at Green Pond Road indicated the water had overflowed the ditch and covered the road.
Flash flooding reported with Highway 87 South between Center and Shelbyville covered in high water.
Flash flooding reported with Highway 96 at Southview Circle covered in high water.
Flash flooding reported with several roads closed in Jacksonville.
Several city roads across north Dallas were closed due to flooding.
Emergency manager reported that the 500 block of S Main St was impassable due to flooding with the water continuing to rise at time of report.
Local emergency management reported several stranded vehicles in high water at several locations across the city of Flower Mound, but all occupants were out of their vehicles by report time.
Flash flooding was reported in Sulphur Springs.
Several county roads closed due to flooding including CRs 514, 618, and 590. Emilia Drive, CR 601, West Street, and Highride Lane sustained road and culvert damage due to the flooding as well.
FM 36 and 1564 between Caddo Mills and Cash were closed due to flooding.
Water was over both sides of a creek bridge on College Street in Canton, and the road was impassable.
A social media video showed floodwaters entering a home in Ben Wheeler.
The local volunteer fire department reported Highway 95 was impassable in Holland due to high water.
Local emergency management reported several roads near Sulphur Wells Road were impassable due to floodwaters.
Social media images and video from a trained spotter showed high water across multiple streets in Holland.
Local emergency management reported CR 125 north of Buckholts had water over the road and was nearly impassable.
Flash flooding reported along FM Road 225 between Douglass and Cushing, resulting in the road being closed.
Flash flood reported with parts of Pearl Street in Nacogdoches covered in high water.
Minor road flooding was reported across the county.
Several county roads flooded, generally the same roads that flooded earlier in the week.
Road 321 near Catfish Creek flooded, as well as several low water crossings.
Multiple road closures were reported including Cowan Road and CRs 512, 331, 578, 618, 504, 590, 338, 572, 825, 668, 444, 581, and 424. A sink hole developed on CR 512 as well.
Emergency management reported flash flooding 3 miles north of Collinsville, TX.
A public report indicated flash flooding near the intersection of Highway 56 and FM 901 in Sadler, TX.
Public reports of water covering roads and  ponding on main street on the north side of  Shamrock were received.
Vehicle stranded with water flowing under  bridge on east Amarillo BLVD.
Media reported there were water rescues at N 18th Street and Treadway Boulevard, N 10th Street and Westmoreland Street, and along S 1st Street. People were helped out of vehicles in high water.
Trained spotter reports completely flooded roads in Westbrook.
TxDOT reports dirt and debris over the roadway, water over the roadway, and low-water crossings flooded.
Water reported to have entered a home on FM Road 9 south of FM Road 2625.
Flash flooding reported with high water covering FM Road 414.
Hwy 30 in College Station just to the east of Hwy 6 was inundated with floodwaters, making it impassable. Dollar damage estimates are cumulative including recent events within one month prior.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several roads in eastern Bandera County including Whartons Dock Rd., Schmidtke Rd., and Lake Forest Rd.

Beginning around 1700 CST to 1800 CST, severe thunderstorms began to train over eastern Stonewall County. These thunderstorms continued to back build for several hours not ending until approximately 2200 CST. Periodic rainfall rates of one to two inches per hour were estimated within this activity with a total of three to four inches of rainfall. Late in the evening, the Stonewall County sheriff's office stated that water was nearly flowing over US Highway 380 between Aspermont and Old Glory. Downstream of the reported flooding, the Double Mountain Fork Brazos River near Rule in Haskell County, Texas saw its fourth highest flow in the past four years of 2740 cubic feet per second.
Flooding from numerous heavy rain events in April and early May led to significant damage.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Cade Loop along the Guadalupe River in Ingram.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing RR 674 southwest of Rocksprings.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The Kerr County Emergency Manager reported flooding along Turtle Creek west of Kerrville. There was a car stuck in high water.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing several low water crossings on RR 336 north-northwest of Prade Ranch.
Emergency management reported that US 380 was closed due to flooding between Rule and FM 2407. The road was still closed on the morning of 4/28.
High water reported on city streets in and around Mount Pleasant, especially on the south side of the city.
Several roads flooded in Nacogdoches.
Highway 42 near County Road 468 flooded and impassable due to high water.
Public reported arroyos were out of their banks and stock tanks were overflowing. Also, reported 3.5 inches of rainfall.
Several roads impassable in Mount Pleasant due to very high water.
Flash flooding reported in Marshall with water covering the road at the corner of West Grand Avenue and Ward Street as well as two other nearby intersections.
Several roads covered in high water across central and southern Harrison County, including American Plant Road, FM Road 451 near Elysian Fields High School, Blocker Road and Five Notch Road.
Highway 190 near Menard Creek was impassable due to flash flooding.
High water reported on several county roads across the southern half of Franklin County.
County Road 4530 and FM Road 2869 closed due to flooding with high water reported on numerous other road surfaces across the northern and western portions of Wood County.
Flash flooding reported in Nacogdoches via mPING.
One lane of Highway 110 North near Whitehouse closed due to flooding.
Flash flooding reported with high water across portions of County Road 173 near Kilgore.
FM 2548 between Midway and Antioch was made impassable due to flooding. Damage totals include flooding over the month period.
The Interstate 45 frontage road north of Huntsville was made impassable due to flash flooding. Flooding dollar damage includes flooding from month leading up to this day.

A pocket of torrential rainfall from a nearly stationary isolated thunderstorm, with measured and estimated rainfall between 3 and 4 inches in a very small area around downtown Edinburg, left 3 feet of water in roads around the Courthouse building, some of which entered structures of estimated depths of 1 to 1.5 feet.  Damage was unknown at the time of this writing.

The City of Fort Worth reported 3 road closures due to flooding. Two were on the south side of town (2100 blk of Cunningham St and 11600 blk of Oak Grove Rd South), and one was just north of downtown (1900 Cold Springs Rd).
Emergency Management reports water flowing across fields over FM 612 near Fluvanna.
Emergency management continues to report many flooded roadways around the Fluvanna area.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing Hwy 83 south of Catarina.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding making the intersection of Kings Way and Mary Lou Dr. in Del Rio impassable.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing the northbound frontage road of I-35 between Randolph and Weidner in northeast San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding covering roads on the Trinity University campus. A few stranded vehicles had to be towed. The weather station on campus recorded 3.36 of rain between 6:45 AM CST and 8:15 AM CST.
Andrews County Emergency Management reported multiple road closures in the city of Andrews.
Curb to curb street flooding with flowing water in the Lone Star Trails Community.
This report was received from mPING. This report indicated potential road closures.
There have been many reports of flooded roadways, stranded vehicles, and water reaching homes throughout Odessa. The cost of property damage is an estimation.
There was a report of flooding in north Odessa, with one vehicle stuck in flood waters. Property damage cost is an estimation.
There was a report of flooding in north Odessa, with one vehicle stuck in flood waters. Property damage cost is an estimation.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding requiring several water rescues near the I-35/I-410 interchange in northeast San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The website ATXFloods.com reported several low water crossings were closed in north-central Llano County.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The website ATXFloods.com reported several low water crossings flooded along Slickrock Creek in Horseshoe Bay.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding sending water over the roadway on FM 2676 west of Rio Medina.
The fire department reports that 41 high-water rescues were conducted around Midland over the course of the afternoon. The property damage cost is an estimation.
A video shows significant water over Industrial Ave. in south Midland, with at least one stranded vehicle. The property damage cost is an estimation.
The emergency manager reports several high-water rescues were conducted near and around Lake J.B. Thomas during the afternoon and early evening. The property damage cost is an estimation.
Emergency management reported 25 to 30 high-water rescues around Odessa during the afternoon. The cost of property damage is an estimation.
This report was received from mPING and indicated potential road closures.
This report was received from mPING and indicated potential road closures.
Flooding across US Highway 84 just north of Snyder.
Video shows significant flooding across State Highway 302 near the junction with FM 1936.
Report of flooding along State Highway 191 heading into Odessa. At least one vehicle is flooded. Other roads in the area are also reported to have flooding. Property damage cost is an estimation.
A trained spotter shows a video of many water-covered roads in the Fluvanna area, primarily along FM 612 in and out of town.
This was a report from mPING indicating potential road closures.
The photo shows one to two feet of water across an RV park in West Midland.
Video of significant standing water over roads in east Odessa.
The Business 20 frontage road is impassible in spots. A police cruiser is blocking the road with at least one stalled vehicle. The property damage cost is an estimation.

Local law enforcement in Castro County reported water flowing over several roadways northwest of Dimmitt. These included Farm to Market Roads 2393 and 1055. Additionally, street flooding was reported in Dimmitt.
Social media posts show several streets flooded in the Aransas Pass area during the morning of the 4th after nearby report rainfall totals around 8.
This was a report from mPING indicating potential road closures.
A significant amount of water was covering FM 1298 south of Lake J.B. Thomas.
A storm chaser reported water over the roadway near the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 1731 and 1760.

TV station KGNS stated that law enforcement in Laredo reported several streets flooded and water rescues across the city. A total of 9 children and adults were rescued from their vehicle in flooded waters. Moderate to heavy rain was falling from 10 PM CST to 5 AM CST with flooded streets persisting through the rest of the morning.
A few streets remained flooded through the morning hours across the city of Laredo.

Emergency Management in Cameron County reported flooding in neighborhoods between Los Fresnos and Laureles due to runoff. There were reports of water depth of 3 feet in some areas. Two-day rainfall in the area ranged from 3.5 inches to nearly 6 inches.
Flash flooding was reported by TXDOT along Interstate 10 West near Cotton.  Gateway West was also impassable and both roads were closed.
Public reported flash flooding in portions of San Angelo in Tom Green County.

An off-duty NWS employee and emergency manager reported flooding in southern Lynn County from heavy rainfall. Approximately six inches of water was over the roadway along US Highway 87 between O'Donnell and Tahoka.
Roads impassable in residential areas of Knox City due to flooding. Flooding also noted at the intersection of Texas State Highway 6 and 222. Event time is approximate.
Emergency Management reported several secondary roads were flooded across northern Navarro County in the Emhouse to Rice to Chatfield area as well as along the Navarro Ellis county line.
Several flooded roadway and stranded vehicle mPING reports were received from the Corsicana area.
An mPING report of cropland and yard flooding was received in northern Hill County.
Heavy rain in a short period of time brought flash flooding in and around the city of Brownfield late on the 17th into the early morning hours of the 18th.
A trained spotter reported that parts of Jefferson Blvd in Cockrell Hill were impassable due to high water, and police barricades were put in place.
Social media video showed water over the roadway and in yards along East Hammond Drive.
Several reports of cropland and yard flooding were reported in eastern Parker County via mPING.
A social media video showed widespread street flooding along Hulen St near Interstate 30 in Fort Worth.
An mPING report of roadway flooding was received in Decatur.
An mPING report of roadway flooding and vehicles stranded was received east of Lewisville.
An mPING report of a flooded roadway and/or vehicles stranded was received in the Irving area.

Flash flooding was observed just east of Smyer along Texas State Highway 114 early in the morning of the 18th. Heavy rainfall from a line of thunderstorms produced a torrential amount of rainfall in a short period of time.

An NWS storm survey and law enforcement and public reports showed extensive flooding in rural Hall County generally along Farm to Market Road 657 between Turkey and Lakeview. Water was flowing over the roadway near the Little Red River and the Prairie Dog Town Fork Red River. Additionally, water was overflowing out of its banks along the Little Red River near Farm to Market Road 657. The rapidly flowing water knocked down vegetation, scoured the edges of the river bank, and washed out a power pole. Mud flows impacted areas north of Turkey along State Highway 70.
An NWS storm survey revealed several flooded fields and previously flooded roadways near Farm to Market Road 193 in northwestern Crosby County.
FM 1696 to the west of Bedias was made impassable due to flash flooding.
Minor roadway flooding was reported by local officials.
An mPING report indicated flooding 5 miles southwest of Springtown.
A local official reported roadway flooding 3 miles east of Samsom Park.

A slow moving line of thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall over Lubbock County which caused flash flooding over the city of Lubbock. Numerous reports were received of water over area roadways. Additionally, law enforcement reported a vehicle submerged under water under the overpass of 19th street and Interstate-27.
An mPING report indicated flooding 2 miles north of Addison.
Rowlett Creek at both Renner Rd and Campbell Rd was reported to be rapidly rising, and a car was stranded in floodwaters on Campbell Rd due to rapidly rising water.
A social media video indicated a stalled car due to high water 2 miles west of Highland Park.

Runoff from heavy rainfall over the city of Lubbock early in the morning of the 18th made its way into the North Fork Double Mountain Fork Brazos River beginning on the east side of the city of Lubbock. This water eventually moved downstream into Buffalo Springs Lake. The emergency manager for Buffalo Springs Lake reported two feet of water flowing over Farm to Market Road 835 west of the lake. The emergency manager reported that the road had to be closed.
An mPING report of flash flooding was received 3 miles south of Farmer's Branch.
Texas Department of Transportation reported multiple lanes blocked on Interstate 35 East near Valwood Parkway due to high water.
An intense portion of a line of severe thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall over southwestern Lubbock County into northern Lynn County. Numerous reports were received of water over area roadways.
An intense portion of a line of severe thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall over southwestern Lubbock County into northern Lynn County. Numerous reports were received of water over area roadways.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain. San Antonio Fire Department rescued a person from a flooded drainage ditch near Tioga Dr. and I-10 in northwestern San Antonio.

Emergency Managers provided several photos of flood waters on Padre Blvd extending as far north as the intersection of Padre Blvd and Dolphin Street.  Poor drainage in the area likely contributed to water depth between 2 and 3 feet along the highway.  Damage was unknown as of this writing.
Roadways were flooded on Ruben M Torres Blvd near N Central Avenue with an estimated 1 to 2 feet of water depth in spots.
The fire department reports a few stalled vehicles and a vehicle underwater. Property cost damage is an estimation.
Several cars were stranded in high water in the city of Odessa. This report is from pictures on social media. Property cost damage is an estimation.
Water was reported over numerous roads in Lumberton. Rising water also caused multiple rescues, impassable roads, and several flooded homes.
Water was reported over several roads just north of Interstate 10 near Hampshire.

Torrential rain, with measured an estimated totals of 3.5 to more than 5 inches mainly from downtown across the north and west portions of Brownsville, created numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding. Standing water was reported on the intersection of Pablo Kisel Blvd and Morrison Road. Roadway was nearly impassable. Additional reports from Cameron Co. and Brownsville Emergency Management included:  water covering roads at IH-69E Frontage and Alton Gloor, Old Alice/Barnard/Price.  A water rescue was reported downtown on 11th and Elizabeth.  Water levels in harder hit areas were between 2 and 3 feet (standing).||Damage estimates were unknown as of this writing.

San Benito PD reported various levels of flooding across town.  The following reports were received:  One foot of flowing water down Brooks Avenue at around 445 PM CDT; additional flooding on Franklin Road, Woodford Street, and Bowie Street.  Water reportedly entered homes on Bowie Street with one rescue required; water was reportedly at least knee deep in some locations (2 to 3 feet).

Harlingen PD received numerous reports of flooded roads during the mid to late afternoon.  These included:  Fair Park Blvd, the intersection of 7th and M St, Spur 5             and Frontage, Eye St, intersection of J St and Fair Park Blvd, Bowie Ave and 25th St,             Frontage Rd. at Primera Rd exit to Wilson Rd, Le Moyne Garden, and Emerald Lake Dr. Texas Department of Transportation was notified and road closures began during the event, with water reported halfway up cars in some spots.

Additional thunderstorms moved over the city of Lubbock on the evening of the second. These storms produced heavy rainfall in a short amount of time across an area that already experienced flash flooding earlier in the day. These additional thunderstorms created flash flooding across the southern portion of the city of Lubbock.

Torrential rainfall, as much as 5.48 inches of rain having fallen in 90 minutes in Rancho Viejo, left pockets of flash flooding during the late afternoon between San Pedro and Olmito, including Rancho Viejo. Reports of high water into structures and vehicle rescues were reported during and after the peak of the downpour. Vehicle rescues were reported in Olmito and near Rancho Viejo; water was reportedly entering homes on Melva Court in San Pedro, and Burr Oak Loop and Agave avenue just south of IH-169 in east Olmito. ||Damage values estimated based on the reports received. || Damage information was unknown at the time of this writing.
Multiple social media videos show minor roadway flooding across the central business district of the Wichita Falls community. Event time is approximate.

Rain and thunderstorms grew upscale along an outflow boundary moving eastward across the South Plains. This activity trained over Lubbock County creating flash flooding across the city of Lubbock. Numerous reports were received of water over area roadways in and around the city of Lubbock. Additionally, several vehicles were stranded due to high waters.
There was street and road flooding in Menard which resulted in roads being closed. Also, vehicles were stranded due to the high water.
There was street flooding along Barrow street with vehicles stranded in Abilene.
The Sheriffs Office reported that FM 2105 and Highway 208 was flooded north of San Angelo.
Law enforcement reported water was flowing over FM 2288 where it crossed the North Concho River.
Law enforcement reported flash flooding at the intersection of FM 2288 and US 87 northbound.
Public reported on social media that a low water crossing on East Carlsbad Loop Road was flooded.

Rain showers and thunderstorms moving out of New Mexico early on the morning of the second repeatedly trained over Parmer County producing nearly four inches of rain within a few hours. Law enforcement in Parmer County as well as pictures from social media showed water over US Highway 60 between Farwell and Bovina as well as several other roadways. Additionally, law enforcement reported several vehicles were stranded in flood waters.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Medina County 911 Dispatch received a call from an individual who was trapped in their vehicle that had been swept off Park Road 37 in high water at Mescal Creek. On the afternoon of the 5th, the vehicle was located about one mile downstream and the body of the driver 3-4 miles downstream just south of the Park Rd 37/FM 1283 intersection in Bandera County. The driver was a 20 year old male.
Public reported street flooding around Angelo State University resulting in streets being closed. Also, vehicles were were stranded. Report from mPING.

At 735 AM CDT, the Tom Green County Sheriff Office received a call about a vehicle truck that was swept away by swift water currents in the flooded area of McMillan and Wright Roads in northeastern Tom Green County. The truck was swept approximately 150 yards from the roadway, to near a tree. The cab of the truck was submerged, and the occupants were clinging to the tree above the flood waters. All of the 5 victims were successfully rescued by first responders from the Tom Green County Sheriff Office and the San Angelo Fire Department. The Texas Department of Public Safety and Texas Parks and Wildlife Department were also involved in the rescue efforts.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing roads in northwestern San Antonio.
Black Creek at Highway 326 reached minor flood stage. This produced minor flooding of several roadways near Black Creek.

There were several reports of flash flooding in the city of Brownsville, mainly bracketed by Price Road and Expressway IH-69E on the west, Price Road and State Highway 48 on the east, extending to the Southmost neighborhood on the south side of the city. Reports included: Multiple intersections along Boca Chica Blvd impassable due to flooded roadways between McDavitt Blvd and  Kings Hwy and Boca Chica was nearly impassable, as well as the intersection known as Four Corners at State Highway 4; flooding extending along State Highway 4 to Southmost Blvd., and flooding along and near the frontage road at Price Road and IH-69E, extending to Barnard Road, and to nearby apartment complexes and shopping centers in this area.||While all locations inside the ascribed polygon may not have reached flash flood levels - 3 feet or higher of ponded water - the reports of impassible roads and photographic evidence suggesting pockets of this level of water depth made the case for a flash flood event in these areas.||Damage to any property was unknown as of this writing.
Flash flooding reported in Tyler near the intersection of Highway 271 and ENE Loop 323.
Flash flooding reported at the intersection of County Road 323 and County Road 426.

Law enforcement reported several roads flooded and closed in Garland including Campbell Rd at Water Oak Dr, E. Campbell Rd at Kinnertone Ln, Naaman Rd at E. Brand Rd, Naaman at E. Kingsbridge Dr, Castle Dr at Lost Pines Ln, and Castle Dr at Hickox Rd.

The Texas Department of Transportation, along with local law enforcement, the public, and emergency management, reported high standing water of 2 to 3 feet in several poor drainage locations of southeastern Hidalgo County that persisted for two more days following historic seasonal rainfall/rainfall rates.  ||This included much of the IH-2 frontage road from east Alamo through the Cameron County line (Mercedes/La Feria), as well as several Farm-to-Market roads which remained impassible for all or part of this time. Overwhelmed drainage systems took time for the water to run out completely, and the Flood Control Project (Main and North Floodways in southeastern Hidalgo County between Weslaco and Mercedes, extending north to La Villa and east to the Willacy County line near Santa Rosa) continued with up to an estimated 20% of freeboard (capacity).||An unknown number of homes in southeast Hidalgo County had at least 1 foot in them, especially in the poorest draining locations where at least 10 inches of rain fell on the 27th into very early on the 28th. ||Damage estimates will be included with the initial flash flood entries from March 27th.

Torrential rainfall with estimated totals ranging from 6 to 12 inches affected southern/southwestern Willacy County during the mid to late evening of March 27, with several water rescues reported in Sebastian along the Cameron County line.  Additional flooding with water depths on roads likely at or near 3 feet occurred northward to Lyford and perhaps the outskirts of Raymondville, and also east to FM 1420 between Santa Monica and Willamar. ||An unknown number of structures had some flooding.  Countywide damage statistics will be available later in 2025.
The left lane of I-35W southbound just north of Burleson was flooded and closed with a police barricade.

Widespread rain showers and thunderstorms developed over the South Plains region early in the morning of the sixth ahead of an upper level storm system. Moderate to heavy rain persisted for approximately two hours causing flooding of area roadways in and around Sudan reported by a storm chaser. A portion of Farm to Market Road 303 was inundated with water north of Sudan.
The inside lane of Highway 110 (Troup Highway) was flooded.

Flash flooding occurred across the city of  Austin with 6 water rescues reported, some  of which included vehicles. On the 2200  Block of Hancock Drive near the Yarborough  Branch of the Austin Public Library, an unhoused  individual was swept away when Hancock Creek flooded. The body of the person was recovered downstream.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were multiple stranded vehicles and high water rescues reported across San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Several low water crossings were closed over northeastern San Antonio.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There were stranded vehicle and water rescue along Old  O'Connor Road in northeastern San Antonio.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Bexarflood.org reported several low water crossings in northern and central Bexar County were flooded.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The exit from northbound Hwy 281 to Hwy 46 was closed for around 50 minutes due to water over the road. There were multiple rescues of people stuck in vehicles in the water.
Off duty NWS employee shows photos significant street flooding.

Report from mPING of Cropland/Yard Flooding.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. The exit from northbound Hwy 281 to Hwy 46 was closed for around 20 minutes with water over the road. There were water rescues of multiple people stuck in vehicles.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. There was a swift water rescue on the I-35 feeder road near Buttermilk Branch in northern Austin.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding. Two vehicles were stranded in water on Steck Ave. near MOPAC in northern Austin. The occupants of these vehicles had to be rescued.

Widespread rain showers and thunderstorms developed over the South Plains region early in the morning of the sixth ahead of an upper level storm system. Moderate to heavy rain persisted for approximately two hours causing flooding of area roadways in and around the city of Lubbock. A portion of Farm to Market Road 835 was closed because it was inundated with water upstream of Buffalo Springs Lake.
Video of notable street flooding in El Cenizo, time estimated from video author.

Several high water rescues were needed for stranded motorists under the railroad overpasses in Longview, including Green Street and Nelson Street, Green Street and Cotton Street, and High Street and Cotton Street. In addition, several low lying areas across the city were flooded as well.
Highway 135 north of the traffic circle in Kilgore was flooded.

The Texas Department of Transportation continued to report flooding along the frontage road near Sebastian well into March 28th, with additional flooding noted by emergency management/law enforcement along Farm-to-Market and County roads in the southern portion of the county.  Flooding continued at homes in the Sebastian area where drainage backups remained.||There was an unknown amount of water remaining in the North Floodway of the International Boundary and Water Commission's Flood Control Project.  Further details for Willacy County flooding well after the rains ended will be provided through updates.

Emergency manager reported a closed road due to urban flooding in Palm Valley near the intersection of Queens Sago Dr and Stuart Place Rd.  Time of event estimated by radar and duration of estimated rainfall of 3 to 4 inches in two hours.

The Texas Department of Transportation, along with Cameron County and local city emergency management between La Feria and Rio Hondo, and other law enforcement, and neighborhood groups reported a continuation of 2 to 3 feet of water depth (higher in a few locations) well into March 28th, with only a slow recession on the 29th and 30th before the water drained out for all but a few locations. Flood related impacts continued as follows:||*Much of the IH-2 frontage between La Feria and Harlingen, and the IH-69E frontage from the Willacy County line through San Benito, was under 2 to 3 feet of water.|*The Arroyo Colorado gauge in Harlingen recorded a record high level of 30.44 feet at 7 AM on March 28th. While some of the record water levels were due to slow flows due to a need for dredging of sediment and other debris, locations inside the levee saw water levels greater than those seen from all but Hurricane Beulah, and low water crossings in western Cameron County were under at least 2-3 feet of water depth.|*State and Farm-to-Market roads between Harlingen and Rio Hondo remained closed from at least 2 feet of water depth well into the 28th.  |*Numerous homes, vehicles, and more remained under water in Palmview, Combes, Rio Hondo, Harlingen, and Primera.  The community of Green Valley was especially hard hit.  |*The duration of high water was partly driven by drainage backups and fill-ups in the Flood Control project of canals, ditches, and conveyance through-ways between Hidalgo, Cameron, and Willacy - with northern Cameron County communities bearing the brunt due to their location having the heaviest rainfall totals, which extended into southeast Hidalgo County. ||Water finally drained out except for a few locations by March 30th.  Final damage statistics will be included in the Flash Flood entry that includes the Harlingen/Rio Hondo/San Benito area.

Significant to locally devastating flash flooding began in the McAllen/Mission metropolitan area during mid-afternoon.  Rainfall rates of at least 3 in 30 minutes were too much for the city's drainage infrastructure to handle, and soon after, city fire/rescue/police reported  more than two dozen roads closed citywide and up to forty homes with an unknown amount of water depth inside, to the Emergency Management Coordinator. ||It was likely that several hundred homes had incident flooding, from affected to major damage - most concentrated in the south side of the city.  The frontage roads on IH2 (Mission/McAllen) and IH-69C (Pharr/Edinburg) flooded with varying amounts of water, and hundreds of vehicles were stranded.  The highest water was at least four feet in spots along the frontage south of the McAllen Convention Center. Rainfall rates were historic for the season, ranging from 1/100 to 1/200 probability events (annual return frequency) over a 2-hour period. McAllen/Miller Airport, located just south of IH-2 and just west of 10th Street, recorded 6.25 in two hours.  ||Additional reports of 2 to 3 feet of water were received from the City of Pharr, with two to three feet of water depth at the intersection of N. Cage Blvd. and E. Ferguson Ave., along/near the IH-69C frontage.  Additional, faster moving/impacting rain bands occurred during the late evening, with the final potent band (with wind) racing through just after 11 PM CST (midnight CDT March 28th).  Residual urban flooding and high water would continue into March 28th and beyond in some areas.||Damage reports for the City, and Hidalgo County overall, will be provided later in 2025.
Two to three feet of water and flooding was reported on FM 755 in northeast Starr County near Santa Elena.

Torrential rains that previously affected the McAllen/Edinburg metro area reached southeast Hidalgo County, from south of Weslaco to Edcouch and east to the Hidalgo/Cameron line, then south along the Mercedes/La Feria line and all the way to between Progreso and just west of Santa Maria. Similar to the situation in the Donna-Weslaco area, the IH-2 frontage road was littered with flooded vehicles, with rescued vehicles along the side of the elevated expressway.  An estimated 3 or more feet of water was on the frontage roads.||The rain in this area came in multiple rounds.  A first round occurred between 430 and 6 PM, with additional rounds between 7 and 8 PM and again fro 930 to around 11 PM,and a final windy round around midnight March 28th CST (1 AM CDT). Water rescues were first reported in Mercedes at around 7 PM CST (8 PM CDT).  As of this writing, damage was unknown but hundreds of structures likely had varying degrees, ranging from affected to major damage.   ||High water would continue well into March 28th and beyond; the flood control system (floodway) had up to 20% capacity due to spillage and pumping of urban flood areas into it. ||Full damage statistics will be available later in 2025.

Torrential rains progressed from Hidalgo into Cameron County during the evening of March 27th, with multiple repeating rounds creating rapid onset flash flooding.  The multiple rounds of rainfall in western Cameron County added up to more than 10 inches for the period, with some areas likely receiving 9 or more inches in just three hours.  Widespread flooding was reported between Santa Rosa, Combes, Palm Valley, and La Feria, with nighttime swift water rescues reported in La Feria and Santa Rosa.  The final band of torrential rain (along with strong wind) whipped through just after midnight CST (1 AM CDT) March 28th. ||The IH-2 frontage road was littered with stalled vehicles, and dozens more were removed and placed along the shoulders in each direction.  High water continued well after the rains ended, into March 29th. ||It is likely that dozens, if not over 100, structures were impacted to various degrees ranging from affected to major damage, with several likely considered destroyed. Full damage data will be available in later 2025.

Texas Department of Transportation reported water of unknown depth was reported in an elementary school.  Photos suggested the water depth was 2 feet outside the building, and up to 1 foot inside.  Damage estimates were unknown at the time of this writing.

The Texas Department of Transportation, along with local law enforcement and the public, noted a continuation of high water along the IH-2 frontage roads between Mission and Alamo from just before midnight (standard time) on March 27th through mid to late afternoon on the 28th, as water was slow but steady to drain out of the area despite fair weather for most of the period.

Torrential rains moved out from the McAllen/metro into the mid-Valley section of Hidalgo County, to include locations east of Edinburg, including Elsa/Edcouch, then south through San Juan, Alamo, and Donna, extending south to around Military Highway (US 281) east of Pharr and near the Rio Grande.||Poor drainage locations flooded with at least 3 feet of water depth, and nearly the entire IH-2 frontage road had 2 to 3 or more feet of water depth, with dozens of vehicles stranded and at least one hundred more removed from the floodwaters. A number of farm-to-market and state highways had pockets of flood waters, forcing closures that lasted into March 28th. ||In this flood area, there were three known indirect drownings when vehicles became submerged in deeper waters in canals/drainage areas during encounters with law enforcement.  One drowning was a juvenile who was unable to be rescued from a vehicle that submerged near Edcouch.||Damage details and further information will be available later in 2025 from these areas.

Emergency manager reported water being pumped out of a house due to flash flooding. The same emergency manager reported a stranded vehicle in east Brownsville due to flash flooding. Water levels of 2 feet or higher spread along parts of FM 511 near the Port of Brownsville, which is a typically poor-drainage location, impacting several low-wheel-base vehicles.

Some of the heaviest rainfall associated with the historic rainfall of March 26-28 fell in Harlingen.  In total, nearly 19 inches was measured by trusted sources, with radar estimates up to 20.5 inches.  During the peak of the multiple bands from early evening through just after midnight on the 28th, estimated rainfall rates were at least 3 per hour for at least 3 hours, including at Harlingen/Valley International Airport, where 5 fell in just 90 minutes before the power went out due to lightning strikes.||Hundreds, if not a thousand, structures had flood damage ranging from affected to destroyed. Damage details will be available for this part of Cameron County, which stretches from Harlingen through Rio Hondo and southwest to San Benito, at a later date in 2025.  Harder hit areas reported up to 4 feet of water, including the IH-2 and IH-69E frontage roads in these areas. For several areas, this event ranked as a 1/100 to 1/200 annual return frequency probability event, with perhaps up to a 1/500 event in a few spots. High water would continue in several hours for a few more days, though rapid runoff allowed for relatively quick recovery.||Full damage statistics will be available later in 2025.
A trained spotter reported 2 to 3 inches of water on side roads.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding closing a few low water crossings in northwestern Bexar County.
Slow moving and repeated rounds of thunderstorms in and around Old Glory brought an extended period of heavy rainfall. A report from mPing indicated water over the roadway along US Highway 380.

Bryan PD reported multiple streets and intersections flooded including: Villa Maria at Harvey Mitchell; Palasota at Finfeather; 500 West Carson; 200 block of Dodge; North Coulter at Park Street; Briarcrest at Earl Rudder Frontage; Carter Creek near Tanglewood Park. Broadcast media also reported flooded roadways in the Braeburn cul-de-sac near Broadmoor Drive in Bryan, TX near Briar Meadows Creek. A member of the public also reported inundation on South College Avenue at Inflow Blvd in central College Station. Inflow Blvd borders a ditch.

Two supercell thunderstorms merged south of Roaring Springs near Texas State Highway 70. The combined supercell remained nearly stationary over this area for approximately 30 minutes consistently dropping very heavy rainfall before moving eastward. After the initial supercell thunderstorm moved east, additional thunderstorm development upstream moved over the same area bringing further heavy rainfall. The heavy rain mostly affected the Roaring Springs Ranch Club. Water was reported over the roadway along Texas State Highway 70 at the South Pease River (Tongue River) intersection. There was an unknown amount of damage reported within the ranch club as well as water over the highway.
An NWS employee reported flooding on a roadway, with water flowing across the road. In addition, extensive flooding was reported across the city of San Angelo.
A member of the public reported flash flooding with water inundating Greens Prairie Road at Royder Road just south of College Station.
Public reported flooding in yard.
The public posted pictures on social media showing streets flooded and yards flooded in Menard.
Public reported streets flooded and yards flooded.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding in Eagle Pass. There was water in homes and high water vehicle rescues. One vehicle was swept into a canal near Roosevelt St. and Austin St. The car became lodged under a bridge at Wilson St. The lone occupant, an 18 year old male, was found deceased in the Rio Grande River, just south of International Bridge II.
