A water rescue was reported at 412 CR 941, located west of Fairfield.
A portion of FM-174, just west of the Brock Road intersection, was impassable due to flooding. Event time is approximate.
Several mPing reports for flooding were received across Collin County.
A social media video indicated approximately 6 inches of water covering the road just north of the city of Graham, with 8 to 12 inches in one spot.
Social media photos and videos showed several roads flooded across Corsicana.
Several mPing reports for flooding were received across Dallas County.
Portions of Old Granbury Rd in southwest Fort Worth were reported closed due to flooding.
A mPing report for flooding was received from the city of Cooper.

Emergency management reported several county road closures near Cooper including the following: FM 2068, FM 128, FM 1529, and FM 71. State Highway 24 North on the southbound lanes was also closed due to flooding on the low bridge.
Social media reports indicate several roads flooded in and around Paris, including Highway 195 and 24th Street. A few homes were also flooded as well as some vehicles.

Amateur radio reported street flooding across Bridgeport and a tree blocking the road on FM 2123 near the Bridgeport Golf Course. Amateur radio also specifically reported Hovey Street and 10th street was flooded.
A road closure was reported near Coit Rd and Lewis Canyon Dr in Prosper.
A road closure was reported near Highway 78 and Century Way in Wylie due to flooding.
Dallas PD responded to a high water rescue at Shady Trail and Glenda Ln. Dallas Fire Rescue reported 13 high water rescue calls across the city.
Multiple stalled cars and one high water rescue was reported due to flooding on Saginaw Blvd.
A trained spotter reported high water on TX Highway 31 west of Corsicana. The road was becoming impassable in spots.
A car was stranded and a high water rescue was conducted at Highway 14 and CR 244 north of Mexia.

The city of Bowie Police Department closed Nelson Street at Mill Street, Nelson Street at the railroad bridge, and Decatur Street due to flash flooding. Social media video also indicated several flooded roads throughout the city of Bowie.

Amateur radio passed along reports of water coming into homes, water over roadways, and stranded cars in Nocona. The Montague County Sheriff's Office also reported that US Highway 82 was closed in both directions in Nocona.
Heavy rain during the night of April 25th resulted in flooding of most of the access road near McCormick Road and I-27. It remained covered in water into the next morning and was barely passable.

Heavy rain occurred on the night of April 25th. There was strong evidence that Spring Creek flooded Shady Lake Drive to the point where the road was impassable and water still remained over the road the following morning.
Emergency management reported multiple high-water rescues in the northern part of Montague County. Multiple boat crews were requested to assist.
A public report indicated that US-81 north of Stoneburg remained closed due to flooding.
Emergency management reported multiple county roads and bridges washed out across the county. Flooding was still ongoing, and Highway 81 near Nocona remained closed due to flooding as well.
High water covered Main Street and other side streets in Atlanta.
High water covered Lake Placid Road in Tyler.
High water covered portions of I-30 on the Texas side of Texarkana. Stateline Avenue was also flooded.
Interstate 30 was shut down from Mile Marker 220 to the Arkansas state line due to flooding.
Rushing water covered CR 2041 just south of Appleby.
The Pecos County Emergency Manager reported approximately 4 inches of water on roads in the city of Fort Stockton, TX. Time is estimated from radar.
Emergency management reported several roads flooded across the city of Bowie.
Emergency management reported that several roads were flooded across Montague County.
Emergency management reported flooding on Rosamond Pkwy east of Hwy 75 in the city of Anna.
Emergency management reported street flooding in Savoy and Bells, with Hwy 56 at the railroad bridge on the Grayson/Fannin County line closed due to high water.
Amateur radio reported flooding near the intersection of FM 1810 and CR 1340 east of the city of Chico.
Multiple creeks overflowed their banks near Mount Vernon.

Emergency management reported 7 roads flooded and closed across Denton, including the I-35 exit at University Drive, Mingo Road underneath Loop 288, and Blagg Road from Mayhill Street to Geesling Road. Other roads flooded and closed across Denton County included Fritz Lane in Corinth, South Shady Shores Road from Parkside Lane to Montserrat Road in Lake Dallas, Liberty Road near McNatt Road in Aubrey, and Creek Hill Way from 12th Street to Hardeman Circle in Justin.
Broadcast media reported that floodwaters as high as car headlights covered parking lots and roads in the city of Krum.
The 2900 block of Keller Hicks Rd near Haslet was reported to be closed due to flooding.
The 1200 block of NE 28th Street in Fort Worth (near the Stockyards) was closed due to flooding.

A nearly stationary supercell thunderstorm dropped torrential rainfall in northeastern Hockley County. A West Texas Mesonet station six miles south of Anton recorded 5.83 inches of rain, with WSR-88D MRMS rainfall estimates of six to eight inches. Numerous roads in this area were flooded and impassible for several days with vehicles reported stranded.

Several slow moving thunderstorms trained over Hall and Childress Counties early in the morning on the 26th. WSR-88D MRMS rainfall was estimated between two to four inches over a widespread area with localized areas between four and five inches in northeastern Hall County. Numerous roads were closed or impassable in Hall and Childress Counties including US Highway 287 between Memphis and Estelline and Texas State Highway 256 between Memphis and Lakeview. One vehicle accident was reported on Texas State Highway 86 northeast of Turkey. The Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River filled its|banks between Estelline and Childress briefly reaching minor flood stage at the Childress 10N river gage.

Several slow moving thunderstorms trained over Hall and Childress Counties early in the morning on the 26th. WSR-88D MRMS rainfall was estimated between two to four inches over a widespread area with localized areas between four and five inches in northeastern Hall County. Numerous roads were closed or impassable in Hall and Childress Counties including US Highway 287 between Memphis and Estelline and Texas State Highway 256 between Memphis and Lakeview. One vehicle accident was reported on Texas State Highway 86 northeast of Turkey. The Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River filled its banks between Estelline and Childress briefly reaching minor flood stage at the Childress 10N river gage.
Flood waters covered Inwood Rd between Loop 12 and I-635.

Many road closures were reported in Jack County due to flooding. Impacted areas included Burwick Rd between Highway 380 and FM 1191, FM 4 one mile south of Jacksboro, and Rock Creek Rd two miles east of FM 1191.
Fort Worth Fire Department responded to six high water rescues across the city.
Multiple flooded roads were reported in Wise County, including portions of W Thompson St, FM 51, Old Decatur Rd at Alvord Rd, Halsell St, and several county roads.
Multiple roads were closed in Fort Worth due to flooding, including portions of E Long Ave, Alta Vista Rd, and Trinity Blvd.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding north of Uvalde. The Uvalde Fire Department rescued a person from high water at Hwy 83 and CR 429 along Leona Creek.
Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that led to flash flooding north of Uvalde. The Uvalde Fire Department rescued a person from high water on Puccini Ln along the Taylor Slough in Uvalde.
Many dry creeks had fast flowing water in them along Texas Highway 70 between Brice  and Clarendon.
Street flooding was reported in Granbury.
The 5100 block of Erath Street in Forest Hill/southeast Fort Worth was closed due to flooding.
Fire and rescue reported water over Highway 84 East in Fairfield. Several side streets were also flooded.

Flash flooding due to heavy rain occurred over Texas State Highway 70 between Girard and Jayton. Several severe thunderstorms moved over the same area producing multiple rounds of heavy precipitation.
Heavy rain from severe thunderstorms repeatedly trained over central Garza County resulting in flash flooding in and around Post. Numerous streets in and around Post were inundated with water.
Emergency management reported significant flooding in a Fairfield neighborhood with at 1-2 feet of water running across yards and streets.
Anderson County Emergency Management reported flooding of low lying areas across the county with 4.55 inches of rain measured in Tennessee Colony.
Emergency management reported that Luella Road at the Choctaw Creek bridge, about midway between Luella and Sherman, was flooded by one foot of water.
Emergency management reported that multiple streets in Bridgeport were flooded. Pioneer Road in New Fairview was also closed due to high water..
Broadcast media reported a home flooded on Dynasty Drive in Glenn Heights.
The intersection of FM 2493 and FM 2813 was flooded.

Intense rainfall from a slow moving storm occurred in and around Happy. A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Happy measured 1.62 inches of rainfall in less than one hour. An mPing report was received of flooded roads in Happy.
Broadcast media reported that McKinney Street at Ennis Avenue was flooded, and a car was stalled in flood waters on Ennis Avenue at Clay Street in the city of Ennis.
Street and road flooding was reported via mPING in Holland.
A creek overflowed resulting in water moving into a yard and basement of a home near Mineola.
Multiple creeks overflowed their banks near Lindale.
High water covered Shiloh Road between Broadway Avenue and New Copeland Road.
High water covered South Georgia Street in Troup.
There was a report of road flooding along state route 163.
Portions of FM 747 southwest of Jacksonville were flooded.
The intersection of Canada Street and Beaumont Street in Jacksonville was closed due to flooding.
A car was stalled in high water adjacent to an insurance office along Highway 110 on the north side of Whitehouse.
FM 449 near Franklin Road was closed due to flooding.
A report from mPING was received of street/road flooding or closures in Fort Stockton. Urban flooding was likely due to a slow-moving supercell thunderstorm. Time is estimated from radar.
Public reported flash flooding across streets with a few vehicles stranded.
Highway 80 near Lansing Switch Road was closed due to flooding.
Multiple county roads across Harrison County were flooded and closed.

A report of street/road flooding or closures was received from mPING on the northeast side of Fort Stockton. This was likely the result of a slow-moving supercell thunderstorm. Time is estimated from radar.
Public reported a creek overflowing due to flash flooding.
Public report of a creek overflowing.

An NWS storm survey revealed significant flooding south of Crosbyton along several roadways. A slow moving supercell thunderstorm produced very heavy rainfall over an extended period of time over areas of rural Crosby County. Farm to Market 40 was covered in mud in several areas east of Texas Highway 207 indicative of water over the roadway on the night of the 24th. Most of the county roads were muddy and impassable at the time of the storm survey.
Pictures were posted to social media of significant street flooding in Lindale.
Public report of street flooding due to flash flooding and a few vehicles stranded.
Public reported road flooding due to flash flooding and a few vehicles stranded.

An NWS storm survey revealed significant flooding northeast of Post along several roadways. A slow moving supercell thunderstorm produced very heavy rainfall over an extended period of time over areas of rural Garza County. Water was flowing over Farm to Market Road 2008 three miles south of Farm to Market Road 651 along McDonald Creek. Most of the county roads were muddy and impassable at the time of the storm survey.
A report from mPING of street/road flooding or closures near I-20 was received. Time is estimated from radar.
South Texas Street was flooded.
High water covered Highway 37 just south of Bogata.
A report of street/road flooding or closures was received from mPING.

Several roads were flooded and closed around Warren including 1943 East and West, CR 4475, FM 1013  CR 4478. Multiple other roads had water covering them, but were not closed including CR 4470 and CR 1450.
At least four to five inches of flowing water occurred across the intersection of FM2391 and County Line Road.
Heavy rainfall resulted in up to eight inches of standing water along 23rd and 25th avenues on the north side of Pampa.

A slow moving supercell thunderstorm trained over areas of Motley County producing very heavy rainfall and flash flooding. An NWS cooperative weather observer reported flash flooding within the city of Roaring Springs as well as flooding over Texas State Highway 70 between Matador and Roaring Springs.
A storm chaser reported that a large stretch of FM 2400 was under approximately 6 inches of rushing water. The entire road is flooded. Time is estimated from radar.
High water covered portions of Highway 49 in low lying areas. A local tow operator estimated water 6-8 feet deep in some areas.
High water covered multiple roads in Gilmer.
Flash flooding throughout the Texas side of Texarkana. High water covered Exit 220 on I-30 West.
A picture was posted to social media of flooding near businesses along Highway 110 South.
A part of FM 2400 was reported flooded out by at least a foot of water. A few vehicles were unable to cross the road at either end. The time is estimated from radar.
A report was received from mPING of street/road flooding or closures in portions of Snyder. The time is estimated from radar.
